<review# 450,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/6/2013,8/31/2013,273,603,7,10,8>Owners, Jeff and Sarah, have a pretty cool thing going on here. I know nothing about Irish food, so you may want to take my review with a grain of salt. Anyhow, these owners are pretty sharp. They've hired Irish Chef Simon to handle their menu.  I think it's a pretty authentic take on Irish pub food. We stopped by the first time on a Sunday evening. It was almost right o'clock. And although they were open, the kitchen wasn't. So, we missed our first dining opportunity. Fast forward a week to a hungry moment. We pull out of the driveway and decide to try again. This time it's mid-afternoon on a Sunday and not only are they open, but so is the kitchen. When we walk in, there are three people at the bar. This was a sign to leave, but it was too late. So we seat ourselves at the bar and Joe, the bartender/server, appears with menus. We quickly learn that he knows all there is to know about this menu. So here's what we tried...corned beef and cabbage egg rolls, shepherds pie and a Guinness beef stew. Funny enough, neither of us are big corned beef and cabbage fans. So why order the egg rolls?  When in Rome...  Anyhow, we were split on these. I enjoyed these and their unique flavor with the bold dipping sauce. The hubby wasn't as impressed. He ate his half, but wasn't raving. He ate the shepherds pie for his meal. Again, he didn't love it, but did like it. He loved my Guinness beef stew though!  And so did I! It was loaded with tender chunks of beef, carrots, a rich sauce and their take on mashed potatoes. They actually load the mashed with leaks. There was a story behind this combo, but I honestly don't remember the reasoning. I liked the potatoes but didn't love them. Now, the Irish brown bread that was served with the shepherds pie was really great when paired with butter!  Overall it was a really nice experience and we will go again. I'm glad we didn't let the strip mall location and limited number of guests deter us!
<review# 451,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/10/2013,8/30/2013,287,787,11,14,11>I hate mornings.  I am a bona fide grouch in the morning. Yep, Oscar the Grouch is my favorite sesame street character and he is totally misunderstood. I think you know where I'm getting at. Can a doughnut make a self-proclaimed morning grouch happy and ready to start the day? You better believe it. Their shop is cute and sunny.  I love the cute little bird houses decorating the walls. Service is friendly and upbeat and they really convey their passion for producing a delicious product. They have a small breakfast menu, but I was there for the doughnuts.Don't worry if the pastry case looks a little empty, you can see the racks of freshly baked and iced doughnuts right inside the kitchen door ready to be boxed up. And people WILL order boxes and boxes.  The lady in front of me started with just a dozen but then her order ballooned up to 2 and a half dozen. All the doughnuts look to be cake doughnuts, but they aren't heavy or greasy at all. They are light and cakey and didn't leave me feeling like there was lead in my stomach. The icing is good too, creamy and not grainy. I bought a half a dozen to share--Maple Bacon, Peanut Butter, Vanilla and Cinnamon doughnuts were the ones I chose--And I can't say there was a bad one in the bunch. My favorite is the Vanilla, probably because it's iced with cream cheese frosting. All had great flavor and goes so well with your morning coffee or afternoon tea.  I'm still going to be a grouch in the morning but if you have to deal with me early, remember this tip--bring me a SMC doughnut!

Yelpers - when you're craving a good Chinese dinner...RUN, don't walk, to this place.
<review# 454,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/3/2013,8/27/2013,56,172,7,10,7>Pretty much every time I get my Johnnie's fix in Elmwood Park I drive west on North Ave. for a few minutes to go to Caputo. Their selection of cheeses is so vast that I have trouble leaving without spending at least $30 on cheese alone. Their prices on olive oil and other Italian pantry staples are good, and you know the quality will be there too.Don't let the name fool you. Besides the expected fresh mozzarella and delicious parmigiano reggiano and peccorino romano, you'll find cheeses from every notable cheese-producing country in Europe, as well as from the great state of Wisconsin and other domestic locales. If you've been relying on Whole Foods or TJs for your cheese fix, trust me, it's worth a drive to check Caputo's out.

<review# 458,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/23/2013,8/23/2013,73,240,3,13,7>Forget what you know about Brazilian steakhouses...until you've been here, you haven't experienced anything.I've read the reviews, heard all the good things, checked out the website, and couldn't wait to try it.  Though we've known about the place for a while, we waited until this past weekend to finally go.  My brother-in-law flew in from Texas (true meat-lovin Texan) and what better place to go?  I called the restaurant earlier in the week to make a reservation.  They take reservations for parties of 5 or more.  Pleasant service on the phone.  Good Start.The steakhouse is in a smaller, modest location in a busier neighborhood strip mall with plenty of parking.  Amazing hospitality began right when we walked in.  The owner/GM saw us approaching and personally opened the door for us.  We confirmed our reservation and he showed us to our seats.  A very nice and roomy table right in the middle of the restaurant, close to the bar, salad bar, and in the middle of all the servers offering the delicious selections of meat.  We had our two little ones with us (ages 3 and 5), and while we were a bit apprehensive about bringing them realized quickly that Brazil Express is truly fine casual dining, completely appropriate and accommodating to kids and larger families/groups. The GM ran through the drink menu with us (didn't try the caipirinha, but we will be back for that!), and started with wine and Brazilian beer.  All very good.  Kids had apple juice in kid-friendly cups.  We headed to the salad bar.  Very good selection of cheese, meats, cold salads, olives, etc.  The chicken salad is awesome.  Towards the end of the salad bar are the soups, rice, and tilapia (offering a nice alternative to the meats).  Other standouts are the shrimp ceviche and the asparagus soup (perfectly creamy and chock full of taste).And then came the meat.  Wow.  Wonderful selection of cuts and meats.  Flank steak, garlic steak, sirloin, filet mignon, chicken leg, pork tenderloin, chicken wrapped in bacon, sausage...the list goes on and on.  But what sets this place apart is the robust, amazing flavor to the meat.  We talked with one of the hostesses.  She told us that their only seasoning is sea salt.  Such an amazing flavor from such simple seasoning.  That's how you know this place is for real.  Our resident Texan admitted as well - this was GOOD stuff...and he's had plenty to compare to.We were full after dinner, but couldn't resist dessert.  Our hostess asked if we wanted to see the menu or the presentation tray.  We went with the visual and out came the tray.  They have a few desserts that are homemade especially in the restaurant, a couple others that are purchased and served (love that they're honest about it!).  We went with the homemade flan and the cheesecake.  Both were great, but that flan is AMAZING.  My mom makes flan as well (albeit, Filipino leche flan) and I've always compared any flan to hers (which is untouchable).  I have to say, Brazil Express' quite literally takes the cake.  It was the perfect consistency and flavor...flan heaven.  I paired it with their sweet chocolate martini...which was a dessert in and of itself.So...now that I've gone on and on.  The only other  thing I can say is that they need to expand....and I'm sure at some point, they will.  It is a smaller place, but it's popularity is evident.  Our reservation was for 4:45.  We left around 6:15pm.  From the minute we entered, it was like a trail of people coming in after us.  The restaurant was full by 530ish, and there was a wait by the time we left.  From what I observed, everyone was treated to the same welcoming hospitality that we were.I love this place.  I really do.  Props to the staff and owners here.  We've been to Texas de Brazil (several times, it used to be our go-to churrascaria), Fogo, Brazzaz, but Brazil Express is the new leader for us.  Just can't beat the service, hospitality, food and price!So if you don't know - now you know. Brazil Express is the only place to go!
<review# 459,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/2/2013,8/22/2013,65,419,4,5,4>Came in today for lunch - normally we go to Mitsuwa but at 12:30 on a Saturday afternoon, we'd've been fighting the crowds for pretty much everything.  So we came here instead.It looks like a regular small grocery store but most of the back corner is taken up by a "food court", which is really one place with quite a few options.  Ramen, sushi, soba, tempura, Japanese curry, and so on.  I had the plate of soba noodles with tofu with spicy sauce.  Nice portion size for $8 - a good-sized serving of soba with 4 big pieces of tofu (soft tofu, in case you have issues with the texture of the soft stuff) with a side salad and a little cup with some cold sauce in it.  Quite tasty and very filling.  Other folks had the somen, the miso ramen and the curry.  All pretty tasty - and if you're a fan of the Japanese curry, you can add a bowl of rice and curry for $1 to your order.As for the grocery portion, it's a lot smaller than Mitsuwa but I think they have pretty much the same items, just not 10 - 15 different kinds of everything.  There's a lot of fresh fish, all of which looked fantastic (and no fishy smell, which I prefer), a small produce section, bakery, personal and housewares, and random non-perishables.  Prices seem comparable.Nice little spot where you don't have to deal with the crowds and you can just zip in and out!
<review# 460,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/8/2013,8/21/2013,16,125,2,5,4>As someone who likes meat and loves cheese, I haven't dabbled too much in vegan cuisine. I recently found myself unable to eat dairy for a few weeks (sob!) so I decided that it would be the perfect opportunity to give Munch a try. I absolutely LOVED my vegan food. I got the vegan grilled portabella and eggplant sandwich, and it was seriously delicious. The bread was wonderful (my boyfriend even kept stealing bites of it.) The veggies and tofu were surprisingly hearty, and while it certainly didn't taste like meat, it didn't feel like I was eating dainty vegan food. The quinoa pilaf was also quite delicious. The piece de resistance, however, was the vegan peanut butter cookie dough shake! I've never had vegan ice cream before so I was a little skeptical, but it was as delicious and peanut buttery as any shake I've had. The boyfriend, who is a bit of a picky eater, also thought the shake was amazing.Even though my dairy-free days are now over, I will definitely come back to Munch to try some of their other offerings. Next time I have a hankering for a peanut butter shake, I know exactly where to go!
<review# 461,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/6/2013,8/20/2013,131,471,4,6,4>My family has a long-standing history with Veterinary Specialty Center: we've been here through the years with various cats and dogs of ours and for various near-death health situations. We brought my mom's dog, Brody, in a few weeks ago when I noticed his abdomen was protruding and, we soon found out, was filling with fluid. We had first gone to a 24-hour Emergency Vet, whose bedside manner left much to be desired, did a terrible job with diagnosis, and caused a slew of stressful (as well as potentially legal) situations with my mom, all the while doing NOTHING for us or for Brody.  We left and went to Veterinary Specialty Center, which we knew and whose expertise we trusted.Tammy B. at the front desk was welcoming and got us sorted out with registration very quickly.  Brody was seen promptly, where he was stabilized and testing began.  While we were waiting for word on Brody, Tammy ensured we were comfortable, asking us of we needed coffee and continually checking on us.  Her warm and upbeat demeanor helped alleviate some of the stress caused by Brody's illness as well as the stress incurred from the Emergency Vet.Dr. Matthew Schnabl, the ER vet, was very thorough with his exam and bloodwork on Brody, quickly discounting the "diagnosis" by the ER vet we had just seen.  He clearly had a lot on his plate, and he and his staff prioritized more critical patients (i.e. a seizing dog) while also trying to help alleviate some jitters being experienced by novice dog owners.  Everyone was very professional and, even though the novice dog owners were concerned over nothing, really, the staff weren't dismissive of the owners' concerns.  They also weren't rude towards the owners when they asked if their dog could be seen and stated they arrived before the seizing dog. (Clearly they misunderstood the purpose of an ER visit: it's not First Come/First Served; it's Most Critical/First Served.)  Still, the staff was very professional and very gracious...I'm also confident these owners left without a single charge.We were there for about 4.5 hours, leaving at 2:45am.  Brody was cared for and monitored consistently by the staff.  My mom and I received regular phone updates and test updates when available.  My only gripe was that, though Brody was under my account (to lessen the whole hassle of creating a new account when we first arrived), I asked that phone calls go to my mom on her number.  That wasn't always the case, so a few times I had to forward voicemails or ask them to call her, since (1) I was not paying for his treatment nor felt comfortable giving the "OK" for treatments, and (2) felt she should be most updated in terms of his care and, if needed, any other pertinent decision-making.  They were always very nice and apologetic, and always made sure my mom was the one to ultimately get the most detailed information.  They also helped my mom deal with the awful Emergency Vet experience, and quickly filled out paperwork for her and faxed it to the necessary location. I don't even want to know what Brody's bill was after the several days he was there (and back again), but it's clear that he was well cared for and received treatment from people who KNOW what they're doing (versus randomly guessing and hypothesizing without clear evidence or data).  I'm crossing my fingers he doesn't need to make a return trip!

We especially appreciated that they had separate clear lines for every movie- this is amazing! Maybe Hollywood Blvd has started doing this too but one of my least favorite things there is standing in a huge crowd with no clear line, people pushing, cutting,  crowding and rushing to get in, with no order to it- it is so frustrating. This was an easy and calm way to handle it- I really appreciated it.I had to get the sweet potato fries- it's been a while- they really are excellent. I also got the taco salad which was actually a little weird. I think they had just fried the taco shell and it was a little too brown and had puddles of grease/oil in the pockets of the shell- it was pretty gross at those points when it was dark and I had no idea I was taking a bite like that- yuck. They give you salsa on the side and I think it's super hot- just a tip in case you don't like things spicy. I don't think I'd get the taco salad again. Both theaters just updated their menu and made some excellent additions. My husband really liked his Cisco Kid spicy burger but said it was messy.We had excellent service yesterday- our server brought refills just on time and wasn't intrusive- we were impressed with that. I don't understand the bathrooms. They have one soap dispenser in a corner against the wall so you can only get to it if you use the far sink- otherwise it is too crowded to get to from the other sinks. The paper towel dispensers didn't seem to be working well either.  Not convenient.Overall, we loved the look and feel of this theater, we love the menu, and the service was great. If we can find another time when we don't mind the longer drive and the traffic on 59 we will definitely be back.
<review# 466,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/23/2013,8/14/2013,58,141,2,8,5>My first time here was for a Yelp Elite event, though I had heard of it, I had never been. A very good friend of my boyfriend and I actually performs at this restaurant once a month under the alias "Michael St. Angel". He's a very talented Elvis impersonator, whom the boyfriend took my mom and I to see one night over a yummy asian dinner and some bomb a$$ drinks! This restaurant really has it all; great food at a reasonable price, a creatively decorated atmosphere, friendly and accurate service, and powerful, tasty drinks. Let me take you on a quick review journey through Chef Shangri-La...The food- The veggie eggrolls are adorable in size and scrumptious in flavor. They're a must have! Additionally, I HIGHLY recommend the Mongolian Beef, Teriyaki Beef Tenderloin, and Mango Chicken (OMG, this is a must!!). It's guaranteed anything you order here will be absolutely delicious and very fresh! The drinks- With a vast selection of 28 tropical drinks to choose from I'd recommend pretty much all of them. They're guaranteed to kick you on your a$$, but they're delicious so you won't even know it until you stand up to leave. The atmosphere- Loooooove the tiki theme throughout the restaurant. You can even purchase a Hawaiian shirt upon entering the restaurant, how cool is that?? There's a tiki bar attached to the restaurant where you can move the party to once your done eating. And considering the abundant decorations, the restaurant is spotless. No cobwebs hanging on the lamps, no dust on the knick-knacks or plants. I thought that was impressive! There's also a little pond in the restaurant, how many places can say that?? Totally cute. The service- Accurate. Timely. Friendly. You almost feel like family or close friends when you're enjoying a night out at Chef Shangri-La. The owners are great and very active in their restaurant. They get bonus points for being so interactive with customers and the staff, you don't see that much at restaurants today. Overall- This is a very unique restaurant that's sure to please your taste buds. Come with friends and/or family- the larger the group the better! Don't miss out on this hidden gem!

<review# 468,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/21/2013,8/12/2013,60,239,3,10,6>This is going to be an easy 5-star review to write.Located on a side street just off of Arlington Heights road with west facing windows onto a cute plaza, it offers a great view of the Arlington Heights restaurant area.  Carlos & Carlos specializes in Northern Italian Food and the preparations are terrific.Bread was brought to our table along with homemade herb butter along with a minced relish of green olives and garlic in EVO.  This was a delicious spread to sample with bread.  I asked our waiter, Edwardo, what this "relish" was called.  I can't for the life of me remember the Italian name.  Ten minutes later, he brought us a small bit of ratatouille to try while mentioning "I thought you might enjoy this."  This was the first of what turned out to be top-flight treatment from Edwardo.  We began with the grilled calamari as an appetizer.  This is not the typical calamari prepared with olive oil and a few spices.  Oh no -- large pieces of calamari with capers, olives and  onions in a just-a-bit spicy red sauce.  I loved it although my wife thought it was a little too spicy for her.  Grilled calamari is a favorite of ours but I have never had such a creative preparation.Next came two small stainless steel cups with blueberry sorbet to cleanse our palates from the spicy calamari.  This was an unexpected and classy touch.We next split the Caprese salad which was very good.  No surprises here, just a solid execution of a traditional Italian salad.My wife ordered the Grigliata Di Mare which is grilled tilapia, scallops, shrimp, red & green bell peppers, tomatoes, and garlic over pasta.  When we saw the size of the sea scallops, our eyes virtually popped out of our collective heads.  My wife loved the dish and still had some to take home.  Once again, the care in preparation was evident as the fish, scallops and shrimp were of the right firmness and not overcooked.I ordered one of the daily specials; Spaghetti in meat sauce with meat balls.  Anyone that knows me, knows that this is my "acid test" for a new Italian restaurant.  (Although my wife thinks I'm a goof for ordering "plain old pasta & meat sauce", I view it as a way of measuring the chef's craft.  Bottom line; if you can't prepare a decent marinara or bolognese sauce, how can I trust you to do the "fancy" dishes properly?)  I asked Edwardo if I could get this dish with penne pasta instead of spaghetti.  I tend to be quite a slob when it comes to pasta.  I figure penne or mostaciolli limits the collateral damage.  I was brought a large bowl with my pasta and meatballs.  The meatballs were prepared with veal and filet mignon and were fantastic.  The bolognese sauce, however, was the star of the show.  It was not oily or runny and clung to the penne as if they were young lovers.  The bits of meat were not pulverized and overcooked as is commonly the case in most Italian restaurants but little BB's that had their own individual flavor.  The sauce was not overly acidic OR sweet, just beautifully balanced.  After 3 fork fills I whispered to my wife, "I think this is as good or even better than XXX"  Her jaw dropped in my reference to our favorite "old skool" Italian restaurant in the city.We were too stuffed to order dessert although Edwardo tried to tempt us by showing us all of the attractive desserts.We had a leisurely meal and all of the courses were perfectly paced.  Edwardo was attentive without being obtrusive.  This was our first time dining at Carlos & Carlos but it won't be our last.  This has become a destination restaurant for us.
<review# 469,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/29/2013,8/11/2013,160,353,5,8,4>To Pho opened on Algonquin Road in Schaumburg a few months ago.  Shortly after it opened, I ordered takeout from there - had their Bun Ca Ri Ga (Curry Chicken Noodle Soup).  And, it was wonderful.  At the same time, I ordered one of their Bahn Mi sandwiches - their house special, to take to work for lunch the next day,Over the past month, I have not really been well so have not gone out too much.  When my wife suggested we get out of the house for dinner, the thought was wonderful.  It was my pick, so I chose here - this time, we would eat at the restaurant.The location To Pho is in has changed hands many times over the years.  It was Palmers for a long time, then another place moved their from down the road which did not last.  If I remember right, there were two or three other restaurants there prior to Palmers,  I sincerely hope that To Pho lasts.This time, I ordered a rice vermicelli dish called "Bun Thom & Thit Nuong".  This was a mixture of rice vermicelli, shrimp and pork,carrots, daikon, lettuce, cilantro, bean sprouts and crushed peanuts served with a fish sauce.  To be honest, it was a little bland for me.  But, I added a shot of plum sauce and a shot of sriracha and the meal came to life.  Kerrie got a barbeque pork Bahn Mi, and Jon got a different version of what I got.  The service was great - local owners who have a vested interest in succeeding are usually great.  And, they lived up to the expectationsInside it is nothing fancy.  It looks like they simply took down the Italian poster from the prior owner and added a few from Vietnam.  Inside it simply looks like a diner, but who cares?  Unless you want something really fancy and all you care about is great food, that's what matters.Before leaving, remembering how good to Bahn Mi sandwiches were, I ordered a couple to go.  I got another house special, and this time I also got a barbeque pork.  I don't think I mentioned - the sandwiches are served on the most wonderful french bread rolls.  Because of the French occupation of "Indochine" prior to the Vietnam War, there is a heavy french influence on the Vietnamese foods.  The sandwiches are large (about the size of a good sub sandwich), on much better bread, have great vegetables included jalapenos.  And, they are $4 each.I'll tell you, you cannot find a $4 sub anywhere in our area 1/2 as good.So, kudos to the owners and to the chef.  If you are in the area, stop in and enjoy.  It will be worth your trip.

<review# 471,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/1/2013,8/9/2013,25,58,4,9,7>I'll start off by saying, the food is 5 stars, easy.  They lose a star for service.  It would really be more of a half star ding, but alas, no go on Yelp.Another Wednesday date night with the hubs so off we went to try the new restaurant in town.  Sadly, this spot has been a revolving door of restaurants.  Hopefully, Davanti will get to stay.  If you are in Western Springs, PLEASE stop here so we can keep them around.  Yes, the city is cool and the suburbs are lame you damn hipsters, but give us some love once in awhile, will ya?The space is gorgeous.  Beautiful design here, even if the "stone" walls seem a bit fake and the chairs are "distressed" in a totally faux way.  It's leaps and bounds over what the space looked like before.The food...oh goodness, the food was heavenly.  I had been ogling the menu online all afternoon so I was prepared for what I wanted to try.  This is a total small plate, sharing kind of place so you can sample lots of things and not hurt the waistline too badly.  Hubby was a little overwhelmed with my bossiness when it came to ordering but he thanked me eventually.Lemme break it down for you:Starters -Truffle egg toast: a big square of a thick, perfectly toasted bread-like thing with fontina cheese in the middle, an egg yolk nestled on the top and thinly cut asparagus on the bottom.  Everything drizzled with truffle oil.  This was my least favorite thing that we had but mainly because I really can't stand the smell of truffle oil.  So, why did I order it?  No idea.  It looked luscious in the pictures and I figured the truffle oil wouldn't be a big deal.  Hubs ate most of it and loved it.Ricotta and honey comb with the most perfectly toasted, crunchy, yet tender, olive oily bread you will ever taste.  Seriously.  It comes served beautifully on a wooden plank with the jar of seasoned ricotta, the bread slices and a small piece of honeycomb (which I believe is locally sourced).  It was heaven.  I could have eaten the whole tray but carbs and I don't get along so even on "Cheat night" I try to behave.  This was probably the largest of the appetizers so it is good for a large group.roasted squash, with faro, hazelnuts, goat cheese and watercress:  This dish is beyond any words that I can use to describe.  Faro (or farro) is AMAZING.  It's a super grain with tons of protein and a low glycemic index so I was all over it.  The squash and the hazelnuts paired perfectly with it and the goat cheese.... are you kidding me?  Now, I'm a total whore for goat cheese but I usually eat it cold.  This was warm and gooey and just beyond delicious. This was hands down my fave of the night and will be hard to resist eating on a weekly basis. I was tempted to just another order and be done with it.Here's where the service got the dings.  We spent most of the night in a room in the back by ourselves, despite there being tables in the main room.  Not sure why.  Maybe we didn't look the part besides be dressed appropriately.  Our waitress was clearly working the other room so we did get slighted in service.  She came by, saw we were finished with the initial courses and then said she would be right back.  That was at least 10 minutes later and we still needed to order the other course.  We saw the water server and the food servers more than we ever saw her.  The water server actually took our dessert order. I was tempted to give him the tip.Heartier dishes we ordered:Creamy polenta and ragout of the day: today it was pork shoulder.  We ordered the small and wished we had done a large.  It is beyond perfection.  The polenta is mixed with marscapone and is a creamy spring of yumminess on your tongue.  The pork shoulder ragout was tender and had a perfect red wine reduction.  Hubs isn't a fan of tomato sauces (despite the fact he makes a MEAN bolognese) but loved this.  We were quickly having trouble picking our favorite.Last dish was the risotto carbonara:  I'm in for ANYTHING carbonara.  Again, it was a small plate, sharing portion so it's maybe 1 cup total.  And that is really perfect.  The risotto was cooked perfectly al dente, the cheese and butter and whatever else they used blended to make an amazing sauce to hold it all together.  The pecorino and the panchetta gave it a nice, salty bite.  Hubs said it was his least fave of the night but I loved it.  Creamy, salty and just delicious.Dessert was the carrot cake.  I relinquished to my man for dessert since I manhandled him over the meal choices.  He loves a good carrot cake.  This wasn't your typical carrot cake.  It was more of a trifle-type thing.  It was crumbled up carrot cake layered with a cinnamon based marscapone. Candied carrot strips were on top.  It was delicious but I'm not a huge carrot cake person so I had a couple of nibbles.I will hands-down be back and intend to eat as much faro as possible.  That is, until I find out how much butter, cream and other cheesy goodness is really in there.
<review# 472,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/24/2013,8/8/2013,50,171,7,10,12>Hidden in a Strip Mall in Hoffman Estates lies one gem of a traditional European style bakery.  Sure they don't have trendy mini desserts (there's nary a French macaron to be seen or any other petite desserts that grace the covers of all the haute magazines lately), but there's much to be said for a great traditional bakery, and Peterson's Tasty Delight is most definitely one such staple.Our original game plan when we got married was that we'd go back to the bakery where we got our wedding cake every year and have them recreate the top layer for us on our anniversary.  Well, I dropped the ball big time this year, which left me scrambling for a celebratory cake for our wedding anniversary (and of course I didn't even think about it until the night before).  I had planned to hit up another local bakery on my way home from work, but I flaked out and headed in the opposite direction. Well crap.Luckily I remembered passing a strip mall every day on my way home from work that had a "Bakery" sign nestled in the middle of the row of stores, and I figured something was better than nothing.  When I pulled up to the storefront, I have to admit that I noticed that it wasn't much to look at, and I wondered if I wouldn't be better just stopping at The Fresh Market or something for a cute fruit tart or raspberry mousse cake, but I figured I'd give them a shot anyways.  While the store is not much to look at, I will have to say that the bakery cases are filled to the brim with amazing looking treats like coffee cakes, muffins, breads, cookies, and the seasonally popular paczkis (that I have been craving since I saw them).  They're all reasonably priced, which is another plus.  They also have a rotating cake display right when you walk into the store - score.  I selected the smallest cake that they had (8") in my hungrier half's favorite flavor (chocolate), since I dropped the ball on the original plan, I figured the least I could do was get his favorite kind of cake and maybe he wouldn't notice.  The cake was just over $12 (including tax), which is a steal given how big the cake is.  Let me tell you, sheer willpower was (almost) not enough to keep me from eating the entire cake after that first bite!  The cake is moist and chocolatey, and the filling is pure whipped heaven.  I've been thinking about having another slice ever since I took the last bite, and I can guarantee you that cake doesn't stand a chance.For a little traditional bakery, Peterson's definitely competes with the more well-known area bakeries such as Deerfield and Jaroesch, no doubt.  I can't wait to go back and try some of the other delightful treats that they offer...coffee cake, your days are numbered.

<review# 481,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/31/2013,7/30/2013,27,78,5,8,4>Do you like getting crazy drunk at a low price in a neat, tropical location? Then Hala Kahiki is the place for you! My friends go all the time and I was finally free on a night that they were planning to go. The drive was about 45 minutes away, and I started getting kind of nervous because it looked totally shady on the outside, like a little shack and I thought I was being deceived by my friends. Oh, how appearances can be deceiving! You walk in and the place is huge! Tropical music is playing, like Don Ho, Elvis, and a lot of instrumental tropical music. It's a little dark, but it's so nicely themed. There are palm trees, fruit lights, tiki torches, waterfalls, you name it! The waitresses wear leis and sarongs and they seem to love their jobs. The drink menu is enormous, bigger than the food menu at most restaurants and there is something for everyone. I started basic, with a strawberry margarita (my favorite drink!) with salt on the rim. The drink was HUGE! It tasted really good, not the best margarita, but delicious! My second drink was a Tiger Shark Martini, which is a watermelon-flavored martini with a gummy shark on the bottom. Tasted just like a watermelon Jolly Rancher! My third drink was a French Martini, pineapple, Chombard, and vodka. This one, I did not like. Very strong, too much alcohol in it. Three drinks was definitely strong enough to give me a nice buzz, we were all feeling pretty good. The servers bring you pretzels if you ask them, and they don't serve food except for chips and salsa. Overall, it was about $28/person for three people, which was not too bad for strong drinks with lots of alcohol. Very good service, GREAT atmosphere, excellent experience, AND it is within walking distance from Gene and Jude's hot dog stand, some delicious drunk (and sober) food if I've ever had any!
<review# 482,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/8/2013,7/29/2013,74,502,3,7,5>This store is super cool and to be honest, I never heard of it until recently.My bf used to come here all the time as a kid so we decided to stop by last weekend.I would say that the store is divided into 2 section, 1 being quirky ready to purchase items and the other being parts and gadgets for you to make a quirky item. I enjoyed the "ready to purchase" item section much more than the other. There were books, metal detectors, tons of science stuff (I even spied a dead frog shrink wrapped ready for dissection), tons of gifts for kids/pre-teens...just a lot of randomness.The "parts and gadgets" part of the store had boxes upon boxes of odds and ends. I think you could totally build a robot with all of this stuff!I think we spent about an hour and a half looking around at everything. I ended up purchasing birthday gifts which were a hit. If you plan on stopping by, check out their website first. There was a coupon that I failed to print out but will definitely do so before I go again.

<review# 485,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/31/2013,7/26/2013,68,207,3,4,3>I had only previously stopped by here to pick up a couple bottles of beer (they have a great selection for such a small little place), but immediately found that the place was buzzing for late on a Saturday night. I thought this was just a small convenience store? False. This place is a heavenly organic grocery store with a great wine, beer, deli, meat, and overall food selection. In addition to that, you can take yummy food to go OR dine in their small dining area (I do mean small, it is not a restaurant, more like a small cafe within the grocery store). But they do have a bar and devoted waitstaff.I ate here for lunch yesterday with some coworkers. While sitting at the bar, I quickly realized that this place values the drinkers of the world. Copper cups were sitting behind the bar, which means they have some delicious ginger beverages available (ginger+copper=yum). They also had Goose Island Bourbon County Stout on draft, so they aren't messing around (even though it is slightly out of season now, this stout is nevertheless da bomb). They were also serving up drafts of something from Solemn Oath (local Naperville brewery) and Three Floyds. Good to know for the future...sadly I could not partake of any of these while out on a business lunch.I ordered a steak wrap, when I really wanted the grown up grilled cheese (my coworker got this...bacon, 3 kinds of cheese, tomato, OMG). But the wrap was good. Really good. I was full and not just on lettuce. I would've added a few more veggies if I were the chef, but whatever. The steak was delicious and cooked to the level I wanted (med-rare), and it was seasoned to perfection. I also ordered their french fries, which were really good (although a bit on the soggy side) AND came with truffle mayo. YUM. Very truffle-y though, so you don't need a ton. My other coworker ordered a bento box...rest assured, if you are going to order this and you find yourself wondering if you'll get enough food, don't panic. I was kinda wishing I ordered it, because it came with a great deal of tempura and teriyaki chicken. The cali roll was large as well, not skimpy.The servers here were really friendly and down to earth. They had a HUGE lunch crowd that day and you could tell they were a little overwhelmed, but never gave anyone attitude about it. I'll definitely be back...there were several things on the menu that I would love to try, and I just love the casual but trendy atmosphere of this place. A good place for foodies, in my opinion.
<review# 486,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/21/2013,7/25/2013,11,260,4,15,9>Love, love, love the All Chocolate Kitchen. If you haven't been yet, you are missing out!  Everything here, from the ice cream/gelato, to the delectable devil's food cake, to the golden hot chocolate (made with honey) is exquisite. Their chantilly cream is the best I have had outside of Europe, and their raspberry coulis is...perfection. Really.(I shouldn't say "everything" because there is one menu item that I can't get over: the linguette, which is very savory, but loaded with too much salt.)The restaurant is decorated with chocolate - what else? There is a large, perhaps 15-20 foot chocolate tree, complete with elves' doors, in the center of the room, and two chocolate creations in the fashion of an Neil Armstrong and a Chicago Blackhawks player at the entrance. Television screens broadcast Chef Roby breaking various Guinness book world records, including last year's largest candy cane. It truly is amazing to see art of this magnitude made entirely out of chocolate or sugar.And the staff is wonderful. Kit is our favorite, and we absolutely appreciate that he recognizes each and every time we walk in the door, always flashing us a big smile and a friendly, "welcome back." True, it may take a few minutes for your food and/or drinks to arrive at the table, but that's because this isn't Starbucks or your local Baskin Robbins - this is a quality restaurant, and the waitstaff takes their time in preparing your item so that it arrives at the table beautifully presented. Usually you can't get this kind of quality and care outside of Chicago, and I for one am ever so appreciative.

<review# 491,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/20/2012,7/20/2013,32,141,2,4,2>This place is hidden in an alley off of Washington, just north of the Potbelly which, itself, is just north of the big Barnes & Noble on the corner. I stopped in here for the first time about a week ago and was overwhelmed at first. That was quickly taken care of when I was approached by one of the very friendly owners of the place (at least, he acted like the owner... could have just been a really happy and extremely helpful employee I guess). This place is an olive oil and balsamic vinegar lover's dream. They have dozens of containers with spigots lining the shelves, containing everything from bacon infused olive oil to 20-year old balsamic vinegar. There are little plastic cups for you to sample as many flavors as you want, and there are little bits of bread you can use to dip and taste. When you find something you like, you simply take an empty bottle from under the container, fill it up under the spigot, and take it up to the counter where they heat-seal the cap in place for you. From what I saw, all the flavors are the same price, the only difference in price being the size of the containers (I believe the prices were about $11 for the smaller bottles, and $19 for the larger bottles). I tried a bunch, including the very spicy habanero infused olive oil, but finally settled on the sun-dried tomato, garlic, and parmesan infused olive oil and a bottle of the 18-year balsamic. Earlier this evening I also had the pleasure of enjoying the red-pepper infused olive oil when my wife and I ate at Fiamme, just down the street (apparently the Twisted Olive provides this olive oil to the restaurant, which in turn gives a plug to the store... I thought that was a pretty cool way to operate, with the bonus that the red pepper olive oil was really damn tasty.I can't imagine going through all that much olive oil that quickly, but I would definitely go back here to refill when we run out.Also, walking past this evening I saw a sign that said there were wine tastings... yes please!

the facility.   The beer was great and with four on tap you have to do it right or people will not be coming back.  For me Church Street delivered on 3 of the 4 beers (not bad at all).  There were two lagers which is not my favorite type of beer however the crisp Continental was an excellent lager.  After tasting the IPA all I could think was "Wow, I need a growler of this brew!" but we already made the call that it was a winner before the Scottish was even tasted.  After the final sample of the Scottish I knew that we needed to come back for another growler.  It had all the flavor with out the bite a Scottish ale might typically have.  Overall, they seem to know their beers as well as have their own style which made for a happy customer.Church Street is a little out of the way and there is a lack of signage (at least that I saw from the road) but is worth the search.  As I drove back down Industrial Dr. for the first time looking for Church Street Brewery I thought that there was no way that the brewery was here.  It was about 6:30, dark, and hard to see.  Then as a beacon of light (literally) came out of the door of CSB I knew we found the right place.... also the address was right and there was a bunch of cars.  So when you are heading there don't worry the GPS is not leading you a random shipping dock.  Round Two:In the second visit the tap room, it was packed and there was a line to the door with  people getting growlers and tastings.   It took us a while to get through to the taps but the growlers were worth it.  There was also a new beer on tap - the red rye.  With only a shared sample (we were slightly pinched for time) I was not blown away.  However, it was extremely cold (the beer that is), almost too cold for flavor and I felt I could not get the full experience.  I will be back for another taste of the red rye with the knowledge that the IPA and the Scottish are excellent.

<review# 500,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/6/2013,7/11/2013,421,397,65,70,67>The Verdict Restaurant is a small and cozy diner located off of County Farm road in Wheaton. Located just on the other side of the street from the large shopping center that is home to Target and Ultra Foods it might not be immediately visible to those passing by (I had never noticed it before) but is well worth keeping your eye open for. The inside is clean with a good amount of seating available, there's nothing particularly noteworthy about the decor.After walking in I was immediately greeted and seated, after looking over the menu I noticed that most of the items here are court themed (hence the name Verdict restaurant). I decided on a skillet called "The guilty" which contained cheese, ham, onions, sausage, and bacon. For a drink, I also decided on ordering the municipal building code violation also known as Cola (well, not really be it would be funny if they carried the naming convention scheme all the way).  I chose pancakes instead of toast as the side. My waitress was friendly and courteous. Not too long after placing my order my food was ready.The skillet I received was nice and hot, the sausage and meat pieces were well cooked and flavorful. The big thing that made this skillet great was that the potato's at the bottom were nice and crisp. The eggs were spot on, and everything had just the right amount of seasoning. This was one of the better skillets I've come across. The pancakes here were fairly average but I did appreciate the thick and sweet maple syrup that came with it. Overall I was very happy with my meal.My general opinion of the verdict was very high, great service, great food at a fair price. I wouldn't say the food here is the best of breakfast places I've visited. But it's certainly in the top 3. I highly recommend Verdict Restaurant, the verdict is in and they're guilty of being a great place to stop for breakfast. Five stars, case closed *pounds gavel*.
<review# 501,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/2/2013,7/10/2013,239,635,13,25,16>I may regret writing this review because the café only has 9 tables, but I have now learned to love Lithuanian food.This space used to house a carpet store and I strongly suggest that they get rid of the industrial florescent lights.  The one over the checkout register (I will explain farther into this review) is blinding to 2 of the tables near the front window.When you walk in, there is a checkout register.  That is because they sell Lithuanian products, including pre-made and frozen food.  As I said, there is a very small dining area with one table placed adjacent to, what I thought was, the kitchen swinging doors. Turns out, on the other side of the wall is a deli with all sorts of Lithuanian foods for sale.  The products for sale include used books, in Lithuanian, soccer jerseys, CDs, and a whole lot of other tchotchke.  Beware, all signage is written in Lithuanian.Now, for the good stuff ~ the fresh, made to order food  After speaking with the manager, we learned there is a large Lithuanian population in the area and this place was very busy.  They, of course, ordered their food by calling the meal what it is, I needed the English translation but fully intend to work on my pronunciation.  Lenten specials include cod, salmon, smelt served hot, beautiful presentation, and mouth watering sides and sauces.  All employees were extremely polite, helpful, and very patient answering all our questions.  Suggestions made by our server were spot on and even my husband has a new favorite beer.  That's saying a lot considering we have dined at Bavarian Lodge, formerly known as Chef Paul, for over 20 years and anyone who drinks beer knows that place carries more beers than you could probably ever sample.  It all worked out because he was able to purchase the beer over on the deli side :)They open at 10, for a late breakfast, 9 on week-ends, and serve lunch and dinner.Go and enjoy ~ you can thank me later.
<review# 502,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/24/2013,7/9/2013,304,479,8,15,9>Pho just might be my new love.  Let's be real though, I have a real thing for ethnic food of all kinds.  It just so happened, this week was my first encounter with Vietnamese.So, Cristie B. and I have been *trying* to plan a dinner for, legit, months now, and it FINALLY happened at Pho Ha on Tuesday.  The weather was damn cold and shitty, so something warm and comforting sounded just perfect (without breaking the calorie budget.)  Cristie suggested Pho, and I was all over it.As mentioned in previous reviews:1) yes, its very small inside.  There were maybe six tables?  When I arrived at 5:15 a few were open, but when we left just after 7, they were packed.2) sure, it's a little divey/dingey.  These places generally, in my experience, have the most authentic food.3) yeah, the service wasn't terribly attentive, but, only *after* the food came.  We were offered beverages and to order right away, and the food came out hot and fast.So, what did I eat?  #25 - Pho with sliced beef and brisket.  Also, #2, Vietnamese spring rolls with pork and shrimp.Everything, and I mean EVERYTHING I shoveled into my pie hole that night was glorious.  The peanut sauce at this joint is TO DIE.  The spring rolls were fresh and stuffed with awesome, fresh flavors.  PHO?  OMG.  When Cristie told me that this was miracle soup, she wasn't kidding.  I jazzed mine up with a TON of beansprouts, thai basil, and let a slice of jalapeno sit in there for a bit... perfect.  The broth wasn't greasy, it was clean and deep with flavor.  The noodles were perfect for slurping, I make not excuses for the noises I made while eating.  I ordered a "small" bowl (a large is only 50 cents more, by the way) and had enough leftover to take for lunch the next day.AAAND, to top it off... my dinner, including tip, cost thirteen dollars.  That's insane.You can bet that I'll be back at Pho Ha soon, and looking for Pho closer to my house!
<review# 503,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/4/2013,7/8/2013,1546,338,20,23,22>THE PLACE USED TO BE A BROTHELActually this place was built in 1847 as a stage coach stop, a brothel and then a grand hotel. How cool is that?The Place:This place is located in the center of downtown Wauconda on Main Street. There is parking on the street but if you can't find a spot then there is additional parking across the street down the road in a public lot, and it's free. The bar/restaurant has some original exposed brick and is nicely decorated and clean. My wife and I decided to check out a band that her brother used to play with some of the members. We had always discussed trying out Middleton's so this was the time to do it. We came in and grabbed a seat at the bar as the tables were already occupied on the lower level. While we waited for the band to start playing, we sat and watched the Blackhawks game on one of their 8 TV's located around the bar. You literally can't turn your head without seeing a TV and for most guys that is pretty awesome. I guess my only complaint is that when my wife was talking to me I lost focus on what she was saying because the Hawks just made a goal or there was big hit on one of the other teams players. The conversation went like this "and she said BLAH BLAH BLAH BLAH BLAH and then she said BLAH BLAH BLAH BLAH BLAH, you know what I mean? Ah yes. It was almost like she was announcing the game while I was watching.The Drinks:This place is known as a Gastro Pub. I thought that was a procedure that you had at a hospital but it means that they have hi end booze and beer which they do. One of the bar tenders asked us for our drink order which we made. I went with a beer while my wife went with her usual cocktail. As we waited for our drinks I looked over the drink menu and noticed that they have a pretty extensive selection of beers, cocktails and single malts.The Food:As we sat there we asked for a food menu and noticed that they have a Friday fish fry so we went with the fish and chips and an order of mac n cheese. I have to say that the food is pretty good stuff. The mac n cheese was made with a mixture of cheddar, gorgonzola and BACON (AEWSOME). Anything and everything made with bacon is freaken awesome and this did not disappoint. The flavor of the mac n cheese was not overpowering. It was just right. The fish and chips included fish that was made with Cod that came with a dill sauce for dipping, coleslaw and fries. The fish was fresh and with the sauce it was tasty. The fries were home cut potatoes and also very good.The Experience:So we came here to listen to a band but because the Blackhawks were playing the second game of the playoffs it delayed their start. The band plays on the upper level overlooking the bar area. We stuck around for a few of their songs before we decided to call it a night. The staff is friendly, very organized and efficient.We will definitely be back here for lunch as well as dinner and of course the drinks.
<review# 504,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/3/2013,7/7/2013,78,284,4,6,4>Big selection of craft beers here. It's my main reason for going to EPH the last couple of times. I don't think they have much on tap, but they do have a lot of Black & ____ combos. Of course, the regular Black & Tan (Guinness and Bass), but also Black & Blue (Blue Moon), Black & White (Alagash White), Black Magic (Magic Hat), etc. I don't know if I would try all of those because some combos are weird, but the effort is nice.They have a beer menu with different bottles from all over the place, divided up by region. It's interesting to set it up this way because you can try a beer from somewhere you've never been, or learn where one of your favorite beers is from. Though personally, I'd like to see it divided by type of beer (ambers, porters, stouts) but this is a nice spin on the beer list.The food is pretty solid. The cheese curds are scrumptious and the grilled cheese is pretty good. They put three different kinds of cheese on there, so when you get it, it is oozing cheese. The New Mexican burger seems okay, but they use some kind of cheese sauce instead of regular cheese, so that's a little off-putting. Also, the pub fries could use some work. They're giant, but taste like the frozen kind. I much prefer thinner, crispier fries.The appetizers are a little pricey, but if you split it with someone, it'll be worth it. Otherwise, just stick to the main courses. Also they have some pretty interesting dessert choices. I think the waiter told us they had Guinness cupcakes! But they ran out. Sad face.Service here varies. Everyone is really nice, but even when it's not that busy, the two waiters I've had the past few times were a little inattentive and slow getting our stuff. It could be because the restaurant has a long layout, and customers can sit wherever, so they probably have to go from one end to the other. I'll definitely come back here while employed in the Elgin area. The beer selection keeps me happy.
<review# 505,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/21/2013,7/6/2013,104,319,3,10,3>Zinnng!!That's how I felt after taking my first "flu shot" at Smuzi last Saturday.  I swear, I felt my ears pop as I poured the invigorating concoction of chlorophyll, ginger and lemon down the hatch.  I wasn't sick, but I was taking all the preventative measures necessary to avoid the contagion that seems to be running rampant around these parts this winter.In addition to my flu shot, I opted for a "Shamrock" smoothie which is a blend of kale, celery, dates, banana, mint, almond butter, and hemp protein and milk.  This is basically health, liquefied.  Some people may find their prices expensive-- I too am on a budget but the benefits of juicing are innumerable, and it is far cheaper to fork over $7 to feel and look great than to be sick.  A juice or smoothie is less than...a pack of Sudafed, cigs, martini, extra value meal and so on..  While I waited for my shamrock to be made, the woman at the counter offered me a sample of the "cleanser" which was sweet and tasty, a juice that would be a great option for someone that cringes at the thought of drinking green stuff!!  I spent a few moments listening to the employees talk about their future plans, such as:  organic vegan chocolate, a "garbage" soup, and a three day detox.  All of these things piqued my interest, and their passion for health and innovative ideas will keep me returning to see what's next.  I actually stopped in today for a juice and shot and the girl at the counter recognized me and seemed genuinely enthused that I was already back for more.  They even had a punch card today for buy 10, get one free-- and gave me credit for Saturday's drink as well.  The parking situation isn't bad, so long as it's not a weekend since we are talking third street in Geneva, but even on Saturdays, there are usually spots in the lot behind Smuzi/Caribou.  If you're looking to indulge in a healthy, guilt free and antioxidant packed delight, stop on by, you will not be disappointed.
<review# 506,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/20/2013,7/5/2013,30,137,6,9,9>We finally made it out to this brewery after we had attended a wake in Naperville (I can't think of a better time to have a drink than after a wake).This is a bare-bones operation because they're all about the brewing, but they do have a little area where you can get a taste of whatever they've got on tap, which changes constantly. It's just a counter separated from the brewery by a half-wall, with stools which can seat maybe a dozen people tops - it's standing room only for the rest. Because they don't serve any food, they're only open from 12- 9 PM Tuesdays through Saturdays and 12 - 7 PM on Sundays. Also, there's a limit of 3 beers per person. But what beer! I'd wanted to try their Kidnapped by Vikings IPA, which I'd heard about, but it didn't seem to be on the list that night. So I tried the next closest thing they had - a Belgian wheat IPA called Mr. Inappropriate (light golden color, dry, hoppy, and a tad bitter but not too much). We then moved on to Chubgutz, a reddish-brown Premium Bitter with a nice earthy, nutty flavor, and then the Mansaka Masala, my favorite of the night. It's a hearty porter flavored with a lip-smacking Chai spice blend including cardamom, vanilla bean, clove, ginger, cinnamon, tellicherry black peppercorn, and Ceylon tea. Reminded me of the Christmas beer we brewed ourselves one year, only heavier on the spices.If you must have food and comfy seats, check out the Events list on Solemn Oath's Website for some of the beer pairing dinners they host at various places around Chicago. But if you don't mind standing and have an adventurous streak, Solemn Oath Brewery is a good place to stop by after work (or a wake) for a great craft beer.P.S. Pay no attention to the address. This place is not actually on Quincy Avenue, but on the street directly behind the Cadillac dealership on Quincy. Also, your money is no good here - they don't accept cash, so make sure you bring plastic.

They have an Early-Bird called at 6:45 pm and then Regular Bingo at 7 pm. They play regular Bingo, Bonanza, Pull-Tabs, Split-the-Pot and plus more! You get to a total of 15 Games of Bingo. For example, when the number 22 is called everyone that has a whistle blows it! Too(t)...Too(t) ... like a train.This was a great random/spur of the moment fun! Don't forget to bring your Daubers! If you're like me and this is your first time playing Bingo you can purchase one for a $1 there! They also have affordable refreshments and snacks that your able to purchase. Or bring your own!

<review# 516,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/17/2013,6/25/2013,107,169,3,9,9>Best sushi I have ever had.  Seriously. Not the best location I have ever eaten sushi in.  Bummer.  The fish here is really something else, like better than any place I've had in the Chicago area, including downtown.  Reading other reviews, I'd say you're best off going on a Friday or Saturday night.  The waitress we had was awesome, the chef was firing on all cylinders, and we had a meal that blew us away.  If the tables in here weren't so flimsy and the ambience were a step up, I would definitely give them 5 stars.  Still, if you ignore the surroundings the sushi is incredible.We started out with the tuna sampler, which was 2 pieces each of three different kinds of tuna.  There was ahi, yellowtail, and super white, served over a small bed of rice noodles.  The dish presentation was nothing special, but to taste the raw ingredient was enlightening.  Of the three, I thought the yellowtail tasted the best, but the super white was interesting, to say the least.  I'd never tried super white before, and I liked it- maybe not quite as much as yellowtail (or bluefin when you can find it), but I liked trying something new.  After that, we decided to try the super white prepared, so we ordered the Ecstasy appetizer.  This was sublime.  It was thinly super white in a spicy vinagarette.  There were some spicy peppers and scallions on the plate.  Amazing dish.For the main order, we mixed it up with some basic Maki rolls (veggie, tuna, and California).  We also decided to try the Ocean Drive and the Summer Rolls as everyone on Yelp raves about them.  The basic Maki rolls were fine, I don't get inspired by the standard maki.  Most places use the "less than ideal" stuff for the rolls, but I still like to order them to gauge quality.  The Summer and Ocean Drive were freaking amazing.  The lemon-covered salmon on the Ocean Drive was some of the best tasting fish I have ever had.  The Summer Roll was reminiscent of sushi that you'd get on a beach in Mexico.  What?  You've never had sushi on a beach in Mexico?  Me either- and this stuff made me feel like I was there!  That's how overwhelming this food can be on your senses.  Far and away the most delicious rolls I have ever tried.  I'm craving more as I type this!Cocktails were reasonable.  We ended up getting a bottle of Pinot Noir, I also had a Sapporo Beer and my GF had an extra glass of wine (I only live about 1/3 mile from this place, so no worries about drunk driving).  The total bill (with tip) came to $150.  I thought this was reasonable given the drinks and the amount of sushi we ordered.  Overall, I thought the cost of the fish was justified by the quality.  Our waitress was great, and the food blew my mind.  If they could dress the place up a bit I wouldn't hesitate to give them 5 stars.  Regardless, I will be back for more.
<review# 517,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/23/2013,6/24/2013,63,60,4,8,6>La Hacienda is a singular restaurant. There is little not to like. That wasn't always the case.Sometimes in life you find restaurants that irritate you because the food is amazing but you get service that sucks. What do you do? Normally, I would say "work around it, fool. Just get the food to go." But what if one of the foods you want is an alcoholic beverage? Then you are screwed. If you want that drink, sooner or later you'll have to go back and sit down and have the meal experience all over again.Normally, I hate going back to eat at a place with bad or spotty service because it makes me feel like the restauranteurs are winning in spite of themselves and they have my money to prove it. However, sometimes that repeat business is just what you need in order for an establishment to restore your faith.I used to think that La Hacienda's service sucked, but man, they have what I can only call "definitive" margaritas. Really, at the risk of sounding like a raging alcoholic, I cannot impress enough how much I love the margaritas there. They are so great. But that's not all. They also have great chips and salsa, excellent enchiladas, and... incredible... decor (you'll see if you go). Occasionally, they have live music that is low-key, well-performed, and actually kind of romantic. All of those things were reasons to go back after a couple bad experiences, so eventually I gave in and went back. The service was great. So I went back. Again, the service was great. So I went back again. Now I can't stay away.Service is one of those "X-factors" in a restaurant that's sometimes hard to quantify. Patrons have wildly different ideas about what makes good service. Personally, I expect a friendly greeting and reasonable ticket times, and that's about it. But that's just my expectation- great service comes from going beyond those expectations so that when I leave my day is better than when I came in. This doesn't necessarily mean waiting on guests hand and foot- sometimes it's as simple as remaining friendly and maybe recognizing your regulars. Great servers also usually suggest something and show some food knowledge. If something comes out wrong during the meal, waitstaff and management turn the situation into an opportunity to show care for their guests. Lastly, places with great service do these things consistently.La Hacienda used to fail in many of the aforementioned respects, and I (rightfully) resented it. However, in my opinion, they have really turned things around. It's rare to see that kind of an improvement in a restaurant, and it deserves recognition. Way to go guys! You are killing it for real.I'll say that there are other places in the area that do some of the dishes a little better, but if you want a great all around Mexican dining experience for a reasonable price -and especially if you're looking for a good margarita- I'd be remiss not to recommend La Hacienda de Roselle. It's pretty great.

The downside is that it's basically one room so youre in a fitness class taking up the entire open floor space with people working out on the machines and running on the treadmills around the perimiter of the room. Who cares, right. I guess this is how they offer classes at low prices; by keeping the overhead down.

<review# 521,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/20/2013,6/20/2013,187,236,8,10,8>Can I move to Oak Park, please? If I ever move here, I would be lying if I said the main library had nothing to do with it. LOVE:-The selection. It is huge. There are books, DVDs, games, books on CD, etc. GALORE. The library also has copies of several different books that are particularly popular, which is ideal. I mean, how annoying is it when you reeeally want to read a book but it's checked out and there are 547893709876 holds on it? That's much less of a problem at this library than at others.-Classes offered. That's right. CLASSES. At the library today, I found brochures for classes on job seeking as well as technology. How cool is that? Pretty darn cool if you ask me. The job search series have classes like "Things About the Job Search You May Not Know...But Should" and "Tips for Submitting Online Job Applications." -Something for everyone. There are huge distinct sections. Children's. Teens. Adults. OPPL has it all and there is definitely something for everyone here. My jaw dropped to the floor when I first came here and I have still not explored the whole thing! I have never seen a library with as extensive of a manga/comic/graphic novel section and I have never seen a library with a huge teen cafe-like hangout section. This library caters to EVERY age group and it's amazing. There is even the option to get materials delivered to your home for the sick/disabled. Incredible.-Technological. The library is ahead of the times when it comes to technology. -Programming. There always seems to be something going on at OPPL. All kinds of somethings. Tonight, there is even going to be a "Dating Game" for 20s-30s singles (first drink free). Today, I saw virtuoso violinist Rachel Barton Pine give an excellent master class here. There are tons of events for kids on the calendar, gaming, open mic night for teens, book discussions, improv workshop, Facebook tutorial, knitting, etc. If you can imagine it, it's probably been done (or will be done) here! DO NOT LOVE:-Steep fines. I know every library is different when it comes to fines, but I think $1/day for DVDs and video games and then $0.25/day for books is quite pricey. Really pricey. Most other libraries in the 'burbs charge $0.10/day for overdue books. Of course, I'm not *really* complaining because I am responsible and I always renew online if I know I can't make the return date. -Architecture. I know this is really nitpicky, but it feels kind of sterile in here. Not homey. I think OPPL reminds me more of a Borders or Barnes & Noble than it does of a library. That's fine, but I don't "love" that about it. I love libraries with some history, like the Riverside Public Library.-Bells & whistles. For example, there are 50 Nooks available for rental (three weeks at a time). There are also self check-out stations. Now, I do not think it is a bad thing at all for the library to have these things. In fact, I think it's pretty wonderful and cushiony. That being said, I can't help but ask: where does all this money come from? Taxes? There are a stunning THREE libraries in Oak Park. No, I don't hate this and I'm not complaining exactly. I just hope that OPPL has not used thousands for these "extras" instead of building an even better library of books and movies.Just because I am not in love with absolutely every aspect of OPPL does not mean that I am not, in fact, actually totally in love with this library. It is as close to perfect as I have seen yet in a library! I'm so happy Oak Park values its libraries.Tip: Beware the first stall of the women's bathroom on the second floor. The space between the wall and the stall is 1.5-inches. Yikes!

And no, I can't promise I won't sneak in some risque questions that will make this rendition reminiscent of those high school and college days...Would you rather...Have a creamy treat that is pure potassium or have a smooth sweet packed with cals?I know it's hard to beat ice cream, custard or gelato, but I can assure you that you won't miss those classic cold desserts when you try the signature frozen banana. Even my ice cream-loving husband had to do a double-take when he got his free sample: "No way this is just pureed frozen ripe banana!" We ordered a large size to split mixed in with granola and the healthified version of fudge sauce made of dark cocoa and fruit juice. I would have appreciated way more granola mixed in throughout, but the overall dish satisfied our sweet tooth. In the end, I would honestly prefer this over the usual frozen sweet snacks any day.Would you rather...Have a comforting bowl of Vitamins A and C or have a savory soup filled with gobs of cheese?On a gray winter morning, a hot bowl of soup sounds heavenly. French Onion soup is kind of a guilty pleasure of mine because of the insane amounts of cheese and bread in it, whereas tomato basil soup is always more of my "guilt-free option." So when I saw Baked Tomato soup as a special of the day, my interest piqued. Hubby and I shared a big bowl of this, and it definitely was like the two soups combined into one. I absolutely adored the creamy tomato base with the layer of cheese glued to the top. However, I would have preferred a bit more of a crunchy crust of cheese. This ended up being one of my all-time fav versions of tomato soup.Would you rather...Have a filling fiber dish or a quick-fix of carbs to satiate the taste buds and empty stomach?Another special of the day was the Spaghetti Squash. Don't be surprised when you find no noodles but squash strings instead. This in-season veggie made a beautiful presentation with half of the shell holding spaghetti-like butternut squash, mixed in with chunky marinara sauce and shaved parm. I did not miss my pasta because this dish was so flavorful with the fresh squash paired with juicy, sweet bits of tomato and salty cheese. It was a huge portion and came with a mixed green side salad. I even ended up taking some of it home for later.P.S. I had some of my hubby's carne asada quesadilla, and we agreed that dish was just as amazing as what I ordered and described above because of the tender meat and just-made salsa.To sum up, this brunch was all about the substitutes with all the health benefits and no loss on flavor. It ranks up there with some of my most memorable brunches, and if I'm ever back in the area, I will be sure to visit again.
