<review# 529,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/28/2013,6/12/2013,57,59,6,10,7>So Red Chopsticks is a new restaurant that has sprouted among the retail weeds of New York and Rt. 59. (In case you're brain has blocked out the eyesore of the dying strip mall, its the one with the Best Buy and the Fox and the Hound). The building sticks out since it's structure is unique, with bright red paneling. A few of my co-workers and I have been dying to get in there, but after a particularly hard workout session, my sister and I decided to treat ourselves to a night of Pad Thai.Ambiance: You can tell this is a place that is still definitely still trying to get their sea legs. The layout itself is typical of a fast casual eatery - attractive tables and booths laid out in grids. That's pretty much where it ends though, since you are greeted at the door by a fairly well stocked bar and really beautiful golden wire lamps. (I'm a sucker for the aesthetic; these things amplify an experience for me).Service: Here's where Red Chopsticks really shined. The place was totally empty when we walked in, but all the of the waitstaff seemed diligently working. (Granted, we walked in around 8:30; I'm guessing we missed the dinner rush.) Our waiter Pablo was a total sweetheart and did not leave us wanting for anything. He was on top of refills, met every request with a smile, and checked up on the food twice. Though I can't remember her name, our hostess was also equally polite, saying she hoped we enjoyed our experience. I know saying something like that is so minor and automated for restaurants, but she was so earnest and I am absolutely convinced that it really *was* important to her (and all the waitstaff we encountered) that we enjoyed our experience.Food: And then we get to the food. The food itself was solid, but we didn't really get anything that blew us away. The crab rangoon was typical; the standout was the thin and slightly spicy duck sauce we had for dipping. The Chicken Satay was sadly a little chewy and there simply was not enough peanut sauce served for the two piece set. My sister asked for the Pad Thai with curry and tofu, which was absolutely delicious. We also got the Sesame Chicken, which avoided the over-sweet tendency of most other restaurants. Over all, it was a good meal at a great price. For all the food listed above, it was about $35 without tip. I'd say if you're shopping in the area and are craving Asian food that isn't Panda Express, Red Chopsticks is a pretty solid choice.
<review# 530,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/30/2013,6/11/2013,127,193,7,7,6>I love the Tivoli.  My first experience here was Christmas '11, seeing "Holiday Inn" for the first time with my good friend Melissa H.  You definitely step back in time walking in for the first visit.  The theatre is split into Aisles!  Step in the moviehouse and you feel like you're in a dream.  The Tivoli has been beautifully restored.For Holiday Inn, they had the old pipe organ cranking, and people were happily singing along to the carols on the screen.  Then the lights went down, the movie started up and people started applauding!  When was the last time you saw that?  Applause after every musical number.  THIS is what the Golden Age of moviegoing must have been like, and I am now a convert to the throwback ways.Free refills on any size popcorn or drink, and a Classic Rewards card enhance your value.  Plus, the last Friday of each month sees a special midnight showing of classic films.  I have seen Raiders of the Lost Ark, Back to the Future and Planes, Tranes and Automobiles during these showings, and they are always great times.  I love the company that has committed to running classic theatres like the Tiv, and only wish they had gotten to the DuPage Theatre in Lombard before its untimely demise.Let's all go to the movies!
<review# 531,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/6/2013,6/10/2013,123,246,6,10,7>What a great local hidden gem this place is. Imagine a sushi version of Cheers. Sure it's not some pseudo-fancy wannabe contemporary joint with ear screeching techno blaring through the speakers causing a person to eat an unnecessarily fancy maki roll at a meth induced pace but the plain homely feel is just what I was looking for.  Yup, the sights have been set on Sushi Ya. Minami is here to show you how it should be done.The place was packed at prime time on a Friday evening so in hopes of a little separation from conversation din of the main dinner crowd, we opted to plop ourselves right in front of the sushi chef. Min, the sushi chef, is also an owner and took great care of us. Mind you, he's Korean and my general opinion of Korean owned/run sushi restaurants are typically dismal at best but they are also almost impossible to avoid so I decided to give it a shot.  I was never happy with the service and food quality at sushi Ya so I was looking to fill the void of local casual sushi joint for my pedestrian sushi needs and Minami certainly seems to be filling said void very well so far.It's important to note that there is really nothing fancy about MInami. Min serves up some great fish without the pretentious notions that seem to surround so many other establishments these days.  They have PLENTY of seating so although I saw a few larger parties waiting for a few minutes there was generally very little wait time at peak hours. I've got a feeling that this may change in the future as others discover this quaint little corner of a strip mall and all the goodness it has to offer. Great for large groups as they have a separated area that I assume is there for just this purpose.  While Chef Min was furiously rolling maki, I carefully inspected the quality of the fish in his cooler and was happy to find that the quality appeared visually to be very fresh and consistent. I was even happier to taste the fish that he cut generous and beautifully shaped portions of for our sashimi combo. No frozen BS here. Everything tasted fresh and the texture and temp was right on. We also ordered a soft shell crab as an appetizer and although presentation was a little plain (as is all the dishes here) the breading was just right and the dipping sauce well crafted. We were just in for a few drinks and a light dinner but my wife being the occasional maki fiend that she is decided to order one of those monstrosities covered in something like 16 different sauces rolled to heroic proportions. I think it was called the King Kong roll and I have to say that even though I'm not really a fan of rolls, the King Kong was an explosion of flavors that rounded off our meal quite well.The service that we received was attentive but not intrusive, which is just the way I like it. Observing that we were having a long and leisurely meal, Sarah who seems to be the head server/manager came over to chat with us after we were done eating. Although she seems young, she exuded charisma and a sense of hospitality and experience that extends beyond a superficial greeting and smile. She chatted with us and gave us another round of the fancily cut oranges my wife liked so much.While viewing the menu I spotted some decently priced lunch special items and made a mental note to stop by for lunch sometime.  In fact, most of the pricing on the menu items are either fair or downright cheap considering the quality and portions. This is truly an affordable every day type of sushi restaurant.I wouldn't be surprised if they remembered us the next time we come because that's just the type of personal service that people seem to receive here and that is exactly what I am looking for. I'll be back soon to sample more of their menu.
<review# 532,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/2/2013,6/9/2013,25,285,5,7,5>The owner, Violeta, is passionate about chocolate, and after attending a tasting of four grand cru hot chocolates, so am I. She prepared the chocolate simply with hot water and served it in tiny cups for a jolt of pure, intense, complex flavor. The Tanzanie Origine Rare 75% from East Africa was my favorite -- dark and fruity with an earthy overtone. Maracaibo 65% from Venezuela was a close second -- rounded and complex with a hint of cinnamon. She also stocks reasonably-priced gourmet chocolate truffles and omg turtles that she makes in small batches by hand. There was a good selection of gelato too and since I'd already exceeded a calorie record for the day I had a scoop of stracciatella that was deliciously full of tiny chocolate bits. Oh boy am I in trouble now that I've discovered this place.
<review# 533,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/2/2013,6/8/2013,65,197,4,9,6>A diamond in the ruff.  I have driven past this place countless times without a second thought until my daughter's boyfriend mentioned a place on Algonquin Rd.. with the best Chinese food he has had, and he has eaten in Hong Kong.  OK, so maybe not as  Fancy, but it has all the favorites.  The Sesame Beef is crispy and sliced very thin, the Kung Pao Shrimp was awesome (spicy for those of you faint of heart) but plenty of shrimp and sooo tasty.  The Hot N'Sour soup was great--some places make it too vinegary or garlicky but this was just the right balance.It was packed on a Saturday night, and the takeout window was constantly busy.  I would have given it 5 stars but service was lacking, two servers for the whole room, someone must have called in sick.  It won't stop me from going back, it was well worth the wait.
<review# 534,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/18/2013,6/7/2013,98,221,11,18,18>I've been talking about going to this place for months, MONTHS!, now and just never made it over here.  We finally went this past weekend, and OHMYGAWDWHY did I wait so long to come here!?!  This place easily has some of the best food in the south suburbs.We got the BBQ shrimp and Voodoo Nuts as appetizers, and both were fantastic.  I'm not a huge sausage fan, but   I really enjoyed the Blue Crab Bisque.  It was way lighter than any bisqu I've had and had a bright, lemony flavor too it.  For my entree I ordered the blackened scallops.  These were some of the best scallops I've ever had in my entire life.  They were masterfully prepared and melt in your mouth.  Scallops are a finnicky thing to prepare so I've been disappointed more than once.  The sweet potato fries were good, but probably the least impressive of everything I ate.  My compainions ordered the massive porkchop and the Crabe avec Crabe.  I had bites of both and both were delicious.  I think I might go for my own crab next time around.  I'm not a big fan or pork chops/ pork products that aren't bacon, and would even consider ordering the porkchop (if it were about a quarter of the size...)  The food was so good we couldn't skip dessert so we ordered the bread pudding which was actually bananas foster bread pudding and amazing.  One of the most amazing things about the food was how subtly flavorful the food was while still being absolutely packed with flavor.The selection of craft beers (26) is outstanding.  They don't just throw some Three Floyd's on the menu and call it a day.  They have an impressive list with several beers on the list I've never seen/ heard of.Our waitress, Wendy, was fantastic - so friendly.We sat in the (newly renovated) four seasons room off the side.  The decor was not at all what I was expecting.  I was expecting more dive bar, less classy restaurant.  In any case, it was absolutely lovely.  I think it was a little on the pricey side, but I didn't feel like we overpaid.  The quality was definitely there.It took me forever to make the trip here, but I most definitely won't wait that long before my next trip!
<review# 535,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/7/2013,6/6/2013,160,654,5,12,5>Do you love music, I mean REALLY love music? If you do, Arcada Theatre is for you. Located near the heart of St. Charles maybe a block from the Fox River, this old-fashioned theatre is now a hub for classic rock performers of the 70s and 80s. I came here to see former ELP drummer Carl Palmer with his own band. Once inside, the charm of the original theatre was plainly visible. A long lobby leads you past a Starbucks, candy store and a ticket window inside. On the opposite side, there's a vendor table and even an "Italian beef sandwich sliders" cart in case you need a beef before the show.Inside, the seating is elegant and the walls are ornate. While this is not as pretty as Chicago Theatre, Arcada retains the old theatre aura, right down to the house organ player, who emerges from an enclosure on the floor, seated on a platform with the antique instrument and descends back down as the show is about to begin. He's an older gentleman who probably is almost as old as the theatre itself. The owner, Ron Onesti, introduced him before the show, saying humorously that the organist came with the building.What I love about this place is the variety of shows booked, from "Jersey Boys" to classic rock cover bands, to older rock or metal bands that can't get into the Ticketmaster venues anymore and rely on outlying clubs or theatres such as this one to have a stage to perform. Tickets are also more affordable than through the TM gauntlet. Ron Onesti has a class operation and is genuinely interested in pleasing his audiences with acts they want to see and has found a niche for acts you can't see anywhere else these days.The seats are comfortable and the place is well maintained. The bathrooms are small but in good shape despite the age of the building. Having the Starbucks and Chicago Turtle Factory as essentially independent businesses acting as the concessions for this place works out quite well in the end. I found myself going to the candy shop twice and even got some things to bring home after the show.I look forward to coming back here for "Genesis Revisited" with Steve Hackett in September, or maybe sooner if another great show pops up on the schedule.
<review# 536,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/28/2013,6/5/2013,21,77,3,9,7>I finally found my favorite Japanese restaurant in the Chicago area!  I moved to the Chicago burbs from Atlanta back in '08 and haven't been able to find a Japanese restaurant that rivaled my favorite in Atlanta until now.  Most restaurants that I have found are primarily about sushi, while Japanese cuisine is an after thought.  So much of Japanese cuisine is delicious that it's a unfortunate that it isn't better represented in restaurants.  But that's neither here nor there, so I'll move on to the review!Isakaya Sankyu is a great balance of quality food and reasonable prices (with one exception that I'll get to later).  My wife and I went for lunch on Saturday.  The place was practically empty.  With not many people to wait on, we got some great service.  They started with some very good complimentary hot green tea.  Our cups were never less than half full before they would come back and top them off.  I ordered the tonkatsu ramen, which was very good.  It was $7 and change, and I was told I could get the ramen set for only $1 more, which included a choice of crunchy gyoza or pork shumai.  I went with the gyoza and they were delicious (not the frozen out of the bag variety).  I also went with a Rock and Roll maki (hamachi and unagi).  For only $5.50, I felt like I was stealing from them.  I thought that they might make the roll smaller, since it was so inexpensive.  Boy was I wrong!  The maki was cut into 8 pieces with a good amount of fish and eel in there.  That made up for the $4.50 single piece of unagi nigiri that my wife had ordered.  The nigiri are the only part of the menu that seem expensive to me.  Everything else is reasonable to cheap in price.  That being said, she really enjoyed that piece of eel.  It looked very good and was a decent sized piece of eel.  She also ordered the katsu don (her favorite) and the shrimp tempura appetizer.  I tried a little of both (I often eat off of her plate) and they were both very good.Every aspect of the meal was very good and for a little more than $30 we had quite the feast.  With Mitsuwa just a mile away, we now have at our disposal a nice Japanese-themed outing in the suburbs.

<review# 538,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/27/2013,6/3/2013,89,150,3,13,4>No down dog or child's pose in this yoga studio!  Get ready for "the awkward pose", lotus, tree and 23 other poses...that would complete the 26 standard bikram yoga poses.The Bikram Yoga sign is visible from 53 on the back of their building.  Entrance is around the front. Leave your shoes at the door!  In the bathroom there are 4 nice clean showers and an open changing room with a cubby hole shelf unit to stow your belongings. Not a big fan of the complete lack of privacy or not having my purse locked in a locker, but by the end of class I was too hot and sweaty to care about anything except a shower!  Arrive a few minutes early to enter the "hot room" and lay on your mat to adjust to the steamy 105 degree temp.  Good thing there is not a clock in there because being a first timer to bikram there got to be a point when I just kept wondering how many minutes I had left!  The hot room is really nice...mirrors all around and some kind of velvety soft yoga carpeting.  I had class with Maria today and while she does not demo the poses, she pointed out the seasoned bikram yogis so that I could find a good spot to watch the moves and follow along.  Maria explains every move and encourages and pushes you to follow through.  She is an expert!  CLASS SEQUENCE:- Breathing/warm up (15 ish minutes)- Standing poses ( 30 minutes)- Seated poses (40 minutes)- Breathing/savasana (5 minutes)That is kind of how it worked! So at least you will know that you are approximately  half way through class once you begin the seated poses.  Really, you can do this!  It's hot, but it is manageable.  I signed up for the new student 14 consecutive days for $24 plan.  I am ready to go back...feeling like I had a great work out today!  Just FYI, I did drink my entire 24 ounce water bottle during class and since being home I seriously can not stop drinking water.  WATER!!!!!There is a water bottle refill fountain in the hall between the locker rooms!
<review# 539,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/2/2013,6/2/2013,176,176,8,8,7>A Mexican and a Brazilian walk into a restaurant....Well, actually, there's no joke here. This is about the marriage of two great flavors! I grew up eating Mexican food. But I haven't had much occasion to sample the flavors of Brazilian food until now. And believe me, this fusion of food will have me coming back for more.A friend had been raving about the food at Changarro and invited me to join her for dinner one evening. I ordered Enchiladas Verdes, the standard entree I order to compare with other Mexican restaurants. They only offer chicken filling, which was fine by me. Overall, they were pretty good and had a decent amount of heat. The dinner plate came with four enchiladas, rice and beans.Now, I don't typically eat a lot of red meat. I do like ground beef in my enchiladas on occasion, but there's no ground beef at Changarro. Instead, they have Brazilian chopped beef and, seriously, you have got to try it!My friend ordered Memelitas, something I had never heard of. Memelitas are homemade corn flat breads with your choice of topping. When my friend ordered hers with Brazilian beef, I immediately assumed the meat would be tough, chewy and hard to swallow like some steak tacos I've had at other Mexican restaurants and taquerias. But, WOW, this was some awesome beef! Full of flavor, tender and definitely something I will order in the future.By the way, we tried three of their Margaritas too. The Mangorita was probably the favorite. They had one with guava which was a good second choice. The Fresa Fresca had  strawberries which were a bit chunky, but still good. Not too overpowering with the alcohol and not your "fishbowl" size either. These seemed more classy. There were a handful of other creative drink concoctions to try too.I stopped back in for lunch on another day and tried their Chicken Enchilada Soup and a chicken taco with avocado. The soup was hearty, full of chicken and large enough to suffice for lunch. Maybe a bit too much salt in the soup for my taste preferences, but still good nonetheless. The chicken in the taco was juicy and tender, the perfect compliment to my soup.Decent guacamole too, in addition to their complimentary chips with avocado-cilantro sauce and another red sauce to which they add a bit of honey.On their menu, I'm already eyeing their Ensalada de Jicama, which is a salad with Jicama, pear, cress, lettuce, hearts of palm, pine nuts and cilantro vinaigrette. You won't find that in a typical Mex restaurant, let alone in West Chicago.Changarro has united the flavors of Mexico and Brazil and brought them to a suburb that needed a unique twist on good food and flavors. Here's to a long and happy union!

Can't get much better than this. GO CHECK IT OUT!!
<review# 542,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/12/2013,5/30/2013,66,166,7,7,8>I've driven past here a bazillion times, since I live in the area and it's been here awhile. I've visited other businesses in this strip mall. But until yesterday, I never stopped here. I had a pounding hunger headache and I needed to hit the auto parts stores over in this area to look for some parts. Yelp reviews told me about how this place had fantastic homemade teriyaki sauce. As a longtime Japanese food fan, I'm usually not the biggest fan of teriyaki -- mainly because a lot of people get lazy with it and just use store-bought sauce. If you're going to do it in a restaurant, make it your own. I don't think that's too much to ask. This place does. Also, as soon as you walk in, you see that they have two things on every table: a bottle of their homemade teriyaki sauce (so you don't have to ask for extra if you eat in), and a bottle of Sriracha. (Proper Sriracha -- no Lee Kum Kee bootleg cocksauce here!) Lunch special is great. You get a little salad with a nice homemade creamy dressing, fluffy rice (white rice is included, but you can substitute fried for an additional charge), and your meat of choice. I had chicken. I'll upload photos in a moment. Drinks selection is your typical fountain stuff augmented by a cooler full of iced tea/energy drinks/Vitamin Water/Sobe. I wish they offered hot tea, but that's a minor quibble. Their homemade teriyaki sauce is great. Add Sriracha to the fluffy white rice and contrast the layered spiciness with the sweet/salty teriyaki and have a very happy party. In your mouth. I heard what I said. They also offer free samples if you're not sure. Stop in and give it a try. I want to try the spicy pork next time. :9

And then, Dr. Rogers taps and then enters bubbling, with a big smile yet calming demeanor. <review# 546,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/7/2012,5/26/2013,133,66,9,7,8>Let me preface this review by introducing my furry babies, Poppy and Stanley, who have requested that they be given a Yelp-y voice to rave about Randall Oaks. And as I can never resist those puppy-dog eyes -- I will now be turning the keyboard over to them.Woof! My name is Ran-rey (translation - Stanley) and I ROOOVE (ahem, LOVE) Randall Oaks Animal Hospital! They are always willing to squeeze me in for impromptu visits -- like the time I drank Mommy's coffee and she was worried that I would get sick...or the time I got into the potpourri and got a serious tummy ache...and even the time I got those weird itchies all over my belly. I know Mommy gets a little embarrassed every time she has to take me in for my bad-doggie moments -- but the doctors never make her feel like she is doing a bad job. They understand that sometimes -- bad-doggie moments happen. But they do have a lot of literature available to help remind other pet parents about some of the dangers for us furry ones -- especially around the Holidays. Oh, and they always give me treats! Lots and lots of treats, as long as I sit for them really good on the table. And if I remember to give them kisses on the way out they'll even give me more treats for the car! But I always eat them before we get to the car. And then I'm sad when I don't have anything to eat on the ride home. Mommy says I need to learn about delayed gratification.  Grrr...My name is Poppy. I may be wittle (little), but I'm FUR-ocious! Rawr! I'm equal parts scaredy-cat and nervous nelly -- and I don't trust ANYONE. I don't really like leaving the house, since most places make me so nervous that I shake. Literally! But I don't shake that much at Randall Oaks. The doctors know that I have trust issues, and they make sure to talk to me in a soothing voice -- and even pet me a little bit before starting the exam. They wait until the shakes have calmed down before doing anything doctor-y like checking in my ears or touching me with that cold thing they wear around their neck. And they know that Mommy gets sad when I cry while getting my shots, so they always take me out of the room for that part so that Mommy doesn't cry too. The doctors try to give me treats as a peace offering after the exam, but I never take them. Sometimes I pretend like I will, but when they put it in my mouth -- I let it fall out onto the floor. Mommy says I'm a snob, but the doctors laugh and give her the treats for later. When I'm back in the car, in my safety harness and SURE that we're not going back for any more doctor stuff -- I'll eat the treats. Okay, here's Mommy now -- she has some stuff to add.Stanley and Poppy pretty much summed it up! Poppy has been a patient of Randall Oaks since the day I brought him home -- six years ago! Like he said, he doesn't really enjoy too many places -- but he does amazingly well at Randall Oaks. They know just how to sweet talk him into a semi-calm state. Though he hasn't required much outside of annual check-ups -- we did bring him to Randall Oaks for some pretty major dental work (requiring anesthesia and everything!), and they were very helpful in talking us through the procedure and associated costs. Stanley, on the other hand, has had almost as many visits to the vet in his two years as Poppy has had in his six! He is the picture of a playful puppy -- even at two years old, he is always getting into or trying to eat something that he shouldn't. He's been seeing the good doctors at Randall Oaks since he was smaller than Poppy (true story!) -- and they can't get over how big he's grown (25 pounds of scruffy, overly-friendly, can't-stop-licking-you doggie goodness).  As he mentioned, it can get pretty awkward each time I have to bring him in for his ailment du jour -- but the staff at Randall Oaks is always happy to see him, and never once have they made me feel like a terrible mom to my furry babes. Oh, and because we all know how pricey veterinarian bills can get -- gotta Love a place that accepts coupons! At our recent visit, we redeemed coupons for $20 off PLUS a $15 rebate on Heartgard Plus and Buy 6, get 2 Frontline doses -- per dog! Their way of showing appreciation for allowing them to be your pet-meds supplier. Looking to save even more money? They'll give you $5 off your next visit for every new pet that you refer!Whether your furry friend is more like my scared-of-everything Poppy or my too-friendly Stanley -- Randall Oaks Animal Hospital can cater to both. With an uber-knowledgeable group of doctors in their practice, beyond-friendly front-of-house staff, and a clean (and cheery!) location -- I could not be happier entrusting my pups' care to them!

<review# 549,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/4/2013,5/23/2013,287,787,10,16,14>Spring Street in Elmhurst kind of has that old timey Main Street USA feel to it--there's a tavern, a bank, a mechanics garage, some family-owned restaurants, a hardware store and then BAM!--a sleek and shiny wine bar. Cuvee Cellars is tops on my list for sipping and browsing. I've wanted to visit for a while and  we spent a nice time sipping on wine, noshing on a fruit/cheese plate and browsing for bottles to take home. The gent behind the bar was very helpful and very knowledgeable about wine without any pretension or snobby attitude.  His recommendations for reds were exactly what I was looking for, so much I so I bought a bottle to enjoy at home as well.At the bar, there are several wines available by the glass and bottle and a small menu of small plates like cheese/fruit, hummus, charcuterie and chocolates. They don't offer wine flights per se, but the short pour option (about $6 each) makes making your own flight pretty doable and affordable.  There is some craft beer available as well as a full bar--which surprised me. But it's a nice option because there's always one person in your group that doesn't like wine, right?The wine shop has an array of wines from the US and abroad, and there are many quite affordable bottles. There are also some sleek wine accessories for sale. There's live music on Saturday nights and seasonal wine tastings throughout the year. The vibe while I visited was totally laid back and relaxing, but I plan to visit soon for live music Saturday nights!
<review# 550,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/26/2013,5/22/2013,151,128,13,21,16>This was FUN!My husband has been dropping hints now and then about wanting to brew his own beer. Ok, that's cool. When we entered this shop we were greeted by a very friendly, enthusiastic man behind the counter. He offered us a sample of our choice: in-house brewed cream soda, or a beer they call "banana bread". Cream-soda me up, Scotty! NOT. Hell yeah I want to try a beer called banana bread! It was easily a half-cup sample. Very delightful. A gentleman by the name of Kyle approached us to see if we had any questions. Questions? Only about a million. My husband yapped this poor guy's ear off for nearly half an hour while I wandered around the shop looking at brew-at-home books and marveling at all the different grains and seeds and flower-like things that can be used to make beer. (I'm sure those ingredients have more technical terms, but they are lost on me.) I know nothing about this hobby, but it seems to me this shop has everything you need to brew your own beer. The more I looked around, the more I became interested in this whole thing. The recipe kits they sell are so cool! (I posted a pic) So, we walked out of there with the starter kit, which includes ALL tools and doo-dads for brewing, including a huge-ass book the size of War and Peace, and the Witbier kit. Kyle was incredibly knowledgable, friendly, and PATIENT. If you're interested in this, go to Home Brew Shop and ask for Kyle. This guy knows his stuff!So who knows? Maybe in 5 years when my husband and I have launched our own super-successful brewing company and I'm sunning myself on the deck of our yacht while holding one of our own in a frosty chalice, I'll look back upon this day, this review, and say.........."It all started when..............."
<review# 551,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/11/2013,5/21/2013,325,653,7,10,7>The Oak Park Arts District is about four blocks of galleries with two cafés (Eastgate and Buzz). There are tall sculptures marking each end of it on Harrison Street and tri-colored crosswalks throughout.I like the street festivals in the summer where you are awarded with granola bars and Whole Foods bags arriving on a bicycle. In fact, it's at one of these festivals that I learned that one of the galleries has free expression art sessions. I went to one once. It was free, but my expression didn't seem free [form] enough for the facilitator. Eh.Oh! As an aside, there's a gallery called Expressions where my parents had their art for a while. They had to volunteer to work in the shop in exchange for having their artwork there. Nothing ever sold.The festival was also where I got some neat earrings made out of recycled counter laminate and bike chains. They were kinda spendy, but they're some of my favorite jewelry so I guess it's worth it.The only thing that's missing from the Oak Park Arts District is an art museum of some sort. Without a museum (or maybe an art school), I see it as just another way for people who make art to sell it.
<review# 552,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/19/2013,5/20/2013,24,110,7,8,6>"Five guys? F#ck the Five Guys! Big Guys is where it's at!"Big Guys in Berwyn is an awesome little fast-food joint that is cool and unique enough to be something special but with enough of a down-to-earth, unpretentious blue-collar sensibility to make it stand apart from the annoying "foodie" scene. The food is delicious, and the staff is friendly, and they serve amazing fresh-cut fries! Prices are a little higher than most fast food, but hey, you get what you pay for, these guys make their own damn sausages! I've never had anything less than outstanding quality at Big Guys. They do a solid job on all the Chicago standards (dogs, beef, polish) but also branch out quite a bit with their crawfish Andouille sausage, Buffalo chicken sausage, and rotating sausages-of-the week, the most amazing of which was a seasonal duck sausage with bacon, arugula, slices of fresh fig and drizzled with bleu cheese sauce! Also don't miss out on their bone-in pork chop sandwich, pot roast sandwich and whiskey glazed Big Ham sandwiches!

<review# 554,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/13/2013,5/18/2013,216,123,9,10,11>A solid 24 hour diner...with doughnuts. Yes, that's right; It's also a doughnut joint. These days, I'm much further South, but still lucky enough to have access to a Huck Finn. Recently remodeled; kinda cozy with a slight nod to the mod. They do breakfast here all day long serving up fluffy flapjacks and eggs done any which way you please. For the breakfast bunch, if you prefer browned eggs, stick with their traditional style of tossing them on the grill, but if lighter eggs are what you seek, request your omelette "pan fried". Hash browns are sliced, never grated or greasy. If you want them crisp, order "extra crispy".  Their BLT, Turkey Club and french fries are good stuff.  Free refills on their iced tea and pop. Yay!  Personally, I'm a sucker for their liver and onions. Yep, I'm one of those oddballs that keeps crap like that on the menu...your grandparents...and me. *fist bump*  Soups here are pretty good. The bottomless breadbasket and java are house staples. Fresh fruit cups, low-cal options, salads and other vegetarian friendly dishes plus a bevy of savory desserts mean something for everyone. I suggest being VERY specific when you order. Do you want beef or turkey gravy? Your dish smothered in it, on the side or nix dat altogether?  I'm an au jus kinda gal myself, but diners love to drown their goods in gravy so speak up.  "Dinners" include soup or salad , choice of potato (you can sub with rice, slaw or fruit) and dessert, but a la carte is also available. Hell, skip the a la carte and go straight for pie a la mode if you please. Their peppermint ice cream is killer! Occasionally, I swing by just for a cup to go. I don't get a cone because of my whole funky peppermint-pieces ritual. Anywhooo.....This isn't where one comes to get adventurous so I recommend sticking to the basics; Those are sure to please.Noise level and crowd vary with the hours.Note:   Most of the waitresses here are awesome and part of why I enjoy coming here...but there's ONE. I won't divulge her name...just givin' ya a heads up. Request a move to another section if you find yourself in the unfortunate position of having been approached by a brooding, bossy killjoy. Ugh, what a mope!  When you see it........

I'm not vegetarian, but I couldn't stop myself from eating this.One of my biggest gripes about stone bowl rice dishes is when the rice isn't crispy from the stone bowl. No problem here as the bibimbap was served extremely hot where you could hear the rice sizzle long after it is set on the table.My favorite item was the rice cake with dumplings. Chewy rice cake with soft dumplings is probably one of my favorite chewy items next to mochi. The broth was perfectly light and but flavorful.Without trying any of the Korean BBQ items, I'm already excited about this restaurant. I can't wait to go back and see what else I'm missing!

<review# 560,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/20/2013,5/12/2013,137,199,3,9,12>As I write this review, it's been about one year to the day when the old Jackie's Pub burned down to the ground, thereby leaving Lockport void of one of the better watering holes in town.  Jackie and her bartenders have always been some of the friendliest people I've ever encountered across the bar, and speaking for myself, it's a real pleasure having them back.  The new building is brighter and more spacious than ever before, leaving plenty of room for an influx of new patrons who may have felt a little uncomfortable in her old place if they weren't a part of the regular crowd.  They're running specials for every night of the week and if you're a fan of Bloody Mary's, Sunday's your day to visit.  But if you're there to catch the game like I usually am, you'll find you get a front row seat to the action no matter where you're sitting.  Widescreen TVs are lined up side to side almost the whole way down the bar, not to mention a few on the opposite side and in the corners, too.  And if they don't have the particular game you're interested in on at the time, just ask.  They'll be more than happy to find it for you.So if you're in the Lockport area and get a little thirsty, stop in at Jackie's Pub on the East side of State St, just south of 10th.  And if you're driving, park in the back.  It's hard to tell from the road, but there's 10x the parking spots that you'll find in front.

off, I get a mid-week weekend.  So one mid-week weekend, or Tuesday as some people might call it, we had a day of errands to run and needed a place to fuel up.  With our first errand completed, I searched for a place to eat.  Ray's happened to be within 5 minutes of St. Joseph's Hospital in Elgin.  I used to work at St. Joe's, and I would always hear that Ray's was great for the morning meal, but never made it a point to try it out.Wish I tried them earlier.  This place is on the East side of Elgin, near Rt. 25 and Rt. 20.  You might miss it, it's pretty small.  When we walked in, at 0900 am, there were 2 tables left.  Our server was almost the same server you've seen in movie diners, wearing that waitress dress, white orthopedic looking shoes, plastic-rimmed cat-eye glasses....Or maybe I was imagining it.  Because this place just looks like every diner I've ever seen in a movie.  Goodfellas.  When Henry meets with Jimmy to discuss his case and Jimmy asks Henry to whack somebody.Reservoir Dogs.  Mr. Pink discusses his philosophy on tipping, while the virtues of the song "Like a Virgin" are pored over.Pulp Fiction.  Honey Bunny and Pumpkin discuss various disadvantages of robbing liquor stores, banks and jewelry stores, and why restaurants are the ideal place to knock over.Casino.  Ace catches Ginger with that smarmy James Woods, I mean Lester Diamond.  Lester then gets his tuchus handed to him in the parking lot.I understand that all of the situations I've listed are gangster-y in nature, but none of the above activities occured at Ray's.  The only crime committed was the murdering I put on my Denver omelette.  The short order cooks here are really true to the name.  I pretty much asked for it, the waitress turned around, turned back around and dropped an omelette in front of me.  It also happened to be very good.  I'm a little particular about omelettes; I'm not crazy about filled omelettes, where the egg is cooked, the ingredients put in the middle and the egg folded over, like a blintze.  I like where egg and ingredient are molded together in the pan, then folded onto a plate, because that's how I do it at home.  And that's how they do it at Ray's.  And the ratio of egg to ingredient was perfect, every square inch of egg had some ham, green pepper, or onion in it.  All omelettes come with hash browns and toast.  The tap water tastes good and the coffee is refilled early and often.  I vote that you come out to Ray's and eat a home-cooked meal.  (see what I did there?)

It may not seem like much but I think little things like that goes a long way, especially when you didn't expect it.  Food-wise, each of the rolls that I've tried were quite good, not overly stuffed with rice, well flavored and yummy. <review# 581,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/12/2013,4/21/2013,43,86,3,6,3>Elly's: For those mornings that you want to shoot the breeze with some friends and enjoy a hearty breakfast and several cups of coffee. On service alone, this place will not disappoint. The food is also good. Both add up to a nice breakfast experience.As I do at all breakfast joints I visit, I ordered a skillet, which to me is the perfect breakfast meal. I ordered the mushroom and steak skillet, which did not disappoint. The hash browns could have been crispier, and the skillet is not as flavorful as the skillets from Wildberry, but Elly's does not skimp on the meat and mushrooms, and a nice layer of cheese tops off this tasty dish. The skillet comes with pancakes, which were pleasantly fluffy. I was really impressed with the service at Elly's. My buddies and I lingered for a bit since we had not met up for a while, and the server was very accommodating. She was neither absent nor overbearing -- the mark of an excellent server -- and best of all, she kept that coffee coming!Elly's redecorated after taking over the space from Sunny Side Up, and it's certainly more inviting and modern. If that memory of the old Sunny Side Up interior has stuck with you, don't let it stop you from stopping by Elly's. You won't feel like you're walking back into the 80's. All in all, Elly's is a nice neighborhood establishment with some tasty food. Bring some friends and stay a while!

Their parking lot is always packed so I recommend carpooling here if that is an option. You will notice many of the customers are considerably older as well, so I do not recommend being too raucous when you are here. Their waitstaff push around food items on carts, so good idea to keep those elbows in. All in all, a happy dining experience. No complaints, I left with a full stomach, which seems to be a rarity as of late...Cheers.

We also sampled the Just Like Heaven smoothie (vanilla almond milk, banana, almond butter, dates, cinnamon, agave). The owner said that everyone loves it and we were no different. I will definitely be ordering that in the future--it was sweet and creamy and the dates were outstanding in it! It was definitely "green" tasting (as in, I knew I was drinking leafy greens) but it was a little bit sweet and the jalapeno kick at the end was a nice little surprise. And, I know it's the JUICE Joint, but I love Intelligentsia coffee, so I had to try their "Juice Joint Blend"...usually shop blends are a little boring (like a snoozy, light roast Breakfast Blend of coffee) but the Juice Joint's blend is really different! It's almost smokey and it's pretty bold. I highly recommend starting with a smoothie or juice and getting a coffee, too! We are excited to go back and try some more menu items and peruse the Good Earth Greenhouse! I am a juice convert thanks to the team at Juice Joint!

<review# 588,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/22/2012,4/14/2013,82,199,2,8,6>Naper Settlement kicks butt! I took a group of my junior high school students there earlier in the week to supplement our Civil War curriculum and for them to get a peak into what life looked like during that time in the world. The kids loved it and I got compliments from my principal when we came back because she had never had so many kids go on a field trip that came back saying they had such a great time, telling her what they learned, and asking when they could go visit the same location again.We were a little time-prohibitive on our field trip because we only had 2 hours to spend at Naper Settlement (we were coming from far away and our kids have an earlier school day and we had to be back in time for the busses). So we didn't get to see everything we would've liked, but we loved everything we did see! We saw the Blacksmith Shop, the Schoolhouse, an older home, a log cabin, and a fort. It doesn't seem like much, but the presentation the staff at Naper Settlement puts on inside each of these buildings is incredible. We were in some of the buildings for 20-30 minutes where the staff gave us demonstrations on building farm tools, taught us out of authentic 19th century school books, showed us how to cook our "food," change our sheets, where we would go to the bathroom in the middle of the night. So cool!The highlight of the trip was definitely the 19th century schoolhouse. They lined us up in a boys row and a girls, brought us into the schoolhouse and taught us exactly like we were in that era. They referred to all the teachers as though we were the "8th graders" and wouldn't let us call ourselves "Mr.", "Ms." or "Mrs.". Seriously, the kids got the biggest kick out of the schoolteacher giving us a hard time... calling us out by our first name, asking us if we'd been out playing baseball instead of studying our math problems. It was too funny. If you bring a group of students here and are on some kind of time prohibitive schedule, make SURE you come to the schoolhouse. I highly recommend Naper Settlement to anyone! I'm hoping to personally attend their All Hallow's Eve event and might even try to take our students back in December when they run an Underground Railroad program.
<review# 589,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/5/2012,4/13/2013,269,638,4,6,6>My favorite breakfast joint in the area!  They have their stuff together here, and it comes through from the moment you walk in the door, to the moment you pay your bill and leave.  Even if there's a crowd, (especially on weekend mornings) they will hand you a pager, and give a pretty close estimate of wait times.  Even thought they are busy, once seated, you never feel rushed to get through your meal, and lingering over another cup of coffee is not frowned upon.  The service, from the host or hostess to the servers have been nothing but stellar ever time.  The food here is great!  I'm a breakfast fanatic, while my husband is more of a lunchy kind of guy.  This place pleases us both.  Start with a cup of their fantastic regular coffee, and move on to the breakfast.  I've had the French toast, which is great, and a few assorted omlete and egg dishes.  I would suggest getting something with toast, because when you ask for jelly, they don't bring out a few individual packets, but a nicely presented dish of two different kinds of amazingly tasty fruit spreads.  I've yet to pick a bad tasting dish here.  I'm also in love with the decor. Natural light coming in from the windows, light brown wall colors, and light and non-garish and complementary wall decor make your surroundings comfortable, and the booths are spacious, well padded and very comfortable.PS- Please never, ever confuse this place with the similarly named Honey-Jam cafe.  This place is better.
<review# 590,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/13/2012,4/12/2013,118,202,6,5,5>Oh me, oh my, OMango!I popped in to OMango for my second visit with a few friends the other night.  It was approaching 9 and we were hungry for something tasty, but not fast food.  OMango was happy to fill our bellies with a fancy feast.Note that the location may be a bit hard to notice.  If your eyes open for the sight of Red Lobster you are right next door.  I won't blame you if you sneak in their back door and snag a basket of hush puppies.  Anyway, back on topic...On my 2 visits the staff has always been very helpful.  If you are a newb fear not!  They can answer questions and help you get to just the right dish for your tastes.  That said I can't help but recommend that any person new to the genre go for a Masala dish - its a very good way to introduce your taste buds to a new friend.If you are experienced you should not be in fear either.  This isn't completely dumb-ed down for the inexperienced suburbanites and offers great flavors and a wide selection.When you are ready to order after looking at the well laid out menu the staff will guide you through a quick ordering process.  They'll answer questions for you about how the delicious Amish chicken isn't beefed up on amphetamines and how they don't use butter in their food prep.  The food preparation may take a little longer than your average McDonalds order but trust me - unless you need that last bite of Naan before a certain momentary doom this is a good thing.  That means your food is fresh and wasn't sitting under a lamp all day catching a tan.  You won't be waiting long, and when you see the food keep piling up at the take out window you'll be glad you stuck around.As soon as the food made its way into our carriage the garlic naan started overcoming and tempting our taste buds.  Our crew knew we had ordered a lot of food for 4 people, but the hungry eaters didn't expect that it would last us 2.5 meals at such an affordable price!  When we got home we were ready to wreck shop but the quantity of food got the best of our eyes and our stomachs.Curries of Masala and vindaloo, tandoori of vindaloo, tekka, and hariyali, samosas, piles of naan and an oh so tasty mango lassi started getting demolished like it was our last meal.  Everything was almost too good to let us talk - but there were plenty of "can I try yours?" and "oh thats fantastic too!"-s.  This food was fantastic, and the amount of full and leftovers we got for $35 was impressive - especially with the quality of the food!I highly recommend OMango for pros and newbies alike!

<review# 596,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/14/2013,4/6/2013,344,146,6,6,6>Serenity now.  A sigh of relief comes over me as I step into Hera Nail Salon, because I know it is time for me to be pampered and relax. :)There is no chihuahua pitched yapping back and forth.  There is no blaring music.  There is no television from the 80's (antenna and all) playing a soap opera or a show in a language I cannot understand.  Just peace and quiet. The salon is bright and clean.  When you walk in, there is a coat rack directly to your left.  Behind the coat rack, there is an array of magazines to choose from that you can read as you get your lil piggies painted up as you sit in their comfortable pedicure chairs.  Faintly they play tranquil instrumental background music, some familiar songs, some not so familiar.  As your nails are being done, you face a flat screen TV that plays movies (mostly romantic) muted with subtitles.  Perf!Prices have increased since I first started going, but only by a few dollars, which still puts them at a fair price.  Monday through Thursday mani-pedi's use to be $26, which is a steal, especially at a nicer nail salon like Hera.  As of June 1st, 2012 the price has gone up to $30 for a mani-pedi Monday through Thursday.  Still a good rate in my opinion.  Fridays and Saturdays a mani-pedi will run you $33.  If you are interested in a French manicure or a little design of some sort, it will cost you a few buckaroos more.The ladies that work at Hera are very professional, friendly, and accommodating.  In my experiences, they have always done great job.  If you're a little indecisive mess, like myself, they are happy to test out a few colors on your nails prior to help you decide.  When you are finished, they will walk you over to the drying station, so you may put your nails under the UV lights for about ten minutes, or however long your heart desires.  Most of the time, a short little shoulder massage comes along with it!Now they do take walk-ins, but I'd advise you to make an appointment.  And when you do make an appointment, make sure you bring some cash for a tip, because it is not able to be left on your credit card.I do give other nail places a try once in awhile, but I always come back to Hera.  Why do I bother trying to fix something that isn't broke?  Hera Nails deserves 5 stars for allowing me to relax!  You should give them the opportunity to treat you to some relaxation, as well.  And if you're a dude reading this, who isn't that into the mani-pedi thing for themselves, then maybe you should just go pick up a gift certificate to treat your girlfriend, wife, sister, or mom...you have to have at least one of those, right??
<review# 597,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/23/2013,4/5/2013,283,456,11,12,11>I wish I could give a place 50 stars and if I was able to, this would be the place. Chauma Gaucha could possibly be my new favorite place and let me tell you why....To start, people complain about their parking lot being difficult to get into. Let me explain this to you, it's simple: you enter the parking lot on Finley just South of Butterfield on the West side of the street. There's one entrance in and you can simply follow the driveway along the West side of the building to the front where they offer valet. We were some of the lucky ones that pulled into the lot as someone that was parked close to the front was pulling out and we got a spot. You enter through the revolving door (which my husband just loves, btw. He always is sure to lock me these damn things by holding it from the outside) and are greeted by smiling beautiful women who check your coats and warmly welcome you to their establishment. There is a large foyer and waiting area with some very comfy leather couches. There did not seem to be an issue for people without reservations, which was very surprising to me and in fact, my friends that frequent the restaurant laughed me for making us a reservation because it's really not necessary. I'm glad we had one anyways and just to be safe you should too.They seated our party of 5 right near the salad bar at a round table. The wine list is a mile long and has options ranging from 'totally reasonable' to 'you are out of your mind if you think I'm paying you THAT for a bottle of wine'. The servers are very well educated on the wine and what is light, what is fruity, what is best for you and they make excellent suggestions. My girlfriend and I decided to let her husband make the call and he selected an excellent pino noir which I surprisingly enjoyed and it was about a $35 bottle. Def not bad for a restaurant of this caliper. We had a 3 year old with us, so we took turns going up to the salad bar (if you can even call it that). Ladies first, then the hubbies. They have everything on this bar,  and I'm gonna try to give you an idea of what I remember. They offer, asparagus, two different lettuce (romaine and iceberg), sun dried tomatoes, olives, fresh mozzarella, prosciutto, Italian salami, parmesan, artichoke hearts, apple salad, potato salad, I believe there was some salmon, fresh bacon bits, green bean salad, fresh tomatoes, a variety of different cheeses, and this list goes on....everything is excellent. Top notch quality, fresh and well maintained. This is not Sweet Tomatoes, people. If a piece of lettuce falls on the floor, a server or other employee picks it up within seconds. Literally. This brings me to my next point I can't stress enough. The service here is excellent. When I looked up for the server it was like he came out of nowhere to see what I needed. When our young man in our party dropped his napkin (which happened more than once, I believe) someone had replaced it with a new napkin and removed the one from the floor within just moments, the glasses we never empty, our plates never sat in front of us to be cleared for very long, if you flipped your card to green, the meat appeared as if from the heavens above and man did it taste like it, too! I have zero complaints and I'm not sure how this is possible but it's true. They give you four main items: the delicious cheesy rolls, sautéed plantains, polenta, and mashed potatoes. Now these are mainly intended to be used as fillers and because they are out of this world fantastic, resist the urge! Hold off for the meat, you won't be disappointed.There is a wide variety of meats they bring out. Mine is the one shaped like a horseshoe. It's melt in your mouth delicious. I also enjoy the flank steak. Everything is seasoned perfectly and you can eat as much or as little as you want. Try the things you normally wouldn't, like lamb. This is the place to do that. Be adventurous and try one small piece. If you don't like something, they won't be offended. Desserts here look fantastic. Sad part is that if you want dessert, you need to save room and that's difficult to do here. Between the salad bar, the 'fillers', the meat and drinks, it's very difficult to polish off a dessert but I have seen it done. Next time you're looking for a good meal, have a big appetite, and want to get a months worth of protein in one night, you gotta make it to downers grove.

<review# 601,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/19/2012,4/1/2013,421,397,59,65,64>Having seen a number of Yelp reviews with outstanding feedback of Sam's Grill & Pizza, I decided to take the risk and make the journey out from my office to Bartlett to pick up some food here on my lunch break. In looking over their options, I saw they had a Chicago style hot dog and knew I had to give this place a try. They have a fairly diverse menu with lots of different kinds of burgers, hot dogs, alongside pizza, wings and other common to these kinds of establishment menu items like Gyros and Italian beef sandwiches. Sam's is located in a small heavily deserted strip mall off of Prospect avenue in Bartlett. When you walk in there's a long counter, a cooler with various types of beverages to your right. And a big menu board on the wall to your left. There's a few tables and a counter if you were to eat in the restaurant itself. A while after stopping in (more on this later) I was ready to leave with the food ordered for myself and my co-workers.On to the review of the food itself. The hot dog I received came on a Chicago-style poppy seed bun. The bun didn't seem to be steamed, but was soft and showed no signs of dryness. There was a thinly sliced pickle on top of the dog, this pickle slice was a bit more sour than I would like, but certainly didn't taint the flavor of the hot dog. There were two long sport peppers perfectly placed on top so that sport pepper could be had in every bite. The peppers were a good balance of being not too hot and providing the right amount of flavor. The tomato on this hot dog was a bit of a downer, it was slightly soggy and didn't cover the entire length of the hot dog. The big problem with this hot dog was the relish, it wasn't the brand, it was the amount. There was around 2 dogs worth of relish on this hot dog. As a result the relish flavor was the dominant taste here. It overpowered both the mustard and what onion was on the hot dog. As for the sausage itself, it was a skinless dog, it was properly steamed and prepared. There was some celery salt on the dog, but its flavor was again, overpowered by the excessive relish. Overall, this wasn't a bad hot dog, but it was definitely a bit unbalanced.The final subject to note on Sam's is the time it took for the order to be ready, Between myself and my co-workers there were two burgers, a hot dog, and fries for the two burgers that needed to be made. This took around a half hour from when I placed the phone call to when the food was ready a ways after I arrived. Overall I liked the food and might be back, but for the investment of time it took for my food to be ready I wouldn't say this is quite a five star establishment. I give Sam's Grill & Pizza four stars. My opinion on this establishment can best be summed up in the following rhyme.Good, but not great and be prepared to wait.

<review# 606,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/27/2013,3/27/2013,270,833,6,8,6>I'm really glad to see a nice little pottery place in the burbs. I have been to a few places like this before, and really enjoyed myself. Thrown Elements is a quaint place to come paint pottery (you don't make your own). It was $4.50 to paint - that includes unlimited paint and tools to paint with, as well as putting it in the kiln. Then you choose a piece of pottery to paint - this can range from $15 to $50. It really depends on how big your piece is, They have more whimsical things you can paint like animals, or more practical like plates and mugs. Then you pick your colors and tools and paint away! After you are done painting, they put it in the kiln for you, and it will be done in about a week.The staff is very friendly and helpful. They get the paint for you, check up on you, and help out any way they can. They had snacks to munch on as well (it was included). It's a nice activity to do with a small group of friends or even with kids. I just wish they had more of a variety of paint colors, tools, and items to paint. Space is limited here, so I'm guessing that's why they don't have the variety I have seen at other places. It would also be nice if they gave you a bowl of water at your table to wash your brushes off.  Otherwise, I have no complaints!

I didn't see any water fountains, either.If you have a dog who needs regular exercise, this would be a great place to check out. We saw several larger-breed dogs frolicking in the snow and did come upon a little bag dispenser, too.  This place has rolling hills, so if you have a hybrid or mountain bike, you could check this out. It's not a loop, however, so you might have to make a bunch of turns to get a decent number of miles in.

<review# 613,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/22/2013,3/20/2013,29,80,5,7,6>Four strong stars, with a fifth possibly on the way. Vino Cellar is in the space that was once occupied by a women's-only fitness place called Contours. All of the windows were frosted over, allowing the clients some privacy, but it was a strange business to have in a space so dominated by big windows right on the street. I never got to see the inside of Contours - I asked, trust me - but I imagine the owners of Vino Cellar did great things to make it what it is now. The pleasant but low-key, partially-wooden decor offers bar and couch seating, along with a couple of TV sets, decent audio, and plenty of wine racks for your perusal. My only complaint: no foot rest. The foot rest makes the bar. Oh well.I suppose I could sit on the couches, but then I wouldn't get to talk to Cesar, who is as friendly as he is knowledgeable of wine. It seems as though my wife and I only visit as they are about to close, but the door's open and we never feel rushed out. The wine "tour" offered is quite reasonable and reminiscent enough of wine country offerings that it has a vacation-like feel to it, without the winery dog. And yet it's home. Surreal.We've never felt pressured to buy a bottle of wine, though the selection is good; between Vino Cellar and 20 West, Lombardians have two good choices for their wine-purchasing endeavors. While 20 West has an excellent craft beer selection, Vino Cellar is the place to actually sample the grape.I had doubts when I first heard such a place would open, but I'm very impressed. If Cesar and Courtney can go local with a snack choice or two, I'll have no complaints... save the foot rest.

We all had a good time and left pretty happy. I'm glad to add this to my list of recommended Indian restaurants in the area.Oh, one more thing: the Yelp check-in offers 20% off your meal, but if you get the buffet, you only get 10% off. That was kind of disappointing, but at least I ate my money's worth!

<review# 617,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/15/2012,3/16/2013,87,333,2,5,4>*Disclaimer: This review is solely based on visits during the Beignet Saturday brunch experience.*The restaurant's unique combo of classic Southern/Nawlins style with Tex-Mex dishes yields an eclectic menu, especially for breakfast (which is offered every day, but the beignets are only on the third Saturday of the month).My husband and I have brought friends here from out of town as well as have patronized it as a party of two. We were not disappointed either time with the atmosphere, service or food.Atmosphere with attitude -From the outside, it looks a bit dated and kitschy with the huge pig. But I got over that once inside because it's cozy and bright. The building is split into dining rooms and the bar. The restaurant area has sunshine orange and yellow tones of wall paint in addition to lots of windows. Upholstery for the chairs and booths is basic, but the decor ranges in African tribal masks, colorful paintings and brass shaped into instruments and suns. On Beignet Saturdays, there is live music of the Southern jazzy quality, which definitely adds to the transformation of the environment. It's more so instrumental, which is the perfect accompaniment to conversation.Solid service -Service started well both times by following accommodations I had outlined in my Opentable reservations from setting up for a large group when our friends visited to saving a booth for two when it was just my husband and me. Service has also been consistent and friendly, probably to go along with the Southern charm, by making suggestions and small talk but also knowing when to leave us alone.Funky food (in a good way) -As far as food is concerned, Chuck's certainly ranks up there for a brunch fan such as myself. I'm always looking for twists on the staples. Almost all the bfast food will have a classic American base like eggs, potatoes and sausage but then the chef kicks it up a notch with bold spices and flavors.Even with the beverages here, we discovered a version of coffee that we need to replicate at home. The Café de Olla is a French press pot enough for two with orange, cinnamon and brown sugar. I love drinking this black to really savor all the nuances of sweet and zesty.With the entrees, a skillet or benny are my go-to brunch items. I've tried the Cajun skillet and the Crab Cakes Eggs Benedict here, and now prefer the skillet only because I am a bit picky when it comes to crab cakes. The crab cakes here tasted and looked like they were made in-house, but they were just not up to the standard of flaky fresh meat that I require. But the skillet had the balanced ratio of potato slices, peppers and Chorizo sausage so that it had a solid kick but was not painful. I also love ordering eggs either poached or over-medium (which they have cooked to my liking here) so that I get a little runny yolk to break open over the other ingredients, acting as a sort of sauce. Now, the toast to accompany the dishes definitely leaves a LOT to be desired. The bread looks and tastes like it came out of a grocery chain bag. I am also a major stickler for quality, from scratch bread, so I need it thick with a definitive crust on the outside and a soft middle on the inside. What REALLY makes this place shine is that special on beignets. We've ordered it as an appetizer when with a big group and as a dessert when just for my husband and me. I've never been to New Orleans, but my husband proclaims himself an expert of the area due to his business trips so he can attest to the quality of the beignets of Chuck's. It's obvious they are homemade because they are made fresh to order, coming out irregularly shaped and hot. In fact, on our most recent visit we almost missed our chance at eating them because we asked for them close to the end of brunch and they were almost out. I would have been saddened if I did not get a chance to eat these heavenly pillows of sugar. Let me emphasize that I am NOT a sweets kind of gal. Give me a bag of chips over chocolate bar any day. But on this day, all bets are off. I am absolutely in love with these bite-size, doughnut-like treats because of the consistency with the slightly crunchy shell covered in powdered sugar and the ultra soft, cakey interior. By dipping them in the chocolate and/or the vanilla sauces on the side, it adds another level of flavor and texture that completes the dish. For only $5.50, this special is a steal.In the end, I can at least recommend Chuck's to you for brunch, my all-time fav meal of the day. It's a place I'm willing to come back to more than once for this particular meal, and it's certainly a place I'd love to try during dinner.

<review# 620,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/2/2012,3/13/2013,123,246,4,6,5>Beep beep beep beep clack clack clack... Ah, the sounds of an arcade. Do kids even know what an arcade is these days? Most probably don't but the flashing screens housed inside cabinets controlled by joysticks and buttons really brings a pang of nostalgia to me. The dark atmosphere punctured by the occasional exclamation of a gamer is a decidedly comfortable feeling as I step through the space time continuum and find myself back at the neighborhood arcade lining quarters up on the screen to queue up for my turn. There is certainly something magical about  a tangible box with solid controls built for one purpose or game. It's extravagant in this day and age but it was the way the real video games were played during my childhood. Kids didn't sit at home by themselves shooting at each other through an internet connection while cursing at each other like some sort of internet tough guy. We hung out at the arcade and made new friends. Real friends; not some faceless person with a silly internet moniker that on a friends list. The arcade was more than just a place to play games.Fortunately, you don't have to bring quarters to play because, as many other arcades these days, Underground has their machines rigged up for free play. How payment is taken care of is a one time $10 fee up front as soon as you walk in to play as much as you'd like -- or closing time which is 11 pm on most if not all days. I remember easily spending $20 worth of quarters for a half day of fun in the arcade at Bunny Hutch in Lincolnwood and that was way back then so a one time $10 charge is relatively cheap -- especially if you consider the ride back in time walking through the doors will give you.Scott, the owner, is an extremely friendly guy and has done a great job of compiling a collection of games that are more than sufficient to send you back to the future and/or spark the imagination of a kid you bring along. I love seeing the smile of kids face the first time he or she walks through the doors and sees a classic cabinet for the first time. But, just in case you're tired of playing the old school games or ready for a new challenge, Underground has Xbox, Sega Genesis, SNES, and Atari systems with an extremely wide variety of games to satisfy your gaming needs! There are two wall mounted TV screens in one corner of the game room set up with various game consoles that Scott or an employee would be more than willing to help you set up to play all while relaxing on a couch as if you were at home. I asked if he has an NES system but he said he is still working on getting one at the moment as they are extremely hard to find in good working condition. I grew up with NES so that is my favored console and can't wait till he gets one in.So, after all that gaming you're bound to get tired, thirsty, or a little hungry. Check out the staple candy selection displayed in the front counter showcase. They even have Cracker Jack. Then wash it down with some Pac Man or Donkey Kong energy drink! There are tables to sit at while you enjoy your snack as well.Do you or your child like this place so much that you want to throw a birthday party here? Underground has you covered with a room at the front of the building that has plenty of chairs and tables that can be rented out. Perfect place to bring a bunch of pizzas for the rugrats so they eat and get back to perfecting their Pac Man or Galaga skills. I wouldn't mind having my birthday party here either!If you're a fan of arcades then you'll probably compare this place to Galloping Ghost. Although Underground is much smaller, Scott has done a good job of distilling the dizzying array of games out there to complete the essentials. Underground is much more convenient for me as it is much closer to my house -- and it's also $5 cheaper. Underground is much better for a more intimate, around the corner arcade feeling. I love Galloping Ghost as the next person but it can be downright intimidating in there sometimes.There are plenty of great places to eat and drink in the Dundee area so feel free to take a break and go out then come back with in and out privileges all day long! Underground really is a great place for great entertainment on a budget so check it out!
<review# 621,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/24/2013,3/12/2013,419,399,5,4,5>If you're Russian or want to experience a true Russian cultural experience, then this is the place for you! I'm Russian and this is one of the few restaurants acceptable by the Russian Community. It's a place to see and be seen so if you've got something fancy to put on, PUT IT ON!!! And don't be shy because you will be judged either way.The place has a swanky, modern, yet still glamorous appeal. The place is a few years old so it's got that new feel to it which I really like. There's a gorgeous foyer with  mirrors to check yourself out, and the banquet hall isn't as big as its partner restaurant Petergof which is located in Northbrook, but Versailles has a trendy feel to it. I had my 25th birthday party here (because that is considered a big number in the Russian culture) and had about 50 people. The packages are pricey and I got the $75.00 package plus tax and tip coming to about $100 per person. You may think that's a crazy amount, but you get your moneys worth. From salads, to pelmeni (Russian dumplings) to cured meats, fish, lamb chops, I mean I think I had it all. Personally love the tounge here prepared in a bread bowl, the pan fried potatoes with mushrooms, the calamari, the seaweed salad with eel and cucumber and those are just the appetizers. My american friends just could not keep up with the food, but hey at least they kept up with the booze. It's byob btw, which is nice since you can bring as much Vodka as your party can handle. I brought the Patron, clearly. The desserts that they bring out are fantastic including Napoleon (which is the best Russian cake) and a fruit platter. Also coffee with vanilla ice cream to finish off the meal, you will leave stuffed with plenty of leftovers to invite your friends for next day brunch/lunch.Now onto the main part of this whole experience-the Music! It's loud, super loud, you can request your favorite songs ($20 a piece) Yes, the whole entertainment factor can add up, but that's a great way to do a shout out for a friend or family member. The band is good, I think three people here, not as good as Petergof's music, but still very good. You may need a change of flip flops when you can't rock it out in your 5 inch Christian Louboutin's anymore. Overall, an awesome way to spend a Saturday night special occasion. Awesome food, great music, your best friends and lots of booze, what can be better?! Definitely a nice gem in the BG hood.

<review# 627,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/10/2012,3/6/2013,56,50,6,13,11>Katy's Dumpling house is a-ok by me!As someone who has lived in China and misses streetfood and dumpling huts (a LOT) these dumplings are the closest thing I can get to the ones made by my Chinese Host Grandma without driving to Chinatown in the city.  Handmade dumplings in a few flavors.  If you like "potstickers" from any other restaurant, get the pork/chive or pork/bok choy. They're your typical dumpling with the flavors you have guilty dreams about.  I've tried the other dumplings here which are just as good, however not everyone is prepared for a different tasting vibe when they're on a Chinese food binge.The noodles here also stand out. They're handmade as well, a bit on the lumpy side, but as chewy/elastic as you could want. When you order soup they package the noodles separately so you don't end up with a bunch of over cooked noodles and broth-free soup. Seriously, don't put too many noodles in at a time... they'll soak up all the soup. I'm looking forward to trying new things here.. but for now, I'm sticking to noodle soup and steamed dumplings.

<review# 629,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/2/2012,3/4/2013,316,231,6,12,8>BACKGROUND:I am from California and I went to college in San Diego.  San Diego is known for it's good Mexican food and it's unique dish known as Carne Asada Fries.  If you don't know, San Diego is about 1 hr away from the Mexican/US border.  Anyway, in the San Diego county, you ALWAYS find a Rigoberto's, Roberto's, Lolita's, MXN, etc on every street.  It was heaven for you french fries lovers, college starving students, or after a good drunken night.  What IS carne asada fries?Carne Asada Fries: french fries mixed with beef underneath a layer of cheese, salsa, guacamole, and sour cream.REVIEW:I heard about Alfredo's through a friend.  He went to my college in San Diego and we're both here for more schooling.  He apparently introduced the restaurant about carne asada fries and now they serve it!Yesterday, I took two friends with me on this hunt for Carne Asada Fries.The french fries were cooked just fine.  I felt there needed to be more of the cheese, salsa, and guac.  There was no sour cream.  There was red bell peppers, which is different.  Portion-size, it was on the smaller end than what I'm used to, but honestly it is just fine.  It is on the pricier end about $9-10 for an order.  However, I felt because IL doesn't even have carne asada fries, it's expected.Well, later on I met up with another friend and she was hungry.  Honestly I was still hungry too.  SOOO I took her here 2 hours after my FIRST order.This time, I found out that he DOES have sour cream.  Alfredo, honey, you throw that in there :)  We also enjoyed a delicious slice of their authentic homemade flan.  YUMSo there you have it.  I gave it 4 stars because I've obviously had better, but the rarity of this dish is worth the price and portion size.THANK YOU for serving carne asada fries.  It was delicious and I will be back for more.
<review# 630,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/6/2013,3/3/2013,280,274,9,10,10>Nothing can prepare you for the awe/horror/wtf??? feeling you get when you first walk through the door. U Gazdy's decor is slightly ambivalent and so unexpected because the restaurant is essentially a dark log cabin from the exterior. However, the interior emits rays of bright light during the day reflected from beautifully intricate wood work (looks like birch wood). The bar area is completely adorned in this wood which gives it a Polish Trader Vics vibe. The fact that this place was absolutely packed with Eastern Europeans at 3pm on a random Saturday made my first encounter all the more surreal.The food here is really really good. It is Polish comfort food that tastes fresh and authentic.The pierogi were soft and pillow-like dumplings. They serve bread with rendered pork fat that makes butter feel like a fat-free food. Upon recommendation, we ordered the center cut breaded pork chop which is a very generous portion not unlike weinerschnitzel. The dish came with delicious "gnocchi-like" dumplings.My wife and I were stuffed at this point, but we were pretty happy.U Gazdy is worth a visit if you're ever in the mood or on a mission for very good Polish food. The owners are also wonderful. My wife and I are looking forward to going back for dinner to try their other menu items.

The food and drinks come out as they are ready and not all at the same time- or at least that's how they did it for us.
