I would definitely have that again, and I noticed that they sell it to take home as well. I appreciated they also had ice water and cups that you could help yourself to. Blackberry Market is much larger than I expected- there is some seating where you order but there is a whole other large room next door with quirky lime green chairs and tables for seating. There were a lot of people working on their computers. I felt like I often do at other cafes/coffee houses that everyone could hear our conversation, but I guess that is typical. It is a nice-looking place with beautiful wood floors. Even the bathrooms are pretty! I loved the tiling and the doors (though I had trouble getting the door to lock- probably user error!) The oatmeal sounds delicious to me so I want to try that next time. The blackberry brownies also look really good. The chicken salad to go also looked tasty. They seem to have high quality ingredients and it sounds like they take great care in each detail and decision on what to offer. It's a great idea to have ready-made dinners to go and I bet this will catch on really well in this area. It sounds like each day it is something different and you can see what they are offering each night on their Facebook page and in the restaurant. It's great to have a new cafe in the area. I like their attention to detail and the quality of the food. I like their story. The prices seem reasonable too. I hope they succeed- I highly recommend you check them out!

Warm woods, neutral grays, natural stones all make this a cozy environment to enjoy dinner, drinks or a quick game on TV at the bar. Weekends will get pretty busy, especially with the AMC 30 Theatres next door. So try a mid-week visit to avoid the crowds and wait times.

I wish I had been brave enough to try the 'Affogato,' which I just learned is a scoop of gelato topped with a shot of hot espresso -- but was already chilly from wandering around the Arboretum. Instead, I opted for a cup of the Cran-Raspberry Chocolate Chai latte. Pure. Sippable. Bliss! The following will likely not do it justice...but I swear it was reminiscent of chocolate covered gummy bears (I know, I know -- doesn't seem a grand enough comparison. But know this -- I truly, madly, deeply LOVE gummy bears, so coming from me -- this is a compliment of the highest order!). For sustenance, I also shared a slice of the Salted Caramel Crunch Cake and a small assortment of French Macarons. ** SIDEBAR: How did I -- a self-proclaimed French Macarons Lover -- not know that they existed  a mere 15 minutes away from home? Shame on me! **The Crunch Cake was insanely decadent. Imagine layers of the most buttery pound cake  and the most rich, golden caramel -- topped with a coffee-cake-like crunch. Definitely  a shareable treat -- even this sweet tooth could not imagine devouring an entire slice solo. Ahhh...and the Macarons. Perfection! We ordered the Passion Fruit (which was so good, apparently, that my dining companion neglected to save me a bite!), Earl Grey, and Salted Caramel. The Salted Caramel spoke to both my sweet tooth AND salty craving simultaneously (the best desserts do!). But the Earl Grey -- wow! Surprisingly, and unpredictably DELICIOUS! The unmistakable taste of Earl Grey tea at first bite -- but with the unexpected hint of (I swear!) FRUITY PEBBLES  at the finish. I know. It sounds ridiculous. But try it, and smile as you recognize that familiar taste :)Cost-wise -- I will admit that they are a wee bit on the pricey side. Two bucks a macaron puts Anna Shea's at the top of the charts as far as what I've paid for the tiny treats (not including the rare gigantic variety). Also topping the charts, however, are their service and quality of goods --  well worth the initial sticker shock. Not to mention their prime parking-meter-free suburban location -- money saved that you can put towards your Anna Shea's splurge!

<review# 642,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/23/2012,2/19/2013,89,150,6,14,9>"Without libraries what have we? We have no past and no future." -Ray Bradbury Seriously, have you visited the Elmhurst library lately? If you are long overdue for a trip to the library, prepare to be AMAZED.  A few library highlights:1) The librarians are friendly and are excited to help you research topics, find books and other sources of information.  They are also very computer savvy and can help you with your Kindle or other technology.2) They have a drive through book drop off and window where you can pick up materials without entering the library (must request drive through pick-up in advance).3) Self checkout and return kiosks!! Kids love returning books and watching the kiosk "eat" them.  Think Redbox return, but for books.4) FREE movie rentals!!!5) Summer reading program with prizes for children and adults.6) It just feels good...lots of sunshine, hardwood floors, high ceilings.  It's warm and welcoming just like the librarians.7) Coffee shop, study rooms, etc...8) If they don't have the book or movie, they will request it from another library and notify you by email once it has arrived!"The more that you read, the more things you will know. The more that you learn, the more places you'll go."  Dr. Seuss
<review# 643,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/8/2012,2/18/2013,414,227,10,13,12>SHUT THE FRONT DOOR!(Man, I really hate that expression. But I digress...)STOP THE CAR!(Okay, that's a *little* better, I guess. :)However you'd like to slice it, if you can get down with the donuts (doughnuts?), you need a south side adventure in your life. And soooooon.Admittedly, I'm not nuts about donuts (see what I did there?). Don't get me wrong: they are, in fact, delicious pillows of goodness. But that being said, I--yours truly with her insatiable sweet tooth to end all sweet teeth--never wake up in the night craving them or anything. And my husband, a loyal DD coffee drinker, never has to snag "just one" donut for wifey or anything of that nature. I just...don't feel the drive to love on them like so many other people do. But that being said, I still appreciate a good 'nut time and time again. Apparently, the time to enjoy said 'nut was, well, yesterday. And omfgoodness, did I EVER enjoy said pillow of perfection.We promised the kids donuts on Friday morning. Instead of making it easy on ourselves and going someplace fast and local, we decided to embark upon A Quest of Deliciousness. A quick search (thanks, Yelp friends!) led us to this little donut joint in Richton Park. As I was reading the reviews, I saw the words "red velvet donut" and my pulse began to quicken. Oh, yes...you did, in fact, read that correctly: red + velvet + donut. Two options: one frosted with a cream cheese icing. The other? Glazed.We went in and our hopes were semi-dashed....no red velvets to be found. But! Fear not! Red velvets were slated to be created a bit later in the day. We bought six chocolate (assorted) donuts for the kids and vowed to come back the very same day to get our dirty, grubby paws on red velvety goodness. (Btw? Six donuts with tax = $6.00 and they are generously sized donuts to boot. Oh, and PS--credit cards are accepted for orders over $5.00.)Later in the day, we returned to Daddy O's again and left with four red velvets to add to our six chocolates. We opted for two with cream cheese icing and two with just the glaze. Last night., we held a donut tasting party with the kids and yeah, it was basically EPIC. And I mean, like, EPIC epic. In short, we purchased eight varieties and every single tasting brought about moans of sugary pleasure. I'm not kidding when I say there wasn't a single dud in the bunch. I mean it...start to finish, these were the best donuts in the world. Possibly in the universe. And if you even semi-appreciate red velvet anything, you will basically want to marry the front door to the building just so you can have easy access any day of the week and twice on Sundays. Five stars all the way, but if I could add a sixth out of principle for the red velvet donuts, I most certainly would.

<review# 646,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/6/2012,2/15/2013,131,471,9,10,9>Wow, this is a really cool place.I was meeting someone here (HE had suggested F+H or Shiraz, but thanks to my Yelp fam, saw Bigby's was a much better choice and I made the call.)  Before he arrived I planted myself at the bar and sort of tried to figure out what I was supposed to do.  Thankfully the bartender (who I later learned is the owner) explained the Bigby's Way to me.  I chose their house rye for starters.  A few other patrons nearby also made some suggestions (very top of the shelf all the way to the right) which came in handy as the night progressed.  It was nice to be in a place where people are friendly and don't make you feel less for being a n00b.Later in the night, the owner came by again and illustrated the beer-rating system (beer bottles + marbles) to us.  Horray for interactive fun!  Now, I'm not a beer connoisseur by any means, so I only recognized maybe 2 beers.  Everything I tried was delish.  My companion and I probably had 8 beers between us.  He ordered some Belgium beer which ended up being $10 of our total tab of $48. The atmosphere is low-key and feels like your friend's house/basement bar (complete with ugly couches with ill-fitting/sliding slip-covers).  They had some live music (a guy playing the piano/singing).  The idea is good, but it was LOUD and made it really difficult to have a conversation without being 6" away from whomever you're talking with. I'm looking forward to going back, though!  Score!
<review# 647,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/16/2012,2/14/2013,273,603,10,12,10>Think 90210's Peach Pit and Mel's Diner. You'll be smacked over the head with nostalgia from the moment you walk in the door. It's like a blast from the past that I've only dreamed of, but never experienced. Until now. We have driven past Uncle Bill's Diner a bazillion times. And a couple weeks ago, we decided that we couldn't just keep driving past. So we pulled in the crowded parking lot and made our way inside. We went back again today, so I'll give you an overview rather than a total replay of one visit or the other. It's totally a diner. A long counter with stools loaded with locals eating breakfast. More tables and booths than I could have imagined squeezed in there. During our first visit, there was one booth available and we snagged it. This time, it wasn't quite as packed so we chose a booth. (The same spot as last time. We're creatures of habit.)Anyhow, the servers work together as a team. There is no rhyme or reason. No actual pattern of who does what because everyone does everything. They are a well oiled machine. Operating in sync at all times. Pouring coffee, refilling sodas, taking orders, clearing dishes. Here you're a Honey or a Sweetie. It works. Don't question these things. Until you're a regular and they're calling your name when you walk in the door, Honey or Sweetie it is. No joke...it's like Cheers - where everybody knows your name and they're they're always glad you came...  Both times, people walked in and someone said 'Hi Joe/Bob/Jim!' And this was echoed about four times throughout the joint. Awesome!  There IS an Uncle Bill. He's a very hard working guy. You'll know exactly who he is.  The booths aren't overly comfortable, but you won't linger. Get in. Order. Eat. And get out. They are busy. It's reasonably priced and nothing fancy. So far, we tried eggs over medium, hash browns, bacon, biscuits and gravy, skirt steak sandwich with fries, ham and cheese omelet and chocolate chip pancakes. Eggs were cooked perfectly. Hash browns and bacon standard but good. Biscuits and gravy were top notch!  Skirt steak sandwich was a mistake. There was nothing wrong with it, but this is really a breakfast joint so I wouldn't order it again. The omelet disappeared rapidly from my son's plate. I loved the chocolate chip pancakes!!!  Light and fluffy with a ton of flavor packed in. Yes please. They cook right in front of you so that's cool. I will be a regular here and some day, I won't be Sweetie anymore. I'll be good 'ol Jen!  I can hardly wait!
<review# 648,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/28/2012,2/13/2013,298,465,5,12,8>This is my vet of choice for our beloved, pain in the ass dog, Rex. =]They are an emergency center so they don't take appointments for visits (except for surgeries, etc.) which has it's good and bad qualities.  It means that if you are not an emergency, you tend to have to wait in your room for a little while for a vet to get there but it also means that if you get there and they are dead, you get right in, no appointment needed.  The place is super clean, open and airy.  It feels like a medical facility, not a vet, in my opinion, which I love.  It makes you feel like you want to take your pet there because they care enough about their work environment to keep it nice and clean.  The vets that have seen Rex have all been super friendly and knowledgeable and most giving examples of things they have gone through with their own pets.  That is always a plus because it makes you feel like they really care about your pet like they do their own. =]  They also offer a monthly payment plan that is around $25 a month and covers unlimited vet and emergency visits, leaving you just to pay for the preventative meds and any other little rarities that aren't included, which aren't many.  They also have boarding and grooming for your pets.  I have utilized the boarding myself and was very happy with it.  The price is right and Rex came home seemingly happy.  I would definitely recommend this place to anyone in the area looking for a place to take your pet.

<review# 651,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/21/2012,2/10/2013,78,586,4,9,6>Including me, this place is now 5 for 5 on getting four star reviews. The place is on Elmhurst Road just north of Dundee where an Arby's used to be. Burritos, tacos, tortas and the like with a wide variety of meat options. The inside is pretty plain, but clean and well kept. This is a sit-down place with wait-service - they also have drive through service too. Took a couple minutes to get to me, but once she did, the server was polite, pleasant and prompt. Chips with salsa are provided, two additional sauces seemed to be somewhat non-descript. I ordered a pork burrito along with two tacos, one chicken, one steak. It was out pretty quickly and all of it was quite good. All of that along with a small diet coke was $11.99 - reasonable.I really hope this place does well - for the most part, it's everything you want to see in a new restaurant; good food, good service, pleasant staff.  I'll be back!

<review# 653,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/25/2012,2/8/2013,160,353,4,11,6>This was our first visit to Lincoln's Whiskey Kitchen, although we've talked about trying it since it first opened.  We were greeted at the door and seated immediately.  The first thing you see if the bar -- an old style bar of polished wood and brass.  They don't call it the whiskey kitchen for nothing.  There must be over a hundred different kinds of whiskey, Rye, Scotch, Bourbon, etc.  The dining room is large and roomy, also with dark wooden tables and heavy chairs.  The lighting is dim.  That may be to hide the prices.  While it's not $$$$$, it's probably $$-$$$. There are standard choices of ribs, chicken, fish, steaks and salads.  I started with a single malt flight - three single malt scotches.  Each one was only about 3/4 of an ounce.  Then, I was boring and had a hamburger and fries.  The rest of the table ordered salads.I have to say the servers really work for tips.  They were extremely attentive and very pleasant.  Even if the food was not good, I would return for the service.  The food was quite good.  The hamburger was seasoned well and served with very fresh lettuce, tomato and onion. The salads looked very good, and they were enjoyed by the others with me.There was no room for desert.I was pleased with the restaurant.  Not only was the food good, I enjoyed the ambiance.  My only reservation was the prices were a little higher than I expected. I may check out their prices for lunches, which may be more reasonable.  But, for a special occasion, I would happily return.

<review# 656,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/8/2012,2/5/2013,50,141,3,6,6>Okay, this place deserves a more extensive review. I've been here a few times, and every time I get the burnt ends sandwich. It's awesome: huge chunks of meat topped with their mustard sauce. I hate the word tender, but this stuff is tender. And the mustard is not very mustardy - it's thastes like thyme and is oh so very good. I've ordered the mac and cheese and the fries as my sides...my recommendation? Go with the fries. They're pretty solid and you get a ton of them. The mac and cheese is a little lackluster and a small portion.The thing that puts this place above and beyond is their customer service. The staff is like teens/early 20's and really nice, polite kids. Twice during dinner last night we were asked how our food was, in a very non-obtrusive and unawkward way. My boo's sandwich was a little dry and so one girl offered to bring out a new one. We're not really the "send food back" type of people, but we decided to take her up on her offer. Not only did she bring out a new, improved sandwich in a few minutes, but she also gave us a voucher for an additional sandwich for our next visit. Score! I think this small act made us lifelong fans. So sweet.Plus they serve beer.

The ingredients are incredibly fresh. In fact, the ingredients here are so fresh that it has ruined other sushi restaurants for me! The quality of the tuna and salmon is unbelievable, and the fish at other restaurants pales in comparison both literally and figuratively.My usual order consists of the sashimi appetizer, fire crunch maki, spicy tuna maki, dynamite maki, green dragon maki, and one "experimental" roll. The sashimi appetizer is simply outstanding and truly show cases the quality of Sushi Ya's ingredients. The app itself comes with four slices of tuna, salmon, yellow tail, and white tuna. Although simple, the flavor of the fish with a little bit of soy and wasabi is, in my opinion, the perfect bite: clean, spicy, and savory.Even though the sashimi here is outstanding, I have always judged sushi restaurants by their spicy tuna roll, and Sushi Ya does it better than anyone else. The roll comes with six pieces for around $4.00; a steal for quality sushi. The roll is packed with spicy tuna that is actually spicy, and I often "fight" with my girlfriend to get an extra piece ("Hey! That's only my second piece!" "No! That's your third; the last ones mine!). My only forced complaint is the wait. The place can be really busy (especially on weekends), and they do not take reservations for two people. On my birthday this year, I waited about 35 minutes for a table; however, the food here is great and worth waiting for.I look forward to returning soon. You MUST experience this place for yourself. Its a true suburban gem.

Sitting down at the table, I couldn't help but smile when I saw the loteria cards under the glass covering. We fell in love with the choriqueso to the point that we were looking for other things to dip in the cheese long after the tortillas were gone. Sadly, we went a little too hard on the appetizers to be able to finish our plates; they were nothing less than spectacular. We didn't mind one bit but appreciated the gesture.It really was a very warm, welcoming place and as other reviewers have noted and it absolutely did feel like home.We rang the bell and walked out to a collective cheer from the cooks in back (a little something the server mentioned - to let them know we had a good time).

<review# 667,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/20/2012,1/25/2013,31,104,5,18,8>I've been avoiding reviewing this place even though I've been steadily coming here for 4-5 years now. It's easy to review a great restaurant that has a few small errors or food that is so so. 4 star and below places are easy to do but this place is hard to find fault with so I begrudgingly give it a perfect 5.Santouka is what it is: A real Japanese Ramen shop. That's the only thing they do and they do it extremely well. That means this is your go to spot for a bowl of hot steaming noodles and soup topped with slabs of meat and veges and seasonings. But a bowl of Ramen can be very complicated. To Begin you have 4 choices of Soup which I think is the soul of the dish. (Salt) Tonkotsu: Not actually just salt, it is a thick, rich broth made from boiling soup bones and marrow for hours and hours until the calcium and marrow leeches from the bones. Absolutely amazing. I think this broth serves as a base for the other soups too. UMAMI in a bowl. (Shio) Soy: A little darker in color, also delicious but lacks the umami kick that the (salt) broth has. Still delicious. If you like soy this is your soup. Miso: A little salty but still tasted great. Spicy Miso: Medium heat, it burns but only in the back of your throat for a little bit. Also very very tasty. The noodles are not too thick or thin and are perfectly suited for the soups. After soup comes your meat choices:The Standard: 2 pieces of porkThe Chashu: 3-4 pieces of barbecued pork belly.The Toroniku: Pieces of pork cheek. (For those of you going ewww pig cheek, you don't know what your missing. Its tender and juicy and flavorful like pork belly with none of the fat.)You can get the meat on the side but prefer it on top of the ramen being warmed by the broth. Standard toppings for every bowl includes: Bamboo shoots (kind of crunchy) -Plant from the landSeaweed -  Plant from the seaPork - Animal from the landA slice of naruto (Fish cake) - Animal from the sea. A well rounded very traditional dish.Yeah they do have little side dishes like small bowls of rice topped with meat, soy eggs, and natto (ultra nasty stink beans in slime) but I usually ignore them. Overall, I cannot find fault with this place. It does what its suppose to do extremely well. Prices range from 9-15 bucks per meal. If you want a proper bowl of Ramen this is your place. If you've never had real japanese ramen, come here and realize how pathetic those dried noodles in a cup really are.
<review# 668,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/27/2012,1/24/2013,89,117,10,10,9>Oh my.The response we got from friend and fellow Yelper, Victoria H. when we checked into Zenwich was "Its about time!" and it truly was. <review# 670,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/25/2012,1/22/2013,107,399,5,10,9>It is not easy to impress me with baked goods. Anyone who follows my picture posts has probably figured out by now that I will make weekend trips to try sweets from everywhere around Chicago such as Lana's, Vanille, Ambrosia, Chiu Quon, Specialty's, and other bakeries. Ironically, although the name of this restaurant isSugar Fixé Patisserie, the reason this restaurant stands out to me is because of how tasteful it is in the use of the sugar (as in not excessively sweet).I tried 4 items. The pumpkin latte was rich with a nice foamy layer on top. It had a strong hint of pumpkin flavor and was very smooth with only a hint of bitterness.The chocolate croissant was both flaky and crisp with very nice chocolate in the middle. The fluffiness was very pleasant although I wish they'd used more butter.The blueberry almondine tart was spectacular. Crunchy bottom, just the right mix of almonds flakes to blueberry. It sounds simple, but once you've tried this item you'll know it's anything but simpleThe tropical entremet... is an item I really can't put into words. Tasty, creamy, fluffy, light... perfect? This is something you have to try if you come here.My only regret now is that I didn't grab more items on my trip here. Although it's expensive, it is well worth it.Update: I went again the following week, just as impressed as the first time.The pumpkin pound cake was quite a treat with a crispy top and moist bottom. A perfect pairing with a strong coffee and not overly sweet.The cream puff was amazing. Instead of putting cream, they put in custard like what you find in creme brulee, which was packed with flavor and had an excellent texture. This item alone like the tropical entremet is worth a whole visit.The passion fruit tart was probably even better than the blueberry almondine one. It contained a delicious almost puddling-like layer of passion fruit topped with fresh strawberries and as usual, a crunchy tart layer.Both the chocolate raspberry hazelnut and chocolate hazelnut entremets were delicious as well. Although it sounds like these should be two identical items with an extra layer of raspberry for one of them, they were actually two entirely different experiences (both good). The raspberry one contained a crisp layer of hazelnut at the bottom and just enough fruit flavor to match perfectly with the chocolate. The pure chocolate one was a chocolate lover's dream with complex rich flavors of chocolate at every layer and no other elements to distract from this experience.As I'm writing this, I feel like running out yet again to grab more delicious sweets.

<review# 673,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/14/2012,1/18/2013,78,284,7,13,11>Who knew a dive bar could have such a selection of craft beer. I'm lucky I even found this place. You probably won't see it at night.Anyway, I came here on a Tuesday night so the place was basically dead, but that's okay. Sometimes you just need a good beer, no matter what the night. Lunar brews their own beer, and possibly grow their own hops based on the tall vine outside of the building, but I could be wrong (would be totally awesome though). I had their Summer Solstice which is described as "refreshing" but it was way too bitter and citrus-y for me. I traded with my boyfriend and had the Apollo American Red Ale he ordered which wasn't too bad. They do offer growlers of their beer, but I don't think I like it enough to get some.However, they do have some other great beers on tap. Unfortunately, they were out of Dogfish Head 60 minute IPA, so instead I had Bell's Two-Hearted Ale. De-lish-ious! They have about five of their own beers on tap along with 12 "guest beers", ranging from IPAs to stouts. They also have a huge list of bottled and canned craft beers, featuring brewers such as Three Floyds (awesome), Laguintas (I hear they're opening a brewery in Illinois soon. Sweet!), and Ska, which is from Colorado and is a beer I've never seen in Illinois until now.The people that were there seem pretty chill. They're all locals, but they seem to come here for the craft brews. Their convos were about different beers they've had, what's good and what's not, etc. Throw in a few bits about the baseball game and these seem like my kind of people!I'd like to come here during the weekend to see what it's like but this is definitely a place I'd come back to. It's like a Binny's in a bar. Oh and if craft beer isn't your thing, they have the regular domestics and a full bar. Lunar, you surprised me. Wasn't expecting to find you in Villa Park but I'm glad I did.
<review# 674,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/26/2012,1/17/2013,60,239,8,13,12>My lovely wife discovered this Itasca secret.  I'm going to share it with you so that you can look for their beers in a local pub or restaurant.We dashed in the Friday night before the long holiday weekend in hopes of grabbing a growler to bring as a hostess gift.  First off, this place is REALLY hard to find.  It's at the end of a long industrial street.  You'll find the building right before the dead end but where is "Unit C"?  Take a turn down the alley, park and walk to the back of the building.  Once inside, you'll notice that this is an industrial warehouse.  Nope, no fancy tap room.  Just a few tables, a small bar with 4 tap handles and some of the nicest people you will meet.  We didn't have time to take the brief tour but we did sample all four of their beers.  We both loved them!  We started with the German lager which was easily my favorite, brewed with imported hops.  It reminded me of the great lagers from the northern parts of Germany.  Next came the continental lager which was very good.  The third selection was their West Coast IPA.  If you are a "hop monster", this IPA won't satisfy you but I found it well balanced and a nice change from all of the over-hopped IPA's out there.  The final selection was the Scottish Ale.  This is one of the best renditions of this style that I have had.  I just love the malty goodness that is typical of a Scottish Ale and Church Street nails this one!The brewery is currently only open to the public on Friday from 4:00 to 7:00.  You can find their beers at a number of restaurants & taverns in the area.  Be sure to check out their website to see the latest establishments that have picked them up.IF you go visit the brewery , remember it's in a warehouse - nothing fancy but you can sip a pint or two and talk beer with the owners.Oh, by the way, that "one" growler turned into three that we enjoyed with family and friends.

<review# 679,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/9/2012,1/12/2013,288,400,4,8,5>What is crossfit?"Crossfit describes its strength and conditioning program as "constantly varied, high intensity, functional movement," with the stated goal of improving fitness (and therefore general physical preparedness), which it defines as "work capacity across broad time and modal domains"[5] Workouts are typically short--20 minutes or less--and intense, demanding all-out physical exertion." - WikipediaSounds intense doesn't it? Well, it is but the trainers here explains every workout step by step and have you do a few test rounds until you're comfortable. They also show you correct forms and let you know what you're doing wrong so you can fix it. Only a week and a half in and I can feel/see the muscles forming on my arms.  The WOD (Workout of the Day) is the fun part, okay maybe not so fun, but you feel so accomplish after completing it. An example of WOD: 3 Rounds for time of:30 Wall balls, 20#/14#20 KB swings, 75#/55#5 Ring HSPU (sub deficit HSPU - sub regular HSPU - sub 3 total wall climbs)15 minute cap. What's KB? What's HSPU? These are terms you'll learn along the way, KB = kettle bell and HSPU = handstand push-ups. Everyday it's a different WOD to create the muscle confusion that helps you burn fat and gain muscles faster. There's always modifications if something is too hard. The classes are limited to 14 people not sure if it's due to the facility size or to make it easy for the trainer to watch everyone and to correct any forms needed. But its more intimate that way, you get to know the people in your class and motivate each other. Jason, the owner/one of the trainer, is a great guy. He's always around and more than willing to assist you with anything and sometimes yell at you, and there is the occasional compliments too. An awesome crossfit facility and I'm lucky to try it out for a month with a Living Social Deal. I can't wait to see my results at the end of the month!

Overall though this place is a real find!  I want to come back and try their other place next door.  I'd be more than happy to eat here again if the line at the other place is too long.  Regardless, I'd definitely recommend this total gem!
<review# 681,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/1/2012,1/10/2013,116,29,3,20,7>What a bargain!!!!!!Went here last night with my husband, his buddies, and a gal pal of mine.  It was a late Bday get together for my main squeeze.The other wives couldn't make it and seeing as how 2 of them are vegetarians, I thought what better to offer the husbands than an all you can eat meat option!!!  He gave the whole speech about how it works and then we were off!!!!The Salad BarYes it's smaller than your average more expensive BSH but how many times have you gone to one of these places and overate at the salad bars and end up not eating as much meat & sides as you thought!  I know I've done that a bunch of times.  There were both hot and cold options at the salad bar so lots to choose from.  Now the average BSH I would say has more than enough vegetarian options at their salad bar to satisfy them.  I would not necessarily say that for this place although I could of easily made a meal out of it.  All depends on your vego eater.  If they would be good with salads, cheeses, hot/cold  veggies, and no big main dish offer (although there was white rice with some options to top it) then it's fine.  If they are more your I NEED A MEAL vego's, then preview the pics or stop in and look first.The SidesI LOVE HOT CINNAMON BANANAS!!!!!  Now I didn't indulge as I normally would of as my 8 month pregger status has left me with limited abilities to gorge but I did try everything.  My fav... the flank.  It was tasty and tender and what a BSH is all about.  2nd fav... the garlic steak.  Great flavor.  Little fat.  Nom nom nom.....  Everything else was about the same for me.  The filet, chicken and something else came wrapped in bacon which is common.  Like most other places, the bacon just never seems to be cooked enough so you end up taking it off and eating the meat by it self which of course is moist cause IT WAS WRAPPED IN BACON!!!!!  I liked the flavor of the sausage BUT I ended up getting a GINORMOUS piece of gristle that I had to spit out so that kind of turned me off from eating more.  But I did like the taste!  It happens sometimes.  Not a big deal.  The grilled pineapple was AWESOME!  I only had one slice but wish I would of had more.  It is great to break up the meal a bit along with the bananas and allows for you to keep going and not falling into the meat coma that usually happens if you don't take a break or break up the meat with something sweeter.Speaking of sweets.......The DessertOnly my husband and I ordered dessert and along with it they brought some vanilla icecream with a lit candle in it were we all sang very loudly and annoying cause it was a fun atmosphere that allowed for it.  We ordered the creme brulee which was VERY GOOD.  Loved the specks of vanilla bean.  It had great flavor and texture and I'd definitely order it again.Overall, I'd go here again in a heartbeat and not think twice about missing out on the other MORE EXPENSIVE BSH options.  I got everything out of it I wanted and at half the price.  $24.99 is just right for what they have and we will for sure go there again.  Great place for groups too.  There were a few kids there which I thought was odd but I guess there are kids out there that love meat as much as some adults.  Perhaps there was a kid meal option?  I know I saw kid pricing.  Just not sure they have any other menu options.  Very pleased with the whole experience and can't wait to bring people there!
<review# 682,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/8/2012,1/9/2013,826,1108,10,11,10>All you can eat sushi for $20 person includes regular rolls, appetizers, and a chef's list of special rolls.  I got a coupon in the mail for $5 off another local sushi place.  But I thought, "tonight I'd really like AYCE sushi instead."  So we headed to Sakura of Tokyo.As soon as we walked in, it felt warm and friendly.  A white, glistening Christmas tree was positioned near the entrance, and a man (presumably the owner?) greeted us with his arms wide open.  "Hellooo!" he said, "I will clean a table, just one minute please," and that's really about how short our wait was.  A minute, maybe.  It was quite busy also.It is clean, and it is not too dark in here.  The lighting is a little dim, but still bright enough that you can read your menu without any eyestrain.  The walls are a peach/light amber color, with bamboo accents on the walls.  This is not at all dirty or dusty like others have commented on.We eagerly filled out our AYCE form:  gyoza, crab puffs, tempura calimari, and an assortment of rolls.  The gyoza was good.  The outside was crispy, I think it was deep fried.  Although it wasn't typical gyoza, I really like it this way.  The crab puffs were a fried food, cream cheese lover's dream!  I don't want to be honest about how many orders we had of these.  But I ate almost every single one.  Don't get the tempura calimari, it is absolutely awful.  It was very chewy.  We ate all of it though, because if you don't you will be charged for food you did not eat.The shrimp tempura crunchy roll was good.  Not too much rice, and a nice crunch on the outside.  We also ordered the rainbow roll, better than many I've had, although some pieces fell apart.  The jalapeno spicy tuna roll is the best spicy tuna roll I've had.  It's like I finally met the "spicy" in "spicy tuna."  The spicy California is just okay, the spicy just comes from a sauce they put on top of the roll.I'm 50/50 on how I feel about the Dynamite roll.  A red chili pepper on the menu denoted it's spiciness, but it did not list "chunks of jalapeno" in the description.  It is a deep fried roll, and even though I usually don't like deep fried rolls, this one was very good.  Except for the jalapeno.  The first piece I had, there was a chunk of jalapeno and it burned the side of my tongue and I started coughing like a dragon smoked some Marlboros.  I picked at the next few pieces, removed the jalapeno hunks, and found a delicious deep fried roll beneath that horror.Our server was very nice, but another girl who delivered the plates to the tables dropped our sushi and left before she identified the rolls for us.  She could use some polishing, but the girl who waited on us for the majority of the time was on the ball.  They thanked us on the way out, and we'll definitely be back for all you can eat sushi.  I would not go back for a la carte though.  There are still better sushi places closer to my backyard for that.
<review# 683,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/18/2012,1/8/2013,216,123,13,19,16>A serious slice of the barrio. The first time I came here it was a late, weekend evening...loud as hell and packed.  It was a sea of cowboy hats and a parade of trucks zipping in and out of the lot. I was up for some noisy fun so it was a perfect fit.  Fast forward to the scene in Animal House where they shout,  "Wait til Otis sees us!"  Bellied up to the bar by some hardcore  dudes who were grim and kvlt.  Staff was attentive. Margaritas were tasty. I highly recommend upgrading the tequila to Patron.I've hit this place up time and time again ...and the appeal for me is that everything and everyone here feels....sincere. This isn't some chain where they'll forget your name a few days from now.  It's essentially being transported to this community within a community. The meals I've enjoyed here remind me of what my Latino friends have served me in their own homes; Food made with care that just made me feel all fuzzy inside and stuff. Meat is lean, yet tender and flavorful. The onions in their grilled dishes are ever-so-slightly caramelized ....leaving them a tad sweet.  Rice is moist and compliments the proteins nicely. Burritos are KILLA...each one hand-rolled by Godzilla. True story, Bro.  As Sarah H. has pointed out, they will go to great lengths to personalize anything on the menu to your liking. Nothing I've had yet has been fiery in the way of sauces.  Their fresh-squeezed lemonade and killer Jamaica are favorites. A heads up: The guac here is made fresh, but it does run on the supa tart side, so when you order, you can request little "no limon".  Do yourself a favor and order "Mama's Specialty" with added grilled jalapenos; it's Heaven on a platter.*swoon*The ladies here are absolute dolls. So friendly and while attentive, they don't hover. I've noticed some of the staff here is not especially familiar with the English language and that is most likely because a majority of their customers speak Spanish. I gather this because I went specifically for Karaoke (which rocked) and it was entirely in Spanish that evening. Felt like a wedding guest with people dancing to lively tunes, women exchanging big hugs (others, hard glances..mmhmm) and tables engrossed in enthusiastic conversation with shouts to friends seated clear cross the room.  If you're looking to linger while conversing over some quality food and that frozen concoction that keeps callin' Jimmy Buffett home, then swing by in the early evening. That seems like their down time when the place is nearly empty; When I want a slow-paced, quiet meal, that's the perfect time. The prices are great and I like that you can mix things up a la carte. It's really about finding what hours there work with your mood. I will never get how La Fiesta packs them in when there are treasures like this. Be sure to grab a menu on your way out. I plan on working my way through it..in its entirety... in 2013: Let's do this! Note: IF YOU ARE IN A RUSH this will NOT suit your needs. You can phone in ahead for pick-up though and free local delivery is available. They have a stone patio that is open during the warmer months.I heart you, La Finka!

<review# 685,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/23/2012,1/6/2013,71,165,1,13,6>Visited Peter Rubi on opening day after hearing about the store at a local Organic foods meeting.  Needless to say I was excited to know that they were going to specialize in only produce, seeing as my family and I are trying to consume more fresh produce and less meat.  The store is set up really cute, and the prices were AMAZING, like Cherries for 1.49/lb and Heirloom Tomatoes for 2.49/lb.  Everything was really fresh, they carry some local, some organic, and some conventional produce. <review# 686,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/28/2012,1/5/2013,63,60,12,9,8>Valli Produce is super romantic. Not as romantic as, say, the Elgin Fresh Market, but definitely a decent "we're just shopping for stuff" place to take a date. This place is a full-on winner all the way.Look, if you're dating someone, there's only so much coffee or beer you can drink and only so many dinner and movies you can go to before you have to go on a "go shopping with me" date. These dates, especially the first few, are perhaps the most important of all. You're not putting on a show of money, power, and style- you're allowing the person you're seeing to sort of "see you actually do normal things. In the wild." That is why finding the correct grocery store to buy stuff for dinner is so important in your formative dating period. Can you imagine going shopping for high quality produce and meat someplace that your "other" might find pretentious? Like Whole Foods? Or lame? Like Jewel? DISASTER. Once upon a time, I did not think grocery stores were particularly romantic. Who could blame me? I shopped at Jewel and occasionally my hilariously outdated local grocer, Pik-Kwik. I also didn't cook then, which may be why I didn't think too much about it. Now, thanks to Food Network and a couple of close friends, I know how to select a good pineapple, perfect tomato, ripe avocados, and find meats with good marbling. Why wouldn't you want a place to teach your hot date cool stuff like that? It's incredibly romantic and scores you big points. Take it from me. I'm about to get married in 6 weeks.But what if you're single? Again, this is important. Valli is about demographics. Do you honestly believe that people who can't cook shop at places that have one of the best produce spreads, butchers, seafood counters, and delis in the area?? Seriously???! This is a place to shop regularly and meet the woman (or man) of your dreams by locking eyes suddenly in the store. Anywhere. Tell me that's not hot. Singles, you'll thank me later.And while there are foods you can bond over, there are other things that only awesome markets have that you can cringe about. Tripe. Sweetbreads. Chicken legs. It's all here.Further, this is a good place to go if you're sort of thrifty. The deli is fantastic and has the best prices on meats and cheeses anywhere locally. They also have a fantastic selection of deli stuffs. Other foods are (generally speaking) reasonably priced. And when you've got everything you need, head to the checkout. The cashiers do not have baggers, but somehow even the longest lines don't stand a chance. These are seriously the fastest cashiers I have ever seen. Anywhere. They do not play games.You shouldn't either. A few wise decisions about where and when you shop could mean a lasting relationship. I'm not claiming Valli sealed the deal early on, but it's possible. You heard it here first. And just in case it works out for you, you're welcome.
<review# 687,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/25/2012,1/4/2013,26,105,3,9,7>"Mom, you need to give this place 5 stars" said my stubborn, picky-ass 7 year old son as he slurped up half the noodles from my ginormous bowl of Pho.5 stars it is! They were stuffed fat with fresh, minty deliciousness and the accompanying peanut sauce was the perfect compliment. Hubs sweated his way through the spicy Curry Chicken Bahn Mi and swears he'll do it again next visit. I  ordered the Steak & Meatball Pho; the portion that remained for my enjoyment after my sons had attacked it was divine. The broth had the right balance of sweet, salt & spice. The beef was delicious and chewy, and all of the veggie/herb accoutrements were bursting with freshness. Hubs and I closed out with classic iced coffees...SO good.  Smooth, rich coffee and the condensed milk adds just the right amount of creamy sweetness. The boys enjoyed smoothies, both of which were great with fresh (I know, third time i've used the word but it's TRUE!) and intense fruit flavors. Service was the right mix of warm and unintrusive. We will be back pho sho!
<review# 688,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/3/2012,1/3/2013,63,74,3,11,10>When we first walked into Sankyu, we were a little alarmed. I guess we've gotten so used to Japanese restaurants that serve a mostly non-Japanese clientele, that walking into Sankyu was frankly a bit of a culture shock.  But it turns out, a really really good culture shock, which we enjoyed tremendously. When you first walk in, you'll notice right away the casual nature of the place, and that everything is primarily written in Japanese (with English as the second language). We thought that was very cool. Along with regular tables, there are also booths where you can kick off your shoes and sit on little pillows, in the traditional style.  Also very cool, and will try that next time.While the service was prompt and fast, it was also casual. There wasn't any of the false obsequious stuff you sometimes get from servers. These gals were friendly but busy, moving about the tables in a cooperative fashion. We had three different people serving us throughout the meal.  It was neat and efficient.Our Japan-immersion experience was also heightened by being seated next to a large and loud table of Japanese men (only speaking Japanese), who had apparently gathered for some sort of happy reunion. We thought it was a lot of fun to be in the middle of all that laughing and shouting.  Anyone who says that Japanese people are restrained, hasn't seen them comfortable and in their own element.The food was good, filling and surprisingly inexpensive, compared to most restaurants, and especially other Japanese sushi places.  I was frankly shocked when we received the bill, and it was sub-$40 for 3 people.  The ramen was outstanding and flavorful, as was the crisp tempura and chicken katsu.  No refills on soda, but a full range of cool Japanese beers and drinks. They also gave us a complementary fried fish cakes appetizer, mung bean salads and a miso soup to match another we'd ordered.  Very welcoming!This really isn't a sushi place. Their maki rolls were fine, but not great. It felt more like the Japanese version of a neighborhood tavern. Casual, but with tasty basic vittles catering to Japanese tastes.And that's the beauty of this place. It's an authentic Japanese tavern, that isn't trying hard to be hip or something it's not.  And last time I checked that, in itself, is pretty hip.

She noticed we were talking a lot while eating the appetizers so she let us know she would hold entree off a bit so we could enjoy the appetizers more. She was awesome.The whole lunch was very pleasant for us. And we used the resaurant.com certificate which brought down the cost to $15 per person including tips. You bet I will come back very soon.
<review# 691,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/6/2012,12/31/2012,89,133,11,16,8>Ah, my 100th review. What better place to choose for this milestone than this place. Here's a quick tip for you: I'm lazy and I hate to cook. Thank Jebbus for El Paso because me trying to cook rice is a disaster waiting to happen. They have some of the best hot foods ever! Who wouldn't want some super delish Mexican food hot and ready to go at excellent prices. The hot food section is towards the back of the store by the veggies. You simply grab whatever size container you want and fill it with whatever food you want. Once all your containers are full you give it to the nice lady so she can Saran wrap those suckers and slap a price sticker on it. After that you go to the register and pay but you must first get some of their homemade tortillas, because  its not a complete meal without the freshly made tortillas. Trust me you won't regret it. They change up the menu so it varies on a daily basis but they always have rice and tamales. Everything I have tried has been great, I have no complaints about the food. The only complaint I do have is that the parking lot is the stuff of nightmares. It's small and supposed to be one way but people choose to drive like maniacs and there's always that one person trying to turn left that holds up traffic. It's a mess. However I don't blame the business for working with the space they were provided or for the fact that people just can't drive at all. I should also mention that this is a grocery store so they have all the essential grocery store stuff. It's also a butcher shop so they have a ton of fresh meat. I mainly come here for the food but they have other things to meet your needs. So hurry up and get here to try some of their amazing food. Don't blame me when you become addicted to it.

<review# 696,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/15/2012,12/26/2012,21,77,4,12,8>This is the perfect place to enjoy fresh and delicious local beer.  It  is a brewery and taproom.  It's not a bar or gastropub.  They only accept credit card (no cash), and there is a limit of 3 beers per person.  It's great for what it is.  They're not trying to be something they're not, and I love it!  You can find me there on most Thursday evenings enjoying a beer after work.It's off the beaten path a bit, so you'll never stumble upon it.  You can't see it from the road.  If you realize that, it isn't too difficult to find.  Inside you'll find a very nice bar and several great beers to try.  If it's your first time, I highly recommend trying a flight of 4 beers.  What's great is that they keep rotating different beers through their taps.  As of this post, my favorites are their IPA (Kidnapped by Vikings), their milk stout (Nourri au Fourrage) and their brown ale (E-Ville), but those might very well run out in a month and be replaced by something equally terrific!  If you keep an eye on their facebook page, they often give some notice (albeit short) if something new is being tapped or what establishments are featuring their beers.  In the next few months, they should have some of the barrel-aged beers ready to go.Like I said, they don't serve food, but I'll bet that if you bring some to share with Dave behind the bar, he wouldn't mind you bringing something in.

<review# 698,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/22/2012,12/24/2012,66,120,4,8,3>My new favorite restaurant ever!Where can you go to get a decadent meal that you know is healthy? Where the entire delicious menu isn't full of fat-and-calorie-laden land mines? NO WHERE but Seasons 52!I love that I can pick anything from this amazing menu and know that I'm not destroying my diet. Sometimes I re-read the descriptions a few times in disbelief - how can THIS be under 500 calories? There are so many things I want, I can't choose! Normally I'm so saddened by the "healthy choices" section of a menu at a restaurant that I pick whatever looks the least terrible. Here, everything is amazing!The flatbreads are delicious and very large. The salads are the same. My favorite is the filet mignon, but that's on the high end of the menu's price range - there are entrees from the $8-$9 range all the way to about $30, but honestly, it's easy to choose an entree for $15 or less - there are so many reasonable options. And the little desserts at the end are delicious and a great size and price for the end of the meal.The wine and drink list...wow. You just have to see it for yourself. They even have healthy options there! And they infuse their own vodkas, gorgeous to see!One warning - MAKE A RESERVATION! If you don't you'll wait FOREVER. It's no surprise, the food is amazing, the ambiance is great, the service is spectacular. And if you're a little past your reservation time...well, dining isn't an exact science. Tables sometimes stay late, it's hard to kick people out ;)
<review# 699,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/17/2012,12/23/2012,20,44,14,11,6>I had absolutely no business going to L'Anne.  I was tricked.  Befuddled.  Enchanted.  Deceived by some warlock.  Ok, so I called my mother and asked for a good place to go for a romantic evening.   She recommended L'Anne to me, and thus started one of the most stressful dining experiences of my life.When you're finishing up college you start to feel yourself change.  You start seeing yourself as an adult.  You do fancy things for the sake of being fancy.  You worry about bills.  You worry about the future.  You think about your career.  You know what it means to grow up.  We arrived early for our reservation, which turned out to not matter because the place was empty, an oddity from what I've heard.  We got seated, and order wine and open the menu.  BAM.  I'm not an adult any more,  I'm a two kids in an overcoat trying to pass for a grown up.  Oh God, oh God.  Calm down.  When did I get paid last?  Do I have enough money to buy anything?  We've already drank some wine, we can't just leave.  Calm down. Calm down. It'll be fine. L'Anne gave us some recommendations, but to save my wallet, my poor poor wallet,  we split an appetizer, Lobster and Pork dumplings.  Portion size was as small as expected, but the food was AMAZING.    We then split Crispy Duck Goat Cheese salad.  To die for.   Then we headed straight to the meat course.  Do not pass go, do not collect 200 dollars.  God I wish I could have collected 200 dollars....In the interest of saving money I got the Pork Chop, which was as good as a pork chop can be.  Since I was being cheap I talked my girlfriend into splurging on the Duck, which was amazing in every way. Other reviewers are right, L'Anne does hover around the table talking about this and that.  We didn't really take charge of the conversation so we mostly talked about the restaurant, which after a while felt a little awkward.  But she remembered me from when I was there a year ago with my family for brunch, which I give her a lot a credit for. We spent WAY more money than I feel the meal was worth, and spent double what I wanted to spend when we left the house that evening.  That's not L'Anne's fault, remember, tricked by a warlock.  But I will say, on the subject of value, there is a fixed price 5 or 6 course meal for (  I believe )  85$ and 95$ dollars a person respectively.  That was outside our ballpark that evening, but honestly the six course meal was only 30$ a person more than what we paid to split two courses and have meat.  If you are going to splurge on amazing food, it definitely has it's value.   I'll be back when I'm a real grown up.

<review# 701,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/7/2012,12/21/2012,421,397,61,80,70>Duke's Drive in is a small 50s style fast food eatery on a gigantic lot of land just off of Harlem Avenue in Bridgeview. There are a bunch of spots to pull up to, where they presumably had some sort of ordering kiosk in the past. There is a large cement area with outdoor picnic tables to eat at near the parking spots. In stopping by Duke's I decided to try the Chicago style hot dog and fries. Service was super fast and I had my food faster than I had my change back from the cashier. The big question is, how was the food?Well I quickly pulled up a stool to eat at the counter on the opposite side of the counter and dug in. The fries were thin long shoestring fries somewhat similar to those served by McDonalds. These had a tastier potato paste inside and weren't as salty or greasy. For those who have read a lot of my hot dog reviews, these fries are nearly identical to those served at a Place in Villa Park called Mickey's Drive-In, and  to those served by a place called Jimmy's Dog House in Downers Grove. These are good fries and are a very nice compliment to a high quality Chicago style hot dog. And the good news is this was a high quality Chicago style hot dog as well. The dog was served on a soft poppy seed bun. The sausage itself was skinless but heated to perfection. The peppers were hot but not so hot as to overpower the flavor of the dog. The pickle was nice and had a perfect level of sour flavor to compliment the relish and mustard which were both well applied. The onions were applied sparringly, there were nice tomato slices on this dog that weren't too thick, too thin, or too sloppy. The only thing that might be considered wrong with this hot dog was that I didn't detect any celery salt. If you happen to be headed down Harlem in Bridgeview, Duke's is a great place to stop for a Chicago style hot dog. It's easily among the best Chicago style hot dog places I've found. Overall, this was a fantastic Chicago style hot dog and is five stars all the way.

Since it seems that things are mostly imported a lot of the items are a bit overpriced. For me these things are just looked at and not actually purchased. Normally when I go to Mitsuwa I go over to the little shop first and look at the pottery, then grab something to eat from the food court or the bakery, followed but a walk through the store picking up a few unique treats to eat. I have never actually bought full groceries there just a few items here and there - but they do have something that you cannot find anywhere else unless you order online. There is a little bit of everything making it fun to just look around.Mitsuwa's ceramic/gift shop is nice though most things are overpriced there are some things on clearance that are actually a great deal for decent quality item. The food court has a little bit of everything though there are only a few veggie options to pick from - there is a Tofu Burger and one place and BiBimBop at the Korean place. As for desserts there are amazing smoothies and yogurt drinks that are tasty and leave you feeling good as well as some ice cream items. The bakery is good - it is not the best Asian bakery around but they have a good selection with my personal favorite is the pear and custard pastry, though it is hard to go wrong with pastries! Another section of Mitsuwa that is a favorite of mine is the importanted drink selection - DBZ soda and fire coffee are just the tip of the iceberg and you can have fun just trying the drinks. The selection of cute animal themed items is amazing with a great deal of animal candies that are hard to resist.  You can spend an hour just look around at the wide range of items not seen in most stores.Overall, I wanted to give Mitsuwa a 4 star rating because it is overpriced but I just like going there so much that it gets boosted up to 5! At Mitsuwa you will have a fun time and see some interesting things, some might be overpriced but the experience makes it fun to shop and see all the market has to offer

<review# 709,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/5/2012,12/13/2012,2184,1339,6,20,13>My friend and I were trying to find something new and fun to do on Saturday afternoon and I remembered hearing about a winery in the Schaumburg area. 'Bollocks!', my buddy said, 'No such thing exists!' We Yelped it and found that said such place did exist in the form of Lynfred Winery. Being the lushes that we are, we went straight over at 2 in the afternoon. We ended up spending just $13 and staying for 2 and a half hours. It was an amazing way to spend an afternoon and they've completely sold me.Upon arriving, we were met with a beautiful building but we didn't see much activity so thought we must have the wrong place. Turns out we parked in the wrong place and tried to enter the residence (instead of the winery) in the front. The winery is in the back and there is a parking lot back there, as well. When we walked in, things were bustling and a strong yeast smell filled the air. We got in line and ordered the wine tasting for $12 - premium. They also offer a non premium wine tasting for $9. The premium includes either an ice wine or a $100 bottle of red. I love ice wine so knew I had to go with the premium. If you are a member of one of their wine clubs, you save a few bucks off the wine tasting. With our $12, we tried 8 samples of wine. A fantastic deal in my opinion! You pay in the front, they give you a list of the wines being served with descriptions and then you take that plus your glass to the back for your servings. I've been to other tastings that give their patrons plastic glasses so I highly appreciated being served in an actual glass branded with Lynfred Winery's logo.Behind the gift shop is a beautiful balcony area overlooking the stainless steal crushing, fermenting and aging area. It is so pretty, relaxing and just fantastic. The balcony seating area has gorgeous stained glass windows and has a rustic, homey feel to it. The tastings were quite generous and the lady pouring was very friendly and knowledgeable, both of which I appreciated. Each month the tastings change which will definitely have me going back. November 2012 features 3 whites, 3 reds, a fruit wine and a premium:Chardonnay 2009Riesling 2009Marsanne Roussanne 2011Merlot 2008Pinot Noir 2009 ReserveCabernet Syrah 2009Cranberry or Rhubarb fruit wineCabernet 1997 or Ice Wine 2009 - only included with the Premium tasting.My personal favorites were the Riesling, Rhubarb and Ice Wine...Can you tell I'm a sweets girl? My friend is not a fan of reds and they had no issue with her substituting the Reisling for all 3 of those tastings.While we were tasting we caught wind of a winery tour at 4pm. Apparently they are offered at 2 and 4 on the weekends. My friend and I jumped at the chance and I'm so glad we did. I've been to 8 wineries & vineyards, gotten tours at them all, and I must say this was the most entertaining and informative. Our tour guide was Barb who was so cute, friendly and well informed. She offered little side stories during the tour and I truly learned a lot not only about Lyn + Fred's wine but just wine in general and the process. The upkeep at the winery is much better than any other I've ever been to, as well. It's just a beautiful facility and so much love goes into it. All of the employees truly seemed happy to be there and passionate about their wine.This is the best kept secret in the suburbs! Not only will I be back monthly, taking all my friends, but I will be joining their wine club. I had an excellent time and it's well worth the visit. Their prices are reasonable and it's a truly fun time. Aside from the wine tasting and tours, they have wine & cheese pairings, food pairings and cooking classes!Pro-Tip: Yelp has a check-in offer for a free baguette! They have amazing, fresh baked daily breads.

Usually Chinese buffets are scary places crawling in alien microbes, but Chi Tung does a really nice job with it all. Thanks!!I ordered the chicken tortellini soup and really enjoyed it but man, that French onion will go down in the books as a favorite soup for me! I ordered diet coke. I should have mentioned something to Jessica and I take the blame for not saying anything, but she was so kind, I didn't want to bother her but the soda had a weird aftertaste. I don't think it was diet coke at all. This is we're they lost that 5th star. Because I don't think it was their machine. I just don't think it was actually diet coke; I think it was like diet RC or some other generic soda. Not a fan. Dinner: I wish I had ordered my sisters meal! Like the soup, her dinner was better than mine, too! She had a chicken breast sandwich and onion rings and I went for the double stack quesadilla, as suggested by our server. The pico was made using VERY under-ripened tomatoes (white and green in color) and large pieces of onion that after the fact, I decided they were easier to remove if you wanted but if not, they were quite large pieces to be chewing into. The chicken used to make the quesadilla was big BEAUTIFUL pieces of chicken breast meat so that was delicious. The rice was incredibly bland. The salsa in the little plastic cup was purchased, not made in house and the guacamole was kinda like "Wholly Guacamole" and was just ok.We ended up ordering 5 desserts to go. One sweet treat for each of us, and one for each of our boys at home. I ordered a peanut butter bar and a slice of the caramel apple pie. I ordered these with the intention of my fiancé and I splitting each, this worked out very well. Next time, I'm getting two of those peanut butter bars, though...they were excellent.I'm looking forward to another visit soon. I think this place will have to end up on our regular rotation of dining spots when we're up the Northern Suburbs. So proud of us for trying a new place and even more excited to bring back the hubby-to-be very soon!

<review# 715,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/13/2012,12/7/2012,29,80,11,8,11>In the three years my wife and I have lived in Lombard, we've patronized no fewer than eight different grocery stores. Gone are the days of being exclusive; in today's swinging foodie culture, we see 'em all. And when you're of a certain age and are looking to sow your oats - wild or instant - you go for different types, depending on your mood and status in life. For a guy, there are four types: the familiar blonde, the smart brown-haired girl, the mysterious brunette, and the redhead next door. (These are stereotypes, not absolutes. I mean no offense to anyone.)Jewel and Dominick's represent the blonde girl. Just as a single guy is expected to be more attracted to the blonde, those that don't study the field go with the stores that everyone's frequented for decades. There's not anything special there. You pay more than you should for what you get. But they're prevalent and always available. Feeling smart, and looking for value and a potentially long-lasting experience? Then the brown-haired girls known as Ultra and Woodman's are for you. They're not as easy to find and aren't as user-friendly, but you get good value, even though you're not as likely to brag about it with your friends.Bragging rights go to those intimate with the exotic brunettes of Trader Joe's and Whole Foods. If you're open to new experiences and challenges that may or may not be rewarding, here's where you go. Yes, I have a past with all of these types, as do many men my age, and I'm glad that all of them are out there. But more and more often, I'm finding myself with the red-headed girl next door, and her name is Mr. Z. (To prove my deep understanding, I appear to be the only poster here that knows her true name! It's not "Mr. Z's." There's no possessive in her name. She cannot be "owned," you see.)Ah yes, my bonnie Mr. Z. She's close by, so close that you may easily take her for granted. She doesn't have everything you'd dream of, but there's more there than you'd ever realize from the outside. She has strengths (meat) and weaknesses (produce), so she won't fulfill your every desire, but you'll get what you need. She may lack qualities that all others seem to have (no Coke products) but she'll atone nicely (Canfield's Diet Chocolate Fudge). She'll even be part of your community, playing nice with the town's elders but still cool with everyone else that wants to know her. Not everyone will admire you for your choice. She's not glamorous. She won't make you look like a scholar or a rebel. They'll wonder why you don't look elsewhere. But Mr. Z has a charm to it, and by being close to her, I've gotten to know her and I can accept her for what she is and is not.No, I wouldn't travel 20 miles to shop here, but that's part of the charm. It's a LOCAL store. Heck, the bulletin board just inside is the town kiosk! Yeah, I guess I could go to Walmart and get what I need cheaply, but that would be the equivalent of buying a doll that needs inflation, if you catch my drift. It's cost-efficient and can be fulfilling, provided that you intentionally ignore how you're bankrupting yourself in other ways. If you don't live close to Mr. Z, you probably won't visit it more than once, if at all. Heck, at first glance, I didn't think much. But if you're looking for creature comforts, and location and convenience is part of that comfort, then you'll find yourself coming back. Just make sure you get her name right.
<review# 716,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/29/2012,12/6/2012,222,278,8,10,10>One little red door, when you walk inside that's all the space you have...a doorways worth. This is a little alley way with the left side lined with all different candies. Some oldies but goodies and some of the new stuff. When you walk in you grab a little white paper bag and make your way through the store collecting your favorites. At the end they dump them out and count them up. My final cost (even with popcorn) never ceases to amaze me...this place won't break the bank.You can grab a soda or a water here too (but keep in mind there is a DQ right across the way if you need something even less health conscious).If you've read my reviews....you already know I love popcorn. They have amazing popcorn, not crazy movie theatre butter popcorn, lightly salted fresh popcorn. You probably need to try it.This place makes me feel like a little kid again....except now I have to pay for myself. But it's so worth it, and still a pretty darn good deal. Best enjoyed in good company across the street at the fountain or at the park nearby.
<review# 717,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/28/2012,12/5/2012,102,185,4,7,7>This store front sells what the basic food vendor cart does. Tamales, champurrado, arroz con leche, paletas, chips, chicharrones, yogurt, elotes, they even have coffee for your tamales. The tamales and champurrado are great! The champurrado is normally described as Mexican hot chocolate. It's thick and cinnamony and chocolatey. Difficult to describe but a can't miss. They have your regular corn husk wrapped tamales and also tamales Oaxaqueños which are banana leaf wrapped and I think the masa is a lot softer in the Oaxaqueños. It's definitely a relief to have this place around because the tamale carts in Little Village have been MIA for a while. But beware, once the stock runs out for the day, they close. So get in early. Oh and it's cash only.

<review# 720,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/19/2012,12/2/2012,133,66,9,9,8>"Come on baby...let's do the twist!"The twist potato, that is! A single potato spiral-cut into a sort of french-fry totem pole (on a stick!) -- it is hands down the most unexpected bakery item I've yet to come across - but oh, so delicious! While waiting on our twisty snacks, we got cozy in the small (but immaculate! - seriously, so clean we felt obligated to de-crumb our table before leaving) dining area with a red velvet cuppie and a mango-pineapple smoothie in the meantime. Sans bubbles, as I just read an article claiming those chewy tapioca pearls to contain carcinogens -- and I thought it best not to trigger my hypochondria. Loved the smoothie - very creamy and so fresh tasting! And though the cupcake was a bit dry in consistency, I enjoyed the flavor and the not-too-rich cream cheese frosting (extra points for pretty pink sugar-sprinkles). And bonus, if your cupcake has a twin on the day-old tray - you can snag the pair for the price of one! One cupcake and half a smoothie later, our twist potatoes arrived - and they proved to be well worth the wait! After the super-friendly owner informed us that there were two options (chili and cheese), we ordered one of each with the intent to share. The plan was to eat halfway down the stick and switch, but I Loved the chili flavor so much I almost kept going (my hubby kindly looked the other way when I ate an extra rung off the chili twist before passing it to him). To be fair - the cheese was tasty too, a bit sweet and more of a baked-on flavor (as opposed to the chili which was sprinkled-on) - but I could not get enough of the chili-flavored twist. If it hadn't taken so long for the first set of twists, I would have ordered seconds! Bottom Line: Definitely do the twist, but if you think you might even consider a second helping -- place your double-order upfront to save time.

The Chorizo cheddar biscuit was good.  Flaky biscuit with bits of cheddar and chorizo throughout.  I wish there was more chorizo, but that's just me.  Friendly service, clean digs.  I LOVE this place!
<review# 724,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/12/2012,11/28/2012,10,43,5,7,5>So excited to have discovered this restaurant. It sits a bit off the beaten path, so I didn't even know it existed until recently. The website seems to be down right now but rest assured they are open and serving up scrumptious food! We could have made a meal by ordering four or five of the small plates (polenta, arancini, fried chickpeas, yes please!), but the entrees were equally as appealing so we limited ourselves to just two. We started with the newest up and coming star on seemingly everyone's menu, burrata (which was delicious), as well as the grilled octopus. The octopus was cooked to perfection, which is hard to do, so we enjoyed it. For entrees we had the rib eye and the risotto. The rib eye was cooked with the perfect pink center, and looked like a labor of love. The risotto had almonds, cauliflower and olives in it, and it was a flavor fiesta! Very tasty indeed. The food took a little while to come out, but once it did you could tell the time was due to the attention to detail and the fresh preparation, so it was worth the wait. And since the dining room is cozy and soothing, it was all that much more tolerable. They have a pretty good wine list, but also offer a $15 corkage fee if you just HAD to have your favorite varietal with their delicious food. The music they had on was interesting. I've never before nibbled on frisee to the musings of AC/DC, but I'd do it again.  Oh, and their posted hours claim they are open until 2, which is a rarity in the Barrington/Fox River Grove area. Not that they would really cater to the drunken stumbling "need-to-stuff-my-face" crowd, but at least we know there's ONE option should we ever find ourselves in need of SOMETHING on our way home from the train station, other than the freezer burned blueberries in our freezer at home.

<review# 726,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/27/2012,11/26/2012,87,333,15,21,21>From the outside, the Maple Tree Inn is a bit unassuming. Set in an older, Southern suburb of Chicago, it's a bit of a gem in the rough. Even though my husband and I live in nearby Oak Lawn, we had not heard of the restaurant until now when we saw it on the Yelp On Tap event specials.Welcome to the South (in more ways than one)-When entering the building, we were greeted by a giant alligator garnering Mardi-Gras style beads above the bar, along with huge purple/green/yellow/white colored masks hanging over the mirrors that lined the back of the restaurant. These items were the most loud decor that screamed New Orleans, however, everything else was more muted with the dimmed lighting, dark wood features of the bar to the white table cloth and candle lit dining room.Going bananas over the beers-My husband and I went wild on the beer menu of 26 on tap. So many rare choices from around the country and world! We finally decided on the Autumn Leaves flight. I am a fan of the caramelly, malty brown ales during these cooler days, so my fav of the four in the flight was the Saugatuck Bonfire Brown Ale. And while my husband always enjoys stouts more than me, I also found  the Ska Autumnal Mole Stout tasty because of the balance of bitter chocolate flavor from the cocoa with the spicy notes of the chili peppers. I later switched to a lighter beer, a Belgian Trippel Karmeliet, which I absolutely LOVED. It reminded me of my favorite season - summer, had a high ABV (8 percent!) and was simply refreshing.Dip it low -Warm corn bread muffins with bits of jalapeno pepper and served alongside a cream cheese dip of scallions and other fresh herbs. OMG. We finished that basket  in probably five minutes flat.Happy Apps-We went with the server's suggestions of fried crab cake and 2x2x2 oysters. The peanut slaw had a bit of kick to complement the mellow crab. I also liked the textural differences with the crunchy shell on the outside of the soft chunks of crab. The oysters were decadent, and I'm glad we got a variety because each one was distinctly different. My fav was the Bienville with the provolone - soooo creamy on top. The Rockefeller and Deviled ones had some kick to them, which I welcomed.Did you save room for (no, not dessert) dinner?-By this time of the night, we barely had any room but we thrive on variety and got two BIG entrees to share. When the dishes came, I couldn't believe the size and thought, "OK, I'll probably have a taste of each and then box the rest." But it was on of those nights when after tasting one delectable forkful, I felt an urge to have more. My husband's Tower of Pork was incredibly tender and juicy, and with the cornbread dressing and smothered eggplant, I was swimming in comfort food. As for the spare ribs, these were incredibly flavorful from the dry rub and in-house smoking, but they weren't as fall-off-the-bone tender as the pork. Another slight letdown was the sweet potato fries (that I requested to sub out the Cajun fries). These were shoestring style, which I prefer thick wedges, and they were honestly a bit flaccid rather than crunchy. Putting a name with a face / food -We were honestly too full for dessert, but as we were finishing up our drinks and waiting for a bill to be processed, the chef visited our and other tables. I always appreciate this gesture when it happens because it was nice to meet who made our food and see how much he cares about his work.Our server was friendly and consistent through the night. I appreciated her laughing at my husband's jokes and also giving us suggestions that were detailed and insightful. She obviously studied the menu and had an opportunity to taste everything.Verdict -This is definitely a place I would love to take friends from out of town who are visiting us and are unconvinced there is anything cool in the suburbs.
<review# 727,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/14/2012,11/25/2012,92,197,5,7,5>We made the three day trek to Warrenville on a sunny Mother's Day to experience the mystical Tap House that has been buzzing continually through the collective conscious of my foodie circle. Low an behold we had arrived.Starving, the cheese fries seemed like the logical thing to order upon sitting, so we did. Yes, cheese fries. We ate them, and ate them and ate them. We could have stood up and left, fatter and happier and fully satisfied when they were gone but we had ordered entrees too, oops. The fries were fresh cut well seasoned and doused in the most delicious cheese sauce that you could imagine. There were other toppings: bacon, shredded cheese and green onion. But who cared when there was this cheese sauce. Some muddled green tea infused hoppy thing, not so good. Then the one that I don't know the name of that I sampled in a small pour and then devoured a pint. So helpful that I don't recall the name but super tasty. I recommend 1 of each, of all, for effect, in sample size.
