<review# 732,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/20/2012,11/20/2012,252,423,5,6,4>I wish this place was like Doctor Who's TARDIS & bigger on the inside but sadly, it is not.  6 p.m. on Friday & they were already PACKED!   I was so glad I had made reservations.  As we dined the tiny waiting area was overflowing & the bar stayed packed to the gills so be prepared to wait or definitely make reservations.  They've squeezed in as many tables as they can to accommodate their popularity so also be prepared to carefully weave your way through the densely populated space to get to your table and/or use the restroom.With that said, once the food arrived we knew why this place was popular.  The food was amazing & reasonably priced.  We brought a friend who never had sushi before so we ordered a variety of things.  A large sake for us to share, 2 tempura appetizers, a plate of dumplings, the American's Favorite Sushi platter & the CPT Roll platter.  Of course it all came with a small salad & miso soup for each of us.  All that amazing goodness cost us $75 before tip.  Sweet!On subsequent visits we have tried various other sushi offerings - all of them delicious.  The Super White Tuna (SWT) is amazing!  How can raw fish melt in your mouth? I have no idea but the SWT delivers.  The volcano roll was also quite popular at our table and good for anyone who shies away from the raw offerings.  Most recently we tried the Kamikaze "rolls" - actually served in an endive leaf, and the Triple KC roll which has no rice & is served in a thinly sliced roll of cucumber.  Those two were my favorites. They also have Chinese food and we've only tried one entree from that part of the menu - the General Tao's Chicken (not General Tso's, as you see at other Chinese restaurants).  This has been our only disappointment.  The cuts of chicken weren't as high quality as I've had elsewhere and the breading on the chicken was completely soggy from the heavy sauce.  I realize anything breaded and fried then covered in sauce will eventually not be crispy but it shouldn't come to the table already soggy.The service is also quick and to the point - you will definitely feel rushed if you come here during peak times.  The service is a bit more friendly and relaxed if you come on a week night when they aren't so insanely busy.They seem to do a brisk take-out business as well so that's good to know if you don't want to wait.

<review# 734,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/5/2012,11/18/2012,166,121,3,6,4>I was lucky to find this joint yesterday evening after a not so good attempt to eat jerk chicken at another restaurant in the neighboring town of Blue Island(soon to be yelped too).   Let's just say that I am thankful for being able to do a quick yelp search for jerk chicken and having this place pop up.    Thank you fellow yelpers for your reviews.  Now.. for the good part, the food!!This place has some seriously good Jerk chicken..  I came here hoping they would have decent food, and I must say that they exceeded my expectations.  the chicken was soo juicy and tender, the jerk seasoning was well balanced and just plain delicious. I ordered the plain jerk, but with a side of their BBQ sauce, but  it was just so good on its own, i just kept the sauce for dipping my bread.. The dinner I ordered came with red beans & rice, and I chose Mac n' Cheese as my other side.   The rice & beans were pretty good, the mac, was not..   The Mac was flavored well, but i found it to be kinda dry and just felt like it was sitting around too long.   The service was good, the owner and his family were working the counter and they seemed very nice and helpful with my questions about their menu.   The prices are very reasonable and pretty much all the dinner were about $10 but the portions were very generous and well worth it. I didnt have anything negative about the restaurant but just a few minor things that keep it from 5 stars..   First, this is a cash ONLY, so make sure you have stopped at an ATM before you arrive because there is no ATM in the restaurant. This is a very small location and there is not much room to eat in so I recommend taking it to go..  This place is kinda divey so temper your expectations when it comes to decor and location.. I definitely will be back to try some of the other food, the jerk rib tips and Jerk catfish are looking very tempting as are some of the other sides.

Decent prices for service and the area it's in.

Both.I love the fact that I can sit in my living room, and have deliciousness served to me by my favorite people! The atmosphere is so cozy, classy and comfortable. <review# 737,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/12/2012,11/15/2012,200,204,5,7,6>Many moons ago, when me and my then fiance, current wife were trying to fill some shelves in the house, we started scouring newspapers and neighborhood signs and the internets for anything resembling book sales.  Book sales from libraries were the usual culprit and ended up becoming a regular visitor to booksalefinder.com .  These book sales usually touted bag or box sales on the last day for anywhere from $1 to $5, depending on the size of your book receptacle.  The great thing with these sales were the finds, and the quantity of books you could take home for literally, a couple of fazools, a few simoleons.  The trouble with this was a quallity vs. quantity issue.  Sure, you could get hundreds of books in an hour, and great titles at that.  But they will probably be very dog-eared. possibly covered in that graying plastic book cover crap, and will be guaranteed to have that old and moldy library odor we all know and love.  Another issue is with booksellers.  People who walk around with software installed on their smartphones in order to scan isbn numbers and quickly and wretchedly figured out what books were worth what, so that they could find books with higher values, and horde all of said titles, or sometimes, they would hide piles of books under tables in order to buy them all on bag/box sale day, pretty much stealing from the library in order to make money for themselves.  There was a very small percentage of booksellers that we've ever encountered that were polite or not socially awkward.  They always seems like they're allergic to the sun and manners.  Not all of them, just a whole lot of 'em.  They are the bane of the library sale, and they are the reason that a lot of booksellers ban scanners/smartphone usage/hording during a sale.  Until one day, we heard a commercial for the store on the radio.  We'd both been familiar with the presence of said store, namely, the Skokie location in Village Crossing from when we both lived in the city.  Having never actually entered one of these stores, our interests were suddenly piqued with the possibility of finding books without book covers on them, or library due date cards on the inside of the covers.  One fateful day, we entered the Palatine location on our virgin voyage into the world of the civilized book buyer.  Yes, an oasis where nary a scanner would be in sight to ruin the experience of a great find.  Half Price Books has all of their books categorized and sub-categorized, making it easy to find whatever you need for your reading pleasure.  They may as well call it Half Price Media, they carry music, movies, books on tape, magazines, even board games, video games...It's the kind of place you can get lost in for hours on end, especially in the Clearance section where the books tend to run from $1 to $3 depending on the store location and the type of book(mass market paperback, trade paper, or hardcover).  Of the close to one thousand books and four hundred Blu-Rays and TV box sets that line the shelves in our house(I had to build custom shelves under our now unusable breakfast bar in order to find a place to properly stash books and movies), I'd say 70% are from various Half Price Books locations, but most of them have come from Palatine, which I think has the best combination of pricing and selection, along with being the closest to our house.  Happy hunting!  Hope you enjoy the journey as much as we do...
<review# 738,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/28/2012,11/14/2012,850,1294,14,15,15>Now that I'm the Yelp Duchess and the foursquare Mayor of La Placita Taqueria, I feel it's my duty to let the commoners (I mean, fellow Yelp/4sq peers) in on a little secret. This is the best taqueria in the suburbs. It could probably even compete for best taqueria in all of Chicagoland, but that's just my not-so-humble opinion.There have been days, I'm ashamed to admit, that I've stopped into this little taco joint twice. I come for lunch (after having already eaten here the previous night) and then find myself returning in the evening for more Mexican. I can't get enough of them and it's quickly turned into a habit I can't break. I might feel worse about it if this were an expensive addiction to have, but the prices are so low that I don't even think twice about forking over my money.My boyfriend pretty much always orders the chorizo burrito and once tried a torta. He has nothing but wonderful things to say about them. I, on the other hand, am a taco girl. I don't like to commit to one flavor for too long, so ordering up three tacos with different meats has me in heaven. I typically get al carbon, lengua and carnitas on Saturday/Sunday. Carnitas are only available on weekends, so during the week I try a couple different ones. I've had the ribeye and it was very good. Chorizo isn't bad either. I've found the food is slightly better on the weekends, but only marginally.One of the amazing things about La Placita is that even when they do it "wrong," it comes out so right. I like it when the meat is fresh and juicy, but sometimes they overcook it a bit. It still tastes fan-friggen-tastic. I've also had some orders that have been lost in translation. For example, I made the mistake of ordering one taco and saying the ingredients I wanted and then ordering a second taco and asking for them to also make it with the onions and cilantro. I ended up with a taco with the first set of ingredients and another taco with the second request. I still ate them and they were all still amazing. I've also been given a taco dinner when I only wanted three tacos and I don't hold it against them at all because the price difference was incredibly reasonable and the beans and rice are perfect!I could go on and on in this review about how much I love them, but lunch time is fast approaching and I think I'm heading back here to get my taco fix.
<review# 739,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/20/2012,11/13/2012,46,197,4,6,4>Lilacia Park is a wonderful place year round though it is most spectacular, as its name implies, during lilac season. In peak season, typically but not necessarily early May, not only are the 700+ (or 1200, depending on your source) lilacs blooming, but also crabapple trees, tulips, daffodils, scilla, muscari, hyacinths and more. The fragrance is heavenly! I come to this small park in all seasons. The Lombard Park District does an excellent job keeping the park clean, green, and thriving. There are fewer visitors to the park in summer, fall, and winter so it's a peaceful escape disturbed only by nearby Metra trains. Lilacia Park is enchanting after a snowfall.If you have the opportunity, do visit during lilac season. Mother Nature is fickle and lilac blooms are subject to her whims, so talk to the locals before you make a long trip to see the blooms. Or if you live nearby visit often, then you'll be certain not to miss the colorful and fragrant spring show.Lilacia Park was originally part of the estate of Colonel William R. Plum, a telegraph officer in the Civil War. He bequeathed his land and collection of lilacs to the people of Lombard for a public park and his house for a free public library. Lilacia Park is adjacent to the Helen M. Plum Memorial Library. In 1929 the land was designed into a park by renowned landscape architect Jens Jensen.Lombard proclaims Lilac Time for two weeks every May (no matter what the lilac blooms are doing) and celebrates with a Lilac Festival complete with Lilac Queen & Princesses, a Lilac Ball, and the Lilac Parade. There are many public events including beer & wine tastings in the park, a 5K run, the Mutt Strut, a pancake breakfast, lilac sales, tours, and more.

Our waiter was very sweet and refilled our glasses often. He and the other man working (probably the manager) made sure everything was well with our food and that we were enjoying our time at the restaurant. I will def be back soon, most likely on a Monday when my work-week needs a little kick-start.

<review# 742,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/8/2012,11/10/2012,70,159,6,6,6>I have a minor confession to make ... I know a cupcake smuggler.She operates within the city, waiting for the mysterious green truck to arrive at the designated time, picks up the willing bits of contraband and hustles off into the alleyways. Maybe it's not a major offense but I think transport of these little cupcakes so robustly protected in their plastic shells between counties feels so ... illegal.You may have heard of these before: Reese's Pieces, Lemon Supreme Pie, Strawberry Banana, Chocolate Peanut Butter Cup, Pistachio, Banana Cream Pie, Sweet Potato Pie and the legendary Elvis, a glorious confection built sturdily on a banana cake base generously topped with peanut butter frosting and a crispy slice of bacon. I've heard you could OD on one of these so I'll keep my serving dose to one for now.At this point my supplier and I have made the exchange. I look around nervously before I pause to inhale the Elvis. I am overcome with so much inexplicable guilt. This is all very good, very, very good.

They have a bazillion glowing reviews and I'm always hearing fellow yelpers talk about Bigby's. I live fairly close so it's a mystery why I haven't been here sooner.We arrived before any crowds on a Saturday night and we were promptly asked (by the owner I'm guessing) if we've ever been. Once he found out we were newbies, he explained the craft beer voting process and their current selections. He also pointed out the beers on tap and wine menu. There are TONS of drinks to choose from. They also have a small selection of flat breads, pizza, cheese platters and desserts as well. We were with a group so we ended up ordering a few pizzas, mainly the Bigby's Hawaiian which did not disappoint. For dessert, we tried the Smores Pizza since I heard so much about it on here. It didn't disappoint either, definitely would order again. The prices are pretty reasonable and they also offer a beer or wine flight for a pretty good bargain.The place overall has a really cool, cozy vibe. The area itself isn't that large but it never got overly crowded. There is an outdoor seating area as well, weather permitting. They have tons of board games to choose from and I also spied an original Nintendo remote control hanging from the projection screen which leads me to believe you can play a mean game of Mario sometime....maybe only during the week?I've heard that they also host trivia nights and I definitely would be interested in that...just need to find out when.We had a great time at Bigby's. The drinks were flowing, the prices were right, service was great and the atmosphere was inviting.

He is the the smiling guy at the front of the house. Doing a little bit of everything to make the visit enjoyable. You want an example?  I'll give you a good one...I placed an order to pick up at a specific time. It wasn't quite ready as there had been a rush just prior. We chatted away for a few minutes and then I kept myself busy waiting. He reappeared with an iced coffee on the house. Ready for it?  I quit caffeine, so I couldn't drink it. Here's my sad panda, err, elephant face :-( I ask if it's caffeinated and learn that it is. I mention my lifestyle change aka no pop/no caffeine anymore. He tells me to go ahead and take it back to the office for someone else to enjoy. Thanks!  When my order arrives, he hands me a bottle of water. Fast forward to today...he brings me water when dining in without a question. He remembered. And even if he didn't, it makes for a nice Yelp story. So just hush and smile. :-) And then head to Happy Elephant for the homemade crab Rangoon, homemade dipping sauce (yum!), basil chicken, sweet and sour wraps and peanuty thai chicken with carrots and broccoli. Oh yeah, it is a cozy place if you eat in just so you're aware. But no complaints from me.  By the end of today's lunch, I was chatting with the lovely ladies from an apartment rental office nearby. One of the gals ended up ordering a crab Rangoon to go based on my rave reviews. She ate one before leaving (so she could make my Yelp review, of course!) and she said it was delicious. Success!  Another Happy Elephant customer!!!

<review# 751,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/29/2012,11/1/2012,157,219,9,14,10>There are several things on my list of "I don't do's"I don't eat cherry-flavored gummy bearsI don't wear sandals with socksI don't run unless I'm being chased (and even then, I'd rather hide)andI don't work outCue Weight Watchers, Groupon, and Center Fit, where *shocker* I found something awesome.As a WW member, it's been a while since I've really needed to start working out, but it's pretty tough. Even the Wii Fit hurts my bod--thank you to years of cheerleading and injuries for my arthritis and loosey goosey ligaments/tendons (yes, that IS the technical term that the orthopedic surgeon provided me with). So I watch Groupon for fitness deals, because I'm a deal hound like that. One day, I see a deal for True Health Studio.  "Hmmm" I say to myself...let's see, shall we? Zumba? Fun! Kettlebells? COOL! Sledge hammers and giant tires? HELL YES! But wait...I can't do any of that...It will hurt.  *sad face*Restoring movement? Now we're talking. Two weeks in and I'm hooked. Steve runs the class as a group personal training, where routines are personalized for each individual in a small group setting. His knowledge of the body and how we move is phenomenal. Rock. On. No pain, no gain? Not in this class. The goal is not to push too far, but to go just far enough to move more the next day. After day one, I was still a little sore, but I wasn't in pain and I was excited to return. I leave each session with a smile on my face knowing that my body is getting stronger and that one day I WILL get to play with sledge hammers and kettlebells.

<review# 754,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/14/2012,10/28/2012,79,108,3,10,2>As The Dude and I were leaving Aodake last night, he uttered what I'm sure the peeps at this place love to hear: "You know, I think I like this better than Benihana!" This isn't some carelessly flung around statement. My family loves Benihana. It's where we go when there's a birthday. It's our go-to place for celebrations. It's where we go when there's any little occasion, like two or more of us being in Lombard at the same time. To us, Benihana is Mecca and we must make regular pilgrimages. However, a friend of mine raves about Aodake, and when I saw they had a Groupon, I snagged it. The deal was for $30 worth of food and a large Sapporo beer (large enough for the two of us to split!). Their prices are lower than Benihana's, so we were able to get two orders of the hibachi vegetables and two veggie rolls for $30. Heck of a deal. So how do the hibachi courses at Aodake and Benihana stack up? 1. Soup: Advantage Aodake. While basically the same soup, Aodake's broth is more flavorful. 2. Salad: Benihana FTW. I just can't get enough of their ginger dressing. Aodake's dressing is a bit creamier, which isn't a bad thing. 3. Shrimp appetizer: It's a tie. I get more shrimp at Benihana, but Aodake's are better seasoned. 4: Fried rice: I prefer Aodake's. It felt like it retained a bit more flavor from the grill. And I liked that all meals came with the fried rice rather than being charged for the upgrade (though I did pay an extra buck to have chicken added to mine). 5. Dipping sauces: Sorry, Aodake, I have to go with Benihana on this one. I crave their ginger sauce like crack. Aodake's mayo-based sauce was yummy as well, though. It was even good with my sushi. When it comes to the main meals, I don't have an apples-to-apples comparison. The Dude and I usually get the Tofu Steak at Benihana. At Aodake, we chose the hibachi vegetables (a great deal at $10.95). We got giant piles of veggies and I had a full meal left over for lunch today. Oh, and I love that they shoot sake into the mouths of people at the table. I was actually able to hold more in my mouth than anyone else at our table. Don't read too far into that, please. We'll definitely be back. At these great prices, we don't need an "occasion" to go to out for hibachi!

<review# 760,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/28/2012,10/22/2012,123,246,7,11,10>I'm honestly disappointed in myself for not making more of an effort to check this place out in the past. This was one of those places that I kept putting off while doing more expensive and much less fun things. This place provided me with one of the best truly down-to-earth fun times I've ever had.Cascade is hands down the BEST value for clean, good ol' American fun. At one time the US was covered with drive-in theaters but only about 400 exist today and it's a shame. How else can you share the camaraderie by taking up massive amounts of space with all the vehicles together while watching a movie on a gigantic screen in the privacy of your own car? This is what I call ingenious excess.It only costs $9 per person for BOTH movies that show that night! They don't play crappy older films that have been out for a while either. Up to date brand spankin' new features are brilliantly displayed on a massive screen high above the lot for a great view from all locations all underneath a starry sky. I don't think it can get much more romantic for the budget conscious. Or the financially able either. Even the kids love it and you don't have to worry about your toddler causing a scene since you can take care of your loud child inside the confines of your own car WHILE watching the movie! It's a win-win-win situation. Wanna know what the best part is? You can bring your own food and drink in. That's right folks. None of that "No outside food or drink" bullchit we are so used to seeing. They even have grills up front for you to cook on!!! Is this place some sort of fairy wonder land??? Seriously, I don't understand how there isn't a months long reservation list just to get in the place. I honestly think it's because people just don't know the level of awesome this place has achieved. This chit is Level Chuck Norris. There is one exception, however. There is a hot dog/burger joint called Scooby's right next door and Cascade must have some sort of feud going on with them because there are signs clearly posted at the entrance gate that Scooby's is NOT allowed. Like, automatically disqualified to enter the Promised Land if you dare bring a single fry from Scooby's in. Don't do it.Now, the pre-movie rules state, among other things, that no alcoholic beverages are allowed. I didn't know about this because I assumed it was okay after reading other reviews so I brought in a large cooler with practically a whole bar in that mother. I was pouring cocktails out the back of my trunk for an entire hour before the first show (btw the gates open an hour before the show so you can pick a spot and tailgate) and nobody said a word. I also saw more than a few parties drinking beer out of cans and bottles. Now, obviously, there were no sideways straight bill hat wearing kegger douchebags pulling kegstands, shotguns, or beer bongs because it is, after all, a family atmosphere. I'm fairly certain that the lone security guard that I saw looks the other way if you're not being a complete dumbass about it so don't ruin it for the rest of us who enjoys a drink or 6 while watching two feature length film back to back. The last time I went, I went so far as to pour all my drinks in to a plastic cup to make it less obvious. Discretion is advised.The first time we went it was a little chilly out so we opted to stay in the car with the windows rolled up and my glorious sound system blasting. It was epic to say the least. You can tune in via FM radio or use the little sound boxes located at each parking spot to listen in on the action. If you're like me, you'll be cranking the sounds up to really experience every nuance of a good action flick. Just remember to start your car up every now and then to charge your battery.The second time the weather was great so we brought folding chairs to set up in front of our car to watch the show under the beautiful starry night sky. Obviously the sound wasn't the best but we loved it just as much. Why? I was allowed to smoke my cigar and pipe the entire time. Now, be mindful of your neighbors when you do this as it can be quite offensive even though you can smoke outside. Common courtesy and all. The little box speakers were adequate in relaying the sound to us just fine.The whole experience is heart-achingly wonderful. They play 50s tunes over the air and on the boxes before the show starts and then complete the experience by displaying retro ads on screen before the movie starts and during the intermission. It makes me wish I had a '57 Chevy, greased back hair with tight blue jeans and a white t-shirt complete with a pack of smokes rolled up in the sleeve to match the vibe whenever I come here. Having my best gal dressed in a full billowy skirt would be the cherry on my sundae.There are few experiences as transcending as spending an evening participating in a great American pastime. If you haven't been to a drive-in before, then try Cascade out. I guarantee you'll have a great time.

I would mos def go back to her. Pro-tip! Check Groupon NOW! before going. Since Salon Sophia is new, I was able to grab a $30 haircut instead of the normal $45.
<review# 762,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/25/2012,10/20/2012,78,284,4,8,5>I love love love the Arboretum! Having lived in the South suburbs my whole life, my family and I never ventured off into the Western 'burbs and Lisle sounded super far. My boyfriend, who is from the W. burbs told me about the arboretum and I knew I had to go.We had a Groupon for $5/person. It was a pretty hot day, but with some water and sunblock, it was still enjoyable. It felt like we biked the entire place but we may have just biked one really long path. Zooming along paths through hundreds of unbelievably tall trees was such a great feeling. There's some attraction along one of the paths called the BIG rock or something to that effect. You have to walk a trail (they have easy and medium/hard paths) to get to it as it is in the middle of the forest. Holy mosquitoes! Bugs were flying everywhere and I was getting eaten alive, which isn't the best for me since I'm allergic. We finally got to the rock and it was hilariously medium sized. I was like "This is it?" So uh, it's not worth looking at. Just a heads up.The rest of the arboretum is amazing. There is a prairie full of wild flowers that you can walk through, though there seemed to be no visible path. We made our own but had to stop eventually because it was completely flooded (it had rained a ton earlier that week). On our way back to our bikes I saw something that made the whole day worth it: deer! We were walking a path, not even paying attention, when we looked up and saw two deer directly in front of us. We stopped and had a staring contest and then they just cautiously walked across and into the woods. It was honestly breathtaking. I've never been that close to a deer. Respect nature and it will give you so much back in return.I can't wait to go back to the arboretum. It's the type of place you can go to any season because of how different everything will look. A seriously great place if you're a nature lover.

<review# 765,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/4/2012,10/17/2012,178,231,4,7,5>FAMOUS FOR- Pancakes (or so they say)BUZZ- Designer StaffI TRIED:- Mexicana Skillet (10/10)- Espanola Omelette (6/10)- Buttermilk Pancakes (7/10)- Oreo S'mores Pancakes (7/10)Believe it or not, this place is in our lunch rotation...sorta. See, we only have an hour, so we don't have time to wait in line. That pretty much limits us to Monday-Thursdays, when the weather is depressing, before 11:15am. Anything outside of that, and this place is constantly packed! If we ever feel lucky, and decide to press that luck, it always ends with a beautiful and friendly hostess handing us a pager. Then, our lunch is ruined, and we go for $1.50 Hot Dog & Drink combos at Costco. Yeah, if that doesn't describe tragedy, I don't know what does (although, might I add, what an incredible price point!).So anyway, like a lot of people who wrote reviews, I'm not a breakfast person either; however, I really enjoy breakfast food. What does that mean? Well, I don't like the idea of waking up an hour earlier in the asscrack of dawn for the sake of eating, as opposed to getting the extra sleep and having a cereal bar instead. However, the idea of a breakfast skillet for lunch or the asscrack of dawn -- because we're still awake, OK (not that Wildberry is open that late)! MEXICANA SKILLETNow here's something you don't see at IHOP or Denny's! Chorizo, Jalapeños, Avocado, Onions, Cilantro, and Cheese. OMG, if you put those ingredients in anything, from popcorn to apple pie, you would have a winning dish! All of that is mixed in a bed of hashbrowns, and topped with a couple eggs. AND you get pancakes (or toast)!Chorizo obviously takes center stage here, flavors are sharp and lovely! And I need to give extra credit here, because chorizo is normally pretty salty and can be difficult to cook with, because you have to balance it so that your dish isn't too salty, but without smothering it. The rest of the ingredients blend so incredibly well, adding flavor, absorbing just enough of the seasoning, to make it an awesome dish! The onions are cooked perfectly (I hate raw onions) to have just enough flavor while not being mushy. The cilantro (I love cilantro) is spread across evenly, with that taste of freshness that only cilantro can bring. And the mixed in jalapeños give it a small but very welcomed kick too, of course, while offering its own flavors to the whole dish. I'm a Tabasco junkie, so after I sprinkle a few pints on every bite, OMG I'm-o In-o Heaven-o! (That's Spanish for all you uncultured folk!) Best Skillet Evar!ESPANOLA OMELETTESo, a lot of time went by since the first time, where I ordered the Mexicana, and I couldn't remember what I got. I knew the name was something Spanish/Mexican, but there's a freaking "Mexicana" and an "Espanola" in the menu. Fuuuuuu! I took a 50/50 chance, and picked Espanola. Wrong! It's basically the skillet, but in omelet form. Remember what I said about delicately balancing the Chorizo's seasoning? This is an example of adding too many other ingredients, thereby smothering the Chorizo's seasoning. Just tasted bland. The essence of some of the flavors lingered, but the seasoning was pretty much gone.BUTTERMILK PANCAKESI guess this is what they're famous for. In general, I think pancakes are swell. And other than Miss Shirley's Cafe in Baltimore, I think all pancakes rate the same. It's hard to mess 'em up.OREO PANCAKEI had been dieting for over 4 hours (um...before the skillet), so in a moment of weakness, I ordered the most undiet item on the menu. Pancakes are stuffed with marshmallow, and then even more is drizzled on top along with chocolate syrup and chips and Oreo crumbles. This is one of those things that look good on paper...but not so much on a pancake. The delicious toppings sort of take away from the pancake, and what you end up with is basically a side-grade from the regular pancakes with syrup.GO WILD!A solid place! The 5 star is for the Mexicana. I get a craving for that every now and then, and I've only seen the likes of it here. Like a lot of breakfast joints, just about anything you get here will probably be pretty good (though not 5 star good). I'd recommend this for anybody, not only because their food is good, but their menu is huge, so everyone'll probably find something to like on the menu.

I will definitely be going to Russell's again, it's one of the best BBQ places I have ever ate at and I am not afraid to say that this place is my new food obsession!

<review# 769,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/7/2012,10/13/2012,10,40,2,12,2>My fiance and I were sad to see Grumpy Bulldog go, considering its epic beer selection. However, when I noticed that this place had opened up in the same spot I decided to give it a whirl. So glad I did! Let's start with beer. They've been open just 8 days but the beers on tap currently include:-Leinenkugel Summer Shandy-Allagash White-Ska Brewing's Modus Hoperandi-Arrogant Bastard-Two Brothers Domaine Dupage-Bell's Oberon-Kidnapped by Vikings (from Naperville's own Solemn Oath brewery)There were at least two or three others, though right now I don't recall which ones. Our server Sarah informed us that they will be adding more soon and may be swapping out some of the current ones as well. I'm not really into Scotch, but they do have a big selection of specialty Scotches available if that's your thing. OK, next up FOOD! The Bulldog didn't really have a lot to offer in that department, so I was delighted to see that Jackson Ave Pub has stepped it up considerably in that department. I'm vegetarian, and was delighted to find numerous salads, appetizers like pita chips & hummus or mac & cheese, potato salad, and much more. Plus, their extensive burger selection included a veggie burger option! For meat eaters like my fiance, you can enjoy either grass fed or angus burger with an incredible list of options and toppings. I went with the Greek burger on a pretzel bun--which was AMAZING! The veggie burger is topped with tomato, onion, feta cheese, and olive tapenade. Fiance had the smoky burger with a grass fed burger and loved it. We split the fries--they offer several varieties including Duck Fat, Sweet Potato, and House Fries; but our server told us about an option not yet on the menu: Parmesan Truffle! I gotta say, those were out of this world and I could eat myself to death and die happy with Parmesan Truffle Fries in my esophagus. The vibe is pretty low key, a welcome environment in contrast with meat market brofests like Features and Rizzo's. Most of the patrons when we went were middle aged, and the music playing via satellite radio included artists like The Shins and other acoustic/indie rock types that definitely didn't drown out conversation. There are a few TVs showing sports and an episode of some CBS crime procedural starring Leelee Sobieski; but overall the noise factor seems pretty low. Be prepared to park further away--it is downtown Naperville--or if you live in the neighborhood like we do, just walk to it. I am so excited for a new, classy but casual establishment that serves food and beers I love! I hope they do well and attract a small but faithful crowd of patrons.
<review# 770,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/19/2012,10/12/2012,58,179,17,18,14>I have been spending quite a bit of time at the pool this summer and one day on my way there I spotted Daddy O's Donuts along Sauk Trail.  I couldn't believe there was a donut shop we hadn't checked out.  Clearly I had been laying down on the job.  I had enough restraint to not cut across lanes of traffic to immediately get my fix, but I did tuck the idea away for a future treat.   A couple weeks later on our way to the pool, my mom and I stopped in.  It smelled wonderful and I wanted one of everything. I again practiced restraint and settled on one glazed and one red velvet.  Eating for two means two donuts, yes?  They were stupendous!  The glazed donut was hefty but still melted in my mouth and it wasn't over glazed.  The red velvet was also delicious; the cream cheese frosting was perfect.   I washed it all down with an ice cold carton of milk and I was grinning from ear to ear.  We then proceeded to the pool and I foolishly thought I could still do laps.  Hello! I just ate two donuts pre-swim.  What was I thinking????  I attempted a few laps, but I could barely get my head out of the water to breathe and ended up swallowing a bit too much pool water.   It was much safer to just lounge on the deck that day and work on my tan.  Believe me, the donut coma was totally worth it, but next time I am stopping in post-swim - and probably pre-nap.
<review# 771,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/15/2012,10/11/2012,92,360,8,13,6>Officially taking the title of "healthiest fast food anywhere near Carol Stream", House of Ancient Egypt / World of Wonders Egyptian Fast Food (I'm still not sure what the actual name of it is) is a good alternative to all that grease lining both sides of Gary Avenue just to the north.First of all, I'm really surprised they even opened. The building has been empty since a mediocre burger joint closed 3 or 4 years ago, then this place was under construction for the better part of the last 2 or 3 years. Suddenly they've broken out the "NOW OPEN" signs.Anyways, we were in a hurry and had a screaming baby, so I went through the drive through. I picked up a mango fruit cocktail smoothie whose name I couldn't say or remember, much less spell. I also got a Shwarma meal.The smoothie was excellent. Giant chunks of banana, strawberry and apple, along with more blended fruit (including mangoes). Oddly, they did not provide me with a lid for my cup, so I had to be very, very careful. Happily, they used enough honey that I could very much taste it. I'd get this again.The Shwarma was shaved beef served with tahini sauce, fresh pita, rice pilaf and a cucumber-lettuce-tomato salad. Oh, and there was also a roasted jalapeño pepper that practically burned my eyes off. Again, considering this is "fast food" and not "fast casual", the flavor and price was great. The beef could have stood to be a bit more seasoned, but overall I agreed with it, and thankfully WOW elected not to bastardize the dish for American palates. Which is another way of saying... the tahini sauce was really freaking bitter, but it felt right.In spite of some questionable decisions on the menu (a "King Tut" ice cream cone? really?) I will be back.

<review# 774,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/21/2012,10/8/2012,160,654,9,13,8>Passing through the auto dealers along Ogden, a sign on my right caught my attention: "Pig Roast Today 1-4 PM". I heard of Standard Market before but wasn't sure if this was it. An unassuming large building like a warehouse, no fancy storefront facing Ogden, plain exterior walls. I pulled into the parking lot and it was jam-packed. I grabbed one of the last remaining spots at least half a block away.Outside, it looked like a reception of some sort was going on. Upon closer inspection, I found it was a line for ice cream samples, as well as people eating in a patio area. I had a very difficult choice to make: Blueberry-lemon or Ugandan Vanilla Bean ice cream? I went with vanilla, as I always judge it as the true measure of an ice cream brand's honest quality. My wife tried the blueberry lemon. It may have been one of the best flavors we tried, as we sampled each other's choices.Inside, even more samples. Freshly squeezed orange, grape and pineapple juices! At 3 quarts/$10, it was a good deal. I chose a mix of apple/kiwi/green grape juice that tasted awesome and had a thicker texture than your ordinary bottled juices. You could clearly taste the kiwi in it.What started as a curious visit turned into a feast in every aisle: goat cheese on a cracker, wine tasting, apple butter, yogurt, BBQ sauce on uncured hot dogs, even a raw milk product. Everything was amazing! "Standard Market" is such an understatement. There was even a musical group performing some acoustic rock and country songs.By now, I was also filling up a shopping cart. Bulk popcorn kernels $0.79/pound! Makes Orville Redenbacher seem like a ripoff. Got me about 3-4 pounds' worth to last a while. I got a bottle of sangria wine, some home-made sausages, and more. While this place has pricier organic and exotic foods, I found it more reasonably priced than Whole Foods.And they have a restaurant inside too, not that I was hungry at that point. I was amazed at the selection, freshness and quality of everything in the store. While Westmont is far from my area, I can see this being a place to visit every time I head to the south burbs. So much to explore and try that this is a must-see place on the culinary map of the Chicago area.

<review# 779,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/15/2012,10/3/2012,63,74,11,13,8>I seriously had a Meg Ryan-esque Foodgasm when we had dinner there! It probably wasn't pretty (guygasms just aren't) but it happened several times during our meal, when encountering a flavor so deliciously transcendent my only choice was to, momentarily, merge with the infinite universe. I'm exaggerating, but only a little. First of all, we loved the look of Mahajara. It's in a Rosemont strip mall, so I wasn't expecting much, but walking in I was struck by how classy, modern and restrained the decor was. Except for some Indian flourishes, it actually reminded me of Grant Achatz's NEXT (with that high ambient light, but thankfully, without the mega price tag). There's even a cool little bar connected, which I'd like to try out sometime.Remember that scene in The Professional, when the crooked drugged up cop played by Gary Oldman quietly asks for for backup, "Bennie, bring me everyone." What do you mean, everyone?"EEEVERYOOOONE!", he screams.  youtube.com/watch?featur…Well, as this was our first time at Maharaja, our order was a lot like that...but without the irrational screaming and gunfire.When you are seated they bring out a bowl of savory impossibly thin and crispy flat chips with a hint of spice, and a hottish green sauce and sweeter red sauce to dip them in. One bite and we knew we were in for an experience. The subtlety and balanced spiciness were dead on.In keeping with the "Bring me eeeverythiiing" theme, we started with the Maharaja Vegetarian Snacks - "A combination platter of samosa, paneer pakora, vegetable pakora, onion pakora and aloo corn tikki",  because we wanted to try a wide sample of delights. All were great, but the battered, spiced and deep fried cauliflower was a particular stand out, as well as the spinach.Thankfully, they aren't light with the Indian spices, like a lot of places trying to appeal to the widest range of tastes. These apps were seriously crispy and flavorful.As an entree, I wanted to try a good range of dishes, so I ordered the Maharaja Dinner Special ($21) - "Tandoori chicken, seekh kebab, shrimp, chicken tikka, rogan josh, and dal makhani"  The standouts from all the standouts were the tandoori chicken and rogan josh.I always tend towards tandoor dishes when eating Indian food, because, well let's face it, the tandoor is one of the most ingenious, bad-ass cooking devices in the history of humankind!  Its a cylindrical clay oven that can approach temperatures of 900 degrees Fahrenheit. Dangle skewered meat in it to sear in the juices, and slap doughs on the sides to get instant flat breads.Wikipedia reports: that the tandoor combines "live-fire, radiant heat cooking, and hot-air, convection cooking, and smoking by the fat and food juices that drip on to the charcoal."  ALL IN ONE DEVICE!  Tandoor, you are so cool!Anyway, their tandoor chicken was the best I've eaten anywhere. Really. Tender and juicy (so often, at most places it's neither), with a perfect balance of savory, very slightly sweet and smoky.  The lamb in the rogan josh was impossibly tender in a savory onion and tomato sauce. We ordered extra basmati rice, just so we could soak up every bit of the delicious gravy.For you vegetarians, the slow simmered, dal makhani (black lentils) in a tomato, onion, garlic and ginger creamy sauce, was a stand out. Run the fluffy, slightly smoky and tender nan through it, close your eyes and reach Foodvana! I enjoyed it as cold leftover, straight from the fridge the next day, and it was still fabulous.  There's just so much more to say about the food, I can't even keep going.  Go, and you'll experience it.The service was attentive and quick. They kept our water glasses filled at all times (which I love!), and cleared plates as we completed them.We didn't try the desserts, but really really really want to try the famous lunch buffet. We even passed by to read all the little signs on our way out.We'll be back. A lot.

<review# 788,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/16/2012,9/24/2012,421,397,28,34,30>Hollywood Boulevard is the original premium theater in Chicagoland, and is still right there among the best. Before I go into what makes this theater so great I should probably explain how the theater works. At Hollywood Boulevard you walk in and there's a ticket counter listing all the movies and showtimes, if you're buying tickets ahead of time for multiple people you (at least last time I tried this) had to show ID as they do not allow kids except for select films and showtimes. Once you get in you sit in a sliding leather chair at a table or up against a counter. Hollywood Boulevard operates as a full fledged restaurant and bar, so you are required to purchase at least one menu item (this could be a drink). The nice thing is admission here is slightly less expensive than most first run theaters so just going in and getting a ticket and a drink comes out to about even with anywhere else. Now that I've explained how this premium theater experience differs a bit from most theaters let me go over the decor. Hollywood Boulevard is themed as a combination of Grauman's Chinese Theater and Old Time Hollywood. You'll find lots of classic movie posters and other decorations throughout the interior along with an Asian theme to compliment the Grauman's Chinese Theater influence. This decoration extends to not just the lobby and hallways but throughout the auditoriums as well.The theater itself is very well maintained and clean on the inside. I've yet to see a significant pile up of garbage on the floor or any other unsightly buildups you often find at other cinemas.As far as the projection and sound goes, the auditoriums are slightly brighter than a most theaters as the waiters and waitresses have to be able to see to bring you your drinks or food. The projection quality, screens and audio are excellent and it's clear a lot of effort goes into making this the best possible movie experience.The food offered by this theater is actually of fairly decent quality. I've tried burgers, chicken fingers, nachos and a few other items over the years and have never been displeased with my meal. They have a fairly wide and diverse menu offering a lot of different dinner choices.Overall Hollywood Boulevard is a fantastic place to see a movie, while not quite as elaborately decorated as its sibling theater Hollywood Palms in Naperville. The overall experience at this location is roughly the same, comfortable chairs, food and drink service, quality picture and sound in a very elaborately decorated cinema. One final note is they often offer coupons to visit again during the regular week and run special screenings of certain classic and cult films. I highly recommend Hollywood Boulevard as a unique place to visit in Chicagoland.

<review# 791,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/13/2012,9/21/2012,158,280,5,11,7>The perfect outdoor destination for recreation of all types. I stumbled upon this suburban oasis a year ago when I started training for long-distance running races. The 7.7-mile paved loop is perfect. There's plenty of shade, water sources, bathrooms and scenery. I've come within arm's reach of deer and regularly enjoy the captive elk. This morning, I saw an adorably fuzzy pack of baby geese!I like running here because it's never crowded, but it passes the "scream test": if I screamed, someone would hear me. There are people fishing and kayaking, as well as picnicking and running. Now that I'm into cycling, I appreciate the paved, flat course, which has several off-shoots to pad my mileage. There's lots of parking, too.Between the fishing, boating and running, you could easily pack a lunch and make a day of it.

<review# 803,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/7/2012,9/9/2012,255,326,7,7,5>Somehow I was coming to Oak Park every other week for a significant part of the winter and didn't realize this was here. The Conservatory is the perfect place to visit on a winter day when you want to pretend it isn't cold enough to freeze snot outside. Although it's a smaller space (three rooms), they've done a lot with it. There are plants hanging from the ceiling, meandering paths, a little hidden seat to sit and read if you like, and yes, the infamous birds. As Yelp's resident Crazy Bird Lady, it should come as no surprise that I loved meeting the birds. If I remember correctly, there were two cockatiels, a finch, a lovebird, an amazon, an african grey, and a conure. There are also clever mice who scamper around the cages, picking up food the birds drop and carrying it away on tiny, furry feet. (I like mice...can you tell?) Also, there's a large pond with very large koi and some turtles. If the huge ficus plants or blossoming cacti don't catch your eye, these animals might interest you.This facility also has a gift shop that sometimes sells plants, and there are rooms you can rent for events. There are special plant sales if you'd like a bit more selection than the gift shop usually offers. Plus, the Conservatory also holds special events for kids called Exploration Stations. Recent topics include Birds, Pollinators, Sugar, and Chocolate. Sounds good to me! These events, just like a regular visit to the Conservatory, are free, although they suggest a donation. You can also give back by volunteering; they train docents twice a year.Parking is pretty easy, the whole place is pretty kid-friendly, and it's conveniently located near both the highway and the CTA. You really have no reason to not go, unless you're afraid of the awesome.

<review# 809,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/25/2012,9/3/2012,33,144,5,7,3>I'm always on the lookout for new places that combine comforting food with good beer. So on my frequent trips down Butterfield in the DG, LB, OB area, I've been enticed by the "Coming Soon" promises of one Trademark Tavern and Tap. This place must be a place for good food and good beer right? I mean it has Tavern and Tap right in the name. It would be a terrible lie (hah, I just put Nine Inch Nails in your brain now) if it didn't have those things.Well, it has those things, and those things are very good, and since it's brand new and I've been having a very good couple of weeks, I'm giving it the full-on five.So first off, considering my wife and I went there on its first day open to the public, the staff seemed on top of things. Now, the place was far from crowded and a few staff members were a bit idle, but our waitress especially was friendly, efficient and eager to get whatever information we needed about the brand new restaurant.As for the food, I was very impressed. The menu is limited, but it's clear they do those few things very well and I'd take that over a huge selection with no direction and mediocre flavor. Plus everything has that air of classing up traditional bar dishes, which they actually pull off where so many others have failed. The nachos (yeah, I know, I know, whatever) were very tasty, covered in toppings, including absolutely phenomenally seasoned strips of steak that were nearly perfect. If that's what they're putting on the nachos, I can only imagine what the actual entree is like. I had a sort of chicken cordon bleu sandwich with a nicely cook breaded piece of chicken paired with ham and gouda on a delicious Italian style roll. Just awesome.The beer list is above average, but not particularly spectacular. That said, the craft beer choices they do have are some very good ones, with a solid selection on tap and even more in the bottle. The highlight is their house weiss which is apparently brewed by none other than Warrenville's Two Brothers, so you'd be better believe it's good.So after months of waiting for this place to open, I was prepared to be disappointed. How could the actual place live up to my expectations. Well, they lived up to those expectations and then some. Give it a shot, and let's give this place the business it deserves.
<review# 810,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/20/2012,9/2/2012,280,274,6,14,13>DON'T DO IT.I KNOW YOU WANT TO DO IT, BUT DON'T DO IT. STOP YOURSELF.You've probably already done and you don't even realize it.Don't compare A Toda Madre to Bien Trucha.These are two very different restaurants with completely different styles of cuisine. The only thing in common between the two restaurants is the fact that both are operated by the same team/ownership.Bien Trucha is quite simply a finished masterpiece. It's reached a point of near perfection and you can't improve upon perfection. It's the same challenge Chefs run into with Signature Dishes. Legions of fans crave...demand encore performances...of that one hit dish. The Chef Artist becomes a slave to this. What does a Chef do in this scenario?He opens a new business that enables him to showcase the diversity of his/her talent. Every artist must evolve his/her craft; cooking is no different.A Toda Madre is a work in progress; it's the Artist's new project. The restaurant is also based on small plates/shared plates style of dining. There is a great list of Craft Beers and House Cocktails. The cuisine is best described as comfort food inspired by Mexican flavors and ingredients. It reminds me of some of my favorite restaurants in Chicago: Avec, Gilt Bar, Girl & The Goat, and the Purple Pig. Here's what we had:Barbarita Cocktail (Really refreshing blend of citrus, spice, and rum)Bread with Chile Morita Butter (Good but I would recommend saving appetite for other delicious items)Smoked Trout Tostadas (Delicious mix of smoked trout, fresh cabbage slaw, and crunchy tortilla)Masa Cornbread Flatbread (Good savory flavors and a good option to share) Meatballs with Tomato Chipotle Sauce (Easily my favorite dish! Moist & flavorful)Chile Relleno (Gooey melted cheese and roasted pepper and sauce hits the spot)We were pretty full at this point. I definitely want to try the Pork Belly Burrito and one of the Large Plate Specials.The check will be the same as Bien Trucha ($35-50 per person with tax, tip, drinks). The service is very friendly and professional. The space is very cool; it's a cozy cafe/bar with two levels. There is plenty of natural light when the sun is still out and the space feels nice and open.I know you think "he's just making excuses; trying to find reasons to like A Toda Madre." But let me leave you with this.......................If Bien Trucha didn't exist, then how f---in stoked would you be to have a restaurant like A Toda Madre open up in downtown Geneva?Maybe that is why they named it A Toda Madre...We need more local restaurants like this.I'm looking forward to gong back soon.

<review# 812,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/30/2012,8/31/2012,209,310,6,7,7>Okay, people.... this is one of the Chicago suburbs' best kept secrets, for oh so many reasons.  My friend had mentioned someone had brought these empanadas into her work but she missed trying them because they were gone before she could get her hands on one.  She had been asking me for awhile to go here.  Now I love a good empanada, don't get me wrong.  I have eaten some good cuban ones in Logan Park.  But EmpanadUS puts a whole new spin on things.  The place is a pick it up and go, unless you get lucky to eat at one of the two tables, which we did, which was good, because 2 were not enough-- we had to go back and get another.  Anyway, I started with a chicken and a mushroom.  My favorite was the chicken.  It was like excellently seasoned, crispy and flaky and piping hot.  How do they keep them piping hot in that display case without getting hard????  Must be the right amount of moisture or something scientific like that.  Anyway, the mushroom was tasty, I am a huge fan of mushrooms.  I went back and got the spinach and was in veggie heaven.  Okay, so the best thing about this place is obivs the empanadas themselves.  But they also have this chimi-churri sauce.... I could not get enough of it.  Literally.  Embarrassingly so, I made 4 trips to the counter to grab another spoonful (community style serve yourself).  They sell this, by the way.  Small or large.  Lastly, another one of the awesome things about this place is the owners.   The two owners, brothers from Argentina, get my vote (yes, both of them), for hottest men of the year.  Dang.  Excellent customer service and super friendly.  So, as much as I hate to give up a well-loved secret, I think this little restaurant deserves kudos!!!
<review# 813,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/20/2012,8/30/2012,178,365,6,10,7>Things I care about (in order of importance):1.  Craft beer2.  Food3.  ServicePrice and ambiance don't even come in to the equation.  I will pay more money for good beer and good food, and as long as there's not roaches crawling on me, I'm cool.  With that in mind, Lunar is DEFINITELY the best bar in this neighborhood.  They have a pretty amazing craft beer list and they even brew some of their own beers (which I wasn't a HUGE fan of...reviews to follow).  Food is non-existent here...which sucks because I get hungry when I'm chugging down pints.  The service was good...you actually have to go to the bar to get your drinks, but luckily, it was during the day and dead in there so we got our beers quickly and with a smile.  As for the Lunar taps I tried, all of them tasted obviously home brewed.  What I mean is, they are unfiltered (which is not usually a bad thing, but these seemed to be extra cloudy), have a strong grain taste, have additional ingredients that may or may not meld smoothly with the rest of the beer's ingredients, and are not as balanced as most craft brews (at least in the malt vs. hops).Lunar Moondust White IPA-  This was an okay IPA but my gripe here (besides the stuff listed above) is that it tasted like a strong wheat beer with some hops thrown in.  It was just too strong on the clove and banana notes for me.  Lunar Apollo American Red Ale-  This was the best beer on the Lunar taps.  VERY strong grain taste, but good hops to balance it out.Lunar Summer Solstice Wit-  NO.  Just no.  I tried my friend's beer to see what the issue was as she was wincing with every drink and this beer was just downright gross.  It smelled terrible and tasted like there was dill in it.  I don't know if it was the coriander or what, but it was not good.  I hate hatin' on people's home brews as I know how hard it is to make something worth drinking.  (I'm still not there yet.)  BUT, if you are going to serve it to the public, I guess I'd expect it to be a little more refined.  Point is, stick with the guest taps or bottled list here and you'll be happy.  And if you want to try a home tap, ask for a sample first.
<review# 814,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/20/2012,8/29/2012,92,197,13,13,12>Okay, ask anyone, I love a good wiener.That is to say a great hot dog.It has to meet my criteria: all beef, a good size, and Chicago condiments. Preferably Vienna Beef.Let me break it down.I am a young girl, my father is an outside salesman. I go on sales calls with him in the evening, me our small dog and his El Camino. We ply our wares in communities that surround River Grove.It is 11 p.m. on a Wednesday night sometime in my childhood. We speed past Gene and Judes on our way home on River Road. My father pulls a u'ee on Grand and asks if I want a hot dog.And so it begins.I remember that first night in the white tiled interior of G&J. A heavily tattooed man with a mustache served me my dog, wrapped in white paper with fresh cut fries and orange drink. I bit in to the dog, it snapped back as only an all beef frank could with its heavenly mustard dripping onto the fries. I was enchanted and Gene and Judes was embedded as part of the story of my life.As a teen, I would make my young boyfriends search ceaselessly as we drove around the winding roads of a suburb that I couldn't remember the name of in search of that hot dog place I remembered from my childhood.As a young women, I would be nourished after a night of drinking and a good, or not so good date that only included pretzels at Hala Kahiki.As a mother, my boys and I would wait 1 hour in line after a soccer game on a Saturday afternoon, to receive the ultimate hot dog nirvana.And so it had begun.Someday soon at 2 a.m. you may see my spawn searching in the area of Grand and River roads with a youthful and (hopefully) attractive companion dying to find the fabled hot dog place.Blessings to you and all of your followers Gene and Jude's. And, if you run into the mustached man tell him that a cute little blond sent you.

Whether it's meat, seafood, tofu, or veggies, it's simply to die for. And deserves the recognition it has received. The menu is limited to sandwiches, a few sides, a handful of salads, and a few weekly specials. Have no fear...there's definitely something here that will make you all giddy inside. And with fresh ingredients nonetheless!After much deliberation, I opted to go for the Veggie Tempura Teriyaki sandwich, that was loaded with tempura veggies and baby greens, doused in teriyaki sauce. I devoured that little sammy like it was my last meal. It was phenomenal. I loved that it contained more veggies and greens than heavy tempura breading. The sweetness of the teriyaki sauce complemented the veggies nicely. I loved that the side of cucumber salad had a hint of red onion and jalapeno to spice it up. Also, delish. My seafood eating half went for the Spicy Garlic Shrimp Sandwich which had fried shrimp, crunchy garlic, arugula, cilantro, and homemade spicy mayo. The mayo def had a kick to it, so for someone like me who is somewhat of a sissy when it comes to spicy food, I thought it was slightly much. However, he also ate it like it was his last meal on earth and is still raving about it. I'm not a huge fan of cole slaw, but decided to go with the gingerslaw for his side. Although I didn't sense a strong ginger presence, it was one of the few slaws I've actually enjoyed and didn't want to immediately spit it out.For dessert, there were beautifully wrapped bags of toffee sitting on the counter and I couldn't resist. We ended up bringing home a bag of the Lavender Sea Salt Toffee and the Espresso Toffee. If I wasn't diabetic, both of those bags would have been eaten by now. ((Damn pancreas)).The service was amazing. For not being "fast food", our sandwiches came out within a matter of minutes. The staff made sure we were happy without our food and wanted to make sure we had a pleasant experience. The guy who took our order also made great recommendations and was happy to answer my 1.2 million questions.While we were there, I also picked up a punch card. Buy 9 Zenwiches and get your 10th for free. The only word I can think of to describe this is the over-used "winning." But seriously, winning!! In just a few trips, we'll be getting a Zenwich just for being a loyal customer.Zenwich is tiny and doesn't offer a ton of seating, so if you leave near by and it's during the busy lunch/dinner rushes, taking your order to go or opting for delivery isn't a bad idea! I love the concept of Asian flavors on ciabatta bread. The fusion of the two created this perfect little place called Zenwich. I absolutely love it and can't wait to get back. I'm determined to try just about every sandwich on their menu. Nomz.

<review# 818,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/15/2012,8/25/2012,57,59,6,9,3>Well, I'm all sorts of screwed.  I'm a huge cupcake fanatic and would have one every day, but have lucked out since my favorite store (Sweet Mandy B's) is too far away and the local store (Sugar Monkeys) is absolutely ghastly.So when I saw the "Coming Soon" banner go up for Miss Joan's, I've waited with barely hidden anticipation and just a little concern over the welfare of my already fragile dieting program.Once the 'Open' sign flickered on, me and the significant other were in. First thought: The store decor is adorable. It's what you expect a cupcake shop to look like, but the bright colors and clean counters really make the place sparkle. The ceiling tiles are custom swirl patterns that really make the shop unique. After I voiced this to the owner's husband, he lovingly (and a little sheepishly) recounted how they cut and installed the tiles all by themselves. Gotta love owners who put their heart (and their backs!) into every aspect of their stores.But you don't really care about the decor, do you? So let's talk taste. Miss Joan's does specialty cupcakes very well, but the basics leave a little to be desired. When it comes to specialty cupcakes, holy moly, are the Smores and Carrot Cake cupcakes good! Miss Joan's cream cheese frosting is among the best I've tasted and the spices in the actual cake itself is to die for. I love old-school carrot cake mixes that have the raisins in them and Miss Joan makes a mean old-school Carrot Cake mix. The Smores cupcake is basically a gift from god - moist chocolate cake with a graham cracker bottom, topped with toasted marshmallow fluff. Yum!But Miss Joan's doesn't particularly shine on basic cupcakes - I love me a good vanilla cake and butter cream frosting cupcake, and here they dropped the ball. The cake was sorta bland and the icing decent, but just not sweet enough. Still, the other cupcakes we had were so good that I'm sure that Miss Joan's is still getting their sea-legs and that the basic cupcake recipes will improve.Also, I know that they are in the process of training new bakers, but they *really* need to have more cupcakes. They usually sell out and close down the shop by 6:30 - 7:00 pm, which when you're getting off to work and need a cupcake fix, is a bummer.

<review# 820,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/30/2012,8/23/2012,29,80,8,12,11>I'm not going to write about The Corner House's opening night, which was a triumph by all accounts. Of course it would be great. Any reason to un-roll the sidewalks in downtown Lombard is worth heralding.I decided to return on a dreary Monday afternoon, when the excitement would be gone and I could get a good feel for the place. And it feels very, very good.Jerome (the manager) suggested a new drink to me, one with coffee, two types of chocolate and latte, and not surprisingly, it was terrific. Hoping for a bite to eat, I got a pastrami on rye which was just okay, but I won't ding them on it because that's not why smart people will come here. They'll come because of the decor, which is amazing when you consider how bleak the site looked just three months ago. They'll come because of the fine selection of coffee, tea, smoothies and desserts, along with whatever else the enthusiastic ownership and staff creates. They'll come because downtown Lombard NEEDS a place like this, where you are greeted with warmth and smiles (from Cloe and James, among others whose names are unknown to me for now) on an unpleasant Monday afternoon.It appears that no expense was spared in re-developing the location. Everything adds to the cosiness of the place: the lighting, the photography on the walls, the counter, the colors... and I really like the bathroom. Low-brow, I know, but not only is the bathroom as appealing as a bathroom can be, the men's toilet offers two different volumes of flushes depending on why you were there, if you catch my drift. How cool is that? Some comfy seating was available, but I sat at the very big table because it was empty; it seems strange to have a such a rectangular table with nine chairs in a coffee house, but hopefully Lombardians who don't know each other will be more willing to share the table with relative strangers and find some commonality, as my wife and I did with Deb on Saturday. This afternoon, I sat alone and looked out the clean windows to my downtown, struggling like so many other downtowns. Only one block away from the train station, there are still some open store fronts to be seen, but through The Corner House's windows, my town didn't seem so hopeless. I like to think that a renaissance is starting for the Lilac Village, and it's starting here. Not only will live music be offered on a regular basis, but a weekly open mike will be coming soon and I'll be eager to sign up. Outside seating is planned, and it'll be put to good use, once Mother Nature makes the prospect more desirable. Just as in hubs of vibrant central business districts, perhaps other community events can be conceived and nurtured, and maybe I'll daydream on how this little corner of the world that I call home is growing again.For those of you that want more out of Lombard, this is it! Don't pass it by. A lot of money and hope was invested in this business. It's time for the many bored suburbanites, trying to find our version of Hemingway's "clean, well-lighted place," to prove that it was a wise investment. Let's do it together at the big table with some inspired cups of goodness.

<review# 822,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/12/2012,8/21/2012,175,170,7,7,7>Let me preface this review by saying this is my first professional massage ever.  This has to be one of the best bargains in the history of massages.  $28 for a "foot" massage that is a full body.  You MUST be able to handle some serious pressure and I have no idea if you tell the receptionist that you'd like it lighter they would do it lighter or not.  I personally have a very high pain tolerance and love a serious ass kicking when it comes to a neck rub.  My wife cannot put enough pressure without her feeling like she is going to break something.  I had a kink in my neck for the last couple weeks.  Since I have always been skeptical of massages in general, and when my wife goes somewhere it costs an arm and a leg, I was hesitant to go and get one.  We went on vacation last week and I considered it beforehand and didn't go, then again while we were on vaca because I coughed the morning we left and it just threw my whole body out of whack.  I never had the chance to go while we were out of town for a wedding just due to the schedule of a wedding weekend when one is in the bridal party.  I finally went today, two days after we returned, and I am so happy I did.  It's a solid hour long and they get you everywhere.  I know people have commented about people not being certified, but this girl knew what she was doing.  I officially feel normal again.  It was so nice, I'm considering going back later this week and adding a half hour to get to 1.5 hours.  I believe its only an extra $14.  Seriously, at .50 cents a minute, this is a fantabulous deal.  I tipped the girl $10, so it came out to be $38.  Well worth it.  My neck finally feels normal again.  I told the girl up front this was my first massage ever (at the end when I paid, not any of that pre-pay BS I've read about at other massage places) and she asked, "Why?!?"  I totally get it now.  Phew, what a relief to not feel like I'm carrying a bag of bricks around on my shoulders.  The ambiance was really nice also.  Running water just flowing away.  Soothing music doing what soothing music does.  Just nice and relaxing.  Oh, and the boiling hot water that my feet sat in for the first 20 minutes felt fantastic as well.  Not sure how they keep it so hot, but it was wonderful.  If you can't handle a little pain and some great pressure from a massage then maybe this isn't the place for you, but if you can deal with it then this is one of the best values in town.  I think you can see from the 1-star reviews and the 5-star reviews that some people just can't deal with that kind of heavy-handed work and some people can.  And when it comes to Chinese labor, I'm wondering if "Customer E." is rocking an iPhone or wearing a shirt made in China because those things are just as bad if not worse if you are so socially conscious.  I, on the other hand, have an iPhone, iPad, macbook, apple tv and 2 apple routers, so....I think you know where I stand on Chinese labor.  What can I say, they make a great product.  I think you'd be pleasantly surprised for a $28 "foot" massage.
<review# 823,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/20/2012,8/20/2012,31,287,11,8,8>For a special dinner, my wife and I dined at Seasons 475. Oops, I mean Seasons 52. Each item on their menu is less than 475 calories and they change seasons 4 times a year. Dang it, I messed up again. Their menu is seasonal and changes 52 times a year. I get confused with all of the numbers. I was forewarned that the entrees were smaller than what you may be used to. I ordered the venison chop that was served with a mushroom ragu, asparagus, and mashed potatoes in truffle oil. Since everything on the menu was light in calories, my wife and I ordered two appetizers, two entrees, and two desserts. I was eating "right" and loving it. This was the kind of diet that I can commit to. Eating right and enjoying food at Seasons 475, I mean 52.
<review# 824,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/3/2012,8/19/2012,850,1294,8,16,9>Euro Grill is all grown up!They used to be located at another small shopping strip in Des Plaines, but a couple years ago they closed down (as did Chef's Corner in Naperville) and I couldn't get Cevapi in the Suburbs. I had to trek it all the way to Chicago. And you're probably thinking, "Tough shit," right? My Grandpa's response to saying meat was overcooked and tough was always, "It's tougher where there isn't any." Well, for about a year there wasn't a single Cevapi place within 20 miles of home. Let's just say that was a very dark time for me.Euro Grill is now located in Rayyan Plaza III, which is a small shopping center on the east side of Elmhurst Rd between Algonquin & Dempster. If you blink you might miss it, but I hope you find it. It's definitely worth it. Everything has been upgraded. I liked the old place because it was small and cozy; however, the newer place is bright and open. They have tons of seating now and the menu has expanded a little bit.The food could be described as "Balkan's Best." They have Cevapi, which are seasoned minced meat sausages served atop a pillowy Lepinja (fluffy Balkan pita-style bread) with a side of diced onions, tomatoes and Kajmak (a buttery sour spread). You can also get Pljeskavica (Balkan-style Burger) or a stuffed Pljeskavica with cheese. If you can't make up your mind then go with Mijesano Meso (Mixed Meat). If you want something a little less messy then you can grab yourself a meat-filled Burek (filo dough stuffed with spiced ground beef). Maybe meat isn't your thing, but have no fear! The Cheese Burek will do the trick. You also have Pasulj (Bean Soup) or Sopska Salata (onion, tomato, cucumber salad) topped with Feta cheese. Another option is the Cabbage Salad or fresh French Fries (ask them to top the fries with Feta!).As you can see, it's not an extensive menu, but it's really all you need to know when it comes to basic Balkan dishes. If you can believe it, the old menu was much smaller. The prices are decent and you can lose a few hours there sipping Turkish coffee, beer or Fructal fruit juices. I highly recommend finishing the meal off with a Baklava or Tulumba (honey-soaked baked treat).

<review# 835,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/22/2012,8/8/2012,4,51,4,3,4>Went here for the first time tonight, and was pleasantly surprised. For a hidden strip mall Thai place, Siri Thai isn't that bad. They were quite busy for a Friday night, with both phones ringing off the hook when I arrived to pick up the meal I'd phoned in about 20 minutes earlier. No complaints there..the food was ready when I arrived. However, both phones had to be attended, so my food sat off to the side for awhile while the person ordering tried to convey their order and make sure it was understood. They apparently wanted to make sure that they got their name precisely right (to that idiotic person--was there going to be a spelling bee for the hostess with your name as a word tomorrow??? Do what I do when ordering take out and someone mispronounces your name--just go with it! It's a little fun, and you're not tying up other people's time for something that doesn't matter too much.About the food...It made it home still warm and so I dug in right away. The portion sizes are the usual for most Thai or Chinese restaurants--large enough for a day and a half of leftovers. The Hot Chili Garlic Shrimp was very tasty and spicy. Probably a little too spicy for most people, but I liked it. It was spicy enough to make the lips and tongue tingle, but not spicy enough to make me run for a glass of milk. Surprisingly, the shrimp hadn't had time to absorb most of the flavors of the dish, and so wasn't the centerpiece of the dish. The eggplant chunks were firm, but had absorbed most of the flavors perfectly. I could almost eat a whole dish of eggplant stewed in any of their delicious sauces after this evening's meal.The ginger beef was a good mix of flavors, but there was a heavy reliance on big slices of onion as a major portion of this dish. The flavor was great, and the sauce will  sure taste terrific over the leftover rice tomorrow, but after the excess onions are dealt with.The restaurant itself had kind of a kitschy feel to it with all the knickknacks for sale right inside the doorway, but this added to the quizzical charm of the place. I'm not quite sure how the $90 bronze golfer right inside the doorway or the miniature 1950s gas pump sitting off to the side got mixed in with all the other items that were a little more related to Thailand's history and culture, but I'm sure they could provide an excellent conversation starter!

<review# 838,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/30/2012,8/5/2012,176,176,5,7,7>If you grew up on Mexican food like I did, you may sense a feeling of nostalgia from the food when dining at Poblano Pepper Grill. To me, the flavor and texture of the entree I ordered was almost like a home cooked meal: maybe not too fancy, but made with heart.I stopped in for lunch one afternoon and ordered the Chicken Enchiladas Suizas (with green sauce) which came with beans and rice. The corn tortillas had a slight crispness on the edges, kind of like when I've quick fried my corn tortillas at home to soften them up before filling and rolling them into enchiladas. The green sauce wasn't spicy at all, but that was okay. The Spanish rice had peas and a few small, cubed potatoes mixed in. The refried beans were okay. They appeared to be made from black beans, too dark to be pinto beans.The chips that were served before the meal appeared to be deep fried in-house (a little greasy). The red sauce was thin (versus chunky) and had a good flavor, but not spicy. And their guacamole was pretty good, obviously made fresh that day. I'll probably order more next time.So these few taste combinations were initially what made me think of homemade food. But the warm feeling came when the owner stopped at my table and introduced herself. She asked how the food was and how I was doing. A very kind hearted woman with a smile who seemed genuinely interested in making sure her food met with approval. Before I left, she thanked me a few times for coming in and invited me back again.You can usually tell when someone is just being courteous versus when someone is genuinely appreciative of your visit to their establishment. I left feeling good. So this may not be the best Mexican food you've ever had, but the home cooked flavor and interaction with the owner is what sold me on my first impression of this place. I love local mom and pop shops for this very reason.Next time, I'll probably ask for their recommendation on a hotter, spicier entree.
