The owner was also very friendly and made sure everything we got was to our liking. The value here is also great costing less then half the price of Texas de Brazil. I look forward to eating here again soon.

<review# 846,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/12/2012,7/27/2012,273,603,7,11,8>My family makes homemade tamales. It's tradition, everyone has an assigned task and we follow my grandma's recipe. It was probably her grandma's recipe, but I never asked. The prep takes days and we spend an entire day as a family spreading the masa, filling and rolling each one and steaming them to perfection.  We use very fancy, specialized tamale making equipment including the large metal baby bathtub, giant pots with lids that don't quite fit anymore and old coffee cups. Don't ask...I couldn't make the family tamales without these things. So, when I walked into Hot Tamale Cucina, I wasn't expecting much more than a 'corn roll' resembling those you find at the local hot dog joint. Boy, was I wrong!!!After being open for only a week, I wandered in at lunchtime. It's clean and bright and the place was packed. Good signs so far!  They are pretty smart. There is a carryout menu stand at eye level on the left hand side as soon as you walk in, so you can peruse the menu immediately. The issue for me is that the daily tamale varieties are hand written on a small dry erase board on the wall near the register. Since the eight types of tamales change daily, I get the dry erase thing, but I felt like the tamales weren't getting a respectable introduction. Go ahead, give me a hard time...I can deal with it. Do you know how much work goes into making just one tamale?  A ton!  The place is even named after the coveted corn husk wrapped deliciousness!  Anyhow, I usually avoid cheese and was slightly disappointed that all eight options included cheese that day. I did ask and they do have choices without cheese, just not that day. Well, I can't visit Hot Tamale Cucina without a tamale. Even if it had cheese. So I ordered a carnitas and pepper jack (I think) tamale, a grilled fish taco and a grilled chicken taco to go. I waited a few short minutes (and signed up for text alerts while waiting) and before I knew it, my order was ready. The gal packing up my order was very nice and asked if I wanted the red or green salsa. Hmmm. I didn't know and kinda wanted to try both. No problem. She gave me both. When I opened the bag of freshly made Mexican yumminess, I found two tamales wrapped together as one. Score!!!  A nice surprise. They included plastic utensils and recycled napkins. Here is my take on my lunch...Go for the green!  Loved the green salsa on everything that I tried. The red was fine, but very mild and kinda boring. The grilled fish was perfect!  Seasoned nicely. It was a nice piece of fish instead of a chopped up mess. I was impressed. The chicken was also seasoned well and juicy. Thanks for not cooking it to smithereens!The tamales. Oh, the tamales!  I don't care that there was cheese mixed in. They are doing things just right. Using a real corn husk to wrap each one, I know that these were steamed properly for cooking. There was plenty of meat inside and the spice was just right. More of a hint which was appreciated. I controlled it by adding some green salsa. In short. Go for the tamales and stay for the fish tacos.

I LOVED my bridal suite. There was a cute desk, some seating, my own bathroom, and a window with an escape route if I didn't feel like getting married...We had our ceremony outdoors in the gazebo, with about 100 chairs set up for the guests. The aisle was a long, winding path through the trees towards the gazebo. Afterwards, everyone mingled on patio of the house for drinks while we took photos in the new pavilion. (I have to note, the pavilion was not yet built when we reserved the place, and we were really excited to have it available for our wedding!) We squeezed about 80 guests into two rooms and the loft of the house for the dinner. The rest of the night was in the pavilion, dancing. All of our guests were raving about what a great place we had picked! Everyone enjoyed using all the spaces that were available, as well as being able to roam around the grounds. I couldn't have asked for a better place for our wedding. We only had a seven-hour block for the wedding + dinner so we wanted to use every moment we had! Music being turned down early and lights being shut off were not cool. This, however, was the only downside to this place.One of my friends is getting married here later this year (on the exact date I would have wanted if we choose a winter wedding). I have no idea if I will be attending the wedding, but I'm excited to accompany her on trips to the Grove to re-live my wedding memories.

<review# 863,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/19/2011,7/10/2012,107,399,4,9,7>One of those understated and little known Chinese restaurants. It has a nice classy modern interior with interesting special rooms for groups. The service is excellent and they fill your water frequently while doing little things that make the experience better such as giving you warm hot towels to wipe your hands before the meal or offering to pack part of your meal during your dining experience if you order a lot. They also speak both Cantonese and Mandarin.I did not try any of their Japanese items but the quality of the authentic Chinese dishes surprised me. They weren't only excellent in comparison to other suburban Chinese restaurants, they were excellent even in comparison to Chinatown (although I hope they expand the choices further in the future).The Taiwanese beef noodle soup had a rich broth with very tenderly prepared beef brisket and delicious handmade noodles (also available at Yu's Mandarin or Chef Ping).The double pan fried noodle was crispy was generous amounts of seafood and a light but tasty sauce.Lu's noodle soup comes with pork, seafood, and vegetables. I ordered the non-spicy version and it was still very light and tasty with all the right proportion of ingredients.The Peking style pork was crispy with a sweet and sour sauce. It could have been a bit better with a deep fry batter and slightly thicker sauce but it was still a solid choice.The Dong Po pork was extremely fatty and tasty. Really made with a very authentic preparation in mind. It is not like the one from iChef in Hoffman Estates. It is nearly identical to the version from Golden Harbor in Champaign except even softer. It's not on the menu but truly worth ordering (it takes at least 20 minutes to prepare though).Although this restaurant is quite a distance further than I usually drive from my house for dining, it is well worth the travel both for the atmosphere and the food.

We must have seemed like secret shoppers because we ordered wine, appetizers (frog legs), the most expensive special (rabbit), savory crepes, and dessert (mousse). Start to finish the food and service were impeccable and timely. As I said, the whole experience was fantastic. The restaurant is more on the high end side, and it's a little pricey, but you do get what you pay for. If you're looking for a location that will make your night, definitely give this place a try. Personally, I can't wait to go back!

<review# 868,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/6/2011,7/5/2012,78,284,5,6,7>This is an interesting place, but I'm a fan. It's a weird mix between nice Italian restaurant and dive bar/towny restaurant, if that makes sense.First, I'll review the restaurant. When you walk in the door, don't stand there like an idiot waiting for someone to seat you (that's what I did my first time and everyone was staring at me). You have to go up to the counter and someone will seat you from there. The food is really good. The cheeseburger sliders are awesome. They kind of taste like butterburgers but they are really delicious. I have yet to try their pasta or pizza, but I'm sure it's good. They really know how to cook their food well. Their chicken parmasan is great. They know how to bread it well so that you're not eating all bread and no chicken. I would also recommend getting the sandwich version of this. You will not regret it. My dad didn't like their ribs, but c'mon, who orders ribs at an Italian restaurant?  Now the bar. I go here for Thursday night football since the bar has NFL network (score!). You can eat dinner at the bar instead of the restaurant. They have about 10 beers on tap and a full bar. As far as the environment? If you didn't know that it was part of Tree Guys, you would think this is a regular dive bar, and I guess it is. A lot of locals come here. There are also the usual drinking-since-10am guys who like to argue with fans of opposing teams, just for the hell of it. Who argues a Jets/Broncos game? Townies. It's funny to hear. If you want to sit, it may be difficult to find seats, but they'll free up eventually. I've seen kids here too. I don't really think you should bring kids to a bar, especially for their birthday, but hey, do what you gotta do. Overall, this place is good. Just don't go to the bar for a nice cocktail. For that, go sit in the restaurant.
<review# 869,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/23/2012,7/4/2012,144,959,12,14,12>Some things change but fortunately stay the same, Mitchell's is luckily one of those places.  Growing up in the south suburbs, Mitchell's was a destination place for ice cream.  It was a cut above the normal treat or baseball win destination.  It was ice cream with panache!  I carried the tradition on with my own children but may have lowered the bar for what merited a trip to Mitchells's.  (It's Tuesday, yippee, let's go to Mitchell's.)After I moved to Frankfort, I went back to Homewood less and there was a Mitchell's in Mokena for a while.  But those hot fudge sundaes have been calling my name lately and I have been answering the call.Why?  Because they literally have the best hot fudge sundae I have ever tasted and believe me, I have tasted a lot.  They serve the hot fudge in a darling mini glass pitcher and it's all hot, runny and darkly delicious.  You get to pour it on yourself so you never get to a disappointing bottom with all ice cream and no hot fudge.  They also have decadent candy that I only allow myself to buy a single piece at a time.The same here is the taste, the care and the ambiance.  The change is that this great establishment was purchased by and is operated by the Bravo Food Corporation of Chicago so there are no worries that it will go out of business.  They even offer frozen cartons of their ice cream at Sweet Mandy B's in Chicago because of a relationship the Bravo Corp has with that bakery.  Change with stability, I'll eat to that.  Let's make it a hot fudge sundae!
<review# 870,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/15/2012,7/3/2012,123,246,10,13,10>Beer snobbery without the snobbery. If I had to sum Bigby's up in a sentence, that would be it.It was a Saturday night and there were only 2 people serving the busy bar and floor but they were quick and efficient and very friendly. Both gave great suggestions and I ended up ordering a beer flight while my wife chose the wine flight. The list of beers are staggering and I simply told the bartender I was overwhelmed and would like him to choose for me after telling him my preferences. Same for my wife. We were both happy with the variety we received as well as portion.They only have craft beer and wine so if you're looking for cheap PBR beer specials then don't bother. If you didn't know so many beers existed outside of the MIller/Anheuser Busch world and are willing to try beer that actually tastes like something then this is the spot to get your taste on. The bartender is extremely knowledgeable and friendly. Just give him a vague idea of what you like and he can whip up a sample that is sure to please you with variety within your preferences. After 15 minutes of sipping, we worked up the munchies so they suggested we try the melted goat cheese as a tasty nibbler that is easily shared. Melted goat cheese in marinara sauce served with bite sized wedges of toasted, seasoned pita bread sent us both to taste bud heaven. It really was the perfect combination with our drinks. I knew it was good when we finished the dish and I wanted to order another one.Don't you hate places that play obnoxiously loud music so that you have to scream at people just to be heard? Me too and Bigby's does a fine job of keeping the volume to the perfect level so that you can still hear it above the din but it's not intrusive. Lighting is slightly dim and comfortable seating, such as couches, are available for a perfect evening of kicking back and enjoying life without some straight billed hat and Affliction shirt wearing d-bag screaming jager bombs next to you. People here are mature but not necessarily old. Just plain comfortable is the best way to explain the ambiance here.Thanks to Cristie B. and Jelena Z. for the reviews that led me to this great find! I'll be making a trip back here as often as possible.

<review# 873,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/20/2012,6/30/2012,325,653,12,27,21>If only SaiGon Pho & Cafe had been my first experience with pho! Eh, but I guess firsts aren't always all they're hyped up to be. Kind of like wine. My first taste of wine was definitely less than exciting. I wondered, "Why would anybody drink this?" and now I've got more of a taste for it. I think the same has happened with pho, only much faster thanks to SaiGon Pho.SaiGon Pho really doesn't look like anything impressive on the outside. It's in a strip nestled among other small shops and practices. It has a neon sign that is reminiscent of an 80's child's light bright. I've been aware of SaiGon Pho for a long time, but was never tempted to try it until I had such a sordid pho experience elsewhere. I needed to resurrect my belief in good (cooked) food and SaiGon Pho did that with flare.A young man eagerly greeted me as soon as I came through the door. It was as if he'd been waiting for me and as if it was his job to ensure my personal happiness. My happiness was his happiness. He sat me at a table near the front window and brought me ginger tea that was delicate, spicy, and slightly sweetened.My friend and I used Yelp reviews to determine our orders - we hardly had to look at the menu. We ordered the vegetable spring rolls to start; then I got SaiGon Pho with meatballs and flank steak and my friend got the same only with no meatballs. Everything was delivered by a man who seemed to be genuinely kind and proud of his food. He patiently explained what everything was and how to assemble and eat it. He gestured to the plate between our HUGE bowls of pho and said that it was loaded with garnishes, but that we could also add some of the sauces that were already on the table. He was amused that we thought that the servings of pho were so large because they have an even LARGER bowl!The pho was really delicious. I enjoyed adding different amounts of garnishes and sauces. My friend liked hers spicy and then she munched on the crunchy bean sprouts. I liked picking basil leaves off of the stem and adding them to my soup. It was absolutely delicious. Noodles flicked broth on my chin as I slurped them with chop sticks. My friend somehow managed with a spoon.To be honest though, the vegetable spring rolls were the best. I've never had anything like that before. The exterior was a chewy rice paper with fresh vegetables and rice on the inside. My favorite attribute was the tempura nestled the length of the roll, lending a tantalizing crunch and savoriness to the freshness of the vegetables.When we finished our food, the same man offered to package our remaining pho and he carefully wrote our names on each container so that they would not be confused. He also gave us papaya flavored candies to enjoy while musing over the bill. Even though we had the bill, and the place had a healthy bustle for a weekday evening, we were allowed to enjoy our ginger tea and chat a bit longer. We only left when we felt like it and were encouraged to return again soon.What a lovely, delicious place.
<review# 874,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/18/2012,6/29/2012,45,72,5,8,5>Eurofresh is a small, crazy busy, store with everything you need for a great price!It is busy for good reason; the prices, the produce, the deli, and the bakery!  You can get some amazing deals on fresh produce and the deli is fantastic but a bit on the smaller side.  The bakery is again small but has amazing Italian cookies and other fantastic baked goods.  With that being said if you go into Eurofresh you have to know what you are getting yourself in for.  If you shop here, plan on going to the store more than once a week.  The produce lasts a week at best and almost everything is ripe when you buy it.   I used to go to Eurofresh for three reasons;1) It is on my way home from work2) Whole Wheat Pitas - 10 for $1.293) Tribe/Athenos Hummus sale - 2 for $3 or even the super rare 1 for $1 (Yeah I buy 10 or more when they are on sale)Then I would go to Dominicks or Jewel for the rest of my groceries and random other needs.  Then I realized that shopping at a produce driven store was better for my budget and my stomach.  There are always sales on the produce, eggs, and some random baked goods but other things like ice cream, boxed items, and other processed foods are extra expensive.  This makes me want to buy more produce and avoid the processed food.  Now that I only shop at Eurofresh my food bill is so much cheaper and I end up eat healthier, what is not to like about that?

<review# 877,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/14/2012,6/26/2012,54,226,3,10,4>So I've been to The Lucky Monk about a dozen more times since I wrote my first review and I can say, without any embellishment or fanfare, that it is my favorite restaurant in the northwest suburbs, bar none.First the burgers:I've tried The Monk, Peppercorn Ranch, Bourbon Stout, Smothered, Grilled Cheese & Green Chile Queso Burgers, and they are all just gorgeous. Beautifully plated and always cooked perfectly medium rare, they are all winners, but especially the ones that rely on the strengths of the burger as opposed to bursts of flavor from its toppings.  Thus the Monk Burger (Tillamook Cheddar + pickle), Bourbon Stout (Tillamook Cheddar + stout braised onions + pickle) & the Smothered (caramelized sweet onions + Gruyere + pickle) really excel, with the proteins taking center stage.Then the beers:The Lucky Monk is a brewpub and you won't find their beer in any local stores, which is unfortunate because it's pretty damn good. I prefer fruitier, less hoppy, fuller bodied ales and stouts and so I tend to consistently order their Solitude Oatmeal Stout, Gra'le, and Tritica Wheat Ale when I want something particularly sweet.  I'll admit I'm not a big fan of their other regulars, but their seasonals have so far been above par, from the powerful Bourbon stout to the refreshing Maibock.  They also have multiple guest taps that trend pretty good.Don't forget the sides:The Lucky Monk's secret weapon has to be its sides. The burgers and beer may get you in the door, but don't even pretend it's not the truffle fries, sweet potato fries, fried pickles or chicken poblano chili that are keeping you here. The sides are nothing short of miracles in potato/chicken/soup form, and that's not even counting the appetizers (giant pretzels with three kinds of sauces perhaps, or maybe deep fried cheese curds yes please?)And just for funsies I've ordered or tasted many of the other menu items including the butternut squash ravioli, fish tacos, al pastor pizza, apple-bacon flatbread & BBQ pulled pork sandwich. They've all generally been hits over misses (the pizza's a little dry though), but I just can't help getting a burger, fries and a beer; they're miles above the competition.

<review# 879,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/29/2011,6/24/2012,65,114,4,7,4>TTOWA rocked my world. It's rare to find a suburban restaurant that provides excellent customer service, high quality dishes, and at reasonable prices. And it being a Korean restaurant...that's just unheard of. I saw the great reviews on Yelp (woot!) so my husband and I decided it was too nice out to cook at home and to TTOWA we went! We were greeted with kindness and welcomes and seated quickly. A bottle of cold water was brought and served to us. I personally love when a restaurant does this because I drink so much water!  It's BYOB too! Our server provided us with a great overview of the menu and gave us time to select our appetizers. When you're offered freshly prepared Mandoo (dumplings) anywhere, get them, it's a rare event! We ordered the Traditional Mandoo - Steamed and Shrimp Mandoo - Fried. Yum! They tasted like they were straight out of a Korean mom's home...pipping hot! Probably better than the ones I've had at my Korean friend's homes. With our appetizers, we were given free cups of soup. It was a bone marrow mushroom broth goodness. I could drink it every day in the winter and be a happy woman. We then ordered our entrees. I had the Braised Short Rib with Rice Porridge and my husband had the Pork Belly with Brussels Sprouts in a Kimchee Puree. Their excellent traditional Korean sides came out for us to snack on while we waiting. Once again, the dishes came out pipping hot. The entrees were a perfect size...enough to share with your partner and possibly have leftovers! Both dishes were seasoned very well. Korean food is very flavorful and overwhelming but these dishes were perfect and complimented by the ingredients it came with. After completing our hearty entrees, we were given a Korean Frozen Dessert Smoothie to cool our palates! Love that! The manager then encouraged us to try one of their desserts so we did! And boy was he right! It was a perfect portion (to share) of a sweet doughy pancake with unsweetened green tea ice cream and a pretty sugar piece to make the plate look attractive and yummy! I'm so excited to take all my friends and family to TTOWA. I know they will love it as much as I did. Don't hesitate, just go here before more people find out about it! Side note: As of yesterday, they've been open 7 weeks. I am shocked at how well executed our meal and service was and being so "young". They know what they're doing!

<review# 884,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/5/2012,6/19/2012,122,412,2,16,8>The Kebab House is a fabulous find in an area bereft of quality places to dine.  Stuck in a seventies-style mall on Grand Avenue among the car dealers, it's a bit hard to find if you don't know it's there. But it's definitely a gem of a find.My friend recommended it to me - this used to be the home of another great ethnic restaurant, Somchai, which closed several years ago. I stopped by after work, as my training studio is just down the block from here.It's exactly the type of restaurant I love in the city - a small Mom and Pop place where the owners are there and they obviously take pride in the food they create. I found the service to be nothing less than spotless - they gave me a complimentary custard dessert (can't remember the name) while I waited for my takeout - it's delish, by the way. And the chef carried all my food out to my car because he was concerned it would spill - great service.I ordered a bunch of takeout and was quite impressed with their menu. They have the old standbys, such as kebabs and falafel; but they also have some unusual dishes as well. They also have a great selection of vegetarian entrees, which is great for me. I ordered the lamb shank, which came in a huge container swimming with fresh veggies and a tomato-garlic sauce. The veggies were enough for a meal. I also got the mixed grill kebab for my husband and son, and a spinach primavera for me. Everything was fantastic, and such large portions - we'll have yummy leftovers for a couple of meals!BYOB - even better!Please support this unique addition to a somewhat boring restaurant landscape. Kebab House will tempt you with savory standbys as well as adventurous new entrees to try.

It opens to a beautiful nature trail where you can see some natural prairie settings and tons of different birds flying freely and an exhibit for their cranes.They even have information with each exhibit on the conditions the animals were rescued from and why they are being kept at Willowbrook. <review# 891,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/26/2012,6/12/2012,280,274,5,12,5>'Local' has been a buzz word lately.Shop Local. Local Farmer's Market. Etc. Etc. Etc.And then you eat at a place like The Turf Room and you realize that local businesses like this have re-invigorated the "Support for Local Businesses Movement". The Turf Room is located in a stretch of bucolic farmland in North Aurora. It is a restaurant that is appropriately framed by its surroundings. That's because The Turf Room draws inspiration from its 'hood' unlike most National Commercial Chains that have invaded every little pocket of America's suburbs. Those chains are manufactured right of the box; it doesn't really matter where they are located. Does Olive Garden in Geneva really differ from Olive Garden in Long Island? Does anyone really care???The Turf Room is quite possibly the coolest OTB in the U.S.A.The space is separated into two distinct areas: An Off-Track Betting Room in the back and a Dining Lodge-style Restaurant. Don't let that description fool you. The restaurant serves Duck, Bison, and Seared Tuna. There is a very good wine list. And the restaurant has a terrific indoor and outdoor fireplace (or firepit). The bathrooms are actually retrofitted horse stalls. There are newspaper clippings of Derby Horses here and there. If you're feeling lucky, you can lay down a few bets in between courses. I've been here six or seven times since I moved from the city. It's one of my favorite spots. The Turf Room has a ton of character....entirely driven by the locale. There are numerous stables in the area. It makes me feel like I'm back in Saratoga Springs watching horses in the paddock right before a race.Who said the Burbs don't have any identity???
<review# 892,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/14/2012,6/11/2012,2251,305,4,9,7>I'm the Dutchess here and I haven't written a review yet? Impossible! I don't even bother "checking in" anymore I've been coming here for so long.... Okay. Looked at my reviews and it's possible. Probably because Francesca's is such a restaurant staple for us that it never dawned on me. And so, I profusely apologize Mia Francesca Intimo. You have treated me so well over the years and I have taken you for granted. Forgive me. Okay. Enough drama! When we first moved here, people kept asking us, have you been to Francesca's yet? It was like a never ending echo. Francesca's Francesca's Francesca's. (Marsha Marsha Marsha!!!) Well, we finally went and about hit ourselves over the head that we hadn't gotten there before. Think of Francesca's as a good friend. It's the place that the neighborhood goes to for warm atmosphere, lively conversation, comforting food that fills your tummy and soul. They consistently serve delicious food. I think over the past years they've maybe served one dish to me that was just too salty. And that's it! I've eaten almost everything they offer on the menu. The linguini mare remains my all-time favorite pasta dish -- slightly zesty tomato basil sauce, hearty linguini noodles, huge shrimp. Depending on the menu for the evening they may throw in asparagus or spinach. The pasta portions are ridiculously huge. Like crazy huge. Always have leftovers to take home. The fish dishes I return to the most are the ones with tilapia -- usually with spinach. (yep. I like my vegetables and spinach rocks the top of the list.) The appetizers are straight forward. We often skip them to leave room for dessert. (Have I mentioned the huge pasta portions -- it's hard to do pasta and an app and dessert. A lady has to choose!) We about die over the coconut cake. If you like coconut, get it! And if you don't see it on the specials menu or dessert menu, just ask. You never know!We even get take-out from this place if we're stuck home without a sitter. Lots of families here with junior high and high schoolers earlier in the evening. Not exactly the place for preschoolers -- pasta thrown on top of the woman seated next to us, red wine splashed on the older gentleman trying to have a lovely dinner with his wife, bread pieces chucked across the room at texting teenagers. It's too much to bare just thinking about it!!! But I digress. The decor is welcoming and inviting. Dark woods, a flowing wave-like ceiling gives a sense of calmness and movement all at the same time. Tight seating that seems to fit the place and doesn't make one feel scrunched in. Exceptionally friendly waiters. Picked up take-out this weekend and one of them saw me and said hello. Asked when I was going to get said phantom sitter so I could come in for a proper date night again. The bar area is pathetic, that I will say. A five seater at best right by the door. But most people don't just walk-in so it's not really meant to be a true bar. You can walk-in for lunch but dinner generally needs a reservation so be sure to call beforehand to see if they can squeeze you  in. You may just see me there!
<review# 893,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/11/2011,6/10/2012,33,144,4,6,4>The Plush Horse is one of the absolute southwest suburbs ice cream places. For homemade, hand-dipped ice cream, there aren't any better places around.First off, all their ice cream is homemade, which not only makes it fresh, but gives them opportunities to make flavors that the other guys who order their ice cream from elsewhere don't.I love the atmosphere of the place, too. It's very old timey in there, with a kind of natural turn-back-the-clock feel, that's only aided by how secluded the 123rd and 86th Ave location feels (it's not, you're only a few miles from the busiest section of LaGrange Rd in Orland). But Plush Horse stands out because it's been the source of many memories for generations of us in the southwest side and now that I'm grown up, I love being able to introduce it to the next one.

<review# 897,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/9/2012,6/6/2012,255,326,10,10,11>Pumpkin Moon is, like other reviewers say, comparable to Uncle Fun in Lakeview. From novelty gifts to seasonal decorations, the store is packed with inexpensive (and a few not-so-inexpensive) items. Do you need Communist Breath Mints? They have you covered. Looking for a humorous or offbeat birthday card? They are in stock here. Did you just use up your last rubber chicken? Pumpkin Moon has three kinds. Don't even BOTHER shopping someplace else for things that look like poop but really aren't!Parking around here is usually pretty good. It's certainly cheaper and easier than parking in Lakeview, and there's a lot of other stuff to do in the area. It's a great place to kill time if you're early meeting somebody for lunch or don't feel like going home yet after your doctor appointment.Of course, I also love that the staff laughs at my jokes. One of the perks of shopping at a small local business over a chain is that they hire people who want to be there, and you don't have to deal with robo-clerks. Whether they are cackling along with me because I'm actually funny, or if it's more of a, "Wow, this lady is totally nuts" kind of thing is anybody's guess, but it's still nice to see a little life and personality. This shop has kid-friendly stuff but also more risque items, because again, they are independent and not mandated to stock or not stock things by a corporate board. This store is therefore not for squares, prudes, or people who think candies shaped like butts are offensive. The silly, the inane, and good-old fashioned nerds will feel right at home, though.

<review# 899,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/2/2012,6/4/2012,157,219,9,23,14>My grandfather, the son of two Polish immigrants, was a stickler for tradition. Every Christmas Eve throughout my life, we would have a traditional Polish dinner, that began with washing our hands with a silver dollar for good fortune and ended with oplatki (which tastes like communion, but the purpose is well wishes for your family). Though my grandfather has passed on, this Christmas Eve tradition reigns in my house. Of course, a traditional Polish dinner wouldn't be complete without pierogi and gwumpki (stuffed cabbage rolls), which we've acquired from St. Andrew's for as long as I can remember. G used to be responsible for ordering and picking up these delightful treats. (Yes, I said ordering--you want them for Christmas, you order 2 weeks in advance. No exceptions). He would never get enough potato for my my cousin and I, even though they used to be the only ones we would eat. Years later, my dad is now in charge, and he still doesn't order enough potato, but I love the kraut and cheese pierogi too. My favorite item is definitely the gwumpki, chock full of meat and rice and topped with a very mild tomato sauce. Happiness.Occasionally, Dad will go pick up a dozen or two piergi on a Saturday morning, and they come out warm and fresh, melting in your mouth as you sneak a few from the pack before dinner. In short, lets review: St. Andrews Ukranian KitchenCheese, Kraut, Potato Piergi = DumplingsGwumpki = Cabbage RollsKielbasa = Polish SausageKolachki = Polish CookiesSaturday Mornings Only from 8am-2pm (Go early, go often)For Christmas orders: Call ahead.To ensure you get what you want? Call ahead. What are you waiting for?Just do it.

Also, the ID checker was a real friendly guy as were both people I dealt with in the players' card area. They seem to have a great staff on hand.Now for the coolest part of the casino, the parking garage! Each spot has a little light above it and it will turn red when the spot is occupied and green when it's open. It's so nice to be able to tell really quickly which spots are open in a lane so you can just skip the lane if nothing's open. Towards the bottom of the lot is a board telling you how many open spots there are on each floor as well. It's a totally futuristic parking garage! I love it! hehe It's the small things that make a difference, I tell ya.

I mean, I don't see Grandma climbing up into one of their chairs. Perhaps, a thought for the future, Wickets.
<review# 903,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/26/2012,5/31/2012,178,365,8,10,8>I think it's about time that I preface all of my beer reviews with the fact that by the time I actually write the review, I'm most likely half to full on lit.  This may sway my vote.  Either way, here goes:ALLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLLL ABOOOOOOOOOOOOOOARRRRRRRRRRRD!  Chugga, chugga, chugga, chugga, chugga, chugga, chugga, chugga, choo-choo!  Yeah, that was a play on the fact that I am drinking in an old train station.  Yeah, I know it's not remotely funny.  Did I mention I'm drunk?Anyway, I finally made it out to Flossmoor Station.  It's in the middle of nowhere but has a great atmosphere and a great presence.  It also helps that the service, beer, and food were all great too.  Apparently there are flights of 5, 10, or 15 beers (each at 4 ounces a pour) so I went with the 5 and figured if I could handle more I would either get another 5 or a full pint.  I stopped after 5.  I ended up trying:Gandy Dancer Honey Ale- This is a lighter beer with a decent rye maltiness and a nice amount of hop bitterness.  Good starter beer for people who like crap and want to branch out into the craft beer (read: good beer) world. Panama Red Ale- This beer is fantastic.  It's a carmel colored beer with a nice balance of malt and hops.  It has a nice hop aroma and a decent bitterness for a red ale.  Apparently, it is brewed with 9 types of malt and 4 types of hops.  Nice.Railhopper IPA- OHHELLYES.  This 7.5% abv beer has a nice malty backbone but it's not too malty.  I actually wrote in my notes (yeah, I'm that guy when I taste beer) that this beer was "effing good".  It also has a nice hop aroma and bitterness.  I actually bought this one in a bomber for $10 on my way out.  Yeehaw.  (P.S.  Buy the beer at the host stand as opposed to the table so you can save some dough on taxes.  Huzzah!)Pullman Nut Brown Ale- I swear, the bartender mispoured here or I don't know what I am talking about...the beer I drank was heavy on the rye, tasted bourbon-barrel aged, and had carmel and nutty notes.  It did not match the description at all.  Either I am way off, or I wasn't drinking the brown ale.Iron Horse Stout- strong, creamy, espresso-y, with a strong barley flavor.  Not bad, but not my favorite stout.Food!  I also ate here.  My husband and I both got the Build Your Own Brewery Burgers.  I loved mine with every thread of my being.  It came out a little more well than I would have liked, but the buffalo sauce, blue cheese, sour cream, and pepperjack were all so fresh and delicious that I didn't care.  I also got the wedges which were awesome.  Especially dipped in the extra sour cream that I got.  YUM.  We also got "cheese logs" but my husband was all perturbed that they had paprika on them.  I was too busy drinking to eat them, but they looked good enough.Service was good, beer was great, and the food was excellent.  What more can you ask for?
<review# 904,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/6/2012,5/30/2012,209,310,6,6,7>I am not a fan of donuts.  I generally skip them all together.  But with my friend's insistence we went.  Spunky Dunker Donuts is the best name ever for a donut shop.  Five stars for originality.  So we go in and a very nice young man gives us the lay of the land.  He is giving us the ins and outs, the most popular and what we've missed because they've already sold out.  I was bummed to hear they were out of brownies.  Boo hiss!  They must be good! <review# 905,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/2/2012,5/29/2012,359,353,8,16,9>$9.95 for a killer Indian lunch buffet?! That's it?!?Yes. That's it. Given that low of a price, I'm sure you're questioning a few things. Is it even worth it? Do they have more than 4 items? Is it good quality, and not some frozen chicken masala from the freezer section at the grocery store? Yes. Yes. Yes.I had been hearing mass raves about Maharaja throughout my office for the past few months. Why I haven't gone sooner, I don't know. I love Indian food, but sometimes it doesn't love me back. Perhaps that was the reason. We went to lunch a little before 1:00pm on a Friday and I'll be honest, I was slightly concerned the buffet would have slim pickins since the buffet starts at 11:30am - and is completely slammed through lunchtime. To my surprise, more and more fresh dishes kept coming out, and the buffet was constantly being refilled. That meant no dry rice, no soggy pakora, nothing cold, and no buffet items with less than a scoop left. Apparently the lunch buffet is open until 3:00pm - so definitely something to keep in mind for a late lunch. The buffet offered vegetarian, lamb, chicken and fish dishes. There was at least a half dozen condiments, and a few desserts to try. Of the dishes I tried ((only vegetarian)) here's what I absolutely loved...**SAUCES**::Mint Chutney::Coconut Chutney::Tamarind ::Vegetable Pakora ((Onion, Cauliflower, Potatoes and Spinach fritters, battered in a thick gram flour, blended with freshly ground herbs and spices and deep fried))::Vegetable Jalfrezi ((Mixed seasonal vegetables cooked to perfection with herbs and spices))::Palak Paneer ((Spinach and homemade Indian cheese cubes cooked with onions, tomatoes,mild spices and fresh herbs))::Yellow Tardka Dal ((Yellow lentil curry prepared with tomatoes, onions, ginger, and temperedwith cumin and mustard seeds))::Chana Masala((Chick peas cooked in a mildly spiced onion and tomato gravy))::Vegetable Biryani ((Saffron flavored rice prepared with fresh vegetables, specially imported herbs,spices, and nuts))::Vegetable Hakka Noodles::Mango Kulfi((Homemade Indian ice cream flavored with mango and nuts))The decor and atmosphere reminds me something out of a bad porno. Between the fluorescent green and blue lights, mass amounts of crystal chandeliers, and the cracked glass wall paneling, I had to giggle to myself a little. Who knows, perhaps this place turns into a disco dance floor at night! Either way, the decor lacked something to be desired...but after all, that is not what I came for!The waiters were very attentive, making sure finished buffet plates were cleared, and water glasses were filled. I especially liked the carafes of water next to the buffet. Let's just say I'm fairly sensitive to spicy foods, so being able to help myself to another gallon of water scores big points in my book.My first experience at Maharaja was spectacular. I wanted to eat until I could burst - or at least until some of my internal organs told me to stop. The food was delicious.I came. I chowed. I left stinkin' of Indian spices. But in  the end, I found an amazing, quick, and inexpensive new lunch spot.

I'd read about the tamales in the local high school newspaper, and being a huge tamale fan I had to try them. The tamales did not disappoint. I had a mixture of the green spicy pork and the mild cheese and poblano ones. I liked the spicy ones slightly more, but the mild ones were also tasty. If you like spicy food though I would recommend just going with the spicy tamales. On a Saturday they were out of the red pork tamales which I believe are medium, so you might want to call ahead if you are making a larger order.I also tried the mexicana sandwich on the toasted bollo. It had ham, avocado, Chihuahua (had to look up how to spell that) cheese, jalapenos and a spicy thousand islandish sauce. It was a tasty sandwich, but the best part was that the employee making the sandwich was so conscientious about making it the best sandwich possible. The toaster burnt the edge of the bread and instead of just ignoring that and hoping I wouldn't care, she re-toasted the bread. These little details make me want to go back because I like to give my money to places that value how they present themselves to customers. Plus I want to go back to try everything else that I didn't. I don't think I'm the only one either because I overheard another customer say  that as long as Aracely's was open, LaGrange would sink a few feet lower into the ground from all the extra calorie consumption.

<review# 920,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/26/2011,5/14/2012,31,287,7,18,13>Siam's House is the best place for Thai food in Chicago, period. I am half Thai and  have been to Thailand three times and Thai food doesn't get any better than this outside of Bangkok. For the past 15 years, Siam's House continues to be my favorite restaurant in all of Chicago. Since I am a regular, I have asked the owner to make a special dish. It's their house fried chicken tossed with a special sauce. It's sweet, salty, sour, spicy - all of the flavors of Thailand in one fried juicy bite. You will not find this dish anywhere since it's the chef's creation. I call it Gai Mai (meaning new chicken in Thai). It's not on the menu but you must order it and you will seriously be amazed. I have taken two pictures of it and uploaded them for you. Even though I no longer live in the area, I still make it point to go out of my way to this restaurant because it is one of the few Thai places in the Chicagoland area that is really authentic. The interior could use some updating and the service can be slow but the food really speaks for itself. The flavors are simply amazing. Even the most common dishes such as pad thai and pad see yew are noticeably remarkable. On top of that, the portions are larger and the prices are reasonable. The dishes that I recommend are pad thai, pad see yew, roast duck over rice, panang curry, spicy basil duck, and fried chicken with papaya salad and sticky rice. These are the must haves when dining here. You'll immediately notice the taste in quality since everything is handled by the head chef and owner - no part time cooks at this establishment.After dining here, you will realize how Thai food should really taste. Welcome to Siam's House.

Onion rings were just as good - crispy, but fresh!! We couldn't stop muching on them!Burgers were GREAT!! Cooked perfectly, not greasy, and although the toppings on the descriptions seemed as though it could be overkill, you could taste everything! Bread was nice and sturdy , but soft (no holes in the bread!) and the meat itself was soft and tender.Always love finding a good burger joint in the area, and the next time that burger craving hits, we'll be back!!Better then smashburger down the street ~

<review# 926,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/26/2011,5/8/2012,137,199,6,14,12>Does Mother Nature intrigue you?  Have you ever seen a community of Herons continue the circle of life right before your very eyes?  Well, it's not too late and only a short car ride away on Rt. 30 in Plainfield, Illinois.Located on the northern side of Renwick Rd and Rt. 30, beautiful Lake Renwick is hidden behind walls and walls of cat tails and reeds, but if you keep looking as you pass, you'll notice a small break in the foliage that reveals a man-made island in the middle of the Lake with (what looks like) a bevy of telephone poles strewn together every which way.  Now look closer...you'll see hundreds and hundreds of nests and birds perched all around, either mating or carefully attending to their newly born babies.  It's amazing to watch the Heron as they fly overhead or patiently wait for dinner to surface from the water, below.  Bring a lunch.  You're gonna want to stay a whileYou'll notice a small parking lot off of Rt. 30, complete with bathrooms, a few tables and a public telescope to bring the Heron community closer to you.  If you have them, I strongly suggest bringing binoculars.  That way you don't have to wait for whoever's using the telescope to walk away.  Have kids?  I think they'll find this experience to be like something at Busch Gardens...only better, because it's FREE!

<review# 928,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/25/2012,5/6/2012,45,60,4,5,4>I grew up eatting lots of Thai food.... Of course, Mom cooked it the best!!  But since moving to this area, I've been on the look out for a place that I could go to... to get my thai food fix I've been craving for.... I am picky... and I don't want to settle for just "fast food thai food".  I wanted originality... I wanted flavors... spices... I wanted to eat my meal and say "wow, we are coming back here, and its close to where we live."Well, I want to say... I think I've found the spot for when i need a little Thai in me.  Went here with my husband.  We had driven by this place several times.  It is located by a Currency Exchange... in a small mall like area with a Jewel Grocery store nearby.  There is really nothing on the outside... that would catch your eyes (besides the sign that says Thai House) if you just drove by... you would miss it.  We went here late Saturday afternoon, close to dinner time.  As we walked in, we were greeted and seated right away.  The place was pretty empty...  We were seated by the window... which I want to say, they have fabulous shell window blinds... and the place actually looked very clean.  We ordered 6 items:  mini eggrolls, salad rolls, a beef salad, and Tom Yum Soup, fried red snapper and a noodle dish.  I can't remember if it was a Drunken noodles... or a crazy noodles... The mini eggrolls were small and cute.  It was filled with chopped shrimp.  The Salad rolls had shrimp, noodles, and basil leaves.  The sauce for the rolls were yummy.  Much better then some place I've gone to.Then our beef salad and soup came.  The presentation looked awesome...  The hubby is more of a meat eater... so I was quite happy that he was enjoying this beef salad.   The soup was amazing.  It really hit home for me... cus the spices were all there for me.  We actually asked for it to have a medium heat too... and I was very happy  with it.  Cus I need that kick especially in Thai food.  Our Red snapper and noodle came out last, but in a timely manner.  The fish looked absolutely amazing... and tasted great too!!  You can't really find whole fish, fried this way anymore... so we were pretty satisfied with the presentation.  I also thought the noodles would be your typical... stir fried noodles with whatever meat you wanted.  But to my surprise, the noodles were delicious.  It was a flat thick noodle... that was fried with a lil bit crisp but soft too.  I was in Thai heaven for an hour... while we were there...I'm excited for our next visit... I want to try some more stuff on their menu.  So...the questions is...  do i go here again?  Of course... very soon too.  I also read alot of stuff about old owners, and new owners... and I have no idea if these are new or old owners.  But I want to say, they were very nice and friendly.  And whether the old place was better or not... I like it the way it is now.  They have their own... Originality style.
<review# 929,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/6/2012,5/5/2012,191,452,4,10,5>Decided to check out a toda madre on their opening night this week.  I love the scene.  From the outside the restaurant seems to be housed in an old suburban home built in the 70s.  (Similar to it's sister restaurant, Bien Trucha).  A friend that we were meeting for dinner even passed up the restaurant because of the deceiving curb view.  But inside, they've constructed such a warm and inviting space with white subway tiled backsplash at the bar, cool aqua green countertops, and soft low wooden tables.  This is definitely an intimate setting where diners can't be afraid of rubbing elbows with each other.  Bonus:  purse hooks at the bar.A toda madre in Spanish is slang for "totally awesome," and I'd have to agree.  Their small Mexican plates are simply rad.  Plates run from $5-11 and are each enough to be shared by three people at most.  Some favorites:PAPAS.  So good that we ate two orders!  These fried potatoes are dressed with a cilantro serrano aioli to give the perfect yet subtle kick.PULPO.  This cold plate of baby octopus, greens, radish, snow peas, serrano, pistachios, grilled green onion with lemon vinaigrette was delish!CHILE RELLENO.   Stuffed poblano pepper with goat cheese, chihuahua fresco, roasted tomato sauce, cream fresca.Drinks here somewhat fell flat.  I tried the Las Hadas ($9), enticed by the grilled pineapple garnish and rum. but the pineapple was dried out and the rum overpowered the other components of the drink.  My friend also tried the Sexy Mamiche ($9) which was basically beer with carrot juice.  Not a good combo.Beware this is not a restaurant made for groups for two reasons: 1) it's a very small space 2) a 30% gratuity is added to groups of 6 or more.

<review# 933,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/11/2011,5/1/2012,220,174,8,9,7>How can I compare the new Glenview House from the old? I can not compare. I never stepped foot in the previous establishment. What I do remember from the days of old were the crowd of softball players hanging out for an after game celebration. Now as I drive by the new Glenview House, the picnic benches have been replaced with patio tables and the whole buildings decor inside and out have been redone. The front and back patio are perfect settings for all things dining al fresco. The upstairs tables have a more reserved feel and a lounge alongside is equipped with cushy seating. The bar and downstairs tables are high backs mixed with tables and booths. The seating downstairs is first come and no reservations are taken. Wide screen televisions mount the bar and booths adding to the casual and relaxed feel. An elevator was installed for accessibility on all levels. This may be the preferred choice for some not willing to try out their balance on the stairs (depending on their alcohol levels!) Loving detail with decor was planned throughout the restaurant, even in the bathroom. The menu holds an upscale feel with down to earth bites, like kobe sliders and duck nachos. The same menu is served both upstairs and downstairs. Entrees are served until a specified time and apps are served until a later hour, until kitchen closes. I have had dinner upstairs and entertained friends at the bar downstairs and both experiences have been top stars. The food is fresh and prepped to allow a feast for the eyes as well as the belly. I had one experience with a burnt quesadilla which threw me off a bit, but no harm done. A full bar stocked and whiskey flights elevate the status of this neighborhood watering hole to a more refined feel. For me this place offers the opportunity to embellish a relationship with all things related to hops and barley. As I have mentioned in other reviews the dazzle of all things bubbling Prosecco will be my love, but beer continues to be my affair. Dizzying array of both bottle and draft are listed with the country of origin, alcohol percentage and the tasty notes of 'oak or cranberry' in the detail. Beer flights are the new man on the scene and allows one to try out different tastes and refine 'virginal' buds. My personal favs are the St. Bernadus, and the Canadian brew, Maudite, but I always turn to my blond ale, Abbey Leffe. She may just be the one I turn to in my times of a 'draft' need. She has a beautiful color rich with gold and a taste that is light and a heft in the background that allows her to hold her ground. Abbey is one that can not be pushed around. Whiskey flights and Ron Zacapa sipping rums have been proclaimed by friends to create the settings for interesting conversations. Word has it that beers with alcohol contents equal to wine and Octoberfest brews are making their way on board. Enjoy!

We stopped in to pick up a sampling of products (namely of the sweet variety) as my kids have been rather less-than-impressed with our prior GF dessert finds. Admittedly, SO many of the items include eggs (sad face!) that I wound up watching the taste tests with our three year old (she's g-button exclusive) and gauging reactions. And let me tell you, the reactions were FANTASTIC.My husband, my son (5), my daughter (4), and our "baby" (she's 2) were the tasters of all purchased treats. This system worked out beautifully as it allowed everyone just a taste but with the ability to offer up an opinion on any tasted item. Items purchased were as follows:decorated sugar cookiesdairy/soy free chocolate chip cookiesa cinnamon rolla donut (glazed)And let me tell you, my foursome loved all four items. LOVED them! (And we still have leftovers, of course, of all of the aforementioned; they're currently squaring away who gets what and when.) My daughter declared the sugar cookie to be *almost* as good as mommy's (awww! Thanks, honey! ;); my husband--a self-proclaimed "donut hater" said he loved the glazed donut beyond reason. My son, who received the adoration-of-cinnamon-rolls gene from yours truly, said he could eat a hundred cinnamon rolls. In one sitting. Preferably today.In short, my loves were all more than happy with the GF sweet treats. While they're by no means a "health food" (c'mon, it *is* a bakery, after all!), as an occasional treat? Oh.my.goodness.yes. Happy faces abound, my friends. For the first gluten-free-dessert-related-time, happy faces abound.

Their take out menu (i had to ask for one) has coupons for $1 off $10 and $2 off $20 or free pasta with $20 purchase.oh and I feel bad, I took pictures of the food and ice tea machine but not the place.. I'm a dork.  It's behind Village Tavern if yer looking for it.

<review# 949,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/1/2012,4/14/2012,58,179,11,11,10>I find that if I buy deli meat from the store, I get over excited and over buy.  The next thing I know I have 17 pounds of salami, turkey and various cheeses.   With only two people in the house on a normal basis, it then proceeds to spoil in my fridge and I am then basically throwing money into the garbage can.  Not good for business.So, in a stroke of genius, my husband and I have started a quest to find a good cold cut sandwich in the area.  I figure this way I can just eat it all in one sitting and not have it go bad in my fridge.  See, I told you, genius. We started out at Ambrosino's.  It is a combo Italian grocery store / deli.  When we walked in, we were briefly distracted by all of the goodies in the freezer section and the various pastas on the shelves.  However, we quickly regained focus and made a bee line to the deli in the back.  After a quick survey I settled on the Italian combo and my boo thang got a meatball sub.  They were both delectable.  The bread was the perfect combination of crusty and soft.  The meats had a great salty flavor that was offset by the vinegary dressing and cool vegetables.  We also got some side salads that were pretty tasty.  My favorite was the loaded potato salad.  The macaroni salad and Greek pasta salad were also good.  The best part is that all of this deliciousness is relatively inexpensive.  The sandwiches range between $5 and $6 and the salads are about $2-$3, depending on size.  The quality is far superior to any of the sandwich chain restaurants and it will run you about the same price.  Check it out before you go and get yourself one of those "$5 foot longs".

<review# 953,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/10/2011,4/10/2012,132,76,8,17,25>Can I be honest here for a moment? No, really honest. No politically correct varnish here. I can? Good. Here goes. Have you ever been out somewhere, anywhere, and noticed a group of individuals who obviously have special needs? Maybe they are louder than you would like. Maybe their mannerisms are odd. Maybe they even exhibit (dare I say it?) inappropriate behaviors. You stare a little, right? No, no. I am sure you mean nothing by it. But you stare. Maybe even make a comment under your breath to the friend standing next to you. If this group rolls into your place of employment; maybe you pretend not to notice when one of these individuals tries to hand you a picture icon of an item he needs. Maybe you hightail it in the opposite direction when they walk down the aisle. Maybe you do all or none of these things. The truth of the matter is that *a lot* of people do this. I should know. I teach teenage boys with severe autism. We venture out into the community several times a week to practice various life skills. We, I am sad to say, see this all the time.That is, my friends, until we encountered the amazing staff at Extreme Trampoline.My boys and I (along with two other classes) rolled into Extreme Trampoline as part of our end-of-summer-school field trip. Drove over an hour to get there. Yup, you read that right, over an hour. No wussy Pump It Up bouncy castles for my boys. My boys could easily be mistaken for the defensive line of any well-ranked high school football team. We came to jump. We don't bounce. And jump we did. For the uninitiated, Extreme Trampoline is something akin to a warehouse with a sunken subfloor and a number of very sturdy individual trampolines built into the main floor (though two of us easily jumped on a single trampoline). We arrived for the earliest jump session and took an entire section of the floor for ourselves. We were assigned a staff member to keep an eye on our section and make sure we all stayed safe (every section is assigned at least one staff member). Our staff member was Ryan. And Ryan, my friends, is amazing. As the morning progressed, Extreme Trampoline filled up with several different day camp groups. Some of the other jump sections filled up. A few different groups of the day camp teens attempted to squeeze into our section and nudge our boys off their trampolines. Before any of our school staff could object, Ryan was on it. He made sure that anyone not with our group was removed from our section and then alerted all the other sections' staff that our section was off limits to anyone but our group. Even when half our boys took a break and a dozen trampolines remained empty, Ryan held fast and did not allow anyone else in our section. Let me be absolutely clear, we did not have a private section. Ryan took it upon himself to give our boys the space they needed to ensure they had the best possible time. He never stared. He never rolled his eyes. He treated all our boys like they were teenage boys. And that, my friends, is an oddity in our world. And it instantly endeared Ryan, and Extreme Trampoline to our hearts.Perhaps you are reading this review and thinking, hyperbolic much? If so, I will assume you have not had the pleasure of knowing anyone with severe special needs. But, if you are lucky enough to know any of these amazing individuals, you know exactly how huge it is to be treated...like average. Like a person. With dignity. And this is exactly what we encountered at Extreme Trampoline.Well done, Extreme Trampoline. A quadrillion stars (and a million thanks).

<review# 959,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/8/2012,4/4/2012,288,304,11,13,13>I think I have finally recovered from my Restaurant Week experience. I did not go to a ton of restaurants. In fact, I only went to one but one was enough. Vie has been on my list for quite some time and Restaurant Week was the perfect opportunity to satisfy my curiosity. We were a party of four. Some of us (me) might have been eyeing the menu for weeks. When I arrived, my mind was set on one thing: FRIED CHICKEN. Yes, Vie is a Michelin star restaurant. No, I didn't want the fancy pants white fish served with a coulis of something or other. I WANT FRIED CHICKEN! Imagine my disappointment when I sat down to find that the fried chicken entrée had been changed to grilled chicken. Gasp! For a moment there, I really thought I was going to lose my shit but I calmly asked the server what the deal was. He assured me that it would not be a problem to do a fried preparation. Yes! Fried chicken all around! After the roller coaster of emotion I experienced over the fried chicken, I was ready for a drink. I wish I could remember the name of the cocktail I had. It consisted of gin and some sort of cherry liquor. I just remember that it was delicious and made me forget about the fried chicken debacle. We decided to get a couple of the special starters/sides to share. The cheese plate was presented with a goat cheese, soft blue cheese, pistachio grain bread, honey and chocolate raspberry jam. It's kind of hard to eff up a cheese plate but I will say the soft blue cheese was absolutely wonderful. We shared the egg salad with fried bread - totally delicious and the fried bread was reminiscent of a fried wonton. Ok, the restaurant week menu. I opted for the crispy pork belly starter b/c this gal loves her some pork belly. I mean, I LOOOOVE it. If I could make sweet love to pork belly all night long, I would but it'll never happen b/c I'd eat it all before I could even get to first base. What? Anyhow, the pork belly was cooked perfectly...crispy, rich with the right amount of fattiness. It was served with potatoes, sopresseta and a vinaigrette. Next up was the roasted yellow beets served with farm greens and ricotta biscuits. Simple, but so delicious. Finally, the fried chicken. I have to admit I was a little disappointed that the breast was boneless vs. a bone-in breast of chicken. It was still quite tasty but when I think of fried chicken I think of picking that sucker up with my hands and digging in. I suppose Vie is not really that kind of place. I mean, you won't find plastic bibs or wet naps on the tables. The fried breast was served over braised thigh meat, greens, au jus and the best mashed potatoes I've probably ever had. You'd think this would be the end of my review, but you'd be wrong. We still had the dessert course. The sour orange float was really tempting me but I could not pass up the warm gingerbread doughnuts. They were little bites of heaven and something I'd order again. We opted for the wine pairing - totally worth it. The moscato with dessert was damn good as was the pinot noir with the main entrée. Service here is truly stellar...as it should be. All in all, a great meal. I would not hesitate in coming back to Vie for a special night out. Who would have ever thought a Michelin star restaurant was nestled in downtown Western Springs? Definitely worth the checking out.

<review# 962,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/24/2012,4/1/2012,223,313,3,12,8>I stopped here for lunch a while a go for some pizza by the slice, thought it was good, then forgot about the place.  Well I had a lazy day off work and decided to order some delivery.  Good thing I did since I've realized how awesome the food is here!  Everything is made fresh from scratch, which includes their pizzas, pastas, calzones, wings, sandwiches, and other dinners.They're located in a tiny plaza, right next to the 53 Biesterfield exit.  It's a tiny take-out/delivery joint, but they do have a few tables (and even some outside when the weather's nicer).Their pizza by the slice is a solid lunch deal.  You get a huge slice overflowing with chewy gooey cheese.  But even better are there specialty pizzas, which are cooked in their brick oven.  You can really tell by how the thin crust is crispy throughout, which makes a huge difference.  The Margeherita pizza is very good.  A simple pie, loaded with juicy plum tomatoes, basil, olive oil, rromano cheese, and some mozzarella.  Their Calamari is excellent!  These aren't your everyday over-breaded, out of a bag, wimpy calamari.  There's are lightly breaded, seasoned, and the pieces are just plain huge!  You get a bunch of fried squid rings and a good amount of tentacley goodness.  It's very fresh, crispy on the outside and very tender inside.  Plus the marinara and tangy cocktail bbq sauce (that's what I call it) are so good.If you're in the mood for some tasty homemade pasta, they have a wide variety to choose from.  Just pick the type of pasta you want, pick one of their tasty sauces, and add some proteins if you wish.  Last time I tried some angel hair pasta with Arrabiata sauce, which was spicy goodness.  Plus the portions are huge and will definitely fill you up.I'll be ordering from here more often, especially for that kickass Calamari!

 Yes, please), the Pom a Dor (made with fresh ingredients) and the Black and White (perfect dessert martini with plenty of kick).  Although those are my standard picks, I've also tried other martinis such as the Nice Pear and Honey "Dew" Me and some of their signature cocktails such as Blueberry Mojito and Cool as a Cucumber.  Try, and you will not be disappointed.  The drinks are strong, and poured generously.  There's no collar on a martini to be found, just outstandingness filled to the tippy top of each and every glass.The staff is wonderful, from the manager Brandon to the servers (Angela is my fave).  They are always welcoming and remember us every time, they consider my bf and me regulars..although I totally don't consider myself to be one #brokegirlproblemsI also love how this place is dimly lit, it's classy and understated without being stuffy.  The food is innovative fare that you won't find at your local chain restaurants.  I've tried several items and never been disappointed.  Back in my meat eating days, the jambalaya was always a go to choice.  Rigatoni tossed in a spicy cream sauce and large chunks of sausage, peppers, and onions..oh my!!  I still steal a couple noodles whenever my bf orders it.The salmon is also fantastic and served with red pepper mashed potatoes that are drool worthy.  For a quick bite, you can't go wrong with one of their flat breads, especially during happy hour when they're $4!!  The stable standard is great but really..how could you not order the magic mushroom?  The name alone enticed me!!The stuffed eggplant is a great appetizer, perfectly cooked with plenty of chunky red sauce.  My bestie and I devoured this and the up in smoke croquettes in no time and the only thing stopping us from ordering more was the fact that we didn't want to f up our buzz.Basically, the TR is the greatest place ever, evaaa.  Go here, eat, drink, and be sure to have a Seedless martini for me!!

<review# 978,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/9/2011,3/15/2012,63,74,11,13,8>I was pleasantly surprised by how good the food is here, and to top it off it's brought to you on a train! I think I was was more thrilled by the train and the whole cool diner experience than my kids, grinning like it was my birthday and I was 5 the whole time.You know? Screw the young ones! Go here because you, as an adult who deserves a freaking break in this world, want old school basic diner food done from scratch the right way.  They only take cash, so bring enough to drop the pedal to the floor. Because when you go here, you need to try everything. Look at their online menu so you know what prices to expect.Their burgers here  are a serious contender to Paradise Pup. They are really that good. My wife, who almost never orders burgers, exclaimed that it was the best she'd ever had. The waitress told us that the beef was fresh and never frozen. Another reason they are so tasty, I believe, is that they use a decades old seasoned flat top grill, which sears the loosely formed patty quickly, sealing in the juices. The crisp exterior is something to write home about. And go old school and get it with cheese and raw onion, cause the balance of onion acidity with savory crisp meat and creamy cheese is real artistry.The fries were crisp and delicious, as were the hand made onion rings. The malted chocolate shake was the most flavorful and best I've had in a couple decades. If they ask you if you want whipped cream on top, shout "Heck yeah!" because it's the real thing. Real whipped cream, not that factory stuff made out of petroleum or artificial guar gum. Those massive cream molecules will undoubtedly race straight to your arteries as the malted sugar high revs your brain to 11, but it's worth it now and then right? You freaking deserve this, the shit you put up with.If you have room for desert, or even if you don't. Get the apple pie, because it's the perfect blend of flaky crust and sweet sour apples and brown sugar carmelization. And get it with their premium a la mode ice cream, because you deserve it. You really do. The shit you put up with.
<review# 979,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/4/2011,3/14/2012,33,144,6,9,6>I love places that managed to hide something special in a non-descript sort of place.Hala Kahiki really doesn't look like much, just sort of lying there on a fairly blah stretch of River Rd.  Heck, I've probably driven past it myself and never even had it register.But it's definitely a place of which you should take note.  It's just a delightful bit of escapism.  Cheesiness done completely right.  To step into its thatch and teak covered walls is to be transported out of a cold Chicago night and into the South Pacific or at least into Adventureland.  The decor is really spectacular.  There isn't just a vague Polynesian feel to Hala Kahiki.  It really allows you to forget you're inside of a midwestern house turned bar and gives off the illusion that this really is an elaborate longhouse in Samoa or something.  It's cartoony, but that's the charm.The overall feel of the bar is one of the nicer ones I've been to, too.  It's quiet, even when crowded as the other patrons all seem to be a respectful pleasant bunch, who aren't there to get plastered and rowdy. It's nice to know there's a place around where one can drink without being bothered by the ignorant actions of others.As for the drinks themselves, basically they're sweet and rum based.  You aren't coming here for the beer or wine lists. It's for creative, fruity, mixed drinks that just further the whole "not in Chicago anymore" atmosphere.  They're extremely tasty and dangerous because they don't taste like alcohol so they're a little too easy to drink too fast.  So come to Hala Kahiki with a limit in mind and you'll be fine.The service is solid, if not spectacular, and I'd like more food options than just the complimentary pretzels, but it's a place that's doing what works so who am I to judge?Overall, it's a fun place.  A cool little retreat in the near western suburbs that will take you away from everything if only for a few hours.

I felt like I was at Universal Studios with all of the props, palm trees and the entire feel of the place. It really feels like you're transported somewhere else for a couple of hours. Even in the actual theater itself, it is very cool, with huge paintings and giant statues around the screen. I LOVE IT! The chairs here are rolling black faux leather computer chairs...I have an identical one at home. Some may find this annoying but I felt it was very comfortable and nice to roll a bit to find comfy positions. You get a table in front of you which is nice & convenient. For the one drink minimum my friend and I just went with a lemonade & a diet coke - so don't feel as if you have to get liquor or food items. The lemonade was delicious, tasted better than your run of the mill lemonade! No other theater has every done that for the GoFoBo rejects!I'll be back shortly and be able to update my review with food information! This was the best movie watching experience I've had in quite some time!Update 3/11: The theater has a fishbowl which you can drop your business card to win up to 8 free movie tickets Andddddd guess who won!? This girl. I went this past Thursday to watch The Lorax with a group of friends and had another great experience. This time we all had food and I was surprised the food was just delicious! Rat Pack Martinis are on special for $5 (normally $9) on Thursday, so I tried the Old Blue Eyes Martini. It has Svedka Vodka with Blue Curacao & a splash of lemonade. I'm happy to say they didn't skimp on the liquor, I really enjoyed the drink. For dinner I had the Super Chicken and LOVED it! Lemon herb marinated chicken with cheddar & monterrey cheeses between two slices of garlic bread. It came with a little tub of mayo & ketchup which made me happy to have those on the side. Portions here are huge, plus the fries the meal comes with is nomnomnomz. Every theater has a different theme and I've been in the Wizard of Oz theater twice now. It's very cool & creepy at the same time with flying monkeys. I HEART HOLLYWOOD PALMS.
<review# 983,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/10/2012,3/10/2012,78,284,4,5,7>I am head over heels for this place. However, I'm going to tell you right now that you WILL have trouble finding this place if you've never been here. It's located in an industrial park, right next to some factory. There is no sign outside so you'll probably get here, look around, not see anything, and think you've made a wrong turn somewhere. Fear not! You have arrived to beer heaven! Just park somewhere on the street and walk up to the grey building. Once you get to the door, there's a sign printed from a computer that tells you you're at Two Bros. Yup. This is it.Never judge a book by it's cover. Once you walk inside, you'll be surprised that it's an actual restaurant. There's a gift store on the left upon walking in where you can get t-shirts with the beer names on them and brew kits so you can make your own at home.Let's talk first about why you came here. The beer. There's something for everyone, unless you want light beer. Sorry, just delicious craft beer made at the very location you're at. My favorite year-round beer is Domaine DuPage. My favorite Two Bros beer is Hop Juice. OMG. It's an IPA which I'm not fond of, but somehow, they make it not taste like an IPA, if that makes sense. It's only in the summer but it's so worth the wait. They also make a bunch of seasonal beers, and some special batches that are available in limited quantities. They only make a few batches of some things, so if you don't get it when it comes out, it's gone. Kind of sucks, but it also makes it special.You would probably come here for the beer and think, meh the food is probably just regular bar fare. How wrong you are. The food is the next best reason to come here. They seem to always be adding new menu items too, but they keep what's good. They have a bratwurst cooked in their own beer. You can taste it when you eat it and its scrumptious. Their burgers are really good too. Definitely have some other things I want to try.If you have time on the weekend, I highly recommend doing a brewery tour. It's free and you can bring a beer with you as your tour the small brewery. The funny thing about it is the place used to be a gymnastics academy at one point. How do I know? Because they didn't bother to paint the walls or take down the "all you can be" signs and gymnastics logos. Anyway, after the tour, you get a couple tickets that you can use to trade in for samples of beer. Youngins are also welcome on the tour. Why not take them and show them something they can't legally have for another 10 years. They can trade in their tickets for some apple cider, which apparently is really good.Still with me? Cool. GO HERE! You will not regret it.

<review# 987,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/20/2012,3/6/2012,45,72,6,8,6>Deer Grove is a forest preserve for all seasons and my little escape from the normal hustle of life - cars, cell phones, TV, etc.On the plus side:Beautiful trails, tons of deer, some peace & quiet, two super nice sledding hills, the lake in the middle, the leaves in Fall, decent biking trails, and fun longboarding roads!I love to go to the the far west side where the creek is meandering, I think it is the most beautiful part of the preserve and you are left mildly secluded.  Once you get far enough into the forest the sounds of the surrounding cites slowly fade away and you are left with a peaceful place you walk, run, bike or whatever it is you like to do.  The name says it all, there are deer everywhere!  I think after going to Deer Grove for the past 4 years, a countless number of  times, there is a 50/50 chance of seeing a deer especially in the morning or at dust.  The two super nice sledding hills are fun and well groomed - the big one further in the preserve (almost at the end of the road) is way faster.  They have hay bails at the end to stop you from going into the lake but most people stop before they get there.  However, with a big-ol-running push you can get your friend all the way to the end with enough force to flip over them!  The lake is nice year round but is very peaceful in early spring.  The Spring Peepers (a small frog with a big voice) make a great background noise for your saunters through the forest.  The Fall leaves are amazing here, since the forest is dense at times when the leaves change color you can see a wide variety of beauty.  The roads are hilly enough to ride a longboard but since you are in the forest be ready for fallen sticks, rocks on the road, wet spots - just about anything - so wear a helmet!  The biking trails are nice if you want to go for a Sunday cruise but ... well I will finish that in a little bit.  On the negative side:Closed mountain biking trails!I understand that Deer Grove is at the bottom of the city and that water pools and is stays wet for days and that the trails would be destroyed if/when mountain bikers ride them when it is wet.  However, why not have some designated mountain biking trails or try to get people to not ride them when they are wet, maybe a sign - "Please ONLY Ride Trials When The Ground is Bone Dry (Otherwise we will have to close the trails again and we know you don't want that)-DGFP"Overall there are so many positives it has me coming back again and again, but with a few more open bike trails they were get the fifth star!  It is a very great place for an escape to nature, a walk, and a great day!
