<review# 989,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/19/2011,3/4/2012,255,326,4,7,6>If you live anywhere close to the Park Ridge Farmer's Market and have been purchasing frozen corn from the grocery store, cease and desist! Immediately! The PRFM has what may be the best corn I've ever tasted. We bought some on Saturday morning to grill for dinner that night. I didn't even need to put anything on it, because it was so moist and flavorful.I also bought some blueberries, which beat the pants off any grocery store berries I've had, including Trader Joe's and Whole Foods (let's not talk about Jewel and Dominick's produce here--that's bush league stuff). Why? Because they aren't pre-packed and left to sit on a shelf all week. The berries I bought were picked on Friday, then put by hand into an unwrapped container on Saturday, the same day I bought them. You know those gross, mushy berries that hang out in the middle of the carton and sometimes mold, spoiling the whole carton before you can eat it all? I didn't have any of those in my carton from the PRFM. Why? Because somebody had *just put the berries in the carton,* and if they saw a gross berry, they didn't put it in there. Only today, three days after purchase, do I detect any signs of mush, and that doesn't really matter because I finished off the carton with breakfast. I *never* get to finish cartons of berries, because some mushy-to-moldy stowaways always ruin the carton before I can get through it. I guess I've just been buying them from the wrong place.Another perk: many of the people working here can answer questions about the produce and other products. They know because they grew/packed/baked the stuff. They can also make recommendations for you if you tell them how you're going to use the item. For example, when I told the mushroom lady that I planned to grill the portobello mushrooms, she dug around her mushroom treasure chest and found me some mushrooms of what she considers the ideal size and thickness for grilling.  She also recommended herbs for the preparation (also available at the PRFM).A lot of people seem to think farmer's markets are pricey, but I don't think it's that bad. The prices ranged from a little less than what I would pay at Jewel to about what I'd pay at Whole Foods, depending on the item. There were also some booths selling the same items from different farmers and at different prices, so you could shop around to find the best prices on many items. Plus, they have items here that you just don't see at the store, like currants. I don't even know if the currants were priced well, because I've simply never found them in a store. Plus, most of it is organic, and I am comparing the prices to the non-organic produce at Jewel or Dominick's. There are, of course, a few ways the PRFM could improve. First, the parking is confusing. There's a lot nearby that says, "AT&T parking only! All others will be towed!" We therefore parked in a metered space next to the lot. On the way back to the car, I saw a ton of people who had not been towed loading veggies into their vehicles. I think maybe a sign or two letting people know they can park in that lot and don't have to do laps waiting for a metered space to open up would be nice. Also, I know it's not as big, but in my head I compare it to the farmer's market in Daley Plaza. To me, it is the holy grail of farmer's markets. Since Park Ridge is of course much smaller than Chicago, it isn't really fair for me to compare the two, but I can't help it. Of course, since I live so close to the PRFM but not close to Daley Plaza, my greens wouldn't wilt on the trip home (if the PRFM has greens sometime I go, that is). Somewhat balancing that is the amount of dogs at the PRFM that aren't at the DPFM. Sooo many cute dogs!Also of note: there's an old guy hand-sharpening knives and scissors in a lot just next to the market. I don't know how often he's there or if he's officially part of the market, but it's pretty cool watching him sit at his old-school contraption and do it. I might bring my dull pruning shears next time and see if he does gardening implements, too.

<review# 996,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/16/2012,2/26/2012,363,708,6,10,8>A delightful little spot in downtown Lisle.We live a lot closer to Downers Grove and Lisle than we used to, so I decided it was high time to start exploring. I brought an old friend here for some chocolate and catching up. As other reviewers note, it's in a little strip mall underneath a condo building, so not the most obvious location, but not too hard to find and easy to park. The atmosphere is whimsical and cozy. And everything looks and smells so wonderful.My friend and I both went for the 5-scoop "bambino" sampler. These are little baby scoops -- about the size of a golf ball -- so you can try a variety without feeling totally piggish. I tried banana, chocolate-hazelnut, heath bar, chocolate java and raspberry. Oh, heavens, they were all delicious. The banana and chocolate java really stuck out, but I would eat any of them again -- or try five new flavors, because they were all pretty tempting. (I did not see burnt caramel, which is a shame, that sounds great.)They also have fondue, truffles, various chocolate-covered goodies, espresso and espresso-based drinks, a variety of hot chocolates from standard to super-fancy gourmet, smoothies and hot tea.We sat and talked for at least two hours and never got any glares or really, any attention at all -- the sweet and friendly owner just let us be. It was never jam-packed but some other customers did come and go while we were there, and I'm glad to see it, because I want this place to survive, so I can bring more girlfriends here!

I was over there faster than you could say "BBQ ME!" and I burst into the front doors with excitement. Luckily, they had everything that I had ordered and I was all set to go! No attitude, no muss, no fuss. It was extremely nice of them to take my order, almost 45 minutes past closing time. We were so happy with our pre-dinner snack - we're never disappointed with Q! Thanks again guys - we appreciate it!
<review# 998,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/22/2011,2/24/2012,359,353,5,5,3>Pho.nomenal.Un.Pho.gettable.I was introduced to Pho about a year ago. Since then it has been a weekly ritual at a hole in the wall near my home. No joke. The highlight of my week is "Pho Friday". However, finding a great little spot near the office for lunch had been somewhat challenging...until I discovered Dung Gia. At first the menu is slightly overwhelming. It's HUGE. I stuck to my tried and true items. The Goi Cuon and peanut sauce (Vietnamese spring rolls - with tofu) were delish! As a non-seaftood eater, it was nice to see a variety of spring rolls...without shrimp! I also indulged in a large bowl of beef Pho. The beef and the noodles were perfect,  and the broth was extremely flavorful. I loaded my bowl with jalapeno and basil and chowed down. The waitstaff was friendly. The service was fast. The food was fantastic. Will I be back??? Pho Sho!
<review# 999,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/2/2012,2/23/2012,209,310,4,9,6>Well, I was so happy to hear of a new bakery in La Grange.  I mean people, my tag line on Yelp is "BROWNIES ARE MY LIFE".  So I have been trying to arrange my schedule to get on down there.  FIrst, hip, hip, hooray!  A bakery open till 9 pm in the burbs!!!!!  My husband and I chose several of the traditional mexican american pastries -- sweet potato camote (sweet bread stuffed with pureed sweet potato, honey & butter), strawberry concha (like a puff pastry  with crunchy sugar strawberry coat on outside), marranitos gingerbread (traditional molasses gingerbread pig shaped cookies) and then I also had to try their frosted brownie.  Now, there is much more to choose from here.  Cupcakes, cakes, cookies.  But I am not one who can have a stockpile of baked goods at her home and restrain herself.  No, if it is there, it gets eaten.  My favs were the gingerbread and the sweet potato.  The gingerbread is airy and light.  With a touch of flavor.  Glazed on top, I can imagine having this with a nice cup of coffee in the morning. I of course, could not wait.  I ate it right when I got home.  The sweet potato was a nice surprise.  UNIQUE and yummy.  Not sugary, yet sweet.  The pastry dough was nice and fresh.  Oh no, I just realized I missed the tamales... ah, next visit!Now for the brownie.  Beautifully frosted, chewy and dense.  I liked it.  Not in my top 10, but not bad.  I would have to add a more natural chocolate flavor.  It was rich, but needs that deep cocoa kick.  Not overly sweet, so that was a plus.Overall, great customer service.  I spoke with the owner.  Extremely nice guy.  I like what they are doing.  I love the nice mix of Mexican-American pastries with the traditional American stuff.  Nicely decorated.  I will continue to try tasty treats at this bakery!  Oh one more great thing.  My total bill, $4.80.  That's in my budget!

<review# 1001,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/4/2011,2/21/2012,54,226,4,9,6>Every time I make the 40 minute trek back home I make sure to go out of my way to get two Gene's and Jude's hot dogs with everything for lunch.  In fact, I've been coming here since I was just a wee hot dog devotee and this whole recent "Best Hot Dog in America" thing pretty much validates my crazy ramblings that, yes, the best Chicago dog is in fact in the suburbs.This place epitomizes a small and perfectly crafted food stand.  I really don't care about the line or lack of seating or even the cleanliness (to be honest, I think the food tasted even better before they had to start wearing gloves) - it's all about the hot dogs and fries.  The tamales are pretty good too, but it feels like I'm wasting a trip when I get one of those.In short, this place is the Gene's and Jude's of hot dog stands (can we say that now?).
<review# 1002,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/19/2012,2/20/2012,160,654,5,8,7>I will admit I never knew about speed skating till Bonnie Blair won all those gold medals back in the 90's. Even then, I envisioned the sport being a distant thing; something that people do in faraway Utah, northern Wisconsin or even Duluth, MN but not anywhere close to Chicago. I was wrong on that one. Being the parent of a rather physical and athletic 5 year old led me to this organization. We discovered them last summer at Taste of Park Ridge. Just weeks before, my 5 year old son had been learning figure skating and enjoyed being on the ice. I asked if he would like to "skate fast." Of course he agreed...Now, Park Ridge is one of a number of speed skating clubs in the surrounding area. These clubs hold regular meets and compete together in the area. While the PR Speed Skating Club's home ice is at Oakton Ice Arena, they are not affiliated with the Park Ridge Park District, so you won't see them in the quarterly catalog of park programs and lessons. Even living in Park Ridge some 7 years now, it wasn't until last summer I became aware of their existence.Speed skating is pretty fascinating to watch. You have people zipping around at top speeds close to 40 mph on long skates with a flat blade. They wear helmets and padded suits, since a fall on the ice can send them sliding towards a sidewall. There's padding around the track for this very reason. The sound of a group of skaters taking off at the  starting line is like a stampede of skates as they all get off to a running start on the ice. Then the gracefulness of the sport becomes evident: the crossover of the skater's legs lets the skaters move on the ice with incredible speed yet making it look so effortless at the same time. Head down low, hands at their sides or behind their backs, the skaters glide with ease on the sheer ice. A breeze blows by as a group of skaters passes you while you watch. For the fitness-conscious, speed skating is a sport that uses every muscle in the body in a coordinated movement. Looking at the skaters on the ice, it is quite apparent the most prevalent body type is tall and slender, with very little fat on the arms and thighs. Most of the skaters are in their teens, though there are adults and some grade school kids too. Among the skaters there is even an older doctor, who also recommends skating to his patients for its obvious health benefit of staying fit.Though we showed interest in the speed skating program, I had to find them since they did not contact me after we inquired for more information at the Taste. A little more self-promotion and marketing would probably attract more people to the sport. The club offers 3 free sessions to people interested in speed skating. It took only one class for my 5 year old to get hooked on the sport. After spending over an hour on the ice till his feet hurt, he came off the ice and said, "No more skating slow, I want to skate FAST!" It didn't take long before I signed him up for the season. The speed skating season runs from September till March, with a bigger regional competition at Oakton and other smaller novice competitions at Oakton as well.The skating practices take place twice a week, Tuesdays and Thursday evenings, about an hour and 15 minutes per session. The ice time for the speed skaters is sandwiched between figure skating lessons and hockey games that happen later. For the cost of a season membership, it is well worth the value compared to the park district's 30-minute long, once a week sessions where you might have a lot less individualized attention from the instructors. The Park Ridge Club shares the ice with the Glen Ellyn club, so there's plenty of skaters and coaches to work with them. And among the notable coaches, PR has Nancy Swider-Peltz who's a former Olympian herself. With my son being the smallest skater out there and no other 5 year olds in the program, he's had a number of sessions where a coach worked with him one on one for the entire class. The progress is immediately obvious and he has developed so much since he began in late September, just a little more than 4 months ago. The organization is a lot like family. We all hang out on the side opposite the bleacher section and watch the kids skate, kind of like soccer moms, we're speed skating moms and dads. We set up and put away the padded sidewalls, fill buckets of water to pour on the ice when it gets rough, and we cheer on our future champions as they learn the sport. It's a good place to start if you like skating and want to get into shape.
<review# 1003,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/10/2011,2/19/2012,850,1294,12,17,17>Pardon my Croatian, but I am a krafne-kurva. I would do dirty, dirty deeds in exchange for those custard and fruit filled goodies. The first time I ever tried them was for karneval aka maskare in Samobor, Hrvatska. I'm pretty sure that sugar isn't the only powder they are rolled around in because they are as addictive as crack.What exactly are krafne? They are also known as krof, krofne, pokladnice, krapfen, bismarcks, sufganiyah and kobliha in other countries. Here, in the Polish capital of America, they are known as paczki. This is a Polish bakery, so you play by their rules and call it what they call it. And it's fun to hear all the different ways people try to pronounce it: "poonch-key" or "punch-key" but it's really "pohnch-key".I've returned to Central Continental every year since I moved to Chicagoland. This is where I come for Paczki Fest. It starts on Fat Thursday (traditional Packi Day in Poland) and runs through Fat Tuesday. Why limit yourself to gorging upon them the day before Lent begins when you can start the celebration on Thursday? That's almost an entire week of paczki partying!With over three dozen flavors to choose from, it is hard to go wrong. But I truly think the traditional raspberry and the chocolate covered custard are the way to go. The gourmet are way too rich, but fun to try just to say you survived. They've also wised up and created a number system not only for walk-ins but for pre-orders now. That means you'll get to enjoy all those calories that much faster. Don't forget your fat pants!
<review# 1004,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/28/2012,2/18/2012,60,239,9,8,7>Our tastebuds traveled to Sicily last night when we dined at Elio Pizza On Fire.  Thankfully, our "tour guide", Adrianna was there to help us choose from their incredible pizza menu.  For most of you, this is unlike any pizza you have ever had.  You don't order a sausage and mushroom or pepperoni, onions and green pepper.  No, no, no... you'll find amazing items like Rucolina, Primavera, Pirata, Gusti, and Dolcezza on the menu.  That's where the lovely Adrianna comes in.  She's both translator and tour guide as you explore the authentic Sicilian pizza landscape.Here's what we had:Mediterrenea Salad - A nice sald for two to share with romaine lettuce, fresh tomato, red onions, Calamata olives, sundried tomato, cucumbers and liberally drizzled with their own balsamic dressing.  This is a wonderful start for your meal.We decided to order 2 pizzas and share them and take the remainder home.  Our first choice was the Ortolana which is topped with fresh plum tomato, mozzarella, grilled eggplant, grilled zucchini, roasted red pepper and drizzled with extra virgin olive oil.  This was a wonderful veggie pizza option!  We sometimes get bored with typical veggie pizzas because it's the same old, same old.  Not at Elios.  You can really taste the freshness of the ingrdients.The second pizza we ordered was the Rucolina.  All I can say is "WOW!!"  Fresh mozzarella, arugula, prosciutto parma, grana cheese flakes, and extra virgin olive oil.  Sounds simple right?  We added red sauce per Adrianna's suggestion and it was quite frankly one of the best pizzas I have ever had!We finished with about 5 slices of pizza to take home for the next day.  Now here's the best part - we had a salad, 2 pizzas and 3 sodas.  Cost = $29.49.  Yes, you read that right, just a shade under 30 bucks.  I have spent 3X the amount at some restaurants and not enjoyed my food as much as I did last night at Elios.Let me offer a few tips that might help you better enjoy your experience:1) It's a real P-I-T-A to find because there is no obvious sign blaring out "ELIO ON FIRE".  When traveling on Lake Street, enter the strip mall parking lot just east of the McDonalds and directly across the street from the entrance to Sal's Beverage Depot.  (It's the strip mall on the south side of Lake with the taqueria right when you turn into the lot.)  Elio is at the opposite end of the strip mall at the very end.2) IF you enjoy wine and beer with your meal, find a place to park and cross the street and grab yourself a beverage at Sal's Beverage Depot.  Adrianna said that people are welcome to BYOB.  NOTE: They do NOT serve alcohol.3) When dining as a couple, whether to order one pizza or two?  If you are really hungry, I say "go for it!" and take the leftovers home.  Not that hungry and want to save a few bucks, share a salad and a pizza.  Throw in a nice bottle of your own wine and you can get a decent meal for two for under $50.    4) Bring cash - they don't take credit cards.5) Ask for Adrianna - she'll take good care of you!  Be sure to leave a nice tip.So there you have it.  A new, family owned restaurant in the heart of Addison serving some of the best pizza I have ever had.  I haven't been this excited since discovering Bigby's!
<review# 1005,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/29/2011,2/17/2012,252,423,5,9,7>This is my favorite breakfast & brunch place when I'm in the mood for a breakfast that's a little bit different & not diner-style.  Hubby & I have to keep coming back because there are dozens of things on the menu we want to try.  Their menu is quite large for breakfast & brunch and the variety is truly inspired.  They have your normal omelettes and skillets but also many gourmet options.My favorites are the Zucchini Cakes (think potato pancake but made with zucchini), the Ham & Sweet Potato Omelet (seasonal), and any of the many Benedicts they have to offer.  I recently ordered an omelet I had been wanting to try but it always got bumped for a seasonal selection; the Morroccan Omelet.  To some it may sound strange but I knew Benedict's Eggs & More wouldn't disappoint.  Medjool dates, bacon, almonds, goat cheese, drizzled with a balsamic reduction over the omelet.  OMG, it was amazingly good.  There's still plenty on the menu to try...want to give some of their French Toasts & Pancakes a whirl some time when I'm not in an eggy mood.The restaurant is small, expect to wait on busy weekend mornings.  Not so bad when the weather is nice and you can wait outside (inside waiting area is tiny).  Because of it's smaller size the tables can be close together but I still love the feel of the place.  And who wouldn't like a restaurant with a tree sprouting up through the floor?  The staff have always been friendly and courteous.  They recently introducted a frequent diner program which is just perfect for those of us addicted to this place!

I cannot wait to go back! My six year old said she wants to go there every meal from now on!
<review# 1007,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/8/2011,2/15/2012,161,158,5,8,6>I definitely love this place like I love crabs.  But be warned, It's always crowded here and probably because they are an landmark of their own.  The day I went, it was a Saturday night back in February (26th) and their entire foyer was filled with people waiting to be called in for their party.  The wait was roughly about 1.5 hour long which would seem ridiculous but when you look at all the hundreds of people standing there waiting with you, you wonder there has to be something here that makes this place so great. Well for one, they have such a huge selection on their menu that it will make any seafood lovers think that they've just died and gone to heaven.  There are so many options to choose from that I had no idea what I wanted.  I knew I wanted crabs but when I saw that there are 10 different crabs I can get, I was blown away.  That night, they even passed out menus while we were waiting in line to be seated to make our ordering time faster.    I went with my BF and his family that night and when we got to the table, we couldn't wait to start the meal.  Here is the break down of some of the memorable foods we ordered and my commentary: Crab cakes & Alfredo pasta- boiled better than fried.Joe's Crab Claws- 4 pieces for $11Ahi Mahi Stirfry- chow fun noodles Kohan Crabs- sweet and warm,.whole crabsSirloin Steak- 16oz. Prime rib, juicy and tender. I had the Crab Claws and they were definitely worth the $11 for an appetizer.  I've been to other restaurants where it was $14 for one crab claw! It was meaty and good but if you really want to go for crabs, get the Kohan meal which was what my BF's mother got.  The portion for that was huge and the meat is served warm.  All of their crabs are fresh and so savory.  The Kohan's meat taste particularly sweet.  I would definitely get this dish on my next trip back.  Now the only thing I wouldn't recommend from this experience is if you get crab cakes, don't get them fried. If you do, they cover your crab cake in a layer of tater-tots-like coating that really ruins the taste of the crabs because it makes your cake taste starchy and at some parts that was burnt, the potatoes were just hard.   I'm just not fond of fried potatoes on my crabs.  My BF got the Ahi Mahi Stirfry and it was really well flavored with a good amount of fish.  Imagine a sort of fish chow fun noodle dish.  If you like seafood and you like Chinese food and you don't want to get your hands dirty (like him), this is your dish.  Overall, Bob Chinn's has great eats! Come ready to get your hands dirty. This place is apt to cater to ridiculous amount of people so it's a good place for big groups.  Service is good but busy.  It's has more of a casual and noisy ambience than a fancy atmosphere. It would make a great place for family dinner or a good meal with friends..

<review# 1009,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/11/2011,2/13/2012,62,147,5,7,6>Massa, as if I even need to further stress how good of a place this is; it already gets some of the best written reviews, as well as word-of-mouth praises. I've heard so many people jump out of their seats to talk about Massa that before I ever went, I pictured it something like a gelato Disney Land.Conveniently located next to my favorite local sushi spot, Inari Sushi, on North Ave. Each restaurant has the same owners and they carry excellence for both locations.I've read a few reviews regarding poor service, but I beg to differ. I've been to Massa around a dozen times and the good service has never faltered. So, enough about that.Now I haven't ventured into the full extent of what Massa has to offer, so I can't thoroughly comment on the food (pizza, panini, etc), but I've heard that they have really good appetizers, and the pizza isn't too shabby either. People have also mentioned the generous portion sizes, which will always draw me in no matter what.But the appetizers are exactly what they should be, the stepping stone to the main attraction: the gelato. Massa makes some of the most authentic gelato I've had in the local Chicagoland area. Everything is thick, creamy, flavorful; everything you'd expect ouf of fine Italian gelato. The gelato menu changes very frequently which is great because I've never had the same one twice and gives me a chance to try more flavors (YAY!). One of my favorites, and of my firsts, at Massa was the cannoli gelato.Overall a great place. I can't give it five stars because I haven't tried the actual food, so upon my next visit I'll make it a point to have the food and I'll post an update.

<review# 1011,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/29/2011,2/11/2012,137,199,6,6,6>I stopped by here last Sunday to watch my friends' little 6 year old play in the Championship game of a Thanksgiving weekend tournament.  I was really impressed with this place!  Two regulation size rinks were being used at the time...one for this tournament, and the other for public skate.  The lobby has a nice, cozy feel of a ski lodge and has ample seating for those who want to come in from the cold of the rinks and enjoy a cup of coffee or hot chocolate.  Plenty of help behind the main desk made waiting in any lines for information or skate rental short and uneventful.  The concession stand didn't have a lot to offer, but had the staples and pretty much what you'd expect to find at an ice rink, to be fair.Trying to find a washroom may be difficult, though...especially for the men.  For some reason, the women's is at the end of the lobby, but the men's is in the north rink, behind one of the goals.  Strange.I'll definitely be back for free skate or maybe even rat hockey one of these days.  Located not too far from I-55 and Rt 53, it's conveniently located from basically all directions.  Seeya there!

<review# 1013,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/27/2011,2/9/2012,136,719,2,8,7>This building is deceptively small looking from the outside. <review# 1014,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/27/2011,2/8/2012,204,392,9,9,6>Stalkery. That is exactly what it has resulted to in order to finally making the moves and stepping a lovely pair of purple stilettos into Coopers Hawk. A friend and I have been going back and forth for months. Both watching when the windows went in, when the bottles in the windows got in, the doors opening...and us cancelling plans to meet up for a wine night. Finally, after much anticipation we made it out for a little indulgence and more decadence that could fill you with glee.Coopers Hawk is gorgeous, from the minute you walk in through the front doors and into the tasting room you're greeted with a tasting from one of the local barrels. Thank and you. From there it's basically fair game on what you plan on doing. And there are three options. For which are bullet-pointed.-Tasting Room: Something from a cross between Sonoma look-alike to well, stand-alone wine supplier. Inside this little hub you've got so many things to feast your eyes on from the bottles along the walls to the bottle toppers and serving plates perfect to hold cheeses and little bits of nosh to accompany some wine.-Bar: Why hello lover, thanks for holding that chair for me. Sexy and chic, especially for Naperville.  This section is brilliant for an after work cocktail, a place to meet up and slink away with a friend/date/whatever for a bit sipping anything and everything.-Dining Room: Where there's a will, there's definitely a way. Beautifully decorated, the spacious dining room is filled with booths and tables. And even though there's enough seating-it surprisingly feels private. Loved this.Something a little out of the ordinary that is a special treat are the wine carafes. They are extremely ornate and look like glass table ornaments-only filled with wine. Hello.For this visit we decided to of course have flights of wine:Sparkling - the beauty of the flights was the Raspberry and Almond. Showstoppers.White Wine - the house blend was smooth and utterly perfect for anytime of day. Any-time.For the food, we kept it pretty simple:Thai lettuce wraps that came with three separate sauces. The caramel was beyond gorgeous for the tastebuds.Lobster and Crab Bisque. Oh holy greatness. Full-bodied bowl filled with enough punch and flavor to make you want another. What an absolute gem for Naperville, this is most definitely going to be a regular place to meet up with friends. Prices are no different than any other type of establishment, the service is spot on and this is that one place where I am more than happy to roll out of the booths with a light buzz from the food or the wine.
<review# 1015,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/21/2012,2/7/2012,91,73,8,12,8>O SWEET CHEEZUS!!Definitely something I'd say about the NEW gourmet popcorn shop on the block, The Gourmet Kernel!  You may wonder, "Maria, why are you SO excited about a popcorn shop?  It's JUST popcorn." *COUGH COUGH SPUTTER* WHAT?!  Popcorn is SERIOUS BUSINESS! Do not disrespect the popcorn!!Popcorn and I have a very long, long long, friendship.  Movie popcorn, caramel popcorn, cheddar popcorn...air popped...popcorn smothered in yummy, oh-so-delicious, and melty butter(my other 'love'). Yep, I am a popcorn fangirl! :) Don't try to take my popcorn away unless you wanna lose a hand!But, seriously, I was SO excited to find out there was a gourmet popcorn(which is way different than just your regular, microwave or home-popped popcorn) shop, which was closer than the other gourmet popcorn shop that I would travel over 25 minutes to to get my stash of popcorn.  I first read about The Gourmet Kernel on the internet and was VERY excited about it being in the Algonquin Commons shopping center. I loved the story about the owner, Judy Reyes, another popcorn lover, who decided that this area needed a gourmet popcorn shop.  And ya know, I am VERY GLAD she opened it up! :)Today, I was greeted by the owner herself, not only with a handshake, but with a hug! Awww, I was sooo touched! And WOO she scored many Customer Service Points from me! :)  While my kids were all jumping around and excited looking at the popcorn, we were able to sample not just ONE, but all of their flavors.  Their regular flavors are and with my review of each:Caramelt - (Caramel Popcorn) - Caramelt is melty buttery carmelly goodness....it doesn't taste "burnt", which is one thing I look for in caramel popcorn, or "too fakey tasting" like artificial caramel flavor. I can tell, when you can taste the butter, you KNOW it is gonna be awesome! :)Cheddar, Cheddar - (Golden Cheddar Popcorn) - Cheddar Cheddar (so cheesy you gotta say it twice!) is definitely cheese factor 11 here! :) It definitely passes my cheese popcorn test and I love cheese AND popcorn!  The cheese is just the right amount to give any cheese lover a euphoric feeling! :)O Sweet Cheezus - (Golden Cheddar & Caramel Popcorn Combination) - Their "Chicago Mix" it definitely gives you the cheesy and the caramel in one happy package.  You will definitely not be disappointed! It's two great popcorns that taste great together! Who knew?Blanca - (White Cheddar Popcorn) - If you want even MORE cheese....the Blanca is definitely the second coming of the cheesesplosion! :) I'll have to grab myself a bag of this next time!:)Kettlecorn - What's there to say?  They have pretty darn good kettlecorn! :9  Salty-sweet.....it's not caramel, but it isn't just plain salted popcorn either. It's both! NOMNOMNOM!  Why wait for fall?  Get it now and experience fall all over again! Popfetti (Fruit Flavored Popcorn) - Popfetti is a popcorn flavor I've NEVER experienced before.  Fruit flavored popcorn?!  WOOOW! Lemme tell you, kids LOVE this stuff. I love it too, but it is VERY powerful...powerful in a sense of OMG SWEET! :)   I think it MAY be "lethal" in too large of a dose.  But, take a small one! :) It's dense in sweetness, but definitely has all the fruity flavors you and kids LOVE!  The fruit flavors rotate, which I think is mighty cool! Flavors include: Green Apple, Strawberry, Banana, Blueberry, and Grape.Finally, we have their "Flavor of the Month" which is decided by Business students of local colleges.  They flavor test and have to come up with the name for the new popcorn flavor.  Another VERY cool thing, I think! Taco Loco (Taco & Sour Cream Popcorn) - Lemme tell you, it DOES taste like taco popcorn.  I love the addition of sour cream, cause I love me some sour cream on my crispy beef taco! :9 Definitely addicting!One flavor I did not try is their Buttery popcorn...I will update when I do try it!The prices were up to par of the other gourmet popcorn shops, but for popcorn as seriously yummy as Gourmet Kernel's popcorn is.  It's a fair price to pay! :9 They fill up the popcorn bags pretty generously...so, don't think you are gonna get gipped, you will get what you pay for!  With the terrific customer service and warm and welcoming atmosphere, Gourmet Kernel does NOT disappoint!  Not to mention, they offer you a bunch of wet naps to wipe your fingers with when digging them into the O Sweet Cheezus and/or Cheddar, Cheddar.  Orangey Colored Fingers?   Not for Gourmet Kernel's customers! Oh, and the employees are not just popcorn sellers, they are called POPISTAS(Like Baristas), which I think is very inventive! :)I'm looking forward to the new flavors in the future because I see myself coming to visit Judy and her wonderful gourmet popcorn shop OFTEN! :)   Gourmet Kernel....you've made a new fan and a new regular customer with me! :) Keep on rockin' the great popcorn!

<review# 1017,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/17/2011,2/4/2012,63,60,13,8,9>There are few reasons to visit Villa Park, but of those few, this is a big one. It's the Disney World of  Villa Park- not in size, theme, business type, revenue, traffic, or kid-friendliness- but in importance as a draw to the community. And that fact is my personal opinion.Lunar is a dive bar with a heart of gold. It's a completely unassuming building that houses the best beers I have ever had. Have you ever seen Die Hard 3: Die Hard With a Vengeance? It's the one where those German guys go into a bank and you're like, "Oh, it's just a bank." But then they get under the building and it turns out that it's the largest gold bank in the States? And they rob it? Remember? And you're like, "I did not realize they had that much gold under that bank!"Well, Lunar is kind of like that. When you get there you figure this bar is way overhyped, and then you find out they brew their own stuff, and you're like "Hm. OK." But then it turns out the bar has many delicious beers for almost any taste. The next thing you know, you are thinking about how this is the most awesome place you have ever had a beer. And how you have never had better beer before in your life. Upon reflection, my analogies in this review have been kind of off. I do not suggest robbing this place with a group of Germans.They do not have gold, or a even a national stockpile of anything. Remember, you are in Villa Park. The point is that Lunar is much cooler and surprising than it appears. It is a delightful experience, and you should go there with some friends and support the brewers in their quest to improve the world through excellent beer.

It wasn't until the night before that we realized we forgot to place a catering order somewhere! We considered our options and went over to this restaurant around 9pm. When we walked in, Vince himself wanted to personally take care of our order. Vince is the sweet Italian grandfather type -- we enjoyed speaking with him. He had no problem with our late order (a few hours' notice is usually all they need) and even threw in an extra pizza in our order for being new customers!After we placed our catering order, we decided to stay for a drink and check out the place. It was lovely -- the lights were low and cozy, the place was quiet (a few diners), and next to the bar was a man playing classic songs on a guitar. A mid-aged couple was slow dancing to his songs. It was very romantic. The drinks were good and moderately priced. We rarely take the time to just sit together for a drink and decided to make this happen here at least once a month.The next day, we picked up the food -- warm and right on time! We ordered mostacolli, a garden salad (with spinach, mushrooms, veggies), garlic bread, and a couple pizzas (we didn't get that extra free pizza Vince promised.... but that's OK). The garden salad came with a few different dressings on the side. I have no complaints about most of the food -- it was all great! We also had plenty of mostocolli left over and it tasted great the rest of the week. However, while the pizza was good, I won't be coming here just to order a pizza. I'll come here for the other food, lovely atmosphere, and friendly staff.
<review# 1020,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/28/2011,2/1/2012,63,167,4,10,6>I have been to Crazy Buffet many times for lunch.  I was here on the first day they opened this location and it is on my standard rotation.It is located in a strip mall and there is plenty of parking.  This restaurant is located in a huge space with lots of seating.  There are lots of windows that make the place bright and cheerful.  The tables and booths are much nicer than I normally see in this type of place.Crazy Buffet is an above average chinese/japanese/american buffet.  For $8.50 (they raised the price in June), you get all the food you can eat.  Drinks are extra, but I always drink water with my lunch anyway.The food quality may not be the highest, but it is certainly not bad.  If you eat fast food, then this would be a step up for you.The hibachi section allows you to stand in line, pick your own ingredients and they will grill it up for you.  I have never tried it because I don't like to take the time and I don't want to worry about putting together a good combination.Pro tip:  Do not let them seat you in the sections closest to the door.  The hibachi grill is on that side and you will walk away soaked in grease.There is much talk of sushi at this place.  The sushi is plentiful, but fish is not.  Remember that sushi is cold boiled rice moistened with rice vinegar.  The toppings that we associate with sushi are variable.  Most of the sushi at Crazy Buffet is served as various forms of California rolls.  There is a little bit of fake crab and some canned tuna, but that is about it.  I enjoy this selection for what it is.  Did you really expect to get all you can eat sushi grade salmon for under 10 bucks?  How could the place stay in business?If you want a little seafood, they do have crawfish in the shell, several kinds of shrimp, and some baked salmon.The Chinese inspired dishes are OK, but nothing great.  Many of the meats are heavily covered in breading.  Of course this is a way to keep the cost down.  I like the black pepper chicken, chicken on a stick  and the spicy shrimp.  The sauteed green beans always find a spot on my plate as well.There is a cold food section with salads and fruits and such.  I have sampled a few but this is not my favorite section.  There are just so many choices that I tend to stick with my favorites.To finish off an already decadent lunch, there are sweets.  The coolest is the eight kinds of hand dipped ice cream.  I almost always get the green tea ice cream.  There are some issues with the way the ice cream is presented.  It is often rock hard and due to the way the sneeze guard is installed, it can be very difficult to get the right angle and leverage to get the ice cream scooped.  I have actually scooped for women who were having difficulty.  I mentioned this to the manager, but he was not sympathetic and merely dismissed me with a "it's health code".In general the servers are pleasant and efficient in clearing plates and refilling water.  I have had times where they were very busy and difficult to find, but that is the exception.Keeping in mind what this place is, I think they do a good job.  Good food at a very reasonable price.  That is why I will keep coming back.

<review# 1024,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/12/2011,1/28/2012,37,313,5,7,5>I want to give them slightly above 4 stars, but not quite 5 stars.House of Pho is co-owned by business partners from China and Vietnam, so their food is very authentic. I tried a number of dishes here, but first off, the most outstanding thing about this place is the price-to-value relationship. Most of their dishes (for dinner) range from $7 (the Pho) to about $12 (some fancier Chinese style dishes). The portions for the Pho, like other reviewers have wrote about, are HUGE. Most guys that will eat a lot will barely finish. So onto the food...Vietnamese Spring Rolls (4 stars out of 5). They contain three shrimp along with the vermicelli noodles and some vegetables. They are authentic in taste and the peanut sauce that comes along with it is fairly thick but complements the rolls well. Why is it not 5 stars? It's a little bit too chewy. I almost think it's missing something that could make it spectacular, but I don't know what it is.Pho Tai (5 stars out of 5). This was one of the biggest bowls of Pho I've ever had. The broth was truly authentic, tasty, and delicious. The thinly sliced beef that comes in it was fresh and awesome tasting. It came with a huge plate of complimentary sprouts, mint, peppers. The size of it definitely got me going and I downed it pretty fast. It will be tough trying to order something else when I'm here other than this!Hong Kong Style Milk Tea (3 stars out of 5). It's A-OK. But it's not fantastic. I was reading how the way you tell if it's authentic is it's smooth and doesn't taste too creamy. It hits on those two cylinders. I got it warm, but the downside was it wasn't sweet enough for my taste. That's probably my own fault for ordering it. I think it's worth a try but I am not sure who would like it.Service (3.5 stars out of 5). Don't get me wrong, the service isn't bad. It's slightly above average. They are a fairly new restaurant so I'm sure they are still working out a lot of the kinks. I would have preferred they come and check our water levels a bit more (but I was never dry so that was nice). I think they could do a bit more checking on the table. Every now and then, I wanted to ask the owner or waitress something but it was difficult to get their attention. We went during a non-busy dinner hour (around 7-8pm) and they weren't too swamped.Ambiance (4 stars out of 5). There are a lot of tables there and I'm not sure how they fill it all. I get the inclination that they are a lot busier during the lunch hour. But there is a lot of spacing between tables. There is nice music going on in the background. It's a nice place for a big gathering or just for a date.

Overall, I am really pleased with my experience,  but wish there was a little more thought put into the cardio aspect of the daily routines. Some days are action packed as$ kickers where I get my heart rate up while resistance training, other days are more of a general weight training class... I prefer the days when I can get the cardio and resistance in one powerful punch!  (This is just my personal preference however.)The one thing I didn't appreciate was the secrecy of what a membership would cost when I first called to inquire about the program.... <review# 1033,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/16/2011,1/19/2012,92,360,4,10,5>So take two for restaurants in this location is Tipsi Monkey, an upscale take on Mexican food. They opened 5 days ago with a splash, so I decided to check it out. The meal opened with freshly baked tortilla chips with a simple salsa. The chips were fantastically crisp, salted just right and not too oily or greasy. I was pleasantly surprised by the amount of heat in the salsa, which tasted fresh and had two, possibly three kinds of pepper in it. We kicked off appetizers with spicy coconut shrimp. Tipsi, in general, tries for the "quality over quantity" philosophy of restauranteering, which is how I found out this dish consisted of six breaded shrimp with a side of slaw. The shrimp were excellent, though physically flat, covered in a layer of coconut and set off just right sweet and spicy sauce. The slaw makes a good creamy counterpoint, and it's seasoned and has raisins in it. Next came the soups, which seem to be free with a menu item for now. The tortilla soup shined; brightly acidic, a complex chicken broth heavily steeped in cilantro, and about the only time someone has served raw onions to me without me gagging. Oh, and served with more tortilla chips. The chicken and rice soup was good; a bit heavy on the cilantro and raw onions though. We went with the taco party option, with chorizo/potato and steak as the meats. You get a ton of stuff with it... more raw onions and cilantro, tomatoes and onions, a light sour cream and decent guacamole.The steak was cooked with pineapples, and was nice and tender. As far as I could tell, it had a decent rub on it. The chorizo was perfect with the creamy potatoes. The interior of the restaurant is dark, and filled with monkeys. Not even joking. The scary one is located above the entryway...I was really impressed with this place, and I hope it does well in Bartlett. I definitely would like to try out some desserts, and I'd like to see how the food settles out after a few months.

<review# 1036,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/21/2011,1/16/2012,99,760,4,10,6>I finally made it to Gaetano's, after hearing much about it from friends, seeing it in Yelp emails, and even having to cancel once. But I'm so glad I made it. I went with two others, and we ordered the "three course" chef's menu, which is served family style for the appropriate number of diners. Note the quotes around "Three Course." Of note, the chef's menu is completely free form, they just check to see if you have any dislikes (such as raw food) or allergies (like shellfish, etc) and then it's all just an avalanche of deliciousness.We had (deep breath):-- sliced beet, mache, and goat cheese salad-- raw tuna carpaccio with mango, hearts of palm, cherry tomatoes, and some other things I forget-- cocoa dusted seared scallops in cauliflower puree-- crab cakes in a spicy tomato sauce-- beef and chorizo stuffed beets in coconut tomato cream sauce-- seared kobe beef carpaccio with garlic bread-- pork ribs poached in orange water with a honey chipotle glaze-- house made (or at least it seemed like it) pasta in a butter parmesan sauce with black truffles-- a shot glass of butternut squash soup with chile and cilantro oil-- a dessert trio of hazelnut gelatto, tiramisu, and panna cota bread puddingSo yeah. "Three" courses. Whatever. I'm glad that I went along with my friends when they said the "Four" course meal made them uncomfortably full. To hit some highlights:The starters (beet salad and tuna carpaccio) were both good, but not really exceptional. I liked the goat cheese with the greens in the beet salad, but I'm not a huge beet fan. And the tuna was tasty, but like I said, nothing remarkable. But this is where the "not remarkable" ends.I would never think to dust scallops with cocoa, but that dark, rich flavor with the sweet cauliflower and the scallops was an unexpectedly good combo. Wished I could have had more of these, but that's OK, since we moved on to crab cakes which were, as I would prefer, long on crab and short on binder. I'm not a huge fan of tomato sauces for seafood, but in this case, it was great. tangy and spicy to offset the rich crab meat.Coconut tomato cream was a great mild sauce for the awesome beef and chorizo stuffed dates, which may have also had a little more date in the stuffing, as I've had something similar to this where the dates got lost, but they were very much as part of the flavor here, which I liked. The beef carpaccio had good beef flavor, and was fun to try and wrap around the little garlic bread sticks we were given. And ribs? At an Italian place? Well, it's kind of Italian fusion, and these were nicely done, with a crispy glazed skin and definite orange flavor from the poaching. A surprisingly good dish.And...oh, man...The one two punch of the pasta and the soup were maybe the best parts of the meal. Perfect al dente pasta swimming in the richest butter cheese sauce you can imagine, and topped with a huge dusting of freshly shaved truffles. Nothing went to waste here. Simple but spectacular. And the little shot glass of soup - I mixed the oils in with a knife, and tried to drink it...and then when I had drunk all I could, I scooped the last bits out with my silverware. Thank god this is on the menu because I am getting it every single time I come back. Great sweet and salty balance, rich and creamy, perfect cold weather food. Cripes.Then, just as we were getting full on the 8th of our 3 courses, dessert. All good - gelatto wasn't iced, tiramisu was dark with plenty of cocoa and coffee flavor, and the bread pudding was topped with chocolate sauce...how can you go wrong.Throughout the meal, our service was very good. Wait staff were attentive, explained every dish to us, checked in without being smothering. No complaints. And it was even half price wine night (every Monday, it seems). They'll let you take the rest of the bottle home if you don't finish, so it's a nice way to try things. I did not partake, but someone who was already on Christmas vacation did.Finally, the price is downright reasonable for the quantity and quality of food we were served. This would have been easily double the price if we'd eaten it downtown. One of my friends had even been told by the chef that the whole reason this restaurant was in the suburbs was to keep cost down. Not sure if it's the real reason or not, but it's working. This is a really, really solid 4-star, a 4.5, really, and that's completely ignoring what looks to be an excellent menu with mostly $10-25 entrees, which if they're as good as some of what we had, are a *steal*. Now to convince everyone I know to come back and enjoy this place with me.
<review# 1037,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/3/2012,1/15/2012,428,1216,5,6,6>Sushi places are so hard to review...In the midwest, this is five-star.  On the west coast, probably four-star.  In any case...I've just had one meal (so far - I will definitely return, if I'm in the area).  During my first visit to a sushi place, I always go for chef's choice sushi.  I did so, and added a tuna roll, given that I hadn't eaten much that day.  The sushi pieces were delectable.  Melt-in-your-mouth fresh and delicious.  They start you with miso, a small salad, and an amuse bousche, and they finish with fresh fruit for dessert.  What happens in between is all about fresh fish, done with an experienced hand.The room is very comfortable, just slightly trendy.  The service was terrific.  I don't have my own chopsticks, but they will store yours for you.So...Chicago-area sushi.  It's down to Nikko and Kinu (Evanston) as my recommendations for best in the area.

I'm there at least once a week - at least. And I have convinced my family and friends to shop there as well. For example, bottles of Mexican Coke - 10 for $1. Valli it up!

As a lifelong bargain hunter, I'm always looking for ways to stretch a dollar without sacrificing quality. For $1.75, you can not beat the value versus cost proposition of Picture Show. The sound, picture quality and cleanliness of the theaters are above expectations. My only ding of a star is that the seats are not as comfortable as Cinemark or AMC. Nonetheless, they aren't painful either, so you can still sit an enjoy your movie without feeling like you were robbed.The selection of the titles that they run rotate much slower than that of a major chain. That's okay for me, as I'm not a regular movie-goer in the first place. Just check their website from time to time to find updates on the flicks and you'll be surprised to find that original-run film that you missed here for a lot less.Highly recommended.

<review# 1049,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/21/2011,1/3/2012,58,156,9,9,10>So I finally got around to checking out this enchanted castle of Beers that actually exists in the suburbs and my only regret is that I did not check it out sooner! <review# 1051,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/7/2011,1/1/2012,31,287,7,7,7>This is the best place for pho in Chicago, period. Bold words since Viet Town is 30 miles from this place but it's no joke. With pho, it's all about the broth and Pho Ha's is number one - pho real. To start, the broth is a true consommé which is clear and flavorful. It requires additional steps and takes a lot of time but at Pho Ha, it's done perfectly right. Once you taste it, you'll be taken away by the intensity of flavor. The broth has a clean flavor that isn't oily at all. At some places, you'll see oil on the surface of the broth which isn't appetizing. There are also other items on the menu that don't require broth and are my favorite dishes to order. My favorite is the egg noodle with shrimp, BBQ pork, and fish cake. I order this dry with soup on the side - it's similar to a traditional Thai bamee dish that I would eat in Thailand. Don't forget the spring rolls and bahn mi sandwiches. The spring rolls always taste fresh and come with a peanut sauce for dipping. There is a limited selection of bahn mi sandwiches but for only $3, I end up getting two anyways. The prices are inexpensive and for the quality, you will keep coming back for more - pho sure.

<review# 1055,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/22/2011,12/28/2011,116,200,6,7,7>This will be short and sweet. Yu's is absurdly good for one reason: Peking Noodles. Dense noodles with a velvety bean, pork, shrimp and onion sauce draped over. The fact that I can get it so close to home makes me deliriously happy. The only other dish I've had from Yu's are the eggrolls and those were fine, but the real show stopper is the Peking Noodle. I've heard rumors that dining in is a treat, I wouldn't know. I walk in, get my noodles and head home to noisily devour them. The food is fresh and fast and delicious. Yu's is amazing and you owe it to yourself to go.

This is great because it allows me to save my limited brain power to take in all the flavors. 3. The beer! There are so many choices!! 4. The food! So many good flavors coming together and dancing in your mouth. It almost felt utopian. The servings first looked a bit on the small side for a professional fatty like me, but while consuming the lamb burger with my amish blue and bacon fries, I realized that it is just the perfect size. 5. The environment! It is dimly light, classy and visually stimulating, but not overboard.  So I recommend the #11, which consists of grass-fed lamb, feta, olive tapenade, greek salad and tzatziki. Definitely got in touch with my Greek side that night. The tzatziki made a presence that was not over or underwhelming at the same time. The amish blue and bacon fries were definitely very gourmet. Life is short, so do not waste it eating bad food. Cheers.

<review# 1064,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/10/2011,12/19/2011,33,144,7,8,7>I have no idea how I haven't already reviewed Christy's yet, but the word needs to be spread about them.  This place is a fantastic little gem of a diner.The menu, both for breakfast and lunch/dinner is pretty expansive.  It's one of those Greek style places that tries to cater to absolutely everyone with everything from American standards to more traditional Greek fare to Mexican... really?  It's mostly successful in that regard.  That "mostly" isn't a problem because the things they get right are so damn good, the lesser items on the menu really don't matter.Breakfast there is all about fluffy.  Fluffy pancakes, fluffy omelets, delicious meats to go with them.  Lunch and dinner is done in that Greek family restaurant style where your meal includes soup and a basket of bread and crackers.  The soup there is always absolutely delicious.  Especially their cream soups.  Just awesome.The dinners themselves, I'm partial to their sandwiches.  They have really good burgers, a great club on toasty bread, excellent pitas if you're in the mood for a gyro.  Hard to go wrong in that regard.The ambiance of the place is definitely "local diner."  If you're looking for a place to spread out, this isn't it.  It's small, but with that cozy hometown kinda feel.  The service is absolutely always friendly.  Just a lot of great people.  And they love the people that come a lot and will give you a card that gives you a free tenth meal after buying nine.  I've harped on and on about homogenization before so it's great to see a place that isn't trying to fancy it up or get trendy.  They know what works, good food, great service, and low prices.  Christy's is absolutely wondering for a quick meal down the street.

<review# 1066,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/19/2011,12/17/2011,178,231,4,8,4>I TRIED- Fresh Spring Rolls (5/10)- Crab Wheel (3/10)- Tom Yum (9/10)- Tom Kha (9/10)- Panang Curry (10/10)- Spicy Combination Seafood (6/10)In college, some friends introduced me to Pad Thai and Pad Seeyou. I fell in love instantly! I then considered myself a Thai expert just because I've had those 2 noodle dishes with each of the 4 meats (beef, chicken, pork, and shrimp). Then one day, on a business trip, I tried Pok Pok in Portland and had the Boar Collar dish they have and instantly realized, I knew jack about Thai! So one day, a buddy and I were wondering what to eat, and I suggested Thai, and Dan Thai just happened to be the place closest to us!The place is in the middle of a strip mall. The location of the strip mall is fairly premium, it's near a big intersection, but I don't think I've ever come into this strip mall my entire life, and I live less than 3 miles from it! The inside is pretty standard to most Thai places I've been to. It has a fairly decent number of tables, and it's usually been quiet when I've gone, which is either later at night or late lunch on the weekends.SPRING ROLLS & CRAB WHEELWell the fresh spring rolls are like everybody's fresh spring rolls. Nothing unique about these. The Crab Wheels are supposed to be crab in "garlic pepper seasoning fried and served with sweet chili sauce," but that's not what I tasted. It just tasted like 1/3 of an imitation crab roll, breaded and fried. Taste was kinda funky by itself. The sauce was really good and helped, but wasn't anything I'd order again.TOM YUM/KHAI order my Tom Khas and Tom Yums extra spicy. I've had both of these and they are both excellent. Perfect ratio of mushrooms and meat. I consider ginger to be a landmine in Thai soups, but although they are present, I didn't have to be as careful as I had to be in other places. I don't know what it is that I've had at other places, but they have this skin of some vegetable (looks like a green onion) but it feels like a plastic straw that I can't chew. They didn't have that either, so I could peacefully drink my soup.PENANG CURRYWith Dan Thai being a random restaurant in a strip mall in Schaumburg, I was expecting that whatever I have here, there'll be tons of other Thai places that are much better. If that is the case, I'm still waiting for a better Penang Curry! LIke the soups, there aren't a lot of "land mines" that I've had at other places. The curry isn't watery like some either, but the consistency is just perfect, like a Cream of Mushroom soup. It's got a perfect peanutty flavor and the heat is also nicely done (even though I'd like a little hotter when I order "extra spicy"). It's a giant bowl too, so be careful if you order with other things. I was stuffed with the appetizer and other entree we got, but the curry was so good, I ended up cleaning out the bowl, and then wanted to die because I was so full.BOTTOM LINEThere was one restaurant out in Wilmette (I think) that had an better Tom Kha, but their Penang was just ok. I think, so far, if I ever had a craving for Thai, I'm going to Dan Thai for the whole package. Almost perfect Tom Yum/Kha and the best Penang Curry I've ever had. I really want to see if there even is such a thing as a better Penang Curry than Dan Thai. I'm going to go revisit my old college Thai place and see if they can hang...
<review# 1067,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/5/2011,12/16/2011,325,653,10,33,17>Seriously. What a unique experience. I have eagerly anticipated the opening of this student-run Robert Morris University restaurant for MONTHS. I even called the university to inquire about it when I first saw it developing near my favorite boutique store Chameleon. The grand opening date was penned into my calender. I went for dinner last night only to discover that Eyrie (which means eagle's nest and is probably a nod to the RMU eagle mascot) is only open for lunch. I went again today right at noon and was greeted by an eager young lady who asked me if I had a reservation. Seeing the bustling crowd, I explained that I didn't, but that I would like to sit at the bar. The bar had a fantastic view of the kitchen where I watched my burger and pumpkin sponge prepared. My burger was really delicious. The bun was toasted and the burger had lively seasonings. I heard the order put in as "medium well-done" but the pinkness of the patty told me that it was medium or medium rare (which is my preference anyway). The pumpkin sponge was really unique. It tasted like pumpkin bread and had a scoop of cinnamon ice-cream on top. The garnishes were candied pecans, caramel, and a wafer. One of the student chefs approached me and politely said, "Excuse me, but may I ask what you think of the pumpkin sponge? I helped to make that recipe and am looking for feedback." How cool is that?! She told me that the "wafer" was really a sweet potato chip. I thought that was really special. My next surprise came when I paid ($16). There was no place to leave a tip! I asked my server where I put the tip and she said that they aren't allowed to accept any tips. In fact, EVERYONE working in the restaurant is a student who is being graded on their labors and are not paid. I felt incredibly weird not leaving a tip, especially for such good food and service. I loved my experience at Eyrie so much that I am eager to share it with friends and family. My only complaint is that they currently have such limited hours so I'll probably have to wait once Eyrie expands to include dinner (and maybe breakfast?).

I have also heard they get very busy at night, so make a reservation.  Again, this is a great place to come on a fancy date where you are looking to spend some decent cash for a great meal.

<review# 1076,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/12/2011,12/7/2011,107,399,4,6,5>This place was a complete surprise for me. Bartlett is one of the last places I'd expect to find an excellent Chinese restaurant. Like other restaurants that have done well in the Top 100 Chinese Restaurants Competition, the authentic Chinese food is amazingly good but the Americanized food is only passable (in my opinion). The food here reminds me a bit of iChef in Hoffman Estates in style but more like Lao Sze Chuan in Chinatown in terms of execution. I don't recall seeing this restaurant in the Zagat Guide, but based on what I've tried so far, I'd probably give them a 24.The Chongqing Style Noodle Soup is definitely something you should try if you love nice hot soup that's not excessively strong in flavor. They are very generous with the amount of whitefish they give you as we were able to make 8 fully loaded small bowls with cellophane noodles and fish with the amount of soup given to us. The mustard greens were not extremely strong in flavor but just strong enough where I noticed them. They can make this non-spicy but spicy soup is amazingly nice in the winter time.The Honey Sesame Crispy Beef had a nice flavor to it, but the texture wasn't quite as tender as I would have liked it to be. My problem though could be that I compared everyone's version of this dish to Sun Shui's Crispy Szechuan Beef and that's why I feel disappointed with everyone else's version. The egg roll was okay but nothing special.This was not on the menu, but we had them make Cantonese-style ginger and scallion red snapper fillets. This was a really nice variation of a popular dish that was perfectly balanced with a strong flavor and not too much salt. The excellent execution of this dish makes me want to try the Chendu Snapper and Spicy Chili Fish next time.The Beef Chow Fun (Gon Chao Ngau Ho style) was one of the best I've had outside Chinatown. It had a strong onion flavor to it and beef that was seared to slightly crispy on the edges. It wasn't excessively oily like most of the versions I run across and had just the right amount of salt to be noticeable but not overbearing.Their Cumin Lamb (Zi Ran Yang Rou) was excellently done with a strong flavor of onion and peppers and lamb that was cooked to a nice tender texture without being overdone and slightly crispy on the edges. I don't even like cumin but the dish was so excellently executed I couldn't stop eating it.I wish I'd taken pictures of the authentic Chinese menu since it's not on their website. Like other highly rated Chinese restaurants, that menu is where you'll really find the hidden treasures the restaurant offers.

Everything tasted fresh, with obvious attention paid to even the slightest details and ingredients. The curry was amazing. Add some Sweet & Sour sauce to the mix, and the kid tore through her meal in minutes. Plate licked clean! At the conclusion of our stellar dinner, just when we thought it couldn't get better, dessert was ordered... The Fried Banana with Ice Cream. Freaking amazing. Slightly resembling a spring roll, these fried wrapped mini-bananas were served hot, drizzled with chocolate sauce, and topped with rainbow sprinkles. Add some vanilla ice cream to this modern twist, and you my friend have a dessert for three well worth the $4.99. Cida Thai just made a Top-Five list somewhere in our books... Most gracious!

Dishes like the Naporitan spaghetti and the mentaiko spaghetti are hard to find in the Chicago area, and they are made authentically and perfectly.  Hit the spot every time!  The sesame ice cream is also very good (another item that is hard to find in Chicago).  Service is good.  But it could get a bit slow if you sit in the flow-over room when it gets busy.  Decor is stereotypical (bamboo, wood-tone, zen garden, etc) but comfortable.  If you go, it'll be for the food.

<review# 1093,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/20/2010,11/20/2011,29,60,6,7,7>The House Pub boasts that their large selection of brews (126 delicious beers to satiate a need for variety, to be exact) will meet any craving you have, whether it be the "schwag" like Miller Lite, or something a little more upscale, like Magic Hat. This bar is like a game of russian roulette where you'll most likely be content with whatever beverage you choose but if you're really lucky, you'll find that one bullet, ahem, beer that'll create a huge impact on you (thankfully, instead of a bullet to the dome, you get a taste of some of the best barley pops ever). The owner, Steve, is incredibly knowledgeable when it comes to the drinks he offers and steered me in the right direction when he suggested a Breckenridge Brewery Vanilla Porter; now it's the only beer I'll get when I'm there. Meander upstairs to the Lounge, which has the romantic date-night ambience complete with hazy red lighting and walls lined with leather couches that any girl (or dude attempting to impress a chick) would love. The jazz groups that play here every Thursday evening and the extensive martini menu will guarantee you'll come back upstairs for more.

<review# 1095,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/7/2011,11/18/2011,42,56,3,5,3>Good food, nice atmosphere, decent prices and somewhat kid-friendly. Service is generally unmemorable (except for one very special waiter--read more on this below), but that doesn't make it a bad thing.FOOD: Typical Italian fare. The menu is long, which is often a bad sign, but surprisingly the food was pretty good. No complaints from the four adults and one 2-year-old in our party.SERVICE: Just fine. Our waiter always seemed to be around when we needed him, yet he wasn't overly enthusiastic about his job. Now, there was one very special waiter. He was an older man who was waiting on tables in our general area. He noticed at some point that my son was getting a bit fidgety, so he stopped by and asked if he could give him some Dum-Dum suckers. Little did he know, this is my kid's absolute favorite treat. So, not only did this small gesture go a long way for calming him down and making him very happy, it gave us more time to hang out with our friends, and that meant we ordered another bottle of wine as well as desserts--good business move, Mr. Awesome Waiter!ATMOSPHERE: Didn't spend much time inside, although it looked nice. The narrow outside patio was quite pleasant. We had a round table for our party of five, which lent itself well to socializing with good friends over several bottles of wine. PRICES: Pretty standard somewhat pricey upscale Italian suburban restaurant prices. If you have ever been an one of these types of restaurants, you won't be surprised, but you also won't feel like you're getting a deal.KID-FRIENDLINESS: So, yeah, no one is going to give you the evil eye when you walk in with a kid. In fact, we saw lots of kids in this place while we were there on a Saturday night. However, they do not offer a kids' menu, so be prepared to order a side of plain pasta and sauce or half-order of one the the pasta's off the menu. Yes, I would go back. Good place for meeting friends and hanging out in a nice, but casual setting.
<review# 1096,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/7/2011,11/17/2011,79,108,4,6,4>This is a perfect example of Yelpers convincing me to give a place another try. The first time I stopped at Lucky Star, I was underwhelmed by the curried chicken. The sauce was a little gelatinous and overall not as flavorful as I would have liked, although I enjoyed the fried rice that came with my meal. That said, I drive past Lucky Star every day on my way home and had seen other Yelpers' positive reviews, so I decided to give it another shot. I stopped by last night and ordered the General Tso's Chicken dinner special (I try to maintain a veggie-centric diet, but sometimes a girl just wants fried chicken!). It was delicious! The sauce was rich, spicy and almost barbeque-y. My only quibble is that in comparison to the generous, heaping portion of chicken, I only got four small pieces of broccoli, which were buried at the bottom. Strange. They also went a little heavy on the rice. I picked white rice instead of fried rice and could have fed a small village with what I was given. I like that their dinner specials also include an egg roll (solid, but not the best I've had) and your choice of a can of soda, bottled water or a cup of soup. I chose the Diet Coke. For less than $8, it really is a great dinner value, especially since it could easily feed two people. As Ah-nold said, I'll be back!
<review# 1097,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/2/2011,11/16/2011,63,167,4,7,7>I have been eating at North of the Border for several years.  I primarily go for Taco Tuesdays.  This isn't really because I need to get tacos for 89 cents, but more because I like the alliteration.  (I often observe TV free Tuesdays, which is somewhat connected.)NOTB is located in a strip mall with plenty of parking in the shared lot.  Walking into the place you notice it is very small, but they do manage to fit about 8 tables in the place.  You order at the counter, but they will bring the food out to your table if you are eating in.  The atmosphere is casual, fast food place.  Nothing fancy, but exactly what I would expect.My wife and I almost always order the same thing... shredded beef tacos and chicken tacos.  At my other favorite taco joint I like to get the marinated pork, but while tasty, it is tough and oddly dry at NOTB.  Every once in a while I forget this and order. I was reminded on my most recent visit.  I have never had the steak tacos, but a reminder to all the haters out there... do you really think you are going to get filet mignon for 89 cents?  As a general rule I stay away from "steak" at low end places.For the first few years that I came to NOTB, they would provide free chips and salsa if you ate in for dinner.  I thought this was very generous considering the reasonably priced food.  Unfortunately, I guess the economics of the situation caught up with them because that stopped about a year ago.  Now I just purchase it anyway.  The salsa is tasty with beans and corn in it, but it is not very spicy.  Not necessarily a bad thing, but I wanted to call it out for you spice lovers.Once again, being a creature of habit, I always get the Jarritos to drink.  I don't often drink pop, but because it is from Mexico, it is made with real sugar instead of high fructose corn syrup.  Taste the difference!While eating, I like to choose a few magazines from the rack that is next to the trash cans.  They have a funny collection like PC Gamer, Us, and some audio/video enthusiast magazines.My interactions with the staff have always been pleasant.  They are helpful and efficient.Overall, this place is good for what it is trying to be.  I am happy to have a taco joint like this in Bartlett.  I will definitely be back.

<review# 1102,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/26/2010,11/11/2011,78,586,4,7,5>I've wanted to try this place for a long time, but it's on the side of a small strip mall and not very visible. So I am seldom reminded of it when driving in the area. But recently I was foraging for something different to eat and recalled my desire to check it out, so I did. There are only about a dozen tables - and all but one were seated, so I was lucky to get the last spot.The menu has a good selection of appetizers and soup, along with about a dozen entrees mostly at or below $10. Started out with some Cheburek, which was ground meat inside a deep fried pastry shell. This dish was fair - it really needed some kind of sauce with it - kind of bland. But, I figured that Uzbek food might be like this (I've never been much of a fan of Middle Eastern or Russian cuisine, and I get the sense that this is a blend of both). Next was Samsa, a baked meat filled pastry served with an Uzbek "ketchup-like" sauce. Excellent - tons of flavor and only $3.Then tried the Mastava soup along with some Lepeshka (Uzbek bread). The soup was a blend of meat, rice and vegetables. One of the waiters (who I knew from his having worked at another place I frequent) suggested adding kefir to the soup; apparently this is often done to cut back on the oiliness of the soup. So I tried a few spoonfuls then added the kefir, which altered the taste. Either way it was good - I'd give the nod to the "kefir-added" style. The Lepeshka was a small loaf of bread - kind of sunken in the center. At first glance, I was worried that it might be a little dry, but after breaking into it and spreading on some butter, it was quite moist and tasty.Finally, for dinner I ordered the chicken kabobs. Served with rice, some sliced onions and sliced pickled pepper, it too was very tasty and flavorful. Came with the ketchup sauce. Not a large portion, but given all the appetizers and soup I consumed, I didn't need a lot more. Ended up taking 1/2 of that and 1/2 the bread home, which I just finished tonight.Overall, this restaurant proved to be a pleasant surprise and one that I will return to again. The food I ordered was unusual, but ANYONE could order and enjoy it and try a foreign dish seldom seen in our many multicultural offerings that is so special and unique about the Chicagoland area.
<review# 1103,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/18/2011,11/10/2011,287,787,6,10,12>I finally got around to visiting!  My favorite nail spot is in the same area so methinks I will be planning my nail visits around lunches at Naf Naf. So soft and light--like a delicious pillow!Because we were so impressed with our food, we brought home the veggie platter for later for dinner. The Tabule was so fresh--great flavor, hint of something citrusy. The Baba Ghanouj was definitely my favorite--nice smoky eggplant flavor--the smokiness was not overpowering at all, very smooth and so delicious with the pita.  The space is nice and very clean--not much in decor. Service was friendly and didn't mind all my questions since I was newbie to this place.  Too bad it's so far from home--I'm thinking about that chicken shwarma again.  Time to book my manicure--that now means lunch at Naf Naf--hooray!
