Luckily my dad was being more adventurous then usual and opted to get two small plates each with me. We sampled the pork belly tacos, seared scallops, spare rib risotto, and chili relleno. First off - its like Two Brothers was trying to win back my heart - pork belly plus Cane and Ebel = love. The scallops were seared perfectly and had a sweet chilli sauce that was so perfect it brought tears to my eyes!! The chili relleno was flavorful and very enjoyable. However, the show stealer was the spare rib risotto. The spare rib was fine, but the risotto was amazing!!!!!!!!!!! I felt bad as I know I hogged it, and I didn't care. Fiance was a little disappointed in the burger as the adobo sauce took over - everything else was enjoyable though. Mom got a roast beef sandwich with some seriously delicious mashed potatoes. Thanks for stepping it up, Two Brothers! We will be back!!
<review# 1106,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/30/2011,11/7/2011,127,193,8,10,8>Get outta town!  A local, café-like shop just a few blocks from my house?What was once many years ago a travel agent (remember those?) and subsequently the second half of a shady pizza place is now a bright spot and great success story, in a quiet part of Lombard; that's to say, quiet except for the high school kids' foot traffic.  *waves old man cane* "Get off my lawn!"Senior moments aside, Momz and I took a walk down here on a whim.  I can't tell you how many times I pass La France per week, but I always meant to get there, and I'm glad we did.  Chef Ben is *exactly* the kind of person I would want to be greeted by any day of the week.  He's close enough; maybe if I pay him a few bucks, he'll agree to wait for me at my place, and when I walk in the door, he can launch into a barrage of "BONJOUR!  Bonjourbonjourbonjourbonjour..."Back to the crepe escape.  Using some of the only French I know, which I learned from watching an old tv commercial for Brawny paper towels, I say, "C'est magnifique!"I tried the crepe Curry a l'Indienne- chicken, mild curry sauce with figs.  It was sweet, savory, and to add a little bravery, I asked Chef Ben's assistant if she could make it a little spicier, to which she gave an enthusiastic YEAH!  She even plated a small dollop of sour cream on the side to help take it down a notch in heat.  Appreciated, but not needed.  Dare I say, it was delicious, but all a little on the heavy side.  As good cooking should be!Mom got the Poulex aux Câpres- capers, red onion, spinach and crème frâiche.  Similar to a Chicken "Caprayzee" as one might say in Italian-American speak.  Top it all off with a nice latte, and I was almost in need of a midday snoozer.  Next time, it's breakfast time, and I believe the Nutella crepe will be calling my name.  I plan to make my presence here known a little bit more.  After all, not many people can say they've got a little bit of La France in their backyard, and mean it!

<review# 1112,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/22/2011,11/1/2011,136,719,2,9,4>Amazing place to rest, relax, and recharge after a busy commute, workday, or just to get away without going away!If you don't want a full meal at the great cafeteria (salads, sandwiches, and made-to-order specials) you can sip a hot chocolate or coffee (they have soy milk!) and even grab a snack at the little coffee shop.Their store has some great seasonal items, and a great little sale section in the back corner.We've made a tradition of attending the Halloween-themed theater hike. We attended our first last summer, it was Huey Lewis.The trolley gives everyone a great behind-the-scenes perspective on the arboretum's background and preservation work.Members get discounts in the store and when they're registering for classes and other special events like concerts and theater-hikes.In summer, be sure to bring adequate hiking apparel/shoewear and plenty of mosquito repellent--even useful advice for  attending the theater hikes.Don't miss their online resources, such as blogs and other information shared by their very talented scientists.I love walking around the Thornhill Center, especially in spring, when the perfume garden is at its best. The secret reflection pond in the kids garden area is spectacular, and the hedge maze is great fun for adults or kids alike.Don't forget your camera, there's always something to capture.The volunteers are all very helpful and great to talk to. I can't say enough good things about this place.

I have lived nearby Kinta for YEARS and hadn't stepped foot inside until a few days ago. Bad foodie! Bad foodie, indeed.I had a sushi craving so I ordered a rainbow roll to go, but upon walking in I would totally eat in next time. They even have a sushi bar! Despite having just expanded, the atmosphere was still intimate and cozy. Now to the food - the rainbow roll was so fresh and the miso soup hit the spot on a gloomy fall day. My only gripe is that the sushi pieces were super huge and frankly easier to eat with my hands rather than chopsticks. This gripe is small though because you get a great value for your dollar due to the size of the sushi. Also, the roll survived a walk home so that just speaks to the quality of the roll.Also, I want to try a bunch of the other items on the menu. It seems to have a good balance between sushi and non sushi so you non sushi people have no fear! They also seem to have great lunch specials!I will absolutely be walking over to Kinta again in the near future. But for the rest of you, come visit! Don't be weary of the fact that it is next to a 7-11 in strip-mall. Kinta will absolutely surprise you!
<review# 1114,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/9/2011,10/30/2011,140,273,1,9,3>Okay, this place is so good that I'll overlook the horrid font used on their menu and give them a good review. ;-)  xnipec.usWe decided to go outside of our comfort zone and try this place, as we live so close to it and all! Let me tell you, we were super pleasantly surprised! I've never had Mayan food and I must say I am a fan.We called ahead, a bit worried that on a Thursday after 5:30 there may be some commuters taking over the joint. We asked to reserve a table for 2 away from the door (Brr!) and when we arrived they already had water, chips and salsa there for us. A cute little touch! If you like spice, try the habanero salsa. Yum. The other salsa is not spicy, just flavorful.I ordered the Sangria which was good, hearty and full of chopped fruit. He enjoyed his margarita (served in a wine glass?) though it wasn't totally a-mazing. No complaints, though. We read tons of reviews before coming in and knew it was important to try the Combinado Yucateco appetizer for $12. It comes with 1 Pescadilla 1 Vaporcito 1 Taco de Cochinita and 1 Taco de Pez. OH MY GOD. It was all so delicious! Try this, if nothing else. We split each item and it had us wanting more. It was great to get a taste of everything. For dinner, I had the Panuchos y Salbutes which were super good - even the soup on the side was good - but it had a bit too much of the pink cabbage for my liking. Not a big deal, it's manageable and you can just take some off. He had the Enchiladas Placeras and they were really tasty too! After the chips and salsa and the combo plate we could not finish our meals - it's a good amount of food. All in all it was a nice experience. They do show a movie on Thursdays which is different, but nice. There were only 2 other couples there while we were there so we enjoyed the quiet evening together. We even stayed for an extra round of drinks and relaxed and the guys were nice about it. We spent a good amount of money here but appreciated the cuisine a lot so it was a nice treat. Service was pretty good and they seemed to appreciate it a lot when we complimented the food - a couple of times! I could see it getting a bit hairy if it is a busy time of day or week, for sure.

<review# 1118,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/19/2011,10/26/2011,31,287,2,7,4>Wonton Gourmet is also one of the few standing restaurants that I have been going to for 15 years that is still around and hasn't changed. If anything, it has gotten better since they moved to a bigger location awhile back. This is the place that I go to when I crave Chinatown food but don't want to drive into the city. Each time I go, I order the BBQ pork chow mein (Cantonese style). It's Chinese BBQ with a light soy gravy over Cantonese pan fried noodles. I have also tried the beef and gailan chow fun, shrimp and scrambled egg over rice, shrimp and lobster sauce over rice, and pot stickers to name a few.Most recently, my friend introduced me to pepper beef with chow fun noodles. It's beef stir fried with black pepper and green peppers in a soy gravy over wide rice noodles. He ordered the noodles crispy and it made all of the difference. The crispy texture went well with the savory goodness from the sauce. It's definitely a dish that I recommend ordering. Wonton Gourmet is good straight up Cantonese food the way it should be at affordable prices. If you live in the suburbs and don't want to make the trip to Chinatown, Wonton Gourmet will satisfy your craving.

<review# 1121,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/15/2011,10/23/2011,223,313,9,9,8>So I think it's a good sign that I like a bar when I get properly sauced there twice in the same week.  I'm glad I discovered this place through a recent Yelp event.  So glad that I was back there 2 nights later to drink some good beer... and drink... and drink.Bigby's is tucked behind an Italian deli, so keep your eyes peeled for their sign.  I didn't know what to expect from the outside but once I stepped foot inside the beer cave, I knew I would like the place.Right when you walk in, there are 2 tall beer shelves to your left full of craft beers and wine to your right.  This is basically their drink menu, but they also have a chalkboard up on the wall with a list of beers they have on tap.  The cool part is their voting system.  Just grab some glass pebbles and drop them into whichever beer or wine you want to see appear on the menu.  The contenders are on the outside wall and the current choices on the inner.The service is super friendly and knowledgeable on the beer selection.  Plus they'll gladly offer free samples if you're not sure what to order.  They also have a small, but tasty selection of tapas style eats.  The Muddy Pig is awesome (bacon & chocolate, hell yah!), but the S'mores Flatbread is money.I brought some friends here and now they are fans as well.  This joint is a perfect place to chill, while drinking some good beer.  Plus there are plenty of board games to play and maybe even challenge the owner Ed to a game of chess.  From the scoreboard on the wall, he's either a chess master or his opponents were drunkards.  Either way a great place to drink and have fun.

<review# 1123,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/2/2011,10/21/2011,151,667,4,5,5>Short of visiting a local farmers market, you won't find fresher produce in the Chicagoland area and at a very reasonable price! Caputos offers a large selection of apples, nuts, onions, and other raw treats. The main draw is unquestionably the produce section. If you're a real bargain hunter, look under the displays for mixed boxes of bruised or slightly old goodies. You can get enough peppers and squash to make a huge soup or other cooked dish for two bucks! Yes!I tend to avoid getting any boxed or canned goods at Caputos only because their prices tend to be higher than Ultra Food, Sams Club or Costco. It is cheaper to bulk up elsewhere on the staples, plus I make most of my own food, so I can't comment on the deli, even though there look like a lot of very tasty treats there. The one other area I hit before checking out would be the bread aisle. They have a fantastic selection of Italian style bread which goes great toasted with a little bit of garlic and olive oil. You can't beat it!Highly recommended as a great stop to replenish your produce inventory!
<review# 1124,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/22/2011,10/20/2011,116,200,9,8,7>I had been fiending for some BBQ for a while now, not sure why. I mean besides the fact that I'm a fat guy and the smells of grilled meat are like pheromones, drifting across the African veldt like so much prey attracting a hungry lion. So I was picking up some sushi from Sushi Today for the wife and remembered there was this new BBQ joint next door so let's try it, right? Right. I was in no mood to dawdle so I ordered a pulled pork sandwich and sweet potato fries and got the fuck out of dodge to get my sushi order and go home. The staff was courteous and the food was up pretty quickly so I have no complaints about that. Got home, dug in and found the pork sandwich with accompanying BBQ sauce totally good. It was more chopped than pulled but it's pork, I'm a fat guy and that means I liked it. The problem came when I tried the sweet potato fries. The last sweet potato fries I had were at Mr Bartley's Burger Cottage in Cambridge and I was so very afraid to order them again, for fear I would experience the same tasteless, greasy nonsense I had back then. I'm sorry to say I was in the wrong again. The bad sweet potato fries strike back! Am I just a fry snob? Is my radar for these things off kilter? I ended up adding my own salt and was able to eat them that way but off the bat both my wife and I both said they had no taste and were, and I quote, "yucky." Oh Julian's BBQ and Grill, I am disappoint. I saw the option for bacon cheddar fries on the menu and second guessed myself and went for the sweet potato option. That will not be a mistake I make twice. Next time I'm in the area for a sushi run I will visit Julian's again but won't be ordering those sweet potato fries again. Still, the BBQ was good and I'm a fan.

<review# 1126,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/13/2011,10/18/2011,38,95,1,5,2>Came here on a Friday evening about 7:00. When pulling into the lot, I was apprehensive because there were very few cars. On a Friday? At 7? Not a good sign. Decided to go in anyway. As we were reaching the door, a couple was coming out so we asked them how their meal was since it appeared fairly vacant. They told us that it was very good and don't worry. Upon entering towards the host stand, we were greeted nicely and shown our seating. Our waiter, Nick, came by and introduced himself, explained the menu and took our drink order. I ordered a martini - up. Small gripe here. It was not the greatest, not cold enough, too much vermouth. Oh well. Here is the lowdown on the food: Salad bar was decent, nice assortment of items. The roasted meats served by the gauchos were excellent. The house specialty, pichana, along with the beef ribs were especially tasty. In fact all of the meats I had were very good. Our whole group of four were in agreement on the quality. The service from all of the staff was very friendly and polite. Now back to my small gripe about my drink. When it came time to pay the bill, I saw there was an extra charge for having my martini "up". Huh? I asked what that was about and received an explanation that it was more expensive to make because it did not have ice. Once again, Huh? I then explained that a price for a martini should be one price and this is the first time I have ever seen something like an up-charge. Oh well. Overall, the restaurant had very good food, good service, dinner pricing was better than most Brazilian restaurants. Drinks, both hard and soft were pricey. I would give it a solid 4 if not for the ridiculous "up" charge. Hey, on second thought, I am still going to give it a 4 anyway. Everything else was at that level. Don't be afraid to go here. It is a nice place with a nice atmosphere to go along with the food and service. They certainly deserve to be busier. Cheers to All.

<review# 1130,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/29/2011,10/14/2011,24,93,2,5,6>Chicago Prime has become a regular haunt for us.The food is excellent, the wine selection superb and the wait staff are true professionals.We have worked our way through most of the menu at Prime over the last couple of years.Escargot, calamari, beet salad.. check, check.. check.. Well prepared and flavorful without being too much.For those at the table not interested in eating snails, simply dipping the table bread (which is excellent as well) into the butter sauce is a treat unto itself.Filet, sirloin, ribeye, prime rib, salmon, halibut.  Check, check, check, check and yup.. check.. Every entree we have had at Prime has been excellent.Make sure you know what rare, medium rare, medium etc.. actually mean when ordering a steak at Prime.  Because THEY do know and that's how you will get your steak.  This is not Outback.  And thankfully, it is also not Morton's.If, after the excellent bread, tasty appetizers, crispy salads and savory entree, you still have room for dessert, you are in for a treat.Creme Brulee and the truly decadent chocolate cake with raspberry sauce are two of our favorites along with the most recent special of strawberries, vanilla ice cream and a sinfully rich cream sauce.While the menu is excellent at Chicago Prime, one of my favorite things about the place is that the atmosphere in the place is up to date.  While there is no doubt you're in a steakhouse and the decore is upscale, it doesn't feel like you've walked into a cave.  Their dining room is spacious and they can accomodate larger parties in a separate room, they also have a very inviting lounge area.With live music most nights, we tend to park ourselves at a high top, have dinner listen to some good music and hang around for a while.For special events or when we're entertaining friends, we'll head to the dining room and spread out a bit.If you like a great steak, done exactly as you asked for, along with all the traditional steakhouse sides and some not so traditional, you will love Chicago Prime.We'll see you there!

<review# 1132,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/29/2010,10/12/2011,371,418,5,10,5>There are a few signs that confirm you're supporting the right kind of business, 1) consistency 2) low turnover 3) how does that jingle go? "Where everybody knows your name!" I haven't been to Andrea's restaurant in 3 years last weekend it hit me like a freight train and I NEEDED Andrea's restaurant. There are more then a few reasons I hauled my ass from Downers Grove to Forrest Park for an omelet and soup. Andrea's rocks. I pulled up and I was kind of surprised that the parking lot wasn't full; it used to be always full on Sundays (church must have not been let out yet). I walked in and asked the same manager, Charlie, who worked there years back (as long as I can remember) for my favorite waitress to find out that she retired. Good for her :- ) I got a new waitress (surely the replacement of the aforementioned retiree, as I recognized all the other staff - busboys, waitresses and cooks). She was good, there was a little hiccup with my side order but she fixed it immediately. The food; I am half tempted to stop typing, and head straight back right now. Good quality ingredients, home made "mom" style flavor and huge portions. I always order the same thing for breakfast and egg white omelet with broccoli and cheese and rasin toast (which they butter - real butter - for you straight out of the toaster so it's all melty and awesome) and I always ask for my omelet burnt, I know it's weird, but that's what I like, and the cooks at Andrea's are the only cooks at any breakfast place I've ever been to that actually burn it for me. I think other places might be scared to over cook it even though I always try to emphasize how well done I want it. As usual, 3 years since my last visit and they burned my breakfast perfect JUST how I like it (and somehow they manage to keep the cheese gooey - yum!) My BF got a steak skillet and he was impressed with how much meat was in it. Before we left we ordered a big honkin container of cream of chicken rice soup (a Sunday staple at Andrea's) and took it home with us for dinner. I ALWAYS ask for slices of fresh lemon with the soup, I'm glad I remembered to still do that. We re-heated the soup for dinner and doused it with lemon and fresh black pepper and it hasn't changed an iota. This soup is hands down, no questions asked, the best soup on the planet. This soup makes all other soup hale in comparison. There is no match, not even close, no way. If I could only eat one kind of soup for the rest of my life, this would be it. Go there (on a Sunday) go ahead and set your expectation bar really high, order this soup, a little squeezy squeeze of the lemon a little pinchy pinch of pepper and you can thank me later. The bathroom here is teeny tiny itsy bitsy and there's only one, but I haven't had a problem with a line or anything. Parking lot is a little small but it's cool if you park on the street legally and not worry about tickets or being towed. (iirc there are some snow restrictions, but I'm not sure).

<review# 1134,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/6/2011,10/10/2011,33,144,12,11,11>Burgers are getting fancier by the day. Why, it won't be long before they're all wearing monocles and top hats, prancing about with diamond tipped canes saying things like "cheerio, old chap, shame about the polo match last night, wasn't it?"But if they're talking, then that means they'll have gained intelligence. And if they've gained intelligence, they might turn the tables on us. Before you know it, hamburgers will be eating people! IT'S IN REVELATION!!!!!Whoa... calm down, buddy.Sorry about that.DMK is a pretty tasty addition to the high quality, crazy topping, gourmet burger scene that's growing and is particularly popular along Butterfield Rd.The burgers are very tasty. Nice a juicy, cooked just right, with a lot of flavor. They have a lot of interesting topping choices that skew even more haute cuisine than some other places which is kinda fun. The fries are fresh cute and delicious and you can get them with a ton of great toppings. We got the Wisconsin Cheddar ones, which, word to the wise, are made with a really strong cheddar. Not for everyone, but damn did I find them delicious. Oh and the milkshake. Thick as hell and tasting exactly like a peanut butter cup in a glass. I can still taste it, it was as close to perfect as a mortal will get.My one big complaint was the complete lack of customizability. Basically, they have a dozen or so pre-made varieties to choose from and you go with those. So if you think some of the toppings on 2 sound delicious with some of the toppings on 5, tough. All I wanted was to swap out the cheese (can't stand blue) on my sandwich and they gave me kind of a hard time. In the end, they wouldn't put the other cheese on the burger, but gave it to me on the side to do myself. How much sense does that make? If they're making them fresh anyway, I don't see why it's so difficult to do things your own way.Oh well, it's not a major complaint. Overall it's a pretty cool place and while it won't replace Tom and Eddie's or Labriola for us, I like it a lot and we'll definitely be back. If only for those milkshakes.... and to eat enough burgers that they can't rise up.

<review# 1136,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/3/2011,10/8/2011,19,116,6,6,5>Came here with a friend for Christmas Eve Dinner.  I've been meaning to come to this place for a while as I have heard good things about it from friends and co-workers, but was a little bit frightened off assuming it was a French restaurant and was going to cost an arm and a leg.  But considering it was Christmas Eve and I had a Restaurant.Com coupon for $25, we thought what the heck and decided to give it a try.The décor reminded me of a modernized French inspired version of Moulin Rouge, the movie and the actual place in Paris.  Nothing too fancy, but you can tell some thought came about when decorating this place.  The place, is of course, very clean, as French Restaurants should be, but without the snooty waitress.  In fact, the wait staff were very friendly and knowledgeable about the menu.  I was pleasantly surprised to find out this place served breakfast, lunch and dinner.As my friend and I came here for dinner, we ordered the dinner menu.  For appetizers, we ordered my all time favorite food,  Foie Gras  (Duck Liver Pate).  I can tell you it is absolutely one of the best Foie Gras I've ever had.  I can still imagine the  full rich flavors exploding in my mouth....for $22.00 I expected nothing less For our entrees, I had the Beef Tendorloin and my friend had the Braised Beef Tongue with sides of mashed potato and fries.  The meat was very tender and just the right amount of flavor, and cooked just the way I liked it, medium rare.  There were plenty of luscious French desserts, but we were just two full to sneak in a desert, even if we split it.  All in all, we were very happy we spent our Christmas Dinner here.... kinda felt like Christmas in Paris.
<review# 1137,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/12/2011,10/7/2011,21,251,3,4,4>This place just keeps getting better.  As they add stock, move things around, and refine the store, I consistently find less and less reasons to go anywhere else.The deli selection is phenomenal, and the produce is generally really good.  You pay far less for a lot of items (limes, peppers, garlic) than you do at the Jewel right down the street.  Outstanding cheese market, and their bread selection is similarly excellent, as they bake their own bread, but also carry La Briola, Turano, D'Amato, and numerous other brands of bakery goods.They have a small but decent selection of wine and beer.  There is a clear catering to Eastern Europeans and a lot of their products, but they also carry standard beers and enough wines that you can always find something.The people are usually really nice, and it's a great neighborhood grocery store.  If you need something really unique, you may not find it there, but if you're going for staples, there's no reason not to try this place.

<review# 1141,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/4/2011,10/3/2011,44,130,4,6,3>My favorite trend lately has been established Chicago institutions opening their second location in Naperville. Not only does it enhance the suburb itself, but makes elegant, notable dining accessible for the entire region who couldn't otherwise make it. Thank you, Hugo's (Sullivan's, Rosebud and Catch 35 too, for that matter)!Hugo's Frog Bar is THE hot spot! The environment is lively (too much so, I'm afraid) with a live piano player and more ambiance than many downtown spots. Even with a reservation, there is a significant wait and the restaurant is always overly busy. Then again, busy spots are often the best, and that certainly is the case here.The menu features fresh food prepared perfectly. Took my mother here for her birthday and she was elated, two years later she still brags about the quality of her meal. Although I only sampled the mashed potatoes, I kinda wish I could order them in bulk so I could have them every night. Highly recommended, but be aware of the noise level: you'll practically be shouting to hear each other, even if you're inches away. But then again, you can't go wrong when the entire town shows up every single night.

<review# 1143,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/10/2011,10/1/2011,36,52,2,9,5>I've been waiting for this restaurant to open for months!Everyday, on my way to work for the past 4 months or so I've watched this restaurant erect from the ground up. I've been waiting and anticipating what was to come and today, I finally got to experience what is was like to have lunch at Cooper's Hawk. After being warmly greeted, my girlfriends and I decided to sit out on the well shaded patio on this surprisingly cool day in August. The space was spacious but still felt intimate. We didn't have to yell to be heard and we couldn't quite make out what people were saying from a table away, it was perfect. Reading over the menu, I was kind of overwhelmed but definitely impressed by the wide variety of dishes. Each entree had a Bin number next to it so, it takes out the guess work of pairing the perfect wine. I ordered the Over The Boarder Egg Rolls as an appetizer for the table and it seems that everyone had enjoyed it. It really could have been split between 4 people although there was only 3 of us. The deep fried chicken wraps were presented with three different dipping sauces and an Asian slaw. The slaw was refreshing and complimented the rolls.There's a Half Sandwich with Soup or Salad combo and I thought that was really great for the $9.99 price tag. I had the Triple White Grilled Cheese with a cup of the Crab & Lobster Bisque. Both were very satisfying and delicious. The blend of cheeses in between the thick sliced sourdough was made extra special with a drizzle of white truffle oil. The bisque is actually their signature soup and you really can taste why. There's real bits and pieces of crab, lobster and shrimp in a creamy tomato base. To round off my experience, I had to try the chocolate covered strawberry and cheesecake lollipop. Although, the white chocolate on the cheesecake was a little too sweet , I did enjoy it. The service was superb. Todd was our server and he was attentive and quick with clearing plates and utensils that were no longer needed. He was also very accommodating when one of the girls had to leave early. I really enjoyed my first visit here, I'm sure it won't be my last.

<review# 1146,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/19/2011,9/28/2011,357,284,4,7,4>Came here with a group of ten for a good friends birthday party and I had a lot of fun. We watched a very cheesy safety video. Then got geared up - we had to wear a jumpsuit, neck brace, ski mask looking thing (which I didn't like because it smelled funny even after they assured me it had been washed), and of course a helmet. After I got geared up I felt as if I was ready to be blasted to the moon. My head felt disconnected and a lot bigger than it's normal size. Plus, it was hot and hard to hear anything with that helmet on. Once everyone in our group was geared up we were ready to race. They showed us that the number next to your name indicates what car you were assigned to. So, we all got in our designated cars. What was funny about this was that I'm so short, I couldn't reach the break or gas pedals very well and they had to bring out these big blue block looking things to put on my pedals and make it easier for me to reach without too much straining. After that they had us take a lap around the course. We had a lot of turns and one very tight hair pin turn that I totally missed the first time around and went through the penalty pit instead. Let's just say the technician working the game wasn't happy with me, but oh well. I just waved and said next time I'll go the right way, sorry. Then after that all bets were off as we were in official race mode. Boy were these little go carts fast! It felt as if I were going 100 mph instead of just 35, but when I got rear ended by other racers I really got jarred but always recovered just fine. The 20 laps go by very quickly, so I don't know if it justified the $10 license fee plus the $25 race fee. However, I had a good time, and would consider coming back in the future, even though when I got out of the car I felt really high from the fumes and lack of oxygen.

<review# 1153,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/7/2010,9/21/2011,92,360,3,9,8>Nicodino's serves consistently good Italian food, mostly made from scratch. They also have a whole bunch of X-Box 360s in a back room for parties, which is pretty neat.We usually get breadsticks, and a pizza or calzone. The most recent time we were there I ordered a veggie panini, which had varieties of summer squash, mushrooms and basil between two crispy slices of bread. There seemed to be a heavy dose of balsamic vinegar, but fortunately there was melted mozzarella cheese in the middle.My wife's calzone seems to get bigger every time we go there, and some while ago it passed the "unreasonably large" mark. I have no complaints about the quality of the dough here or with the breadsticks - in fact, that homemade dough is why I like this place so much. But it feels like there's a pound of cheese in there, and that's a bit much.The breadsticks are fantastic, since they are just rolled out dough sprinkled with parmesan (the standard less-good American variety, not Parmeggiano Reggiano). They're served with a chunky tomato sauce that leans way, way acidic, so if you like your tomato sauce fresh and without as much sugar, you'll like the sauce.In the past when we've gotten pizza, I've felt that's where all the ingredients in the restaurant come together well. For a local, independent alternative to Panera, Nicodino's is a good place to go.

<review# 1155,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/8/2011,9/19/2011,255,326,4,9,5>Paul Douglas Forest Preserve is one of my FAVORITE places for birdwatching! While the trails are pretty flat and don't offer a challenging hike, entering at Grassy Ridge Meadow gives you access to multiple bird habitats. You can see birds that like wet thickets (common yellowthroat), marsh-dwellers (marsh wren), birds that prefer ponds, lakes, and streams (great blue heron), birds of the forest (eastern towhee), and species that nest in wildflower prairies (eastern meadowlark). You can even get a look at heron and cormorant nests at the right time of year. Of course, with all the small birds, you get a few raptors, too! The trails are better for biking or in-line skating than real hiking, because they're mostly paved and have little variety. Kids will be bored, and maybe worse, they are likely to be buzzed by red-winged blackbirds if they stray too close to a nest. For me, getting buzzed is a plus, but it might make your tot cry. The couple of unpaved trails are not marked well and aren't tended well, either. I didn't follow any of them to completion because the tall grasses were growing over them in some places, so I worried about stepping on a nest or a snake. There's also a soccer field near the parking lot, but it seems a silly place for it since a badly-aimed kick will cost you your ball (unless you disregard the signs and try to wade into the swamp, that is--not a good idea). To sum it up, come here to birdwatch, bring your binoculars, and leave the kids at home.

<review# 1157,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/26/2011,9/17/2011,28,222,4,5,4>Recently visited the newer location in the old Ruby Tuesday building, which appeared to be lightly renovated.  In spite of the lacking service (it was a busy Sunday brunch) the food makes this a solid 4-star review.  Once our order was taken the food runner was the last person we saw until we were nearly done; no checkup from the waitress to make sure the order was correct or to ask for additional items.  Also had no water refills until we were ready for the check.  The place was emptying out and them the waitress started come back around, so either she was a little spacey or they were understaffed that morning.Pancakes were as good as were in the old place, and the menu seems to have expanded, with a larger kitchen most likely.  I opted for the seafood omelet which can sometimes be a risky maneuver but it was done really well.  The side of wheat toast was burnt, but we sort of laughed at the irony.Good to see the quality is still there after taking on a much larger space.
<review# 1158,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/11/2011,9/16/2011,270,833,9,11,11>This was my first time going to a movie theater & restaurant at the same time. I heard some great things, so we decided to try it out. The theater is decorated like the actual Hollywood Boulevard and old movie stars (we had Charlie Chaplin in ours). The theater chairs are very comfortable - they are like nice desk chairs. You also have a small counter for you to set your food/drinks on. The menu has a variety of food - everything from burgers to Mexican food to salads. One thing to remember is that the food comes out as it is ready, not all at once with you party's food. I thought the food (I got a burger) was a little over-seasoned, to the point where I couldn't eat the whole thing.The staff was very friendly and helpful. They come about 4 times - once to take your order, once to bring your drinks, once to bring your food, and once to take away plates and bring the check. They are good about not standing in your view of the movie and taking orders quickly and quietly.Going to movies anymore is expensive in general...but here you definitely pay more. We paid a regular price for a later movie on a Friday, plus money for each meal (the prices are pretty comparable to Apple Bees or TGI Friday's). Honestly it is a pretty good deal for everything you get, but I wouldn't do it every weekend.
<review# 1159,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/29/2011,9/15/2011,850,1294,13,16,18>Growing up I was deprived of three basic childhood things - I wasn't allowed to watch sexist TV shows (Chipmunks and Smurfs), I wasn't allowed to 'dress up' with makeup, and I wasn't allowed to play video games or anything with violence (including water guns). I feel that a large chunk of childhood normalcy has gone untapped and I definitely attribute that to my Toys-R-Us philosophy: I don't wanna grow up!I've tried to quench my thirst for things I missed out on by having impromptu snowball and water balloon fights (in my 20s), but it just never fully satisfied me. Something was missing and I realized what that was when I started playing Big Buck Hunt a couple years ago: I wanted a gun and I wanted to shoot stuff. And being from MN, you would think I had gone hunting a time or two, but that feeds into the whole non-violence household rules. Instead, I got to embody passive-aggressive and had no outlet for the rage. Although, don't get me me wrong, I would never actually "shank a B". That is what the kids say these days, isn't it?So I show up at Galloping Ghost expecting something akin to a Dave & Busters or Gameworks, which are fine and dandy, but they aren't real arcades. Sure, they have Pacman and Frogger, but that's about it as far as throwback goes. I'm pleasantly surprised by a rather small store packed full of all the classics - tabletop Pacman, Mortal Kombat, Star Wars, Revenge of Doh, Tetris and a number of others that I've never heard of - for only $15 of unlimited play. It was actually a little overwhelming and I hate to say it, but I felt a little ashamed being there. I was early and figured I'd pass the time... playing games!I started out on Revenge of Doh and wondered how I was going to make it through three hours of gaming. Before I knew it, Michael G. shows up and half an hour has already passed. You really get lost in the fun. Unfortunately, the game froze on me, so I decided to try a little bit of everything. Some beast of a woman was hogging my beloved Tetris, the only game I ever got to play growing up, which I huddled over like a junkie when my dad took me on Best Buy trips.Let's just say that I had no trouble finding games to play. Three hours flew by and in those three hours I fought a Soviet army, shotgun blasted evil clowns, put on a skin-tight body suit and battled Karen C., tried to escape from a haunted mansion, body slammed hookers with knives and got lost with Joanne W. and Michael G. in a world of colorful, descending blocks to the tune of an electronic Kalinka and other such Russian favorites.Supposedly I wasn't allowed to play all these games because of their graphic nature and all the bloodshed. I kind of get it now. The insane CarnEvil characters would have definitely given me nightmares when I was younger. I had bad dreams about  the Stay Puft Mashmallow Man for three years after seeing Ghost Busters. However, I now have the sneaking suspicion that my parents picked up on my addictive personality quite early and were only saving me from myself. So, thanks Mom. You tried your best, but I'm gonna ride the white horse known as Nintendo and Sega down at Galloping Ghost.

<review# 1161,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/10/2011,9/13/2011,45,100,1,8,5>The part of Elgin near my office is a culinary desert.  Working here has inspired me to drag my behind out of bed fifteen minutes early to make my own lunch.  In the Neighborhood Deli is a welcomed anomaly.My coworker is into their soups, which I hear are superb (I'm restraining myself from spelling "superb" so it'd be a pun.  Just thought you should know that).  I'm all about their sandwiches.  What distinguish this place from its nearby all-purpose lunch joints, are the ingredients.  The first time I went there, I was pleasantly surprised to find interesting toppings like sauerkraut, caramelized onion, or roasted garlic mayo in many wonderfully concocted sandwiches.  I took one look at the menu, and I instantly knew I was at a place run by people who care about food.  You can't really go wrong with any sandwich here, but my personal favorites are The Abbott (Vienna corned beef, swiss cheese, saurkraut) and St. John (beef, caramelized onion, blue cheese, horseradish cream sauce). For less than $9, you get a gourmet sandwich, a drink, and a bag of chips.  I simply can't ask for more from this affordable foodie oasis.

<review# 1164,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/10/2011,9/10/2011,63,167,7,10,8>I have visited The Bavarian Lodge many times since I first discovered it around 2007. I like to get there right at 4PM when they open and spend a few hours savoring the experience.In the past we have chosen a table in the bar side, but that made it hard to interact with other patrons and the bartender. We have also noticed that the table wait staff is perhaps a bit too busy to give great service.So now we park at a corner of the bar and everything is great.  The bartender, Tyler, was friendly and prompt. She has a true appreciation for the beer as well and offers suggestions based on personal experience. The chairs are comfortable and the rail is in just the right place. I was able to sit and enjoy my visit without squirming in a bad chair.The beer is great. They don't brew their own, but they have a fantastic selection of Belgian, German, and American craft beers. There now have about 40 different selections on tap, and probably double that in bottles. The biggest problem is trying to decide which ones to try. Due the the massive variety of beers, they do not offer the kind of samplers that are common at brewpubs. The bartender explained that the variance in prices from one brew to the next is also a factor which makes a sampler infeasible.Oh, if you hate beer, they do happen to have Miller Lite on tap. The description on the menu describes it as "Very pale yellow with a seltzer taste. What did we do to Milwaukee to deserve this?"On each of my visits I have tried different beers, but to give you an idea, here are a few from one of my visits All of them were good.3 Floyd's Moloko - milk stoutGouden Carolous TripelGreat Lakes Xmas AleOmmegang Chocolate IndulgenceDark Horse 3 Guys Off the Scale - I love this barleywineDark Horse Black Bier AleSurly Furious IPA - an excellent example of the style!The unique selection and imported nature of many of the beers means they come at a premium price. Many of the stronger beers are served in smaller 12oz glasses. For me it is worth it, but if you are looking for cheap beer to guzzle, then look elsewhere.The food at Bavarian Lodge is good, but nothing to rave about. The concentration on German cooking means that most everything is "brown". Not to say that I don't like liver dumpling soup, spatzel, sausages, meat in gravy and sauerkraut, but it is, what it is. The beer justifies the long trip from my house. The food helps fill me up in between beers.The veggie schnitzel was an interesting departure from the traditional menu. The roast duck is also pretty good.  I find myself returning to the hunter schnitzel most of the time.I like the atmosphere at the Bavarian Lodge. It has plenty of dark wood and relatively few TVs. The music is quiet enough to permit conversation. The choice of music was a little odd... not polkas, but not top 40 either. Since it was mostly unobtrusive I didn't mind much.Overall, I would recommend this place for anyone looking for a great selection of great beer. The crowd is a mix of younger and older and everyone seems to be able to enjoy themselves. I will definitely be back. I just wish it was closer to Bartlett. Then again, if it was, I might never go anywhere else!

<review# 1167,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/10/2011,9/7/2011,51,284,3,8,3>i think momoya just became my favorite place for à la carte sushi in the western suburbs! with its nondescript location in an aurora strip mall, it doesn't look like much from the outside, but inside is some super fresh and super delicious sushi.i shared four rolls with my fiancé: spicy tuna, philadelphia, crunch and amazon. the spicy tuna roll was fantastic. this stuff is easily some of the best spicy tuna i've ever had- sweet and flavorful with a slow, spicy burn. the crunch roll was sweet, crunchy and creamy. best of all, all of the fish was excellent. we ordered a couple of pieces of nigiri- salmon, tuna and shrimp, and it was all great. the salmon in particular was really fresh and flavorful.the price is decent- not cheap, but not crazy-expensive, either. the philly and spicy tuna rolls are in the $6 range, while the specialty rolls are around $12. the service was REALLY quick and our waitress was friendly. skip the overpriced, trying-too-hard sushi "lounges" like shinto and try momoya instead!

<review# 1169,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/15/2011,9/5/2011,37,128,3,8,5>4.5 stars is really my rating but I'd figure I'd round up for them. :)Catch 35 is my go to place for a really nice meal in Naperville and also to hang out in the bar (which is where I decide to sit most of the time).  The staff is really great here and the ambiance is nice.  Compared to Sullivan's down the street, Catch 35's feel is quite different.  There's a good amount of warmer tones in the restaurant but it doesn't verge on bright and it isn't really dark like Sullivan's.  I don't know about you but the ambiance of a place is pretty important and between the staff and feel of the place, it gets 5 stars.As for the food, it's really good.  My only complaint is that they use WAY too much oil in their dishes.  Order a side of veggies and you're guaranteed to see them glistening.  So if fat is what your body likes the least (meaning it adds to your weight quicker than carbs), which is the case for me, you'll want to get things on the side or special order the dish.If you like to squat for 2-3 hours in a place (I like to journal or do a little work there) the bar is great for it.  I haven't had one server get annoyed that I was there for as long as I was and have even gotten to know several of the employees.  And of course, be sure to tip well if you squat for a while.  If you become a regular and are a good tipper, it usually comes back to you like in any restaurant.More specifically on the food: the bar has specials most weeknights so be sure to check them out.  Thursdays are half price on selected bottles of wine, which is sweet.  And if you don't finish it they'll package it up for you so you can take it home.  Their dish preparation is really great and what they do with fish is wonderful.  The steaks are good but not like a chop house so be mindful of your expectations there.  Having said that, I wouldn't say to stay away from the steaks but I would suggest going for seafood as it's their specialty.All in all, this is probably my top restaurant to hit in Naperville.  And a special shout out to some of the great staff there: Kim (typically dining room), Christine (cocktail server) and Tammy (bartender).  I look forward to seeing them on my regular Thursday visits.  They're awesome.PS - if you sit in the bar next to the window you should be able to pick up a wifi signal from across the street.  I believe it's called "Kroehler."

No question that I will be back. Mmmmmm.......Donuts.

<review# 1180,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/28/2011,8/25/2011,60,239,7,6,7>This reminds me of some of the hot dog shacks of my youth (pronounced "yout") except you can sit down and enjoy your dawg.  This to me is luxury in hot dog dining.  No standing at a counter in an unheated shelter ala' Wally's (I REALLY miss you Wally!).  The pup is your standard Vienna with the natural casing and it's got plenty of snap.  The fries are gently laid next to your dog, unlike some of the establishments that manhandle and mash your fries into your dog.  (Do you hear me G&J's and Nana's??)  Speaking of fries, when you get them straight out of the fryer, they are irresistible.  If they've been sitting, yes they can get soggy.  But guess what?  G&J's are ALWAYS soggy and greasy.The dog is adorned in standard Chicago style which means mustard, onions, relish and peppers.  No tomato or pickles.They have rotating flavors of Italian ice which is a nice touch.  Finally, I like the fact that the owner and his employees treat you like they really appreciate your business.  Some of those other hot dog purveyors act as if they are doing you a favor by selling you one of their precious dogs.Good for you Gina's!
<review# 1181,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/5/2011,8/24/2011,24,16,5,6,7>This is everything I want in a restaurant.There is bocce ball (which is very easy for new players to pick up) both inside and outside, and bowling, both of which provide ample entertainment.  The outdoor bocce court is covered and has removable walls for inclement weather.  If I remember correctly, the bowling lanes offer free socks.There is a brunch on Sunday mornings that is to die for.  Unforgettable staples are the chocolate fountain, the chicken marsala, the omelet/carving station, and the mimosa (1 is included but you must ask for it).  They also have an excellent selection of hot tea bags.There is a fantastic dinner menu with dishes that are just as delicious as they are elegant.  The wine menu lead my to my favorite wine of all time, which I have subsequently bought upwards of a dozen bottles of: the Saracco Moscato di Asti, a sweet, sparkling white Italian wine.  Last time I ate there, it was even on sale for half off ($15 instead of $30).They have a Thursday night ladies' night special with $3 specialty cocktails (read: martinis).  I can't think of any other place, particularly not one this nice, that serves martinis for $3 a pop, even on special.  When the weather is nice, I long to be sitting around their big bonfire located in the outdoor patio out back.  It is a wonderful environment with ample seating and even heat lamps for when the night turns chilly.  The restaurant serves homemade s'mores.  The only drawback is it closes a bit early in the evening, probably due to liquor serving restrictions in the town of South Barrington.  Although, that's probably a good thing, because I would stay there all night given the option.I cannot recommend this restaurant highly enough.  It is my favorite place not only for dinner, but for brunch and evenings out with friends.
<review# 1182,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/9/2011,8/23/2011,75,174,3,5,2>Dumplings and noodles are their forte here. The skin has the best combination of firm and soft, best described as "Q" for those who speak Taiwanese. The dumplings and the noodles are hand made in house, and are arguably the best tasting noodles I have ever eaten, and this is coming from a guy who prefers noodles over rice. Their noodle soups are also very delectable. I normally get their beef noodle soup or spicy seafood soup. Both will make good work of your taste buds and you will work up a good sweat eating either one of these. Another one of my favorites is the "Stir-Fried Onion Pancake with Shredded Pork". (Name in quotes because it is really long). The shredded pancake resembles shoe-string fries in appearance, and the meat is thinly sliced, again, making good work of your taste buds.The Five Spices Lou Mei is also for sale to go. For those who drink, Lou Mei goes well with a cold beer on a hot summer day. We all know how Chicago winters become very cold, and Katy's is the best place to go on such a day. The restaurant is very small, and all the windows steam up as a result from all the kitchen action. Though it may seem off-putting to some people, I see it as a part of the dining experience. The dining area is small, and there is self-served tea available for consumption. There are a handful of tables there, and the dining area is relatively noisy (but not unbearably loud). Service is "strictly business". I would not expect the friendliest of waitresses. They are not rude, not nice, but get the job done. You will forget about that as soon as you start eating. If you have read this far, go try it. It is located in the strip mall behind the Jewel on Cass and Ogden, northeast of the intersection. Cheers.

The restaurant has foods like pizza, eggplant parmesan, rice balls, salads, sandwiches, etc. I've even noticed over the counter medications used in Italy like antacids, (don't know what the other stuff was). I don't know what it is about this place but they serve the best martini's around. Ice cold and big. Just how I like them. I am not much of a filet person, I prefer rib-eye or perhaps a porterhouse (which I know has a filet section.) This W.R. rib-eye has to be one of the most flavorful beef cuts out there. Medium rare is the way I roll each and every time. One of the best things this evening was that Gibsons - Rosemont was celebrating their 10th anniversary and these rib-eyes were priced at only $20. As our waiter said, "this will be the best $20 steak you will ever have". He was right (or psychic) Everyone's steak was cooked to perfection. We split an enormous twice baked potato three ways, which was plenty, and the vegetable combination. The veggie combination was great. Spinach, mushrooms, cauliflower, green beans, asparagus, and carrots. All my favorites. Everything was perfect. The grand finale for the evening was Gibsons Turtle pie. This dessert should not be legal. It is a humongous wedge of Ice cream, macadamias, fudge and caramel over a buttery crust. It is magnificent. This thing can be shared with eight people. No fooling, it is that big. The three of us ordered it and we could only dent it about half way before waving the white flag. I have been to just about all of the top steakhouses in Chicago and in my book, Gibsons is Numero Uno. I keep finding myself coming back here again and again.Great drinks, service, and most importantly, great food. I am giving them my first 5 star review.

<review# 1200,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/28/2011,8/5/2011,161,158,3,6,4>This place has good authentic Hong Kong cuisine.  I visited here with the boyfriend and his family who are Chinese and knows quite a big about Canton and Hong Kong dishes and they have been fond of this place. Luckily, when I'm with them, his family always order a plethora of dishes and being that it was my first time at the restaurant, it really gave me a good idea of the many dishes that they offered.  We had a fantastic luncheon that felt more like a feast with beef and seafood congee, beef chow fun, 2 kinds of rice rolls in soy sauce and XO sauce, hot and sour soup, turnip cake, wonton thick rice noodle soup. The chow fun and rice rolls were really flavorful and it didn't look like any other chow fun you would get from other cook-cutter Chinese restaurants.  It was not too soft nor hard and had the right about amount of a bit crunchy-ness to it.  Though with fried noodles, you will get a bit of oil and this restaurant will use oil.  But I guess that comes with the food.  The congee soup was very good and it was made Canon style so the rice was more fluffy than other congees.  Just have a taste of it if you're looking for something warm to start with and you'll see what I mean.  The hot and sour soup was good but I must say it tasted a bit more sweet than it was sour.  Every place makes it different and they just need to adjust the balance.  Turnip cakes was yummy and wonton soup was delish...  Overall, I was pretty satisify with this place and I would visit again.  The food is good though the service can bit a little abrupt but they'll get your order out quick (which is pretty accurate of most local small-business restaurants). <review# 1201,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/11/2011,8/4/2011,371,418,9,10,8>The Morton Arboretum is pretty awesome. I'm not going to lie, I shied away from ever becoming a member here because i considered this place a nice place to visit, but more of an uptight no-fun zone that was pretty to look at but I felt like the attitude there was too serious.But things have changed, it used to be that there was no running or bike riding and things overall used to be, well, tighter. Now, I'm NOT AT ALL saying they've let this place go at all. It's still just as beautiful - if not more beautiful as ever, but now you can ride a bike through it, this is a BIG deal to me. I enjoyed my first bike ride through here so much that I became a member on the spot. Being a member has so many perks, discounts on merchandise, events and classes, as well as discounted admission for friends.If the Arboretum wasn't beautiful enough the I could spend half the day in the gift shop and the other half in the Gingko Café (I hugely recommend the buffalo wrap and the crab salad - yummm!)Tips: Bring/use bug and sun protection. HYDRATE, it's something like 16 miles on the hiking trails and 9 miles on the bike trails. If you're riding a bike, ride mouth closed, I had some kind of unexpected winged snack in one of the west loops of the park.5 stars.PS, every person I met from the entrance gate to the visitor center, restaurant and gift shop was just lovely.
<review# 1202,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/1/2011,8/3/2011,21,16,6,6,6>Honey is one of my favorite places to eat. The service is outstanding - only second to the food.  There is a full coffee bar!  I had a coconut latte last time it was here, totally delicious! The menu features fresh takes on home classics, you'll see meatloaf, bugers, veggie burgers, crab cakes and so on.    Dietzler farm beer, organic salad greens, etc. are also featured in thier offerings.  My favorite menu item is the veggie burger.  I love how it's savory with a hint of sweet from the veggies.  Made this way, it doesn't try to taste like meat, the flavor of the veggies really shines and it's wonderful!  The house salad is made with organic greens and has a delicious vinigrette that I wish they bottled.  But if you feel like indulging, the regular fries or sweet potato fries are also very good.Save room for dessert, the cupcakes are just yummy!  Moist cake, light buttercream (a generous portion!), - without being oversweet -  in different flavors daily.  Coconut is my favorite.  There are also Gluten Free Cupcakes.I highly recommend Honey.
<review# 1203,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/8/2011,8/2/2011,33,144,11,10,7>Well, it's official, I am in an abusive relationship with broasted chicken. I love it, it's fantastic, but it treats me badly. But then I go back to it and it's wonderful and then treats me horribly again. Over and over this cycle occurs.Well it's clear to me the time to leave has come.Which is a shame, because I found a place with some of the tastiest broasted chicken I've ever had. It had a great crispy skin that was actually juicy and flavorful on the inside, none of that disappointing blandness once the skin is gone. I love the seasoning overall. I'm not enough of a foodie to put my finger on the exact ingredients, but they set the chicken apart, for sure.It came with fries, which weren't too special. Standard crinkle cut, but at least they were crispy.The good news is, broasted chicken isn't all Billy's has. I've had their hotdogs before which were standard, but good, and my wife recently had a grilled chicken sandwich called the "Superchicken" that she absolutely loved. Since they see to put a little extra care into their chicken especially it's good to know I have other options to bring me back.So if your digestive system has more integrity than mine and you're looking for some of the best chicken around, definitely give Billy's a try. It's another place that doesn't look like much, but they've got it where it counts.
<review# 1204,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/18/2011,8/1/2011,125,148,6,7,6>How did I JUST find out about this place? This is a hidden gem of parisian delight nestled in the northwest suburbs of South Barrington that has been open since '09. I sauntered in after perusing the Arboretum early Friday evening during rush hour. I wasn't exactly thrilled to sit in more traffic, I might add while raining, and thought perhaps an early dinner (nosh) might lift my soggy spirits. The bar and restaurant were beautifully decorated. Le Bar was designed and made by a French wood artist (Fabien Gilbert) in an art nouveau style. It truly transported me to France. Well ladies and gents, I am in le love. The staff is super knowledgable and sweet. The decor is tres chic. The food is unbelievable! Not to mention, the expansive and reasonably priced absinthe, apertifs, wines and champagne. I was totally in luck because the Friday special was $7 glasses of Veuve. My day was totally turning around! Mario, the bartender, definitely was no newbie behind the bar. He matter of factly told me recommendations for food, when the hot nights to come by for live music and fun and information on private parties (if i should ever want to have an AHEMbridalshowerAHEM here in the near future). So let's talk food...they have a running list of specials of the day prepared from the chef in addition to the full menu of sweet and savory crepes, Chateaubriand Filet Mignon au Poivre, duck à L'Orange, salads and more. I was totally overwhelmed and impressed. I opted for the special tuna and shrimp in wasabi/aioli sauce appetizer and for dessert the warm berry compote and chocolate crepe. Everything was not only beautifully presented, but magnifique. I hope to make it back soon for their Ladies night on Wednesday's featuring $5 Martinis/$5 Glass of Wine/$5 Mixed Drinks or for a brunch on the weekends.  I suggest you make a special visit for this culinary treasure. It is definitely worth the trip!
<review# 1205,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/21/2011,7/31/2011,7,63,1,9,5>I refuse to go elsewhere. Period.I was in here a while ago on a recommendation from a friend who has gotten all of his tattoos done here. Needless to say, I was not disappointed. I wanted to cover up a mysterious mark on my hip, so I called that morning and booked an appointment with Rod. I brought him a picture of what I wanted and he redrew it while I filled out the necessary forms. His drawing was exactly what I wanted, and he went to work.Everything is clean and sanitary here; there's no "dirty tattoo shop" feeling like I got from a few other places. Everything is cleaned and sanitized, nothing is "recycled". Everyone is easy to talk to, doesn't give you a hard time, and is willing to help you out with any questions you have or anything you need.In the end, he was done in about half an hour, gave me a reminder on how to take care of it, said to call with any questions, and sent me on my way. Quick, painless (especially important since I am a wimp and have the pain tolerance of an infant). I am more than pleased, and would not recommend anywhere or anyone else. I'll be back soon!

<review# 1208,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/13/2011,7/28/2011,4739,1870,37,31,23>Aaaand The Bad Bridesmaid Award Goes Toooo...drumrolldrumrolldrumrolldrumrolldrumrolldrumrolldr­umrolldrumrolldrumrolldrumrolldrumrolldrumrolldrum­rolldrumrolldrumrollME! (natch)When my B-maid dress came in from the bridal shop I was shocked to find it was SofaKing big that when I tried it on I could zip the whole thing up, put it over my head, and it let it drop straight to the ground. Yay a bridesmaid tarp! So I tucked the dress away and worked on erasing the God awful fitting experience from my memory until I absolutely had to deal with it.It's now 2 weeks before the wedding (okay, it's a little over a week and a half until the wedding) and turns out, I'm probably gonna be sh*t outta luck taking my Andre the Giant sized dress just anywhere. Enter Lorenzo's: a well reviewed tailoring and alterations shop that's been in business for over 25 years, is oh-so-conveniently located within 10 driving minutes from my favorite Thai food spot, and says they'll have no problem getting my dress done before the wedding. PAYDIRT! Besides the size of the dress, my other problem is that I have a really  hard time wearing strapless dresses because there is no strapless bra in existence with a small enough back measurement and a big enough bust measurement. On any other day of the year the size of my body to my boobs ratio would work in my favor and then some, but not at a wedding- Not at my best friends CLASSY wedding where all the other bridesmaids will look thin and flawless and I'll look all oozy like those squishy Mr Bill toys that when squeezed the two eyeballs pop out... but replace eyeballs with tittays. So I head into Lorenzo's hoping they can pull off the miracle gross of alterations I know the dress needs and I'm expecting an older polish lady or a little Italian man or someone that could be typecast in a sitcom based on looks for what most people would think a tailor or seamstress would appear to be... but what do I walk into? Uhm. *blushes* Well... a super sssmokin' hot late 20s/early 30s something guy complete with tattoos and a mini mohawk. Soooo, there's that. He's incredibly professional and tells me what he'd mentioned over the phone- that the owner is out of town until Thursday but as long as it's not an actual wedding dress he can do the measurements and have the seamstress sew it up for the next week. You got a deal, Buddy!The dress (which I had been affectionately referring to as "the Beast") is so big that he needs to actually pre-pin before I try it on and do the actual measurements and alterations pinning on top of the first round of pins- so my dress is basically 1 part green shimmery taffeta and 10 parts metal. I felt like a flamboyant Iron Man, but the dress felt like it would fit snugly and it appeared that he understood when I said I needed the top part to be TIGHT so I could tuck my bubbies in and have the least amount of nip slips possible.  I had dropped the dress off on a Wednesday and with the 4th of July holiday weekend they said it could be ready Tuesday. Turns out, the dress needed so much taken out- something to the tune of 8 inches, that it ended up taking a little longer (but that worked out better for my schedule anyway) and I got to pick up the perfectly fitted dress on Thursday AND they were so nice that the owner gave me quite the deal on The Beasts alterations. The dress was a hit and my boobs only almost came out a few times due to the lack of a quality strapless bra and my excessive booty shakin' BUT overall it was a showstopper and I owe it all to the super sexy crew at Lorenzo's, whom I will now count on for any and all my alterations needs.

It's creamy, fresh and delicious. It's pricey, but good chocolate always is. You can watch them make chocolate through a window and when you are done with that, you can wander inside and buy a whole bunch!! They have homemade ice cream which I understand is fantabulous. (I can not eat ice cream)This is a great place to buy a box of chocolate for a gift. My Grandma and sister are both fans. The s'mores are "graham" crackers, with caramel and marshmallow and then completely covered in yes, you guessed it, chocolate!I love Graham's. Writing this review has persuaded me to visit very soon followed with a wine tasting down the block at Galena Cellars!
<review# 1211,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/6/2011,7/25/2011,44,130,7,9,4>Personally, I couldn't have felt more out-of-place in the glistening, corporate complex that graces north Naperville. Maybe it's because the restaurant shares a lobby with an investment firm, but it felt a little like peering into the Big Boy's Club: it wouldn't phase me if a multi-million dollar Wall Street deal took place here over steaks 'n' scotch.Anyway, on to what matters! The waiter was extremely attentive and considerate. Even the bus boy, when pouring ice water, shielded his hand with a napkin to prevent any water from potentially splashing me. I was shocked by this move and said as much. The poor soul's demeanor suggested he may have been lashed before, god help that wayward drop of water.A fresh basket of bread (cut into clever slivers that resembled chips) arrived alongside cloves of garlic, which the waiter crushed right in front of us with a fork! The beet and apple salad was superb, with an excellent (and light) touch of vinaigrette. And my mom had to restrain herself from licking the plate clean of her birthday dinner (mushroom dusted mahi). Solid menu, superb service, beautiful environment. I could've sat back and watched the traffic all day.

I really like their being 24 hours during weekdays since I sometimes keep very odd hours, and a good workout at 5 am or 11:30 pm is not unusual for me.The spa is great! I got a 30-minute massage from Stacy that began as a bone-crusher, but she loosened up some scapular tension quite well. The steam room is well-maintained, yet there is no sauna. These are expensive due to the special wood required on all surfaces.I rent a small locker which is enough to store a few changes of clothing, toiletries, and workout shoes. Additionally, they offer a laundry service so your clean clothes are returned into your locker the next day. There's no way I'm toting sweaty workout clothes to work to wash them that evening.There is a constant specter of over-selling service, staff are always suggesting some new thing. That might be new to me since that never happens at country clubs, but they have a revenue stream that is different than FFC.One evening, quite to my surprise, was a member appreciation night with samples of food from local restaurants, music, and promotional sizes of sports drink. I'm certain it did not cost the club very much, but goodwill like that goes a long way.

You read that right, SHRIMP!  Not some puny vegetable egg roll! By the time the pad see ew I ordered came, I was one bite away from full.  Needless to say, I took more than half my lunch home.  Guess it's pad see ew for lunch at work tomorrow!So you're at the end of your meal.  What's one of the frequently asked questions after we're all happy stuffed?  ...Anybody have gum? Yup, CK's got you covered! You'll find a stick of Wrigley gum with your  check.
<review# 1217,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/29/2010,7/19/2011,2184,1339,9,10,9>Wildfish is one of the best sushi places in Chicagoland, hands down! The sushi is all fresh, very tasty, and the service is fantastic! The location is great, there is a ton of underground parking (people who say there is no parking must not have seen this underground parking...the stairs lead right up to the front of Wildfish) and the ambiance is intimate and very classy. Definitely make reservations though!I went yesterday because the last Wednesday night of each month they have an all you can eat event for $32. This includes a ton of appetizers, rolls and nigiri...it is a great deal! A lot of really good rolls are included on the Wednesday night menu.  Of course you can order off of the regular menu, too, but the all you can eat sushi is a much better deal.For appetizers, we had Wild Tartar (Spicy tuna & salmon served on crispy tortilla chips...very good but eat it before it soaks into the chip making it soggy!), Edamame, Vegetable Tempura, & Gyoza (Pan fried pork dumplings). For our feast we had 3 Philadelphia Rolls (standard fare of cream cheese, salmon, avocado & cucumber... I think they make my FAVORITE Philly roll here), Crispy Spicy Tuna (Sushi rice pan fried with spicy tuna...this is actually an interesting looking roll...reminds me more of cake pieces then sushi pieces), 2 Super White Tuna pieces (amazing), 2 Yellow Tail  pieces (also yummy), 2 Red Snapper pieces (surprisingly good), Crazy Dragon Roll (snow crab meat with seared spicy tuna & tempura crumbs,  Indiana Jones (Shrimp & asparagus tempura, unagi, egg, wasabi mayo, black rice)  and then we tried pieces of some various rolls...I cant remember the names of them all. They have about 6 different rolls you can grab pieces of in a buffet style and the rest can be ordered off the menu. Most of the appetizers you go up and get buffet style, as well, except we ordered ours off of the menu.So to summarize price wise, we got (Wild Tartar 10, Edamame 4, Vegetable Tempura 8, Gyoza 6, Philly Rolls 30, Crispy Spicy Tuna 17, 2 Super White Tuna pieces 6, 2 Yellow Tail pieces 6, 2 Red Snapper pieces 6, Crazy Dragon Roll 17, Random other roll pieces, 3 Green Tea Ice Creams 9,  Indiana Jones roll 18) $137 would have been the retail price not counting the random rolls pieces we tried (and we both tried at least 6 different pieces) and we paid $64 for the two of us.The whole staff was great. The servers were very attentive to our needs and our water glasses never went below half filled.There was so much more we wanted to try, but we just got SO full! :) Next month we will definitely going back to this all you can eat event.They have some of the most creative rolls at Wildfish. A lot of newer sushi places actually had chefs that started at Wildfish and 'borrowed' some of their roll ideas I've heard. Wildfish truly is the original sushi place for some of these creative rolls.They have some great desserts here, too! The green tea ice cream is the perfect way to end your dinner. They also have these fruit ice creams that come in half of a frozen real fruit piece~refreshing and light and yummy!
<review# 1218,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/29/2010,7/18/2011,92,360,5,6,5>Mmm. Pho Ha was a good experience all around, from the coconut shake made with real coconut milk, to the quality of the broth, vegetables and meat that came with the pho.Any issues I have with the place are small. There was barely any parking in the strip mall, which isn't usually a problem out here in the 'burbs. The minimum dollar amount for a credit transaction is a hefty $15, so I had to walk next door to an ATM for cash.Inside, it's pretty much no frills, and all Asians. (The whole place had a familiar feel, down to the Orlando Magic game that was being broadcast from the LCD TV next to the cash register. You know you're eating with other Asians when...) The menu is a short list on two pages, so I could make up my mind as to what I wanted quickly. There was 25 minutes between when I got the pho, and when I got home, so I can't say I had the pho fresh out of the kitchen. Still, this was seriously savory pho. Maybe it was the balance of the duck sauce, the chili sauce and the broth, or the mint, or the freshness of the meat. I have not had better pho anywhere else in the suburbs.This place is a treat. I'm glad it's close by, because I want to go back and have it in the restaurant itself.
<review# 1219,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/26/2011,7/17/2011,79,108,13,15,13>It is an inevitability that if there's a gyros joint somewhere in my vicinity, I will eat there at least once, however, Stav's has grown on me more and more.I started just getting gyros sandwiches and gyros plates, then I expanded to their chicken and salads.Gyros are pretty damn good, and even good reheated when you can't finish all of it in one sitting!  That's a hard thing to accomplish as many times reheated gyros are chewy and basically inedible.  Now their chicken.. holy moly!  The meat falls off the bone.  The Grecian spices or their BBQ flavors are terrific, albeit once in a while the skin is a tidbit on the burnt side.Now, the trumpets herald the excellent Greek salads they offer.  You can have a small or an ultimate salad... always crispy lettuce, fresh tomatoes and cucumbers, crisp and slightly potent thin slices of onion, green pepper slice, dolmades (rice in a grape leaf), feta cheese, and kalamata olives, all can be covered in their spiced vinaigrette which is in a separate container so you can dose it out at your own convenience.  Make sure that you phone ahead to place your order if you're going to the drive through window because this place is NOT fast food and you'll end up waiting if you just show up.The restaurant area is always clean, and has a flat screen television, but I've never dined-in.
