We were there at lunch time on a Saturday and they were doing quite a brisk amount of business. The place is small, just a few tables, so you might want to consider getting your order to go if you come at a peak time.I'm only sad they aren't in our neighborhood so we can't frequent Zenwich more often.
<review# 1222,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/30/2011,7/14/2011,850,1294,12,12,16>A fellow Minnesotan once perfectly summed up my spice tolerance: "Ketchup has a zing to it." Well, that was what I'd have said some years ago. I've been working on choking back the Scoville tears and can now enjoy hot wings (with a ton of ranch) and other meals that pack a little heat. If you've read Carolynne M.'s reviews, I envy her courage/masochism.I wanted to do something special for my 700th review, so I searched Yelp for anyplace including a 7 and found Heaven on Seven, which happens to be in the same city in which I live. I immediately called my food-adventurist buddy and bugged him to go with me every day for the past two weeks and finally broke his resistance to driving all the way from Wheeling to partake in delicious Southern food.HoS is easy to pass if you aren't looking for it. It's just one of many tiny storefronts that dot Main Street. Now you can thank me for bringing it to your attention because you're going to get some quality eats here. My friend had a delicious Breaded Catfish with Coleslaw. I highly recommend the Sweet Potato Polenta with Andouille Sausage and Carmalized Onions, Orzolaya with huge chunks of Sausage, Chicken, Shrimp and Tomatoes, and a cup of the Gumbo. I personally prefer a more brothy and seafood-packed Gumbo, but this one isn't bad. It "has a zing to it." A real zing, not the MN ketchup kind.It was a bit on the pricier side, but not outrageous. I think it could be a good date spot, because it's kinda colorful and kitschy (Mardi Gras beads hang from thousands of bottles of different hot sauces and original artwork covers the brick walls) without being campy. The waitstaff were all friendly and attentive. The dessert menu is both impressive and daunting, we skipped it because we had enough leftovers to last all weekend. I'd like to come back and try some other dishes and get my sweet tooth fix.
<review# 1223,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/19/2011,7/13/2011,12,51,3,5,3>Great wine, perfectly cooked steak, ncaa basketball = perfect night.This is my first review on Yelp, but definitely not my first trip to a nice steakhouse.  I travel a lot and try to hit "the best" steakhouse in whatever city I am in.  We made the drive from downtown based on the excellent reviews and it was well worth the drive.  I am going to make two reviews here, first for those that live in the city - the drive to Schaumburg was easy and the menu was well worth the trip.  We had the Thai Buffalo shrimp for an appetizer, and I could have ate these all night.  The sauce was amazing, the perfect blend of a little sweet and some spice.  Shrimp can easily be overdone, these were cooked perfectly.  The filet had a nice sear, and was cooked perfectly for each of the members of our party.  The bernaise sauce was excellent, but I only used one bite of it because the steak was perfectly seasoned.  I have definitely had some steaks at well known steak houses that needed some extra flavor, but this steak was perfect.  The sides all sounded fantastic, but we could barely finish the garlic mashed potatoes because the steak and appetizers were so filling.  My wife has bread pudding for dessert at every restaurant we go to, and I have tried most.  The banana bread pudding was among the best I have ever had.My review for those of you that live anywhere close to Schaumburg... why haven't you gone and tried this place yet!  You have no excuse not to go.  If it is worth a 30-45 minute drive for people in the city, then it is definitely worth an even shorter trip.  Why go into the city and get a inferior dining experience when you can get a perfectly cooked steak and great experience without the hassle.  Go there and write your own review - you will not be disappointed.  Great for a date night, business dinner, or just when you are craving a great steak, great atmosphere, and a restaurant and owner that truly care about your dining experience.  With the economy the way it is, the owners of this restaurant know that you may not be able to afford to eat out as often, and therefore want to make sure your experience is memorable.  We saw the owner going around and checking on every table, the servers knew the menu and could recommend a great bottle of wine to compliment your meal.  The specials sounded amazing, I wish I could have sampled each one.  I guess we'll just have to come back again....and again...and again.
<review# 1224,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/3/2011,7/12/2011,50,245,2,6,5>My family never misses this festival.  We really think it's the best in Chicagoland and uber-family friendly.  We have it down to a science.  We arrive at 11:45 and park  in the Boy Scout lot by the main entrance. The $15 cost is totally worth it especially since we walk in looking like we're on a weekend campout.  We bring chairs, blankets, lots and lots of semi-frozen factory sealed water bottles, sun block, bug spray, paper towel, wet wipes, cards, newspaper, reading material for kids, camera, contraband Tootsie Rolls and fruit snacks and I think that about covers it!  We are definitely ALL IN!  Oh yeah, and a couple hundred dollars!  Entry is $12 for over 11 years old.  There is a list of what is allowed in on their website.As soon as you set up your little campground or picnic area you can leave your stuff there and walk around.  Of course, we don't leave valuables and we tuck stuff away under our chairs a bit but have never ever had anything stolen.  Speaking of lost stuff.  There is a child check in area where you can put a paper bracelet on your child with a corresponding tab with a number you receive to keep.  You fill out a form with your name, the child's name and your cell phone number so if you ever get separated they know who to call.  Also, the brightly colored shirts of all the volunteers make it easy to tell your children who to go to if they do get lost.  Luckily this has never been a problem for us but the peace of mind makes us feel better.  This is the main reason I feel safer here with my kids versus other large festivals like Taste of Chicago and others.There are two stages and with yesterday's 100 degree temps it wasn't too difficult to choose the south stage with the shade way in the back.  We loved the 9 hours of awesome blues performers even though we had to watch them on the screen because of the distance.  We missed Styx at the other stage but by the time the sun went down it was too full over there and our stage was awesome anyway!It was nice being near the kid's stuff.  Bouncy houses, petting zoo, kiddie shows, playground.  All free with entry.  We don't waste our money on the Carnival rides.  We save our money for food.As for the ribs.  Porky and Beans closely followed by I Love Fat Guys are our favorites this year.  But I can't say I ate any I didn't like.  Of course the kids love the Dippin Dots.  This place is also very clean and friendly which is a huge bonus that you rarely get at these things!  I think almost everyone is a volunteer and I often wonder if participation is a requirement for residency there are soo many volunteers.  All with smiling faces.  We plan our Fourth of July Holiday celebrations around this festival every year and will continue to do so for many more to come.
<review# 1225,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/1/2010,7/11/2011,204,392,7,5,5>Self Serve Froyo+Mid Day Stomach Grumble = Major Destruction.The bell from the front entrance dings as you walk in, nobody is standing behind the counter and all of the sudden you freeze in your tracks as you see many...aka UH OH flavors of froyo in a help yourself line that is set up for some serious devouring. You're doomed before you can reach for the cup.YoGo Station is a standard self serve pitstop that is compact but filled with everything you could possibly need to fill the void of a cool snack. From flavors like original tart to glorious newbies orange or mango there's bound to be something for all of the kiddies.The topping selections are, I don't want to say lacking as there is pretty much everything any other froyo stop would have like nuts, chocolate, mochi or even fresh fruit. But for some unknown reason I was craving the Fruity Pebbles. This craving does not succumb this lady in blue and when I didn't see it I dove into the mochi and snickered off. The texture is in tact, the froyo isn't icy and drab where so many other places go wrong. It's light, airy and just the right flavoring. I stuck it out with original because I'm flashy like that. Note to self: There is a reason it's called self serve....Go with Caution. A slip with the wrist and dip with the hip can cause you to whip out a little extra dough. Yield the yellow tape and pull the tab down slowly.

<review# 1227,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/23/2011,7/9/2011,255,326,4,6,5>Believe it or not, this golf course and the nearby walking/bike path is a great place to bird watch. Yes, yes, I know it's a mini golf course run by the park district. I do come here to mini golf, and I do appreciate that the park district is resurfacing some of the greens with new "grass." Nevertheless, the real reason I mini golf here and not someplace else, besides the close-to-home location, is the birds.I've spotted swallows, swifts, ducks, geese, two species of heron, a cormorant, an egret, cardinals, crows, red-winged blackbirds, song sparrows, hawks, and even some of the feral Quaker parrots usually seen in Hyde Park and Addison. There are the usual colorful finches and chickadees often seen in these parts, plus the occasional harder-to-spot migrant species. There are always baby ducks and geese at the right time of year, and the swallows will skim the water all around you as you place your ball and prepare to calculate your number of strokes over par.I don't recommend the concessions here, because half they time they're gross and not even the right temperature. I recommend coming here to become infuriated by a tiny plastic ball, see some wildlife, take a walk, and hit the batting cages. Bring your sunscreen and sit out on the picnic tables by the water so you can watch the birds and fish while you sip a beverage. It's a great summertime afternoon activity.
<review# 1228,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/13/2011,7/8/2011,29,60,10,14,6>I'm writing this review while still in my sweet hotel-stay induced happiness coma so will try my best to recount important details. I can't even explain how incredibly bummed I felt when I returned back home this morning. Normally, everyone loves the feeling of laying in their very own bed after an evening spent somewhere else, but I actually found myself missing the comfortable king size bed I slept in last night.First off, I love how beautifully the hotel lobby is decorated. The winding flight of stairs through the middle of the room is gorgeous and gives the hotel a very elegant look from the moment you walk in and scan the scenery. The small bar located at the furthest end of the room (past Atwater, the hotel restaurant) is a nice place to unwind before going to bed. It wasn't incredibly packed around 11pm (a big relief) and ended up being a comfortable place to hang out for a bit. I must say I was surprised that two drinks cost us 20 dollars, though. Also, another perk was the super sweet concierge and desk staff. The concierge was very polite and helpful as soon as we checked in. He dropped us off at our restaurant and promptly picked us up when we called for a ride despite the hotel seeming pretty busy yesterday evening. Our room was very nice and particularly spacious. The "river front premier" suite included a balcony overlooking the fox river which was very serene this time of year and extremely romantic. It looked amazing and I really wish I'd brought some warmer gear so we could spend some more time outside. I also enjoyed the very large bathroom mainly for the huge tub, which I relaxed in until my little piggies started wrinkling like prunes.The turn down service adds a nice touch with milk and cookies left on the counter. The flat screen tv was placed next to the bed in a convenient viewing location although we didn't watch much tv. The continental breakfast includes various pastries, granola, meats & cheeses, sliced fruit, etc. They definitely step it up from the stereotypical crappy "cereal and bagels" fare where some hotels think it's acceptable to skimp. There's one big reason I'm only giving the Herrington four stars as well as a tiny criticism which I'd like to address. The small annoyance was I noticed that the ceiling had a few loose pieces of plaster that seemed to be flaking off... obviously, I didn't see this until the morning. It wasn't a huge deal but I'd suggest they smooth it out because tiny flaws can really ruin a great room. The gigantic blunder was when my bf was looking for a lost article of clothing and started searching under the comforter, between the end of the mattress and bedpost, and finally under the bed and to his (and my) dismay, found a pair of underwear... which were not mine. So gross. Overall, I would love to return to this hotel sometime in the future despite the minor concerns. This was the best Valentine's Day I've ever had and I believe a lot of credit is due to the Herrington. I feel spoiled after our relaxing stay and worry I'll be turning into one of the hotel brats who expects near perfection wherever they go... it's nothing but the best for me from here on out!

<review# 1232,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/14/2011,7/4/2011,364,363,5,9,6>I once believed that the two words "honest mechanic" together compromise the most sneered at oxymoron known to mankind. I also once believed that a company providing excellent customer service was something that a consumer's dreams were made of. Enter Nofsinger's, forever changing my opinion of both. So Old Blue needed brakes and a tune-up and trying to find a repair shop to kindly tend to her without gouging my checkbook was quickly approaching something close to torture. I must admit that the whole business was so unpleasant that I put off the repairs much longer than I should have, until I couldn't any longer for fear that the brakes would fail Girlspawn on her way home from work and her ghost would haunt me eternally. I didn't want her last words to be, "Thanks Mom, for being a cheapskate," so I begrudgingly set to the task of getting it done. Forever the cheapskate though, I scoured the local ads and my trusty annual coupon book for deals. Unsatisfied, I almost gave in to "the devil you know thanks to advertising" and almost settled on a chain repair shop. That is, until my instincts told me to check Yelp, and low and behold, there was the chain shop with a lousy star and a half. Yeah... scrap that. Girlspawn is worth a lot more than a star and a half.Sorting the local shops according to review, there was Nofsinger's staring me right in the face. I was rendered speechless by all the 5 star reviews. Wait a minute, this is a repair shop. Who the heck gives a repair shop 5 stars? Repeatedly? What the heck was wrong with my eyesight? Nervous and skeptical, I made the call. The rest is history. Nofsinger's exceeded my expectations in every way possible. From start to finish, something I once viewed even more unpleasant than getting a root canal now stands out as one of my most amazing consumer experiences ever. And really, all I did was make a call. Old Blue was in and out in 4 hours. She was cleaner than she probably has been in 5 years. She didn't make me cry when the bill was paid. Old Blue is now happy, Girlspawn is safe, and I have new-found admiration and respect in an era of customer DISsatisfaction.Yes, they clean your car inside and out.  Yes, they drop you off and pick you up. Yes, they talk to you like real people. Yes, they are honest and fair. Yes, this was real life and not a crazy dream.99.9% of businesses out there really need to take a lesson from Nofsinger's, because THIS business knows how it's done.**EDITED TO ADD** Way to go, RJ in Oak Park. Your unrealistic expectations aren't their fault, and your crappy review should hopefully stand out as the aberration that it is.

<review# 1237,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/19/2011,6/29/2011,118,202,7,7,6>Two Brothers spiced things up a bit this year with the addition of Hop Juice Black - a slightly meaner cousin to an already strong but well balanced beer.  The balance in flavor helps hop juice from being feared by those who like a lighter beer but still provides plenty of punch to those who prefer something a bit heavier.This celebration is all about these beers and their release into the wild for the masses to consume.  It also features the rest of the Two Brothers beer line-up, some great Two Brothers food (love the fish tacos!) and guest beers from other breweries like Lagunitas.On that topic, if you really want a guest beer get a lay of the land - there is a limited quantity of brew and there are 2 lines in a close area.  I missed the Lagunitas Barrel Aged Imperial but I did get my hands on another guest brew later.The lines were a bit long this year, but nothing I wouldn't expect out of any similar event.  With any kind of planning you can pick up food / beer tickets when you buy your take-home beer and avoid the other line all-together.  Food lines were long earlier in the day but there was no wait later in the evening.  Some of the day the Hop Juice lines were non-existent, and other times there was a decent wait.  Things averaged out to be as-expected, but I wonder if there isn't some way to improve on it a bit for next year.In any case, the juice was loose and the crowd was great.  It's good seeing people you know and meeting new ones while enjoying fresh, delicious, libations from a great brewer.  Overall I had a great time and I'll be back again next year!

My husband was in love. For two glasses of wine, calamari, filet mignon, stuffed chicken, and dessert our bill totaled $80. Great price, great service, great meal. We'll be back.
<review# 1239,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/9/2010,6/27/2011,27,158,7,13,8>I absolutely am in LOVE with this farmer's market.  Every Saturday I head here super early and gobble up plenty of fresh fruits and veggies to last me all week.I've gotten amazing strawberries, peaches, blueberries, raspberries, watermelon.... and everything is ripe, locally grown, and delicious.  The blueberries are some of the best I've ever had.  There is every veggie imaginable, and it's been fun creating new meals out of all the local, fresh produce.  Plus, I can easily fill up a bag with about $7.00 worth of veggies.  Sweet, huh?And to those peeps who say "it's overpriced blah blah blah" .... Fine.  Leave the goodness for me.    Go to Wal-mart or Jewel and buy pesticide ridden, crappily imitated fruits and veggies that are shipped from three countries away.  Don't support farmers whose livelihood depends on their local neighbors.  Go ahead and keep on supporting factory farms that are ruining our environment... Ignorance is bliss.But hey, I do understand some of the stuff is pricey.  But you DO get what you pay for.  I paid $5 for a carton of strawberries and they were the sweetest, ripest, yummiest berries... which we devoured in a day.  THAT GOOD.  Was it worth the money? Hell yes.  And next week I went back for more and they were already out of season.  (tear tear)  I moped for at least an hour.  And then bought ripe, wonderfully juicy peaches instead.  I love it.  It's in a wonderfully quaint area downtown, and there are coffee and tea shops all around- plus, the people watching is always a good time.  A fun way to start the weekend.  There are plenty of other stands to peruse- everything from  flowers, pies, and jewelry to meat and salsas and more. Definitely worth the stop at least once.
<review# 1240,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/1/2011,6/26/2011,127,193,10,6,6>Halt!  Dost thou possess an appetite fit for a king?Hast thou the courage and nobility to travel to the Ellyn of Glen?Then travel ye to "Sir" Alfie's Inn, and bask in the bounties of very family friendly-priced sandwiches, dinner baskets and Domaine DuPage from Two Brothers.  Seriously, when in medieval suburbia, drink local.According to a local historian (aka, my mother), medieval-themed jaunts used to be all the rage back in the day.  This one has remained since 1967, and it's easy to see why.  Delicious sandwiches (I had the Down Under Chicken, with no-nonsense cheddar and bacon, on a kaiser bun), and cold beer would've won Sir Gawain's approval, along with the dark, secretive atmosphere.  Seriously, there's a wooden sign on the front door that remains warning against cigar and pipe smoking, and still one in the dining room proudly designating the No Smoking section.  Throwbacks aplenty with the large booths and the two cozy fireplaces indoors.As Fair Lady Rachel J. noted, not a lot of frilly service, but it is good all-around.  I tried the length of our meal to manage a smile out of our server, but to little avail, A barrage of pleases and thank-yous finally made some headway.  Next time, maybe I'll put some extra shine on my armor.So, fair knight, whenst thou desires refreshment at the roundtable, embark on a crusade to Alfie's and indulge to thy heart's content.

<review# 1248,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/7/2011,6/18/2011,107,399,7,16,10>I'm not a huge fan of Korean food. But this is not really because I don't enjoy Korean style cooking but more that I haven't been very impressed with most Korean restaurants I've visited around the US and Canada.With that said, Ttowa is changing my attitude towards Korean cooking. If you plan to eat here you should make sure you're pretty hungry first because it's pretty much impossible to leave here without being very full. Some people complain about the price on these reviews but keep in mind that expensive Korean food is still around $9 to $14 a person unless you get the more expensive items. This isn't really that different from the price of going to Panera and cheaper than a lot of the nearby restaurants. Considering that you're getting high quality, freshly made, time consuming dishes I'd consider the price charged here to be very fair. The menu may look a little limited at the moment but the owner plans to add items to the menu in the near future.Every meal comes with the standard Korean appetizers (I got between 4 and 5). Scallion pancake, mung bean salad, kimchi, spicy broccoli, and bean sprout salad.The traditional (pork and beef), shrimp, and grilled chicken mandoo are excellent here. It's not easy to find freshly made dumplings around Chicago, especially in the suburbs. These are made daily with a nice thin skin. I prefer them pan fried but they are delicious steamed and boiled as well (I had to try them all in 1 day, they were really that good).Dduk mandoo kuk is a rice cake dumpling soup. It's made from bone marrow stock that's been prepared over days and is quite tasty without being overly salty. It's a great way to enjoy the dumplings in a broth but more importantly eat the deliciously chewy rice cake that's also used in Chinese cuisine. They generously provide plenty of rice cake in the broth so you have plenty to enjoy.The jeon bok juk is an abalone porridge that contains black sesame, broccoli, pine nuts, shitake mushroom, and fresh abalone. It's a bit different from the Chinese style congee although not that different from the more grainy Taiwanese multigrain porridge. It has a nice flavor and consistency to it.The hae mul pajeon is a guilty pleasure of mine. You will find something similar in Vietnamese restaurants. Basically you take shrimp, squid, and scallion and put it in a mix of flour, eggs, rice flour, and green onions. The result is a very delicious almost like Asian seafood pancake/crepe/pizza. It's kind of hard to describe but it's crispy and delicious. This is one item you must try in addition to the dumplings if you plan to visit.The chap chae noodles are also good and not very spicy like some of the other local restaurants. The pork belly is another nice dish which is a tad spicy but goes great with rice.You finish the meal off with a nice cold yogurt drink and candy.Don't worry if you do not speak Korean, the waiters/waitresses speak perfect English and are knowledgeable about the food. This place is kind of tucked away at the end of the street but is likely to become a local secret (like Sushi Para) once more people find out about the excellent food here.I can't wait to try their expanded menu when it comes out.
<review# 1249,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/7/2011,6/17/2011,261,335,6,7,7>Well, well, well; what have we here? A little bistro with elegant food, wine, and desserts so decadent that you feel like a Buddha when you leave. If you're on a date, come here. If you're making up after a fight, come here. If you're trying to impress a client, come here. If you just want a quiet and interesting meal where you and your significant other can simply reconnect, come here. That's what we did tonight and we weren't sorry. This is not a particularly fancy place. But I think it's the entire package that gives it panache. On Tuesday, you bring your own bottle. As to the food, please remove your calorie counters from your computer area, close your eyes, and get into this food! We each had an opener: a mushroom risotto with cilantro, scallops and a warm lime butter (drool); the other was spring rolls with a super sweet lobster. Both were great. We nixed the salad and evilly plotted a shared dessert. There are nightly specials here, but they have a pretty nice standard offering too. I loved the 'am I seeing red hot' seared scallops that came with a sweet corn and yam hash and grilled fennel. My guy had pork that glazed with Bourbon and with a melted cheese pot and swiss chard. Okay, right about then, we were groaning inaudibly. It's not that we downed both dinners, but the food was great enough to savor it nice and slow. Thank God, the coffee came-eth. Isn't it also lovely that there are Tread-climbers for nights such as this!
<review# 1250,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/5/2011,6/16/2011,63,55,10,8,7>When I die, I'll know I'm in heaven if it looks and smells like Anna Shea Chocolates.I stumbled across Anna Shea by accident one day, when I was looking for a place I'd heard carried Foiled Cupcakes in a store.  Which - side note - they do, if you want a delicious Foiled Cupcake and aren't in their delivery area. My quest for cupcakes came to a full stop, however, when I saw the woman in front of me at the counter getting a cup of fabulous smelling coffee and a plate with two beautiful bon bons.  Now, historically, I am a straight-chocolate-don't-need-any-of-your-fancy-­stuff sweets aficionado, but when I went over to the counter to look at the bon bon selection, my mouth hung open aghast.  The variety of beautiful little chocolates, truffles and bon bons are laid out on a marble slab, organized by season, type, and filling.  Each one is a beauty to behold before you even taste them, shimmering with color and shine and yes, on some, even a glitter.  I immediately succumbed and bought a box of 9.  Yes, they are a bit pricey ($25 for 9 bon bons) but hey, I'm all about quality, not quantity.  And these little gems deliver.  I ate one a day and it was the happiest 9 evenings I've had in quite some time (unless my family is reading, in which case, the time I spent with you was equal in enjoyment).  They have a selection of "standard" bon bons that are available year round, and augment that with seasonal treats around holidays and, well, the seasons.  The lounge itself is cute, if not overly girly, and there were mothers with daughters sharing pots of hot chocolate as a special treat.  I plan on bringing my daughter there for a special afternoon soon.  If you have a craving for chocolate, buy a Hershey bar.  But if you worship chocolate and covet it for its powers to smooth over all  your rough edges, treat yourself and have a bon bon at Anna  Shea.  If your mood doesn't improve, you're probably dead.

This was my first dinner experience here and I chose to indulge with my sister. We ordered more than we should have, but it was okay because we had hungry gentleman at home (watching the Hawks game) awaiting our arrival with leftovers. We started with the famous crab rangoon and the egg rolls. Yummy in my tummy! Honestly, I think the appetizers are my favorite part of the meal. Not too greasy. Beautifully crisp and seasoned just right. I would like to work my way through the rest of the appetizers, but can't seem to get much further because I like these two so much. We moved on to soup. My sister had the hot & sour which I am pretty sure she loved. I tried it even though I am not a fan of egg in the least bit - regardless, the flavor was delicious! The kick was delightful. I ordered the Chinese Chicken Soup which I found to be a unique combination of white meat chicken, cilantro, vermicelli noodles and lime. My only wish is that it was served piping hot which it was not. I will just make sure to ask them to do that next time. I should point out that for $15.95 each we could have ordered a box with soup, an appetizer and some sushi or another chinese dish, I thought about this and under normal circumstance that would have been the way to go. Since we were purposely over-ordering, we ordered three separate dishes instead. A honey glazed steak, general tao's chicken and chicken chow mein. We were looking forward to the steak the most and it was our least favorite dish. There was nothing wrong with it other than it was not what we envisioned. The steak was cut into strips, breaded and sauteed with sauce and veggies. Again, it was fine, but not what we expected. The general tao's chicken was spicy, lightly breaded perfectly and had just the right amount of sauce. I think three or four different types of peppers are used in that dish, so every step of the way, I felt a different type of heat. A bit of spice right away, a different more intense heat as I ate a little more and then a nice after "burn". I don't really know any other way to describe it, but it was quite good. Finally, my favorite of the main dishes was the chicken chow mein. We should have ordered lo mein to get a soft noodle, but the pan fried chow mein was a nice change of pace. The large pieces of unbreaded chicken were plentiful. The veggies were cooked perfectly (although there were mushrooms included that I didn't notice on the menu) and the sauce was the "icing on the cake"! Service was great! Our server was knowledgeable and kept answering all of our questions without hesitation. He was not obtrusive and seemed to know exactly when to drop by the table. I've said it once and I will say it again...I will be back soon. p.s. Delivery is now available!!! :-)

Lighting and drapes provide great ambiance.Lovely restaurant for a very special night out, but I can't recommend it for a favorite place to come often, as portions are so small and prices so high.

We had a group of 3 so we ordered 3 entres and 1 Large Hot & Sour soup that all came out to roughly $20.  We had plenty leftover to take home afterwards.  Even if you had ordered a small it was decently proportions and it was for under $5.  There were some dishes that were House Specialities but they were still very good deals at $5-$8.  Today I tried everything vegeterian: Vegetable Kow, Tofu Country Style and Egg Foo Young Mushroom.  The Egg Foo Young, hands down was the best I have ever tasted and it didn't even have meat! I didn't even miss meat the whole time we were eating.  The veggies were fresh and green and they were cooked just right, crunchy and not over-cooked.  They did used a lot of corn starch in their sauce as far as I can tell because it was thick (so note that one meal will make you full for a while) but their seasoning and flavor were not over the top or too salty.  The only thing I wasn't totally fond of was their Hot & Sour soup that tasted too sour! It tasted like they had went overboard with the vinegar but hey, if you are a die-hard fan of that soup, you'll find a way to get used to it.  Overall, great place.  So affordable if you are a college student or anyone just looking for cheap Chinese eats.  Come here to order or get take out.  You just gotta know that if you are going to eat-in, they don't have bowls and they will give you your food in Chinese cartons and plastic boxes (it's ready for you to take to-go afterwards). There are no official silverware or plates, so  plastic forks it is! It's not about the service or presentation here but their food alone will leave you feeling satisfied ;)Oh and Credit Card payments of amount $15+.
<review# 1267,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/16/2011,5/29/2011,19,116,6,12,7>I first fell in love with Hawaiian culture the first time I saw the Barefoot Hawaiian dancers perform at the Tiki Terrace restaurant.  I was so impressed with the dancing and the colorful costumes that I looked at their website and found they offered dancing classes, plus the classes were very affordable.  The school is located in Des Plaines and have two Dance Studios. They also have a Hawaiian store that sell an extensive collection of Hawaiian shirts and dresses; as well as all things Polynesian.  The classes are separated by Women's, Men's, and Children's dance classes, and they also offer Ukalele and Polynesian drum classes; as well as Fire knife Dancing for men.Shortly after seeing the Barefoot Hawaiian dancers perform at Tiki Terrace, I enrolled in their  Kane (men's class) Dance class every Monday night.  The owner and instructor Gwen Keneddy was very nice and patient and really knew her Polynesian culture.  The classes were taught in a fun and safe environment, and I learned allot of the dances in a short amount of time.  After a few weeks of taking classes, I was invited to perform with the Barefoot Hawaiian dancers at local outdoor events and parades, while pretending to be a Hawaiian native. Lol.  The school provided the materials to make the Polynesian costumes, and we paid and assembled the costumes ourselves with help from the more experienced older girls (or the Hula Nazis, as they were nicknamed). I have been with this Dance troop a little under two years before I decided to retire from dancing, but overall, I enjoyed this part of my life.  I will never forget the people I met and befriended during my time with Barefoot Hawaiian; it was like joining a member of a large Hawaiian family and Gwen was our mother.  If you have an appreciation of Polynesian culture; I suggest you enroll in their dance, Ukalele or drum classes. You will come out with a more appreciation of Polynesian culture, and walk away with a new family.The classes are held one day a week, during the evening, and a normal semester is 8 weeks and only $10 per class.

You place your order as you first walk in and are given a number to display at your table-top. The food runners bring you the piping hot orders straight to your table. It did not disappoint- cooked to perfection (medium), just enough spice, cheese and other condiments, and the pretzel roll was salty, sweet and soft and chewy. I was in burger heaven. The fries on the other hand were a little too al dente for my liking. Kristina and I split a red velvet gelato cup. OMG I practically devoured the stuff. It was insanely rich and creamy. I can't wait to go back and try other flavors. I hear so many wonderful things about their breakfast, so I definitely need to go back again to try that part of the menu. Labriola is a great pick for delicious, high-quality bakery noshes at affordable prices.

This is only take-out. No seats or tables, save for a bench inside if you're waiting for your order. I've learned that calling ahead to pick up is the way to go and they are always spot on for the wait time. When they say 20 minutes, it's ready in 20 minutes. This is the first time I've had Broasted chicken and I am now a fan. The chicken pieces are large, have a nice crispy coating and stay juicy and tender after cooking. The menu gives you a nice array of combos, sides, dinner packages. The ribs are OK, nice tangy sauce, although the meat is not "fall off the bone" like I prefer. The fried shrimp are good--nice plump shrimp, served with cocktail sauce. The fries are probably the loser in the bunch. Crinkle cut fries that just seem a little soggy every time we order take-out. If we need some starch, we opt for the broasted loaded potatoes instead--it comes heavy with cheddar cheese and sprinkled with bacon--it really is a delicious meal in itself! They don't sell beverages, but if you're making a run for the chicken, there's a liquor store a few doors down where you can pick up soda or beer, wine...whatever goes best with the chicken! Friendly and courteous service from phone call to pick-up.

Typical classy Italian look, white tablecloth tables, Italian music. There's a large dining area as well as a separate bar area on the opposite side of the restaurant. The bar area had a band come in to perform around 8:00 pm which was alright for me but might have annoyed some of the other customers trying to dine peacefully.They forgot to bring us bread in the beginning and we didn't get any until midway through the meal, and my brother had to ask for it; upsetting, but we dealt with it. We ordered the calamari fritti (fried octopus) and the vongole cotto (baked clams) for antipasti (appetizers). Both dishes came very small in portion size compared to what I'm used to for Italian meals, both at home and at Italian restaurants that I frequent. There were a dozen baked clams but each one was literally the size of my thumbnail. We could have eaten an order each. Same for the calamari which was really only enough to feed one normal person; but with three grown Italian men, we were left starving after the appetizers. Though, I will say, it all tasted great.For dinner, my brother ordered the linugine with broccoli and shrimp, my dad ordered the linguine al olio con gli spinaci (oil with spinach), and I ordered the tortellini paesano which was tortellini with prosciutto, mushrooms, and peas, in an alfredo sauce, and I had them add Italian sausage which went really well with the dish. They pasta came in massive bowls that definitely madeup for the small appetizers. The prosciutto and mushrooms that were cooked with the sauce in my dish really made the entire dish and I loved every bite of it. I heard no complaints from my family and they thoroughly enjoyed their meals as well. I was the only one capable of finishing every bite, so that goes to show you the large portion sizes of the main dishes.The service was fair. The waitress didn't come by much, but when she did she made great conversation (mostly about Italy) that kept my family content.I had the tiramisu for dessert and it was great as well. Very large piece of tiramisu, good enough for 2 or 3 people for dessert. Very rich, very good.The bill was pretty pricey, pricier than I expected, but then again it's Oak Brook, so I'm not TOO surprised.I'll be coming back here soon for another meal.

Sure it bothers me that that wasn't a complete sentence, and now my temperamental mind will not be balanced until harmony is sought. Remedies? I'll always have the assurance of a weekly grammar Nazi thread, but when trazodone withdrawals have left me with nothing but an abundance of energy, less time is spent staring at computers and more is spent outside interacting with the two legged masses. What I found on this humanitarian voyage: a restaurant that prides itself on homemade original burgers holds its veggie burgers to the same standards. Harmony was sought and achieved at Tom and Eddie's as countless patrons, veggies and meaties alike, sat across from one another without arrogant remarks toward the others life choices. Well, I didn't go table to table eavesdropping, but it's safe to say that after eating their veggie burgers, we might have converted some die hard animal predators. The edadame burger, quite aptly titles Yin and Yang, is the perfect burger consistency. Boca burgers, don't even try to compete. Normally, I'm suicide-sensitive, but boca, if you're listening, you really are worthless and have nothing to live for. Back to positivity and the worthy of living, Tom and Eddie's fries are just perfect. They're lightly salted, crunchy on the outside and feel just like a potato should on the inside.Lots of the old trusted Yelpers have suggested perusing the menu before entering the restaurant. The setup of this burger joint sort of like Panera except that your food is delivered to your table. As with most things that pose problems in my life, I avoid them, so takeout it was. Now I don't feel guilty for tipping or not tipping.
<review# 1278,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/6/2011,5/18/2011,284,80,3,4,1>When you think of a zoo, I'm certain the first thought is about caged wild animals, and maybe the fauna on display too! Our favorites (in no particular order) are the new bear habitat and the bison, which never seem to move very often. There is an an enormous primate house that guides you through monkeys and apes of South America, Asia, and Africa. Sometimes, finding them in their hiding places is half the fun. Don't forget there's a hippo wandering about as well! The dolphin show is always a treat, yet many people overlook it because they don't schedule their time very well.No trip is complete without playing in the Hamill Family Zoo, where there is always newly-sanitized toys, a small animal to pet (held by a zoo employee for your safety), little caves to explore, and usually some form of craft projects. My daughter made a spider out of a yougurt cup and pipe cleaners.If there's time and interest, a ride on the wooden carousel is a must.Brookfield Zoo is more of an outdoor venue for anything that strikes our fancy than strictly a zoo.

The restaurant is clean and quiet, and I hear they have a really fun karaoke room in the back - I didn't see it but my friends seemed to think it was pretty sweet. Totally cant wait to go back here again and try everything else on the menu.

<review# 1284,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/30/2010,5/12/2011,92,360,3,7,3>It's hard to go wrong with the meat-ad-infinitum concept, but although Chama Gaucha wasn't the first to get there, the restaurant does execute the concept very, very well.What little food I had at the salad bar was quite good; a wide variety of vegetables, cheeses and salads. The marinated mushrooms in particular were good, and the giant block of Parmagiano Reggiano at the head of the line were particularly nice touches.There was also a selection of dried hams that tasted pretty close to Iberian ham. I have no idea how Brazilian it actually was, but it was good. That said, you should save your appetite for the main course.The main course consists of at least 10 selections of meat (2 chicken, 2 lamb, 1-2 pork, 5-6 beef), most cooked perfectly and whisked to your table by eager servers with knives and skewers at hand.In spite of the frenzied nature of this type of dining experience, you actually have control of the pace of your meal. This is because of the "I want / don't want meat card" at the table at the beginning of the meal, and also because the portion sizes of each piece of meat are appropriate (1-2 oz. per piece, tops.)The serving team also takes requests, and so were able to send my requested piece of meat to my table in a reasonable time. The highlights of the meat part of the meal were: 1.) the Costela, a well marbled, tender AND flavorful (but apparently underappreciated) cut of beef rib, 2.) the bottom sirloin (Fraldinha), crusted in sea salt but with tremendous flavor even without it, and 3.) both lamb cuts (the chop and the leg), which provided a good diversion in flavor and texture.Most of the rest of the cuts were just all right to my taste buds, particularly the parmesan crusted pork.With the meal came sides, including a really crispy parmesan-crusted polenta that was excellent, decent mashed potatoes and fried plantain (my personal throwback dish--I hadn't eaten plantain in forever before this). Of course we had to have dessert, so our table shared a creme brulee and papaya cream topped with cassis. The creme brulee was as good as you should expect from creme brulee, but I liked the flavor of the papaya more.For a place every bit as good as Fogo de Chao without having to drive downtown, Chama Gaucha hit the spot for me.

Well, I will say that I was pleasantly surprised at our meals.  People in my department are notorious for loving really good foods.  We have food days several times a year and we LOVE to eat.   People mostly liked their meals, and they were filling.  For myself, salmon was cooked perfect.  I did enjoy the cedar flavor (salmon was cooked on the cedar plank and presented that way - see the pic).  It also came with asparagus, assorted veggies and a few potatoes.  Ofcourse, to meet the calorie requirement, my food was not heavily seasoned.  At the same time, the fish was cooked so perfectly, I didn't mind.  I actually enjoyed eating healthier for a change.  Overall, I enjoyed my meal but didn't feel I was entering the food coma stage. Ofcourse, the waiter presented us with a desert assortment that resembled a centerpeice.  Again, presentation was key, but the deserts themselves were each in a shot glass.  Like mentioned, it was super smart marketing in presenting a spoon in front of each person dining.  I mean how could you say no right?  A small portion of desert after eating a healthy meal??? OK so I had the java chip (Not sure what the full name was).  I'm not a huge desert person, but that one small portion was just enough for me and it was pretty satisfying. Overall, I'd go back as I've started to eat healthier.  Expect to pay 8-20 dollars depending on what you order (we had the lunch menu).  Overall, nice decor.  Great service.  A nice change of pace and pleasant surprise.

<review# 1291,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/22/2010,5/5/2011,255,326,4,7,3>We bought some plants from Pesche's in the spring, planted them, and come summertime, they aren't dead. Woohoo! Some of this might be because we followed instructions when planting and have good soil, but even with those measures taken, if you buy an unhealthy plant, it will die no matter how well you care for it. Also, we have a reputation around here for killing plants, so I am now convinced that Pesche's sells only healthy, hardy plants to its customers.Unfortunately, there's a lot of emphasis on and promotion of non-native, invasive plant species, just like at most garden centers around here. I understand the "tropical" department is really meant to be houseplants, but there were plants like Japanese Barberry that are meant to grow outside but are invasive and dangerous to grow in your yard, as they'll likely spread to other areas and crowd out native plants. They do also sell non-invasive alternatives to these plants--for example, Ninebark is similar--but I haven't seen employees actively promoting these better alternatives. In fact, there are signs encouraging people who want to attract hummingbirds and butterflies to purchase flowers from a list Pesche's has devised, and on that list are several invasive flowers alongside native species. I understand that there's a demand for these dangerous plants, but I feel like if garden centers actively promoted local species (and after talking with the staff when planning our own flowerbed, we know they are knowledgeable enough to do this), the demand for exotic invasive plants would decrease.Aside from that, Pesche's is a great place with a lot of history and a lot of inventory. Coyote problems? You can purchase humanely-harvested coyote urine to scare off the furry critters from a rack right underneath a picture of JFK taken when he was in the area for a parade. Need a trellis? There are many to choose from, and while you browse you can wonder if a German prisoner of war stood where you're standing during WWII , because down River Road a bit there once existed a prison camp who used Pesche's for their work program. (That's right, if you lived in Des Plaines in the 1940's and had flowers delivered to you, the delivery man may have been a Nazi spy.) Do you need window decals to decrease bird strikes? You can buy them here while contemplating the hard work and dedication that goes into handing a business like this down from generation to generation.This place gets crazy busy at certain times, and you'll see police directing traffic in and out of the parking lot. My advice? Stay away on those days. Somebody is likely to tackle you in a greenhouse over the last petunia tray on Mother's Day. You can come back next weekend; there will be more. In fact, if they don't have what you want, you can ask in person or call to find out when what you need will be in stock. We, for example, showed up two weeks before they put out their coneflower sproutings, and they told us exactly when to come back to get some.Overall, I'd like to give Pesche's five stars because I love family-owned businesses with excellent service and great inventory, but I don't think I can as long as they're encouraging people to buy plants that destroy local ecosystems and/or require excessive chemical fertilization and watering to survive in Illinois. Signs or pamphlets promoting something like xeriscaping instead could drum up just as much business without imperiling the environment.
<review# 1292,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/24/2011,5/4/2011,28,222,5,3,4>I've eaten in enough airports to cringe at the thought of it.  Occasionally I'll find a little gem but this is above and beyond.  Typical Bayless quality and taste.  I took an early cab to the airport to make sure I had at least 30 minutes to grab a breakfast torta before heading to the tunnel to C.Walked right up to the counter, feeling sorry for all the people in the long queue next door at McDonalds.  I opted for the Eggs & Rajas and 10 minute wait for my food was probably less time then the McD's line.The bread is just as good as Xoco's and the peppers were great.  I'll fly United more often now just so I can eat here.As others have mentioned it 's located next to gate B11 in Terminal 1, just to the right of the tunnel to Concourse C.(BTW Yelp managed to completely mess up many of the reviews for both Tortas Frontera lbusiness listings at ORD, deleting my first review for the Terminal 3 location and then moving my original Terminal 1 location review to this business listing.  After 3 emails to support I gave up.  But I've eaten at both locations multiple times and they are both top-notch, so whether you are flying United or American you are covered for tasty Baylessness for breakfast, lunch, or dinner.)So here is the original review for THIS location:Terminal 1 no longer has a lock on the best food in the 60666 area code! <review# 1295,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/11/2010,5/1/2011,65,419,,6,2>Just.  Wow.  Some friends had a Groupon for Zenwich so we decided to tag along.  From the outside, it doesn't look like much - this is a book that should not be judged by the cover.The service was extremely friendly even though we  came in about 10 minutes before closing.  A lot of places will rush you out - not here.  We were told to take our time - the guy working the counter (owner?) said he was glad we were there to enjoy the food.  Us, too!  I ordered the katsu pork sandwich and it was amazing.  The pork was perfectly cooked and crispy and the sauce...  Best sauce on a katsu anything that I've ever had before.  Just right spices and the slaw on top added to the crunch.  It was so good, I almost wished there was no end too it but at the same time it was very  much a "get in my belly!" experience.I also tried my husband's beef curry sandwich, which was like a tender pot roast with Japanese curry sauce - also really, really good, and our friends had the bulgogi and the mu ping sandwiches and they were both quite excellent.They were out of a couple items because it had apparently been a very busy day - that included the ciabatta bread that some of the sandwiches come on.  Definitely not a bad thing!We'll definitely be making another trip back to Zenwich - I can't think of anything like it in the area and good service along with good food is unbeatable!
<review# 1296,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/24/2010,4/30/2011,288,304,6,7,5>Ok, it is known by many that I am a sucker for an "old person restaurant". I mean, c'mon....most likely creamy soup will be on the menu and you will always walk outta there with the feeling that youth is on your side. What's not to like about THAT?I've dined at the Rosewood MANY  times....our holiday parties are held here, most of our committee meetings are held here and I've lunched here often. You know what? It never disappoints. The Rosewood has offered up some solid food each and every time I've been here. For our work dinners we usually do the appetizer platters. Jimmy hooks our group up with plates of calamari, shrimp cocktail and brushetta. You can't really go wrong with any of these. Steaks are plentiful at our table and in some cases I've never seen such large pieces of meat...oh my! For lunch....we are a fans of the chopped salad and the crab cake sandwich. The california chicken club sandwich is also another solid choice. My only (slight) criticism is that the fries are those "coated" fries...you know what I'm talking about. Remember when BK "changed" their fries? Now they have this sort of "coating" on them. If you are a french fry connoisseur like me, you know what I'm talking about. ANYHOW, Rosewood's fries are like that. I'm not a huge fan. Last but not least - desserts. The apple purse. Dear GAWD....that apple purse is delicious. We ALWAYS have this at our holiday parties and every employee who orders it (and there are a lot of us) look forward to it.  Baked apples are tucked into a golden flaky pastry purse and served with a side of cinnamon ice cream. Y-U-M. For birthday's, Jimmy will bring ya HUGE whompin piece of white chocolate mousse cake with raspberry sauce. I'm not a huge cake person but THIS cake is delightful. The interior is nice and there is a bar area. The service has always been great and the food is pretty affordable. Definitly one of the better dining options in the Rosemont/DesPlaines area.
<review# 1297,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/23/2010,4/29/2011,19,108,1,5,3>HONEST. COURTEOUS. TIMELY.  EVERYTHING I'VE ALWAYS WANTED AND NEVER EXPERIENCED WHEN HAVING WORK DONE ON MY CAR. PERSONALIZED SERVICE TAILORED TO MY NEEDS!!!Owner Mark Nofsinger really has the right idea about how to treat people.  He had a conversation with me, he explained things clearly and in terms I could understand.  He was extremely polite and helpful, and even funny!  The staff: very polite, helpful, and approachable with my specific questions.  From the mechanic (I believe his name was Mike) who did the estimate, test drove, and worked on my car (he, as well, explained things well and in a manner that I could clearly understand), to the guys that gave me a ride somewhere and back while my car was worked on, were all super nice and professional. The level of communication was perfect.  At all times, I was aware of what I did and did not need, and how much everything would cost.  There was no guessing game, no sales push for things I really didn't need. You know, being a woman, I sometimes believe that mechanics gamble on the fact that I don't know much about cars, and they could probably get away with charging me for things that I don't need.  It's really sad when someone tries to take advantage of you, but it happens.  As it did to me.  You see, I brought my car into a Midas shop first.  and they told me I needed things I didn't need.  The only way I could even sense it, was by the delivery of this information-  the guy sounded like he was lying (changed the subject when I asked a question, etc.).  So I got a second opinion. (of course, I Yelped mechanics in my area to find someone who had good reviews! Nofsinger's had all 5 star reviews...and I agree with that, and they're receiving 5 stars from me as well).  Anyways, Midas quoted me a price for "necessary" work for $1,100.  At Nofsinger's, I was told by the mechanic, "I'm not going to sell you anything you don't need".  He inspected the car, and determined I needed tie rod ends and an alignment.  I was experiencing some loud rotational noise, and Mark Nofsinger suggested rotating my tires to see if that would aide in noise reduction.  It did significantly.  In the end, I only paid $248 dollars, they let me know what things might need work on in the future (but were okay for now), and thanked me for my business.  NOW THAT'S WHAT I CALL CUSTOMER SERVICE. I CAN'T WAIT TO TELL EVERYONE I KNOW ABOUT MY NEW MECHANIC.

<review# 1304,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/13/2010,4/22/2011,18,32,3,8,3>I can't believe I'm just now finding out about this place.  But now that I have, let me just say...chocolate heaven.  I called on a day when they were closed -- but the shop owner had forwarded the line to her cell phone and indicated she'd meet me at the shop if I wanted to come in.  I'll be honest, I initially took that as a really bad sign -- just wasn't sure how  good they could be if they were that (what I assumed to be) desperate for business.  Nevertheless, an hour later I walked into the shop (you'll notice I use the word 'shop' versus 'store' -- this place is TINY so it just seems fitting) and it was at that point that I knew my relationship with downtown Forest Park would never be the same.  Bought a bunch of truffles so intricately designed you almost hate to eat them...until you do, at which point you decide that, work of art or not, they just taste too sinfully delicious to not devour them.  Since it was my first time in, she gave me a free sample of their signature French cremes...something I've since found myself dreaming about.  So good in fact, that I asked for four to take home and the shop owner, bless her chocolate-covered heart, gave me all four at no charge!  This place is pretty much one of the best hidden gems ever.  I can't wait to go back.
<review# 1305,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/8/2010,4/21/2011,55,299,3,4,3>FYI: This is not a restaurant that you can dine in. It's merely TAKE OUT Thai/Chinese food. This place is pretty awesome! So far, I've ordered Pad Thai, Panang Curry, and General Tso' Chicken. I'm not positive, but I think the owners are Thai, which is a very good sign, if they're selling Thai food! COST: The prices here are very reasonable for most all their dishes. It's relatively cheap - it probably helps because they are not a restaurant. I have a feeling that they're knocking off $1-2 their dishes because it's take out food (as compared to a nice, fancy sit-down restaurant). Not only are their prices reasonable, but they are also pretty generous with their portions. It's all very reasonable...AMBIANCE: It's like a hole-in-the-wall. Once you walk into the store, you're in front of their counter and you can see their kitchen, where they're cooking all the food. It's really nothing fancy or glamorous, but that really does NOT matter! (as long as it is not dirty) Every time I'm there, the lady/person cooking is always washing the wok and the stove area with water ... between meals and all... so it was good to see. She was very thorough because she kept cleaning and cleaning (or so I thought). FOOD: The Pad Thai and the Panang Curry was delicious! I can't give you any details because it's been awhile, but I remember thinking that I will definitely order from here again. The General Tso's was good, but not a "WOW" meal, ya know? It was just .... fine. Side Note: I went twice within the past couple of months. They must have had their children there. They were really cute helping out the 'rents with orders, etc. I asked the little girl what her favorite dish was out of the whole restaurant, and she chose Pad Thai. The little boy said his was the General Tso' (i think), which was why I ordered that the last time. Since they or their parents or whoever owns it, I figure they can eat anything and everything on the menu and know what's best.... it won't hurt to ask them!CONCLUSION: I will go back to this place again..and again.. and again... Just gotta let time pass in between because Thai/Chinese food is "heavy"...!!!
<review# 1306,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/4/2010,4/20/2011,51,246,5,8,3>We didn't really do our research with Vie. We heard it was good, yelpers were fans, and hey, the chef won Iron Chef. Deal was on. Hubby surprised me with a "Let's celebrate the weekend" reservation to Vie and off we went to our adventure to...Western Springs. It's near the Metra station in a nondescript building. Parking is street or in a lot across from the building. We went in, was seated immediately, and was given a good few minutes to settle in with our menus. Our waitress was very supportive with our endless questions and wavering between..tasting menu or to not tasting menu tonight? She even went into the kitchen to check how our preferences worked with the tasting menu that the chef had planned. After all that, we decided to just order on our own. amuse bouche: chilled shot of pureed melon with a squirt of jalapeno gelee-great opener, refreshing with a kick of spice at the back of the throat. I do prefer salty openers, but this was playful and fun.appetizer: pork shoulder-nice blend of shredded pork/carmelized onions/arugula/grapes..nothing uber special, but it was simple and was a great appetizer, flavors were well defined and melded well together.Salads-heirloom tomatoes with fried curds and watermelon salad. Both were very pleasant. The tomatoes were a good mix of green, pink and red, so you could go from tart to sweet and pair it with the salty curds. That being said, the curds were a bit salty. The watermelon salad was brilliant: it really exemplified what I liked about Vie...the ingredients and flavors are allowed to be independent and raw (eg not candied, foamed, etc etc). The watermelon was thinly sliced and then the carrots formed a pile on them, with the proscuitto layered on top of that. Pecorino and almonds were sprinkled about, small enough to not overpower, but large enough that you can figure out that the 'perfect" bite, would include all of the above. And when you did, you got the juice of the melon, salt from the cured meat,sweetness of the carrots,  texture from the nutty cheese, and crunch of the almond. It works in your mouth in a decisive manner...and that what is I appreciate about this place. But more on that later.Entrees: ribeye and chicken two way. Ribeye was cooked perfectly, and the sides followed suit. The meat was flavorful, juicy and the potatoes rounded out the comfort dinner plate. The chicken came fried and also crab cake like. The fried chicken was juicy and spiced well, very delish. The crab cake like chicken was shredded chicken that was formed into a square patty and then pan fried...parts of it tasted like pork. Both went well with the creamed corn, but the corn was a tad too sweet and was polar with the salty chicken. Dessert: butter cake with blueberries, and a scoop each of lemon/blueberry sorbet, triple vanilla ice cream and smore ice cream. The butter cake (man, how can you go wrong with those two words together?), was delightfully rich...all in all like a dissectted buttery blueberry tart with ice cream. Without the butter cake, it would just be blueberry mush. ;-) Went well with house blend of coffee. The sorbet was much more blueberry than lemon, almost to the point where I wondered if the lem-on was lem-off the slurry. The sorbet ended up being gelatinous and not icy enough. Lucky for them I love blueberry, but it really was a sloppy sorbet. The smore ice cream was not overly chocolaty and the marshmellows made just the right amount of appearances. Winner here: the vanilla--extremely full and heavy cream flavor, and if  you like the bean-y vanilla...it's in there too. Service was spot on that Friday night: water never went less than half full, dirty utensils were quickly swiped away, plates magically disappeared the minute I finished, our waitress was attentive but gave us our space, and when was the last time someone called me miss or mademoiselle? With a smile?The five stars was for the whole package, where the ingredients are local and the food is decisive and honest, no tricks or camouflage to make them work. The food just works. Another plus: city dining without the city lookers...sometimes I just want a place to go and get good food, no hassle with onlookers, seen to be seen, stared down by the waitstaff because, hey, we don't order alcohol.  Our waitress even found a way to make our check LESS, reminding us of the dine around deal. Real food, real people..done really well. That is why we are going to come back...;-).

<review# 1309,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/26/2010,4/17/2011,4,63,4,2,3>It is difficult to rate Mexican these days, as one might imagine.  The little mom and pop places have been popping up every other block so I kind of gave up trying them all.  Besides, I'm not coming home at 4am anymore.  I'm in bed at a decent hour and, well, sober.  BUT.... when on the occasion when I am indeed suffering from 'Irish Arthritis' (that's where you get stiff in a different joint every night, for those of you who don't know) I usually focus on late-night Mex joints to eat. Admittedly, Hacienda Cocula is close to home, still they have a full menu and the original is in the HOOD in the city near Pilsen.  I'm not too crazy about their burritos. I'll reserve that for El Farol, hands down.  But, Hacienda does well with their upper price meals. The steak dishes are excellent, and reasonable. Salsa is another indicator for me if I choose to gravitate to a place and Hacienda Cocula has a nice, spicey saucey salsa with great chips.  They also make a stellar Guac. A sit down place, clean, but somewhat lacking in warmth because, I think, the lights are a tad too bright at night (hurts the Irish Arthritic eyes,  dontcha know), and the constant blaring of the two televisions broadcasting Telemundo.  Lunch time is mostly Guerro clientelle, and I like to catch the news (in English, por favor) but I feel funny asking the staff to change to Linda Yu. So, I settle for Telemundo, and occasionally will ask for interpretation from the waitress as to why someone is walking with a burro through a bedroom (on telemundo, not hacienda).   I do ask them to turn the volume down, occasionally. The TV is definitely annoying.  But, I digress.  The food is good, with a good presentation.  The service is prompt and excellent.  For the LaGrange area I think it is a good introduction into the Mexican cuisine and culture for the locals without scaring them too, too much.  Pilgrim Americans when venturing out of their comfort zones with ethnic cuisine certainly like to feel that an establishment is clean and sanitary as soon as they walk in; a fine line in this arena with Pilgrims. But I think they will find their sensory perceptions to be satisfied at Hacienda Cocula.  Cafe' Salsa can wait. Bring the family.

<review# 1313,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/14/2011,4/13/2011,116,200,5,6,4>Been meaning to try Just Kabobs for a few weeks now, didn't get a chance until tonight but the wait was well worth it!I welcome anything that isn't yet another burrito joint or chain restaurant in this corner of the suburbs so I was very happy to see El Pollo Loco replaced by this Greek place. Never liked that chicken joint anyway and there are plenty of bad memories associated with it so I'm glad it's gone. I swung by this evening and picked up an order of their skordalia ($2.75, goooood), a beef kabob plate ($5.99 great) and some rice pudding ($1.75 decent). Their skordalia is very good. Cold pureed potatoes with onions and garlic served with pita to scoop it up with, garnished with kalamata olives. Not everyone was a fan but having had it at Pick Me Up before this stands up as just as good and local! So bully ho for skordalia. I think kabobs and I picture tough cubes of leather that I have to chew for 5 minutes before reluctantly swallowing. This was anything but. Tender, moist and so, so flavorful. I got two skewers served over delicious pilaf with a pair of roasted potatoes. A chunky salad accompanied it, nothing special there. The main event was definitely that meat. Perfectly seasoned and cooked, delicious. The rice pudding? Standard issue, nothing to write home about but I'm a big fan of this place. Service was very friendly and quick, I'll definitely return.

<review# 1316,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/15/2011,4/10/2011,91,73,1,7,5>Chocolate, Chocolate, and MORE Chocolate!When Anna Shea's Chocolates and Lounge opened up in South Barrington, I was totally drawn in by the idea of a "chocolate LOUNGE".  I love chocolate! This quaint, cute chocolate shop was originally located in Tarrytown, New York and owned by Anna Shea.  I am thankful that she moved it to South Barrington and she had quite a following over there too.Anna studied to be a chocolatier in Finland and her bon bons are like little works of art!   Everytime I go to Anna Shea's (which is as often as I can!) all the new people who come into the chocolate shop are amazed at how cute and artistic their bons bons are.  They have a lot of exotic bon bons that you would not find anywhere else.  For example, they have their "By the Fire" bon bon filled with a Cognac Caramel and their "Cosmopolitan" filled with a Cranberry Vodka Ganache.My favorites are:Jewel of the Nile - Walnut Butter, Black Walnut Liquer and Cinnamon in Milk ChocolateKrystle's Banana Foster - Banana CaramelHanna Paulina - Coconut GiandujaMon Cheri - Cherry Cordial in Milk ChocolateMy Precious - Cinnamon CaramelScott's Peanut Butter - Peanut Butter & Milk Chocolate (also my husband's favorite!)andHazelnut - Hazelnut GanacheThey routinely put out special bon bons for the holidays like Valentines Day and St. Patrick's Day.If you think that Anna Shea's ONLY about artsy bon bons, then you are WRONG because it is SO MUCH MORE!  They have quite a menu of hot drinks, wines, dessert martinis, and even cheese plates to indulge in.Items of note from their menu are the Chocolate and Wine Pairings where you can get two classic bon-bons of your choice and a glass of wine.  If you prefer the coffee/hot chocolate route, they have items such as Frozen Hot Chocolates, Chocolate Based Chai Tea, and Ultimate Mocha Latte. (Which I totally recommend!)They have other unique chocolate experiences such as a Chocolate Fondue for two and for the little ones, the Princess Tea for Two. As well as an variation of White, Dessert, and Sparkling Wines for those not wanting to go the chocolate overload route. :)If you truly want to dive into the velvet brown lusciousness of chocolate, try their Liquid Truffle Sipping Chocolate.  It is much like the drinking chocolates that are a bit thick and like an EXTREME hot chocolate, but OH SO MUCH BETTER! :)  Try one if you dare!  I dare you!Can you tell I've been here WAY TOO MUCH for my own good?  Heh heh....anyway....They also carry Gourmet Cupcakes from Foiled Cupcakes, which are yummy and Chocolate Covered Strawberries too! YUM!  I'm only done with the chocolate shop area as far as this review goes, but if you step through the double doors into the comfy lounge that Anna Shea's has you will not be disappointed!Anna Shea's is my "go to" place for a Girls Night Out after dinner.  We sit, we consume yummy chocolates and just chat.  They have two large couch areas, which can be reserved for special occassions. (Valentines Day, Anniversary, or Date Night Out) When the weather is warm, they have outdoor seating, if you prefer to enjoy the nice weather day or night.  Their staff is friendly, courteous and accomodating.  You just order and pay at the front and then take a seat and relax as the staff brings your delectible delights right to you.  On CUTE CUTE plates and ADORABLE cups too! :)  I'm all for the cute factor! :) Just a warning though, if you are on a budget, or will like have a fit over a $2.00 bon-bon, then, do not go to Anna Shea's Chocolates.  South Barrington is basically a town that is full of large million dollar mansions and the shops in the Arboretum are "upscale".  It is a bit pricey, but I think it is TOTALLY worth it for that once-in-a-while indulgence or special occasion.  If you want to score brownie points with your girlfriend/wife, take her here, if she loves chocolate...she will love you even more!Anyway, enough gushing about this place, you, yes you there reading my review....get into your car.....drive to Anna Shea's (during business hours of course!) and get yourself some awesome chocolates!You will not be let down and you will think you are in a chocolate paradise!

<review# 1322,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/27/2011,4/3/2011,122,412,3,4,3>This festive Latin American restaurant has become one of our go-tos in the burbs when in the mood for delicious Latin food.The atmosphere is lively and electric, just like a fiesta shoud be.  Great drinks always - they make a mean caiparainha here.  The food is always consistently good.Last night we had ceviche and shared the seared tuna, which came with plaintains and veggies, and it was light and yummy.  That's what I really enjoy about their preparation style - using the lively flavors of citrus, fruits, and spices, they prepare fish and meat simply and allow the tastes to mingle for a succulent meal.  I also dig that they are very vegetarian friendly - they have a fairly extensive vegetarian menu, including a delicious acorn squash stuffed with rice and goat cheese - mmm!  And they list on the back of the vegetarian menu diet restrictions of each entree - very helpful for those with allergies or gluten sensitivities.The best thing about Maya is their gorgeous courtyard patio, complete with firepits, arbors, trees and flora.  I cannot wait till spring to enjoy a night out there - they'll even supply blankets to cozy up under when there is a chill in the air.
<review# 1323,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/17/2011,4/2/2011,294,135,9,8,7>Oh, Prasino, how I love you so. If you were a woman, I'd have my way with you, and would quite possibly be inclined to marry you. Suburbanites do not need to make the trek to Chicago if they wish to dine at a trendy & modern organic restaurant, Prasino in St Charles has got it all, and then some. With clean lines, a chic urban look, just the right lighting to set the mood at night, and a soundtrack made of trendy house music, Prasino creates the perfect atmosphere for dinner with friends or with a date. Modern, trendy, posh, swanky--whatever you want to call it--the stylish look and feel of this place is very appealing, and I like it... A LOT. But enough about how much I like the atmosphere in this place. On to the deliciousness that fills this place! We started off with the Mozzarella Risotto Cakes and The Farm. The risotto cakes had a nice texture and were full of flavor, the tomato sauce that came with them was great compliment to the cakes and not too overpowering. The Farm, a whole wheat flat bread, was like a small cheese pizza that was big on flavor and deliciousness. The feta, goat cheese, and truffle honey came together just perfectly with the golden melted mozzarella that topped it all. I liked it so much I was tempted to order another one! Our starters did not stop our insatiable appetite for deliciousness. We needed to move on to the entree portion of the menu. I ordered the Roasted Half Amish Chicken, my date ordered the Butternut Squash Ravioli. She tried some of mine, I tried some of hers, both were delicious. The chicken was roasted to perfection--full of flavor, golden on the outside, and juicy & tender on the inside. I really liked the roasted beets that the chicken was served on, I think they went well together. The Butternut Squash Ravioli was great too. The Parmesan on it wasn't too overpowering and normally I like sauce with ravioli, but but there was no need for sauce with the sage brown butter that was on it. For dessert she had the chocolate molten lava cake and I had the coffee panna cotta. The molten lava cake was great, as they usually are, but I believe that molten lava cake is passe. I think of it as the quiche of the 2000's and I didn't expect to see it on Prasino's dessert menu. Now, I'm not a big fan of coffee, but I am a HUGE fan of panna cotta, so when I saw that they had coffee panna cotta I just had to have it! The coffee panna cotta was simply divine--it's smooth, creamy, and melts in your mouth. The presentation of the panna cotta was nice too: panna cotta off to one corner of the rectangular plate with a thin chocolate wafer set in the top of it and some walnuts covered in some sweet coating scattered across the rest of the plate and drizzled in a caramel/coffee sauce. It was a dessert for the eyes and foodporn for the tastebuds. I am officially a fan of Prasino in St Charles. It has a great atmosphere, a green approach to operating the restaurant, a delicious menu with plenty of choices that are vegan/vegetarian/gluten-free, and excellent service, all of which could easily earn a solid 10 star rating, but Yelp only allows me to hand out 5 at a time. So, for now, I'll give Prasino the first 5 stars, then I'll give them the other 5 stars when I return for another foodgasm.Holla!!!™

I highly recommend them.Overall, I've never had a bad experience and I haven't been there enough to try everything, but I greatly recommend this place and the price is cheap! You can get an entire meal for under $10!

I feel horrible about saying this, but every interaction I've had with the workers and managers has left me thinking they're just a few fries short of a happy meal. They seem like really sweet, good people, just not the brightest. I would go into detail but then I'd just be a jerk.
