<review# 1337,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/15/2011,3/19/2011,176,176,4,11,8>Though I've been dining here for years, I still think JC's is a nice, family owned Mexican restaurant with great food. A friend of mine raves about their green enchiladas, to which I heartily agree that they are quite good.The owner knows me by name and always greets me with a smile and seats me promptly. She asks me follow up questions on conversations we may have had from previous visits. I've seen her treat other regular customers the same.Recently, after finishing my typical order of green enchiladas with a side of guacamole, I asked the owner where she buys her avocados. When I go grocery shopping, the avocados I find (especially in midwinter) tend to be lacking in flavor, overripe or going bad. I don't have much luck in finding good avocados. But, I was impressed with the quality and flavor in the guacamole at JC's.The owner let me in on her secret to good avocados. She's got it down to a science in determining how solid the avocados are when you first buy them, how long to let them ripen, where to store them, etc. And though she buys from a wholesaler, which I don't have access to, she offered to sell me avocados direct from her restaurant whenever I wanted. And so, I added a few to my tab last time I was there.How's that for service? And I think it all started a few years ago when I stopped in at JC's for the first time. I complimented the owner on her voice when she was softly singing to the Spanish music playing overhead. I've had nothing but good service ever since. See what happens when you're nice to people and expect good things! And though the service may be slow at times, or maybe it's not the perfect Mexican restaurant for everyone, or maybe the shipment of avocados isn't always the best, I still love the fact that it is a family owned restaurant and that I get a genuine sense of welcome whenever I visit. The minor things don't really matter that much when one is treated like a valued customer.
<review# 1338,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/15/2010,3/18/2011,19,116,4,4,5>What can I say, I luv this restaurant.  I have been coming to Tiki Terrace even before they moved to this new location.  The restaurant is bigger and the décor is at a grander scale.  I have to say that I used to dance with the two brothers who own this restaurant.  We were part of a Polynesian Dance Troupe a few years back, so my review may be a bit biased, but I will try to be as honest as I can.  Firstly what I love about this place is the Food.  There is no where in the suburbs and especially in the city where I can find authentic Hawaiian cuisine like this.  Their menu offers a wide variety of island fair.  My Favorite being the "Killer Kalbi, the 10oz Maui Mahi, their Bora Bora Eggrolls and the Kalua Pork with the BBQ sauce.  Secondly, I luv the décor, and considering the brothers did most of the renovations and the carved statues (tikis), I could really appreciate the hard work that went into Making this place feel like you were in Hawaii.  Thirdly, I thoroughly enjoy the Friday and Saturday night Dinner Dance Show.  The dances are very authentic, not your usual Hula dancing, but my friends have commented that the dancers are all white. There no better place in Chicago to take your friends and family if you are looking for that Unique Polynesian dinner show experience.  I picked up my friend from the airport last Friday night from Ohare  (he is from Vancouver) and immediately came here for the dinner and show.  He enjoyed the Polynesian Dance show and learned some things about the different Polynesian dances while we enjoyed our dinner and sipped on our Tiki Drinks.  We didn't have the dessert because we were just way too full, but I have had their dessert before, my most favorite being the Haupia cake.  I don't really care for the Chinaman's Hat dessert.  Just a warning, During the Friday and Saturday night shows, the menu is very limited as they have to deal with a full house.  Also for lunch, they have a $6 lunch menu which is an awesome deal!  My coworkers and I come here once a week for their lunch menu.  At times, the service can be very slow.  I have experienced this on my last visits, especially for lunch. Therefore, I call in my lunch order ahead of time so my coworkers and I don't have to wait too long.

<review# 1342,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/10/2010,3/14/2011,33,144,3,5,5>I enjoy alcohol.  Who doesn't you say?  Well, I assume plenty of people do, but I enjoy it.  I don't drink to get drunk, I don't drink because it's expected of me, I drink because I enjoy what I'm drinking.  So when I look for a liquor store, I don't just want stuff like Bud or Bacardi or Smirnoff.  I want the good stuff.Sal's has tons (certainly literally) of the good stuff.  Sure, there are your 7 foot tall stacks of 24-packs of he cheap stuff, but then there are aisle up isles of craft beers, wines from all over the world, lots of great stuff.  And it's all really well organized, making it really simple to find what you need.  This place isn't as "nice" as Binny's.  It's pretty much a warehouse on the inside and you won't be finding any wine experts to help you pick out the right bottle for you, and the selection isn't quite as massive, but it's got most of what you need at good prices.  Plus, for us at least, it's closer to home since the nearest Binny's is Glen Ellyn, so it's certain the best place for us within a 10 minute drive.As for prices, they seemed to be pretty average on beer, surprisingly cheap on wine (5.99 for a 1.5 L of Barefoot... sure Barefoot is the cheap stuff, but that price is usually what the 750 mLs go for), and a little bit pricey on the hard liquor.  I especially noticed the rum was more than you'll usually see elsewhere.Overall though, I was pleased.  We picked up a 12 pack of Leinie's Summer Shady, nothing super fancy, but it will be a nice summer treat.  If that's what you're looking for, Sal's is a good place to look.

<review# 1350,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/24/2010,3/5/2011,191,452,5,10,7>White Chocolate Grill=white hot!With husband and Groupon in hand, Fridate night was upon us!  After doing some damage at Chicago Premium Outlets in Aurora, we cruised over to WCG to check it out since we'd heard so many good reviews from friends.  Reservations on the weekends are definitely a must (unless you don't mind eating before 5pm or after 9pm).  We were promptly seated, even though we arrive about 10 minutes early, in a comfy oversized leather booth.  Our waitress was super friendly and never left us wanting.  Coke products, definitely a plus.  I ordered the white chocolate martini ($9), basically a chocolate martini that's lighter in color-not much difference in taste.  I do love having it served in a chilled martini glass.  Honestly, I wasn't expecting much from WCG in terms of food.  Pleasant surprise, they've got great sammies!  My husband ordered a steak sandwich.  Though he wasn't asked how he wanted it prepared, it came out a tender medium with thick slabs of steak and gooey Monterey Jack cheese on a French baguette.  I couldn't keep my hands of my husband's side of skinny fresh-cut fries! It was love at first bite with my blackened fish sandwich.  The grilled organic white fish tasted fresh and had a great spicy bite!  I enjoyed the fact that they loaded on the lettuce and tomato too!For once, we saved room for dessert (thanks to WCG for listing their desserts first on the menu as a gentle reminder).  We decided on the French White Chocolate Bread Pudding ($7.59).  I'm not typically a fan of bread pudding (don't like mushy desserts), but this bread pudding had great hold and buttery, cinnamon flavor (almost as if they used croissants!).  The generous dollop of whipped cream really added to the layers of sweetness without giving us a total sugar rush.  All their desserts are portioned for two, but we still had to take a doggy bag home.  I'll definitely be returning soon.  Happy hours are offered both during weekdays (2pm-7pm) and weekends (2pm-5pm) at the bar or patio.  They also offer a prix fixe "Date Night" menu for $28.99 per person that includes an appetizer to share, 2 salads, 2 entrees, and a dessert to share.

<review# 1352,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/12/2011,3/3/2011,252,423,3,7,5>I'll admit it took hubby and I quite some time to try Gold Class Cinemas.  We love movies and the price did put me a off a little.  I am pleased to report, however, once you go Gold Class watching a movie in a regular theater is slumming it.  I am hooked!If you plan on going here take some time beforehand to sign up as a member on their website.  It's completely free and as a member you get discounts on your tickets ($2.50 off per ticket) every day off the week.  Also as a member on Tuesdays they have $3 glasses of wine and beer plus discounted select food items.  With our member discount our two tickets were $40.  Considering you are going to pay $10-$14 at a regular theater now it's not much more to spring for the "Gold Class" experience.I love the ambience of the place; it's more like you are going to a chic lounge than the movies.  Lots of comfy chairs, couches and tables to use while you peruse the menu.  There are a couple of big fireplaces at either end - a welcome treat on those freezing Chicago nights.  The restrooms were spotless and we were there on a busy Saturday night.  While their menu is a bit limited and some items seem pricey, everything we tried was absolutely delicious and top-notch quality - plus they quantity of the food was good as well!  They also add a few seasonal additions for drinks and appetizers to the menu which changes throughout the year.  Now my husband and I just couldn't decide so we decided to try 3 appetizers and a dessert, in addition to his beer and my two cocktails.  The price for all the food and drinks including the 20% tip we left was $97.  Yes, that is steep for movie fare but as I said, all was very good both in quality and quantity.  In the future I would only split 2 appetizers and maybe a dessert as we were quite full when we left.  They also come around and offer free little bags of popcorn and if you don't already have a cocktail they offer a complimentary soda-fountain beverage.From the seasonal Winter menu I tried the Ginger Collins cocktail - absolute yum - I had two! - and the Bacon Wrapped Shrimp which also came with bacon wrapped water chestnuts and bacon stuffed olives.  OMG -everything is better with bacon!  From the regular menu we also tried the Spinach and Artichoke Croquettes (my favorite....wonderful cheesy & creamy fried goodness) with marinara for dipping and the Calamari "Steak" - big and wonderful strips of calamari fried in tempura with a wonderful wasabi-mayonaisse dipping sauce.  All of it was scrumptious!For dessert, yes we just had to try dessert, we had the Cinnamon Dusted Cheesecake Flautas with Raspberry Sauce - also from the Winter menu.  While these were quite yummy, the raspberry sauce was more of a drizzle on the plate - not nearly enough.  It would be better if in addition to the lovely presentation with the sauce drizzled they have a little cup of it for dipping the flautas in.  Each item we ordered came out of the kitchen super-quick and was delivered discreetly to our table in the theatre.  If you need another drink or any other items you simply press a button on your table and a server comes over within a few minutes.The chairs were also oh-so-comfortable and you can recline them to whatever degree you like.  An arm of each chair opens up to store your coat and/or purse in.  They have blankets and pillows available upon request for the ultimate snuggly experience.  I've read in other reviews to order your tickets ahead so you get a good seat - IMO there are truly no bad seats here!  Each theater only has like 24 seats and the front row is 25 feet from the screen, certainly not up too close for the average person.  Even the seats in the side rows are very good.  I would only recommend ordering your tickets ahead online just to make sure they don't sell out.  We will definitely be coming back regularly.  If you want to save some money skip the food and cocktails - it is still well worth the experience.
<review# 1353,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/12/2011,3/2/2011,73,255,1,6,5>If it's possible to fall in love with a restaurant at 7 years old, my son has found his first true love, and we've found our "regular" Chinese food place. The food is great. Seasoned well, and comes out fast. The price is reasonable for the amount of food. They have Kirin, which I loved. And the atmosphere isn't that red, gaudy BS that you see at other Chinese restaurants. Our "test dish" for Chinese places is Orange Chicken. The orange chicken here literally tastes like you are eating oranges with your chicken. And I wasn't hungry 40 minutes later. Like Japanese food? Well you're in luck because they have that as well. The Sushi bar is great. The service the first time we went was a little iffy, but the 2nd time was superb. The owner is there often and asks how things are. They also have a kids menu. Bonus.
<review# 1354,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/28/2011,3/1/2011,58,186,5,15,8>OK, it's Friday night... Wife and I are in the mood for something Asian....We don't feel like going too far....Since we needed to make a run to Walgreens, I suggest we try Crazy Buffet since it's next door.  I pass by this place a hundred times on the way to work.  This area usually seems sort of dead, but I noticed the lot was pretty full.  Since I'm a bit skeptical and usually have bad experiences at Buffets, I decide that this is the perfect time to pull out my phone and check my handy dandy Yelp app!OK, this place got pretty good reviews.  Ok fine, let's do it.  Upon entering, I'm actually surprised at the size of this place.  For some reason, from the outside, you wouldn't picture this place being so big.  Inside, it was very full of customers.  We were promptly greeted, seated and surprised that their staff actually checked up on us regularly at an Asian establishment.  (You're downright neglected in some Asian restuarants...)  My soda, tea and napkins never ran out.  Plates promptly replaced with clean ones as we were eating crab legs.  Pretty good service so far.  I'm still skeptical of the food being most Asian Buffets suck.  I give it a chance based on the Yelp reviews.  I check out the stir fry bar, sushi area, seafood areas, main course areas and desert areas.  They have a lot of stuff!I must say, I actually like this buffet and I'm not a buffet person.  Why?  Well, this place is very cheap.  15 bucks?  Ok, so not every dish is perfect.  The crab rangoon was sort of soggy.  Some dishes aren't nearly as authentic as other Asian places, but overall, there was a lot of tasty dishes and the good far outweigh the bad.  There's a lot of variety here.  There is something for everyone.  If you want something else, go to the stir fry bar.  You can dish up your own meat including chicken, scallops, beef, pork, shrimp, veggies, noodle type, etc. and bring them to the cook.  He'll cook it up, add whatever sauces you want and your all set.  It's pretty comparable to Sir Crazy if you've ever been there.Where else can you go to have oysters, spicy tuna rolls, crab legs, shrimp, clams, stir fry bar with decent service?I'm glad there is a place super close that is kind of a hidden gem for cheap and good eats.15 bucks?  That's a pretty good deal for the stir fry bar alone.  I heard lunch is only 8 or so bucks.  I suppose I'll check it out sometime...
<review# 1355,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/21/2011,2/28/2011,258,159,9,7,6>You've no doubt heard the term vegetarian, but one I coined for myself is "Carnitarian".  I am a true carnitarian and proud to be one.  Brazilian Steakhouses are a Carnitarian's delight, a veritable plenipotentiary of all-you-can-eat animal flesh to feast upon.  Personal favorites include the ribeye, the picanha (top sirloin) and (drool) the bacon wrapped filet mignon.  Chama Gaucha compares very favorably to the more well known BSH Fogo De Chao.  In fact, I thought the salad bar here was better than Fogo's as it had a bit more variety.  Chama Gaucha is perfect for a date night or fancy shmancy business meeting.  My only objection was that parking was extremely scarce even though the place was only half full but other than that, five stars all the way.  Muito bem, obrigado!
<review# 1356,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/12/2011,2/27/2011,850,1294,8,7,8>You would swear I was pregnant with the roller coaster of cravings I've been having lately. This week I was jonesing for all things Asian, and Thipi Thai rescued me from the gourmet spiral of hell I've been slowly slipping into since eliminating almost all restaurant excursion expenses.My GPS directed me to the old location, so I was able to get a feel of how much they have expanded. The new location is much more accessible and better suited. The decor is extravagant without being overwhelming. The ridiculously open space gives you room to breathe and the low lighting allows you to relax, slow down and catch your breath. The most gorgeous aspect is, without a doubt, the upside down umbrellas that dot the ceiling.So back to my X-rated food fantasies. Is it hot in here? Or is it just the curry?I had been dreaming all week about succulent beef bits perfectly cooked with just the right amount of oil and loaded with flavor swimming in a sea of bamboo shoots, baby corn and basil. Thipi Thai was able to accommodate with their Lemon Grass Beef ($10). I got my taste buds ready for the saucy 'splosion by splitting an order of Deep Fried Pot Stickers with Karen C. ($6). It was a new and welcomed experience, but I much prefer regular stickers. The beef dish was delicious, but they aren't kidding when they say GARLIC sauce. I washed it all down with a tall glass of Thai Iced Tea ($2!!!).Oh, Thipi, you're my new guilty pleasure.
<review# 1357,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/26/2011,2/26/2011,2184,1339,7,10,8>I just went here for lunch today and was surprised at how good the food was. It reminded me of Chinatown and I think it's the closest to Chinatown food I have ever found in the burbs!My meal started with the hot & sour soup which is VERY spicy! I was proud of myself & my sensitive taste buds for having as much as I did. It has some tofu in it and something we couldn't quite identify but thought maybe it was eggplant? I found that to be an interesting selection.Then we ordered the fried bread thanks to the yummy looking picture a fellow Yelper posted. It was a good addition at $3.30. It was steaming hot, lightly deep fried and just tasted so moist and appetizing. I loved it! I added the egg roll to my lunch special...not necessary at all with the HUGE amount of food we got but I really wanted to give it a try. I consider myself to be an eggroll connoisseur and can never seem to find the perfect one. I would venture to say that this might just be the best eggroll I've ever had! No joke! It wasn't overly deep fried, came out of the deep fryer nice & hot. I loved the crispiness of the outside. It was a very thick eggroll filled with a lot of tasty ingredients on the inside. It cost an extra $1.25 to add to my meal but it was well worth it!For my main entree, I ordered the sweet & sour lunch special with white rice (it comes standard with fried rice). It was just a bit over $6 and was a huge portion. The chicken pieces were very large and moist compared to other places. The sauce was the Chinatown standard...orange and saucy! It wasn't overly amazing but still good. My friend got the beef chow fun which I tasted. Now that was amazing!We were one of just a few tables in there for lunch. The service was very friendly, much better then the standard Chinatown which I keep comparing this lunch to. Food came out very fast which was perfect for our lunch. We have an hour for lunch...it took us 10 minutes to get here, 10 minutes to get back to work, and in that 40 minutes we had soup, appetizer, side dish, main dish & chocolate fortune cookies...didn't go over on our time at all! Definitely will be coming back here!

<review# 1359,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/13/2010,2/24/2011,20,100,2,3,4>My boyfriend and I went here because we had a coupon from AmEx for $25 off a $50 purchase.  After perusing the menu we decided to splurge for a fancy date night.  We honestly thought we probably wouldn't go back, because I'm very unlikely to want to spend that much on dinner on a regular basis.Color us wrong!  It was very pleasantly surprising.  Their whole spiel is that they change the menu 4 times a year (once a season, get it??) and everything is fresh, local, and under 475 calories a plate.  The portion sizes and the lack of carbs clearly helped make that 475 number possible, but even with that said, I was impressed!  I ordered the venison chops and got 2(!) chops, the most amazing sweet potato puree, and a heaping pile of perfectly cooked veggies.  My boyfriend ordered the crab stuffed shrimp, which was basically pure crab over butterflied shrimp (no breadcrumbs to keep down the carbs/calories? oh darn!) and another heaping pile of perfectly cooked veggies.We were both very full after our meals... but not full enough that we couldn't resist the mini indulgence desserts.  Think a gigantic shot glass filled with something supremely divine... I got the carrot cake and he got the peanut butter and chocolate mousse.  For $2.50 a pop you don't feel guilty getting a dessert.  Way to strategize, Seasons 52!All the entrees were between $15-$20.. so not cheap.. but surprisingly and happily affordable for a random splurge.. perhaps we'll be coming back for the fall menu shortly.. They did say the menu is about to change again!

They are able to customize any cakes and pretty much will do anything you ask of them. We get their apple strudel ALOT and because they are so incredible, they often run out so either call in the morning and ask them to hold you one (which they definitely will, if you ask nicely) or they have apple delights that are just as good and individually sized. When they are on their annual vacation and closed for a week, it makes me a little sad, but I know they will be back. <review# 1363,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/9/2011,2/20/2011,288,304,8,12,12>Yay! I am a fan indeed! I had been itching to try Zenwich for quite some time now so when I received notification that Zenwich was this week's Groupon...I took that as a sign that I needed to get off my booty & high tail it on over to Elmhurst for some sandwich nirvana! This cute & small (very small) shop is located in a strip mall that you probably have passed a dozen times. While the location might be a bit lackluster, I assure you the food is not. I had the Mu Ping which is grilled caramelized pork, pickled carrot & daikon, cilantro, cucumbers, jalapeno, onion and house made mayo served on a toasty ciabatta roll. Homemade seasoned chips, ginger slaw and a pickle accompanied my porky little number. The chips were quite nice - they were a little sweet and a little spicy and I was glad I ordered an extra bag to snack on later. The cost for all this deliciousness? $7.50 !!! (minus the extra bag of chips...which are a whopping 2 bucks!) As I said, the place is small...there are a handful of tables at best which wasn't a problem for me as I was ordering to-go. I imagine dining during the week during the lunch time rush would be a bit risky...fair warning. You might have to wait a little bit for your order which is very clearly stated for you at the counter. Zenwich is NOT fast food, so expect a bit of a wait...it's totally worth it and you will not be disappointed. If you are looking for something new & fresh...look no further!
<review# 1364,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/5/2011,2/19/2011,57,94,3,7,6>Stopped in for dinner tonight.  Will be stopping back again.  And again.  And again.   And I don't even live in Crystal Lake.Good hand-tossed pizza is a joy to find.  I know how these are made; I got a tour of the kitchen at the Elgin Nick's.  Freshly-made dough, proprietary sauce, good ingredients.  Very professional staff.I like black olive pizza.  Yeah, yeah.  It's a little weird.  Mainly, because its one of those pizza combinations that's a disaster waiting to happen.   If the olives are weird or tinny, it'll drag down the rest.  If the sauce is wrong, the toppings won't help cover it up.  If the crust isn't good, then the pizza has no texture.. and don't get me started about weird cheese.  A perilous thing is a black olive pizza...But not here.  Everything was perfectly balanced... the delicate fullness of the olives, the full tomato taste of the sauce... with that almost buttery note of good cheese interacting with the acid of the sauce.  My partner noted that he loves the corn meal on the bottom; the little bits that keep the thin crust dough from sticking.Such a simple thing.  Sometimes, its the "simple things" that can be tricky.  When you nail them, you nail them.The service was good; playful but very busy. The ambience is really great; I love the barn/lodge feel of the place and the holiday lights are so cheery during this dark time of year.  The massive doors and scale of the place shift your mind into readiness for a good experience, IMHO.We finished with a cookie.  An great big chocolate chip cookie, with two scoops of moose-track ice cream, a mound of whip cream and chocolate syrup on top.  It took three of us to finish it.  The fourth stayed out of it: he'd started with a moose mousse shake of some kind that he said was incredible and worth every penny.  So, Nick's knows dessert, too.Just don't ask for coffee.  They don't have it.  Really.  But who really cares?  They have Sprecher root beer by the bottle; that beats restaurant coffee in my book.

<review# 1368,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/3/2010,2/15/2011,172,208,3,6,5>The ice cream and bubble shakes at Village Creamery can be described with one word: "splendiferous!!!" They carry your usual flavors, and also plenty of Filipino favorites. Ube, Lychee, Avocado, Jack fruit, Coconut, and my favorite, Mango are just some of the specialty flavors they carry. They also carry the specialty flavors in quarts, and pints, although they are a bit pricey. They carry ice cream cakes, and they even serve hot food like empanadas, pancit palabok, and egg rolls. Seriously, I don't come here for the empanadas, but its nice of them to at least have it. In case you are wondering, the "bubble" in bubble shake is just tapioca pearls, but it just makes the shakes that much better. Village Creamy actually has two locations in the area, the other being down the road in Skokie, on Oakton St. There are fewer things that are as gratifying as having an ice cold Mango bubble shake on a hot, sunny, summer day. Actually, it doesn't have to be a hot, sunny, summer day for me to enjoy a scoop of ice cream heaven. FYI: They accept credit cards, with a minimum $10 purchase. So bring cash if you think you're spending less than $10.

Now in my defense I thought the Beef Noodle was a cup of soup. Holy Lord, it was a big ass bowl! No wonder the waitress looked at me when I went on to order another dish.The spicy beef noodle is excellent. It lives up to the hype. It was all the flavors I love: beefy, spicy, cilantro-y, noodley ... perfection in a bowl. I could make a meal out of that alone. The Hunan beef was also very delicious. It was very flavorful and spicy without blowing your head off hot. The beef and veggies were also cooked perfectly. No too chewy meat or overly crunchy vegetables. Just yum. Prices are slightly higher but the portions are huge. I still have some leftovers that could last a couple days if I wasn't such an oinker.It's a shame I have probably drove past this place so many times (I've always seen the printing company signs) not knowing the deliciousness inside. Definitely a highly rated restaurant on my list and probably in the top three Chinese places in this area.
<review# 1373,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/17/2011,2/9/2011,5,10,4,6,4>I turned the car around on Sunday to go here for brunch because my friend and I thought it looked funny on the outside with the ancient sign and old-school diner feel and might make for an interesting story. Fortunately, all my visions of random sketchy greasy food on dirty tables were shot to pieces. It was amazing. The couple who seem to own it are adorable and super-friendly, and the rest of the staff seem to genuinely enjoy their jobs. They all came over to sing happy birthday to a guy who seemed to be a regular, and our waitress was really fun to chat with when she came around. Everyone had a smile on their face, which effectively melted away all of the mid-winter cynicism that drove me to walk into a restaurant I was expecting to be terrible in the first place. The decor on the inside pretty much matches the sign on the outside. It is like stepping into a time warp of kitschy-ness, but I sort of wish I could live in it all the time. Anyway, the food. That is why people go to restaurants. So good. My friend and I shared a feta omelette and french pancakes with strawberries, both of which were delicious. The omelette was American style, beautifully golden on the outside and cooked perfectly. The french pancakes (I am unclear how this is different than crepes, which were right above them on the menu, but whatever), were also really good, and completely filled with strawberries. Simple comfort food that is prepared carefully. Delightful.Coffee was good but not life-changing, but more of it appeared at exactly every moment I wanted it to even though it was crowded in there on a Sunday around noon. We also paid much less than we would have at the trendier places in the area and had better food and service than I have experienced most places. I would move in if I could.
<review# 1374,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/2/2011,2/8/2011,119,104,,5,3>Four stars for value and decent food.As previously reviewed, the portions are big and the prices are just right.  In addition to a falafel sandwich, we ordered a beef/steak shish kabob sandwich with baba ghanouj and knafeh for dessert.Falafel was far from the best, but not as dry as others described.  I tried knefah for the first time, and something tells me there are much better versions out there.  It was mushy and the cheese was too sweet.  This only leaves two more items to write about and validate my four-star review.Yes, the baba ghanouj and kabobs were that good.  Ok, ok, the kabobs were a little overcooked, but they tasted good.  And the baba ghanouj was like having an eggplant guacamole stuffed inside my kabob sandwich.  I paid an extra buck for it, and it was well worth it.  I feel so cheated when I pay an extra buck for a brush of guacamole on a burrito or burger.  So this extra dollar made me feel like it was well spent.I'll be back for meats as a platter or shawarma.  Skip the dessert though.  Recommended.
<review# 1375,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/9/2010,2/7/2011,213,305,13,11,11>My boyfriend has been putting up with my crap for three years now, and it seemed like something to celebrate.  Enter Raffi's on Fifth!  Because it's stealthily located within the old Fifth Avenue Station near downtown Naperville, it can be easily overlooked when planning a nice dinner out - but really, it should be at the top of your list!  We had difficulty settling on one appetizer, since everything sounded good, but we ended up getting that night's special: smoked salmon rolled up with crab salad and served over greens.  It was light and delicious, a perfect way to start our meal.For my entree, I couldn't not get lamb.  Come on, you're in a Mediterranean restaurant, you HAVE to get lamb.  I chose the lamb kebobs, and... sd;alfkjsd;lfads;kjdsdf;alsdkf;dlksfkja  What?  Oh, sorry, that was just my fingers spasming from the memory of those tender, juicy, flavorful, medium-rare lamb kebobs, marinated in red wine and tomatoes, and delicately flavored with mint.  They were accompanied by rice pilaf and roasted onions, tomatoes, and bell peppers.  This dish was incredible, and I can't recommend it enough.My boyfriend ordered the fettuccine alfredo with shrimp.  This classic pasta dish didn't offer any surprises - I mean, you know what you're getting with fettuccine alfredo - but it was also probably the best fettuccine alfredo I've ever tasted in a restaurant.  The sauce was creamy and rich (but not too heavy), and the shrimp were very plump and had kind of a smoky flavor.  Very good...although my boyfriend conceded that my lamb kebobs were superior.  Nothing beats delicious, well-prepared lamb.  That's just the way it is.The service was attentive and polite, although our waiter was definitely a Seinfeldian "low talker"...I half-expected him to try and sell me a puffy shirt for my upcoming appearance on "The Today Show."  The ambiance is semi-fine dining - the decor is lovely, but not so posh or stuffy that an impoverished grad student like myself would feel uncomfortable.  It's perfect for a fancy anniversary dinner or just a nice evening out with friends.  To use a sartorial analogy, Raffi's is like a cute blazer, in that you can dress it up or down depending on the occasion.Chic, versatile, and delicious!  Rah rah for Raffi's!

<review# 1382,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/15/2011,1/30/2011,60,239,4,3,3>Serino's is one of those places that takes me back in time.  Growing up on the NW side, I used to pedal my bike to a little storefront sub shop at the corner of Belmont & Central Pk.  Jimmy's had a small menu with maybe 7 or 8 sandwiches and the only "sides" were your choice of Jay's chips. But, man did Mr. Jimmy make the best subs around.  He used Gonnella French bread, the kind that Mom used to grab out of the tall barrels at the A&P or The National.  You know it had that hard crust but tasted so good on the inside.  I loved the end pieces and would ask Mr or Mrs Jimmy if I could have the end piece.  They were always so nice to us little snot-noses as long as we behaved in their shop.Mr & Mrs Jimmy's really built a heckuva sub sandwich.  It's not like the corporate sub chains where you get precisely 3 slices of meat and two slices of cheese BUT you can have all of the iceberg lettuce you want!  And some of these chains brag about how they bake their own bread "so many times a day".  Yeah, big deal, it still tastes like doughy fluff.  How boring...OK, that's right, I'm reviewing Serino's.  Sorry for the time warp.  We've had subs from Serino's at least a half dozen times and we love 'em.  I'll drive past 2 Subway's and a Quizno's just to go to Serino's, they're that good.  Let's see, I've had the Italian, American, Serino Special and Paesano.  You know, I can't say that I have a favorite.  I love them all.Veggie friendly?  Serino's has you covered.  The Caprese (grilled eggplant, fresh mozzarella and tomatos) is fantastic!  They also have a "Veggie" which is mostly cheese.  My wife isn't a big meat lover and loves it when I surprise her with a Caprese for dinner.  I even like them especially with a glass of Pinot Noir. They have a nice little deli area where you can buy meats, cheeses and specialty salads.  I have bought the small containers of salads to go with our subs and have never been disappointed.Here's a little tip when you want to cook up a quick pasta and red gravy for a fast meal.  Try Serino's Marinara or Meat Gravy that they have on the counter with a box of Barilla pasta.  Their pasta sauces are cooked right there by a lady that could be "Mama Serino" and are better than anything you can buy in the store. Geez, this was an awfully long review for a sub shop.  Sorry about that but I really like the place.  The only thing preventing me from giving it 5 stars is they don't use that crispy, crunch Gonnella bread that I love.  Don't get me wrong, it's pretty good bread but just not quite Gonnella.  If they ever switched to that great bread, I think I would have to find me a Schwinn Stingray, put a baseball card in the spokes and travel back in time to 1971.
<review# 1383,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/19/2011,1/29/2011,78,342,2,2,2>Wow!  I just had a major experience at this place.  I kept seeing this place pop up in my Yelp Feed and they were all 5 star reviews.  So I set out on a mission to try this incredible sushi that I had been hearing all about.  Finding it was the hardest part of my journey - I wish that I had read the review that said that this sushi restaurant is actually inside of the Chinese BBQ restaurant.  Once I got there, I saw this small sushi bar and about 5 tables.  The waitress was really friendly and was happy to make suggestions - there were several specialty rolls to choose from, so if you like that kind of thing like I do you will be happy here.  I ordered the Salmon Obsession, Yellow Tail and Scallion and the Spicy Crunch.  All of them were excellent and I would absolutely get them again - though I also want to try some of the other fabulous creations of Chef Soon.  The best part of this place is the feeling you get here.  It is kind of hard to explain, you almost have to go and experience it yourself.  I felt like I was in this underground foodie paradise - Chef Soon and his assistant come to the tables and talk to you.  They want to make sure that you love what you are eating and that you will come back for more.  I could tell by watching some of the interactions between Chef Soon and his patrons that they had been to this place several times and that they appreciated both his food and his company.  I can't agree more with Dana when I say that it is so obvious that these people love what they do, and when you find a restaurant that displays this kind of quality, you are impressed.  I do hope that Chef Soon gets his own place someday because I do think he could use some more space and an easier to find location.  I wonder if people can sit in the BBQ seating area if the sushi area fills up - not sure about this.  All I know is that  I will back soon
<review# 1384,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/28/2010,1/28/2011,92,360,2,7,6>SIlver Lake is a small chain of 7-8 Chinese restaurants in the west / northwest suburbs. I'm pretty confident that Roselle was its first location.This is our third time eating here. We ordered the pot stickers for an appetizer, and boy, I really wish every Chinese restaurant would decide to pan-fry them instead of steaming. Pan-fried, they're a bit crispy on the sides, and taste much better. They're served with a fermented fish sauce and red chili sauce -- use both, although if you're sensitive to hot foods, the red chili sauce can get very hot.Just for kicks, I ordered a Silver Shrimp and Scallop from the house specialties menu. Theoretically, this dish shouldn't work - it's shrimp and scallops, breaded, then pan-fried, then drenched in a sweet cream (?) sauce, with sesame seeds and steamed broccoli. Despite questioning the wisdom of covering fried breading with white sauce, this was fantastic--the scallops and shrimp were cooked just right (not rubbery), and the sweetness of the cream sauce wasn't distracting.My wife ordered the Empress Chicken, which features fried, breaded chicken, green peppers and carrots covered with a sweet BBQ sauce and sesame seeds. This was also made perfectly.Is this authentic Chinese food? Probably not. But it's the best place to find Chinese food if you don't intend to drive into Chinatown itself--and from my experience, Silver Lake now beats, hands down, some of those popular restaurants in that neighborhood.
<review# 1385,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/15/2011,1/27/2011,65,785,,6,4>Bien Trucha is indeed a little gem of a place near ol' downtown Geneva.  It's been on our bookmark list for a while, and it seemed like a good time to try it at an off time like 1:20pm on a Sat, but we still had to wait 35 minutes, which wasn't bad given its capacity.  This little place has about 10 seats at the bar, and maybe table seating for 24 or so I would estimate, and it seems to be a sort of yuppy hot spot in town.  I can now see why folks usually have to wait an hour+ or whatever outside the door.Everything is freshly made and tasty.  I really enjoyed the bean paste with the tortilla chips, and don't ever recall having such in the past with chips.  We also had the cazuelitas de camarones (like a cheesy casserole, this one with shrimp) and served with 4 little flour tortillas, as well as tacos Arrachera (4 soft tacos with skirt steak and guacamole).   Overall, I would have considered a 5 star rating for our outing, but both dishes were over the top salty, and I don't know if it was off or if typical. The interior was clean and chic, and not dated as the plain exterior might imply.  The bar area was busy with patrons and their ~$10-$12 exotic and fruity Mexican drinks.  They give you clean plates for each dish, leave a carafe of water, and have nice music going - all nice touches.  It's slightly pricey for the serving sizes, but you get freshness and quality here.  Main drawback again is it's tiny.  We've tried it now, and I don't think I'll want to wait for an hour or so in future, but it would be a fun place to take a visitor who is willing to wait.  They've been in business for 3 years, and needless to say  - no reservations!

<review# 1387,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/11/2010,1/25/2011,63,83,4,5,4>I originally thought I'd give this place only 4 stars, but the more I thought about it, I realized I just had to give it 5...I just couldn't think of a single thing I disliked, and things here are not just "good" or "not bad" or even "great"...everything I had was awesome, delicious, A++++, super, duper, mega awesomely awesome.  Now I think I might be a little biased because pretty much everything they serve is one of my favorite foods ever.  Good wine?  Yes please!  Assorted meats and cheeses?  Hell yeah!  Unique bruschettas?  Bring it on!So here's the lowdown on some specific foods I had on my latest visit...we didn't order actual entrees, but opted for an assortment of appetizers and plates to share.  Although, I should mention I have tasted various entrees including the gnocchi and salmon, all of which were superb.  But alas, I am a big fan of the snacks-as-a-meal form of eating, and since DOC has such great apps, I find it hard to make myself order an entree.  Okay, back to the specifics...We got one of their Butcher's Plates were you can pick an assortment of meats and cheeses which are served with assorted bread and crackers (and how can you go wrong with cheese and wine?).  We had aged gouda, gruyere, blue cheese, and prosciutto.  The gouda was perfectly smokey, do not pass that one up!  The gruyere was perfectly hard and crumbly, how I like it, and the blue cheese...oh baby - and I don't even like blue cheese!  It's like no other blue cheese you've ever had.  Those poor quality, stinky, cheap blue cheeses you find in salad dressing or as crumbles at the grocery store give this blue cheese a bad name!  It's served with an apricot jam that just pairs with it perfectly, giving such a great balance of flavors.  The prosciutto was sliced super thin, which I love, and had great flavor, not too salty.  It went great with the gruyere.We also had the "Daily Dip Duo" which was fresh made guacamole and roasted red pepper hummus.  The guac was super tasty - actually it tasted a lot like the guac I make, so it's gotta be good, right?  :P  The hummus was great because you could actually taste the roasted red pepper - I hate when a place says hummus is a certain "flavor" and you don't even get a hint of said flavor.So what else?  Bruschetta baby!  We got a plate where we got to choose three kinds (from a list of maybe 6 or 7).  We had the traditional mozzarella, tomato, basil one, the roasted red pepper and goat cheese one, and the ricotta, pistachio, and honey one. All were absolutely delish!  The bread was perfect - not too hard, not too soft.  The toppings went together perfectly.  The goat cheese was creamy and tart.  The ricotta, pistachio, honey was a little sweet, but not too sweet.  Yum!So last but not least for our appetizer feast...chorizo-stuffed, bacon-wrapped dates.  o.m.g.  If you are a carnivore, such as myself - GET THESE!  So many wonderful flavors!  The date was sweet, but the chorizo countered that just right, the bacon was smokey and crisp and went perfectly with the tomato-y sauce it's all served with.  Ooooooh baby, I want more!...Then dessert (hey my husband ordered it!)...they don't have much as far as dessert goes, but you don't need to when you have giant, warm, skillet-cooked chocolate chip cookies served with ice cream!  Since we were celebrating my birthday, I indulged...and it was grand.So what else?  The wine!  They have pretty much anything you can ask for...it is a wine bar after all.  What I'm especially fond of is their specials on certain days from everything from half-priced bottles, to half-priced flights, to half-priced glasses.  You can definitely drink well for decent prices with specials like that.  I also like that they have other special event nights, like ladies night, which offers drink specials, manis, and massages or movie nights with drink specials, free popcorn, etc.  I have to get to DOC for one of those some night soon!The service was absolutely great.  We had a large party and not a single thing was out of place.  Our waiter was attentive and great.  The ambiance is nice and intimate.  The place is kinda small, but they take reservations.  All in all, I wish I lived closer so I could come here more often...I'll be going back again in no time, I'm sure!

They stock both polish and american items and even have a decent wine selection if you're trying to keep everything in budget. My boyfriend got the Venetian sandwich, which was pretty darn good when I snagged a taste. I went for the Brazilian: italian bread, thinly sliced ham, lettuce, red bell peppers, and pesto sauce. YUM! One of the best deli sandwiches I've ever had the pleasure of consuming.The women working the store were very nice: attentive without being in your face and they really know how to make a sandwich! The gals even gave us a clip-card thingy: eat a certain number of sandwiches, get one free! Excellent.And for two people and a drink, the entire meal came in at around $12. The sandwiches were so much better than your typical Quizno-Subway sandwich shops and the fact that they are much cheaper makes me a very happy Evelyn. I'll basically be stalking Ellie's Deli from now on.

<review# 1393,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/16/2010,1/19/2011,161,158,3,4,3>I've been coming here for years since they opened.  It's always a fun place to go and to show your friends.  "There's only like 2 of these in the 60 miles radius, you know" (I don't know, but they don't know that).  The cool stuff:  you get to watch a movie while lounging on an all executive-leather chair, getting your fingers dirty and saucy on a burger or chicken wings.  Notice: an order is required per person so you can't get away with just a water (at least not if the staff can notice). Tip: come with friends (it's much more fun), come hungry, and if possible, come with a coupon in hand.  They give out coupons on a regular basis for free entrance passes for two.  If you sign up to be part of their email club, they usually send your passes for free screenings too.  So overall, there's really no excuse not to check this place out especially when you can see a free movie for the price of a meal.  Just last week, I saw The American, The Other Guys, and Eat Pray Love all for free!!Their food is OK, not the best but you'll live with it since you'll be so distracted in trying to keep up with the storyline.  And it's also nice that at this theater, you wont see too many tweens.  They serve alcohol so it's restricted admission.  Yay to no more kids kicking in the back of your chair as you're trying to sit back.And my last tip is, don't go here if you are going to be serious about watching something.  Between all the whispering to the waiters about your order, them ducking with the person in front of you and behind you, them juggling to get the tray of food in to you in the dark while trying carefully not to spill on you, you will find yourself looking up every 10 minutes going "What?? What happened? What did I missed?"  And likely, your friends wont fill you in on any of it because they either missed it too or they're just cruel.  Yeah, I went here to watch Inception and.... totally didn't get it.  Was far to distracted by my wings.... P.S:  The Coconut room is the best room in the house.  Hope that your movie is there at least once because it has a star-lit ceiling (not real stars though).

<review# 1395,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/10/2011,1/17/2011,99,133,6,12,9>It was bound to happen. My foodie hubris chased me down, pushed me to the ground and stuffed me full with sinfully delicious food.   I thought I knew all the Chinese restaurant trade secrets:1. Put all your customers in seats by the windows so it looks like the restaurant is packed when people do a drive by to scope it out.     a. Make sure the customers in the window are Asian, it'll draw  White   and Chinese people to the restaurant because they'll think it's authentic.  2. Have 2 separate menus with completely different items. 1 for the authentic food and 1 for the Americanized food. Asian Bistro apparently said psshh to the rules. As we were doing the drive by bf was getting cold feet, it looked like no one was in there. I convinced him to give it a shot. We walk in and there were actually quite a few people in the restaurant and they are all Chinese! Turns out the English and Chinese menu has all the same items! Originally, I had read the raving reviews for Asian Bistro and was a skeptic. If this place was SO good, how come I haven't heard about it from the Chinese community? Um...turns out maybe I'm not THAT Chinese. I realized this when the server gave me a menu all in Chinese. After a few minutes of pretending I had to come clean and tell her that I'm pretty much illiterate. To which she responded, Sorry, I'm so embarrassed (those words are the most uttered words in the Chinese language). Hmmmm...more like I'm so embarrassed. I was so excited that she assumed I could read based on my spoken Chinese. I didn't want to disappoint and thought I might be able to pull it off! The furthest I've gotten before was just been asked which menu I wanted. Anyways, on to the food. Literal translation of the dishes we ordered (English name may differ):lamb cooked 2 ways- one side was mongolian style the other side was a spicy lamb. The spicy lamb tasted like something I would find in an Indian restaurant. Flavored with cumin, other spices and lots of heat! So good. The mongolian lamb was the winner. Wasn't too salty, wasn't too saucy. Def not the kind you get at P.F. Changs. Lamb was cooked perfectly for both dishes! Tender and plump!  vegetarian chicken - Everyone makes this dish differently which is why I sometimes don't like to order it. It's basically lots of thin layers of tofu skin. The Asian Bistro version is my favorite. Lots of shitake mushrooms folded into the many layers of tofu. Delicate and tasty! empty heart veggie (veggie core is hollow)  - it's so hard to get this anywhere in the 'burbs. I've been craving this veggie for so long. it was cooked perfectly. wasn't too oily or too salty which is often the case at other places. We looked around to see what other people were getting. It all looked awesome! This place is legit. I can't wait to go back and try more items on their menu!
<review# 1396,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/5/2011,1/16/2011,116,200,6,12,12>As an unabashed gamer geek I think gaming stores are among the most important stores around. I stood in Games Plus tonight browsing and making small talk with the owner Rich and the counter help for the evening Bob. Two honest, good nerds like myself who loved all things gaming and were passionate about their pursuits. Back and forth geeks of all ages fluttered, some old and some young, some with kids of their own and it struck me: Real, honest-to-goodness gaming can and should never die. Pen and paper, dice tossing gaming. That stuff binds generations together. Connects parents to kids and siblings to one another and strengthens the bonds of friendship like nothing on earth can.What else can you do with people where you rely on their cunning and smarts, their good judgement and instincts? Creativity and their fearless pursuit of self-enrichment? It might seem melodramatic but there's something irreplaceable about sitting around a table lined with junk food and Mountain Dew slaying ogres with your ogre slaying knife (it's got a +9 against ogres!) and not giving two craps what the outside world thinks or says. Real, honest-to-goodness gaming that is threatened every day by Call of Duty, Black Ops and a bevy of other online options that rob us of that camaraderie and connection, replaced by solitude and weak social bonds. No, real gaming has to live on and watching the folks coming and going tonight drives that home all the more.Games Plus is outrageously important. It's big, well stocked with games from every corner of the planet and then some and their dedication and attention to detail is second to none. They have plenty of room for people to sit down and try out the new wares they've bought and parking is plentiful and free. It's next to the Metra for the carless city dwellers and close to lots of food options so you won't perish during whatever epic session you find yourself in.In this Xboxed, Wii'd out world where oftentimes kids are segregated from their parents it's places like Games Plus that will serve as our salvation and deliver us from the ills that tear us apart. I'm Matt W, proud gamer geek and I whole heartedly recommend Games Plus.

The interior is very nice, with rich, warm wood, a couple of fireplaces and comfy seating. And lots of flat-panel TVs for whatever game is on.The menu is decently varied and I had a hard time deciding, but I went with one of the specials, a turkey melt on ciabatta with havarti and spring greens. And in true M. family fashion, we started with nachos.The nachos were solid, not fantastic but good enough to get them again. Tons of cheese (some of it not-quite melted), a little skimpy on the refried beans, decent guacamole, good salsa, plenty of ground beef. My sandwich was very good; the only mild disappointment was that the turkey appeared to be processed deli-cut, as opposed to nice pieces of a roasted turkey (like Thanksgiving leftovers). But the bread was quite good, the pesto mayo and havarti delicious. The fries were solid. Service was friendly and competent, no problems there.Next time I'd like to try something different on their vast menu, but I was definitely pleased enough that I'm sure we'll be back.Edit: We came back, just over a month later -- and I must say, the mac & cheese (with tomato, bacon, onion and a garlicky-crumb crust) is AWESOME. I make some good mac & cheese, and this blew mine away. Carb-o-licious heaven.

<review# 1403,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/16/2010,1/9/2011,4739,1870,49,24,20>The review you are about to read is true. Only the names have been changed to protect the innocent. To say that Brixie's is an institution would be a vast understatement. This bar is older than my grandmother, made it through the Great Depression, saw the first man on the moon, and probably partied like it was 1999 the whole way through. 5 stars.Now, any bar that's been able to stick around for so long is bound to have a few quirks, and I'd say Brixie's main eccentricities come in the form of it's customers. Don't be scurred, just be prepared for an experience that could be filed under peculiar, offbeat (in a good way), and/or downright bizarre... but keeps you coming back for more. IMO, 5 stars.On the (late) night of the BF and my visit, we walked into a somewhat sparsely populated bar and the always outstanding beer list. We took some seats at the bar and were promptly served by a bartender who had been beer-tending at the big B for 18 years, now. Low turnover is generally always a sign of a great bar. A few rounds of craft beer and a foursquare check in later, we're googling the place to see what it's story is and learning a hell of a lot about Malort in the meantime. ::cringe:: As we do this, we notice another patron at the bar trying to get our attention. We'd been trying our best to ignore the 50 something feathered haired gentlemen because we were almost certain that only a few minutes prior he was barking like a dog, but in a pirate accent (picture it, people) in our general direction. We finally acknowledged his grumblings as he asked us what we were doing on our "machine." The machine was my BFs iphone and apparently he was implicating us in his conspiracy theory that we were controlling the bar's music from our phone. He seemed upset, so in an attempt to ease his worries the bartender showed him the knobs behind the bar for the volume control... unfortunately, it did not control the volume level of the voices in his head.To him, we were still a threat. To be fair, we were a little buzzed and began to egg him on a bit. The BF would point his "machine" in his direction and I'd ahem little things about Elvis still being alive and my involvement as the second shooter. Date night was going along quite swimmingly.Now, if I had to describe how he looked, I'd say Jim Caviezel at about 56 after he went crazy from getting struck by lightning twice during passion of the Christ. This is your brain on lightning... and too much Christ, and maybe a few 'Nam flashbacks as well.At one point he told my BF, the guy next to me, and myself that we're "fucked". Still not sure what that meant but the guy next to me (a regular) was a little uncomfortable with the idea. Then, he began reminiscing about when he could:A. Smoke in bars while... B. Getting sucked off by whores.  After this, the bartender told him to watch his mouth in front of the lady (ahem, he was talking about moi ::in a dainty voice::). The bartender's scolding appeared to profoundly affect him as he 'tapped out' from the bar and  headed over to the jukebox to create a classic rock carnival for our ears. The music appeared to calm him, though he did at one point threaten to give the BF a 'knuckle sammich' for agreeing with him, then 10 seconds later they were all good in the hood. Mood swings can be a b*tch, bro.Brixie's: proving that awesome things can happen after 2am.Moral of the story: Making friends is fun and having great beer in an exciting, fast paced, environment is even better. 5 stars.
<review# 1404,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/9/2010,1/8/2011,176,176,1,7,3>Known as the 'jewel of Lombard', I had heard about Lilacia Park for many years and had seen the park from the Metra train quite a few times, but never got around to making  a visit until the Spring of 2010. I think my reason for not stopping was that the lilacs are only in bloom for a short time and each time I thought about going, the lilacs were no longer in bloom. After missing the 2009 blooming season, I vowed to make it in time for the next one.The park is nice and expansive. Though the weather was a bit chilly and overcast on my visit on 5/6/2010, I had a pleasant stroll through the quiet park with my camera. Many varieties of lilac bushes were in bloom and the fragrance was heavenly. Several walking paths were accented with a beautiful array of tulip beds, daffodils, day lilies, and other flowers. A few benches were scattered throughout the park for lounging and relaxing.A gift shop and library building are on site, as well as a small greenhouse, though I didn't stop to see those areas. I saw two lilac-colored booths at entrances to the park in case you want to make donations to help sustain the park.Overall, it was a nice park and conveniently located next to the Lombard Metra station. Probably a great place to stroll on a sunny day anytime of the year whether the lilacs are in bloom or not. But be sure to be intentional about going when the lilacs are flowering. I mean, that's what the park is named for, right? You'll be glad you did.

<review# 1408,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/1/2010,1/4/2011,33,144,6,6,4>Comic books.  One of the early ways my kind was finally able to express our geekiness.Good stores are hard to come by, so that makes this place a bit of a ... oh you almost caught me in a terrible pun there.  I was going to call it a "gem" but no sir, I'm a better writer than to resort to that.  The biggest plus of this place is the lady that works there.  She is super helpful, always greets you as soon as you enter the store.  If you need help finding something specific, she'll drop everything and help you.Like any good store they're completely up to date on comic book issues... plus they carry The Guild which was surprisingly not easy to find elsewhere and Felicia Day really deserves to have her comic more widely available.  There's also a huge amount of sealed back issues of nearly everything.  From common stuff like Superman or the X-Men to slightly more obscure like The Sandman to stuff even I've never heard of.  Whatever it is, there's probably at least one back issue of it in there somewhere.  And everything's reasonably priced considering the pristine condition it's all kept in.Apart from the comics there's a wall with geeky t-shirts (always a fan), a bunch of collectibles ranging from lower priced action figures to really nice $100 statuettes.  They also have a few D&D manuals and miniatures and customizable card games.  I've noticed a couple times a handful of geeks at a table in the back playing various games, so if you're looking for a gaming group, might be worth checking out.My only complaint would be it's a fairly large store but there isn't a huge amount of stuff in there.  I really feel like the extra space could maximized to increase their stock of various comic-book related geeky items and really solidify this place as a fanatic's destination and give it that fifth star.Overall, a great comic book store, really set apart by those who run it.  Part of being a geek is the community aspect of it, and you can't beat  a place with an owner who understands that.

<review# 1413,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/16/2010,12/30/2010,11,43,3,6,3>After months and months and months of waiting, the storefront with the big sign that proclaimed "Opening Spring 2009" finally tore down the sign and opened their doors in Winter 2010.  My co-workers had been intrigued by the concept and were really excited that it had finally opened so at the last minute, we switched our annual holiday lunch to Chicken & Waffles II.  We were all really surprised how nice the interior was - the place looks much more upscale than the name might imply.  Staff were incredibly nice, very patient, and very gracious.  Upon receiving the menu (which is a lot more than just chicken and waffles), it took everyone quite some time to decide.  Our group ordered a pretty wide variety of items off of the menu - chicken, waffles, burger, red beans & rice, cheese grits, etc - and everyone seemed pretty happy.  I was a little disappointed with the selection of healthy meals (everything healthy was ultimately paired with something that wasn't so heathy), but ended up ordering the Sir Glen, which included eggs (which I was able to order whites for a higher price), turkey sausage, and pancakes (which I was able to order buckwheat for a higher price).  I will say however, that my meal was really good.  I only ate one of the waffles, which was more than enough.  They're not quite the waffles that I'm used to - not big belgian waffles, and very soft, but when the syrup is added - still are very good.  Many of the foods on the menu reminded me a bit of Wishbone (which isn't too far away in nearby Berwyn).  In all honesty, if I had to choose between the two, Wishbone still has my vote.Overall, our group seemed really happy with the place and everyone indicated that they'd definitely like to come back. I probably would not go back on my own, but only because the variety of food for someone wanting to eat healthy is very slim, but wouldn't say no if invited to join a group there.  Overall, if you're looking for a place with some real comfort food (which I can imagine this occuring quite often with Chicago winters) though, I would recommend this place.

<review# 1415,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/26/2010,12/27/2010,252,423,2,3,2>We LOVE Schnitzel Platz! It's our family's favorite place to celebrate special occasions and to bring out of town guests. We have tried a few other German restaurants and this place is the best!Everything is absolutely delicious! We've tried a number of items and our favorites are the Jaeger/Hunter Schnitzel (pork schnitzel with a yummy mushroom sauce) and the sausage sampler plate. Meals come with either a cup of the soup of the day or the German salad plate (a variety of cold German salads). And there is a nice big basket of pretzels rolls, rye bread and crackers brought to the table. The servings are very large and we always bring leftovers home. You can share a meal for a small fee. And they might seem pricey but they are in line with pricing at other German places and you do get ALOT of food. Now I'm not a beer fan but my husband and father-in-law do enjoy their large beer selection. You can even have a litre of beer in a glass boot! They also have a number of wines and after dinner cordials which are quite good. And don't forget dessert! I believe the dessert menu might be smaller during Oktoberfest but normally they have a huge selection of tempting cakes and strudels. Your server might go over the tray of them pretty fast but don't worry, they are happy to repeat or answer any of your questions.A few notes about their hours- they are closed on Tuesdays. They also are closed for a few weeks in Autumn each year to return to Germany (the owners and some of the staff are from there) so be sure to check. If you go during Oktoberfest(Sept-Oct) the center of the restaurant has rows of picnic tables with table cloths lined up to accommodate the crowds. They do have booths along the outer walls of the resturaunt though. And if you come on a Fri, Sat or Sun make reservations. They are typically packed on these nights year round.  And I would be remiss if I didn't mention the two-man German band who entertains on the weekends. They are fabulous and will have the whole crowd singing along. Everyone has a little German in them at Schnitzel Platz!

<review# 1423,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/7/2010,12/19/2010,7,63,2,3,2>Working in pet nutrition is a tough field, and it's refreshing to find someplace that cares as much as you do.I came into Happy Dog Barkery in winter of 2009, and I can't get enough! I see how some reviews complain about the prices... You get what you pay for, folks, and you are what you eat, so feed your dog cheap stuff, get a sick dog. Feed your dog healthy, natural, biologically appropriate foods, and get a healthy, happy dog. Seems simple, no?The bakery is wonderful! I love their adorable little treats, and we are always sure to stock up when we are here. I live an hour away, but my little girl just loves to come in here. The staff is so nice to her, they are so understanding of her shyness (two years ago, she was "breeding stock" at a puppy mill. Today, she's my baby girl and best friend, and I love to bring her everywhere to help bring her out of her shell). They are always polite to us, and love to give her little bits to munch on while we shop.Their baked goods are wonderful! Shilah loves the cheddar and spinach treats we get here, and we're hoping to get a little cake made for her adoption day coming up soon (they make custom cakes here, too!!!). We adopted a second dog back in March and I can't wait to bring him out to see Happy Dog Barkery! They also have a ton of natural foods and treats here, which makes me happy. They have a really cool selection of foods, treats, accessories, home goods, dishes, car magnets, beds... It's a real surprise every time you come in as to what you will find this time. It's like discovering a whole new store when we manage to make our way out there! We've gotten some really unique items here for my pups, and I will definitely be back soon!As far as the comment about garlic being toxic? Only in large quantities. We use garlic as a natural flea and tick preventative (this has been done very safely for centuries to keep biting insects away; ever wonder where the garlic wards off vampires legend came from?) and they are both totally healthy and have not had even a mosquito bite since we started using it. I would like to see more wheat-free treats, since I feed them grain-free raw food, but in small amounts I don't worry about it. Treats are, after all, just that, a treat.In summary: A great store, with a unique feel, polite staff, awesome selection, and great baked goods. HIGHLY recommended to anyone who loves their pets!
<review# 1424,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/30/2010,12/18/2010,204,392,3,8,5>Not gonna lie, the soothing sound of crooners like ol' blue eyes himself will turn me onto the menu of Catch 35 any day.Sunday marked the last night of my mom's visit to the area that I now call home and rather than cook her something amazing we decided to paint the town red. Which is actually not very easy since the town is pretty small, but there are a few options where you can get swanky and festive. Catch 35 is one of them.I called prior to our dining time to see if reservations were necessary and when the hostess said it was quiet, we decided to get ready and make a jaunt around 7:30pm. There were several other patrons dining but the room was nowhere near packed, it was perfect.The dining room is dimly lit by candlelight, the ceilings stretch cathedral-esque high and if you're sitting around the edges it boasts a romantic atmosphere. I am not so sure about sitting in the center of the room but we were sat on the backside of the bar in a booth. The waiter dropped in and while he explained the menu, he tackled the prix fix option. If you are dining and this option is available, I highly recommend it.For our dinner, we each enjoyed a lovely crab bisque starter, the main entree was honey dijon crusted whitefish for me, she had a lightly blackened salmon. By the time dessert rolled around, I was beyond full but as it was part of the prix fix options a meal could not have been wasted. I ordered the pumpkin cheesecake and my mom got the pecan pie. The cheesecake was almost a show stopper,  it was dense enough to almost have been a full coffee cake but was still moist enough to be considered a cheesecake. The pecan pie was loaded with nuts and was aromatic.Catch 35 definitely captured my tastebuds for an evening out and I can see this becoming a hot spot for whenever a random dining luxury needs to be slipped into the budget..a la suburbia.
<review# 1425,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/10/2010,12/17/2010,283,456,3,3,3>The day my grandfather passed away a lot of my family was in town at the hospital to spend his last hours with him. Mid afternoon, my uncle and I decided it was getting late and we all needed to eat. He asked the family if they wanted to grab a burger or try a local linen table cloth with reasonable prices. I, being not too shy, said, forget the burger, we've had a rough couple days, let's go to linen table cloth place. We followed over to the Arboretum to find this restaurant in the corner I NEVER knew was there. We walked in to this great lobby with what appeared to be a number of different places but all rolled into one. What a cool atmosphere! We were escorted back (the 14 of us that we were) and were sat quickly. We were all in a down mood, but were greeted by a smiling face with positive attitude kinda guy. He was knowledgeable about the entire menu and really impressed my whole family from start to finish. Now, we're Italian and I mean we're ITALIAN. I like to judge any restaurant by their Soup, Salad and BREAD. And wow, where we pleased. He was kind enough to hook up my grandmother with a cup of soup to "try out" and really satisfied the needs of everyone at the table. The food was great. Most of us ate off their Lunch Special menu but a few of us ordered off their main menu and no one complained about anything. We had everything from the soup/salad lunch combo to one of their pasta dishes. The atmosphere was great. Very comfortable and it was pretty evident to me that they really put extra care and attention into training their servers. I have nothing negative to say except that I wish their dinner specials, which we go in for once in while, were served daily. I love this place and recommend it to anyone for any event or to grab a quickie lunch. GO SEE THESE GUYS! I promise, it'll be worth it.
<review# 1426,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/18/2010,12/16/2010,288,304,6,7,7>My friends and I headed on over to Honey Cafe after running a 5K race. That's right, we are runners now and needed to fuel our bodies with some tasty treats because that's what runners do. Honey Cafe is a cute little space with its sleek & modern decor. Upon entering you'll notice a little counter with their bakery items including their cupcakes of the day. Today's variety consisted of vanilla bean, red velvet and pumpkin. Mmm, pumpkin. I stuck with breakfast while my fellow runners (did I mention we are runners now?) stuck with lunch fare. I got the caprese benedict and it was delicious. Upon receiving it I was concerned that the focaccia bread might be a bit much but it wasn't and I dug the basil infused hollandaise. My running partner ordered up the chicken pot pie. The skies had turned dark and the temperature had started to drop...so why not warm up with some pot pie? It looked amazing. I had a bite and the pastry was flaky & crisp. Yum. The last of our trio (who smoked us in the race btw) ordered up one of the specials of the day. A trio of sliders - veggie, beef, crab - with a side of mixed greens. It looked delicious. She enjoyed her sliders but felt the veggie slider was the best of the bunch. We also shared a side of sweet potato fries w/harissa dipping sauce. I would gladly eat an order of those by my lonesome. The fries were a nice hearty cut & finished w/sea salt and the dipping sauce was pretty damn good. Now, I have to say that while the food was great...the service was lackluster. We had to wait...for everything. Honey Cafe was going to get a three star review. The restaurant was not super busy & there was just no excuse for the waiting we did. They redeemed themselves by recognizing this. We each ordered a pumpkin cupcake to-go...b/c you know, we are runners and all the runners I know eat cupcakes. Upon presenting the check, the waitress apologized for all the waiting and informed us that the cakes were on the house! Score!The cupcakes were delish. The frosting was amazing! Oh, and if the mood strikes you...try the latte of the day. I had the coconut hazelnut and it was a delightful way to warm up. I look forward to more races and more tastiness from Honey Cafe.

There is the Schaumburg location, which now calls itself "County" donuts, I believe. Then, there is the actual "original" located in Crystal Lake. I love them all. I especially enjoy their mint chocolate chip donuts. Sometimes I have friends who visit me at school bring a half dozen or so from home. Don't judge me. I usually share them with those who have never experienced the goodness.All of the locations have a retro pre-fabricated feel, with tile floors and permanent stools at the counter. I chose to review this relatively new location based on its cleanliness and quick service. Complete with a drive-through, this donut shop meets all my expectations for a quality donut shop.
<review# 1428,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/29/2010,12/14/2010,392,404,3,5,4>The Spinach Pan Pizza from Piero's is my favorie pizza in all of Illinois.  Yes, better than Lou Malnati's.  Better than Pizzaria Uno and Due.  Better than Gino's East.  And way better than Giordano's.I have had it at this location, as well as the HIghland Park location and it is always pure perfection.  The pan pizza resembles more of a deep-dish style pizza with the thick crust and the sauce on top.  The spinach has a delicious garlicy-ness to it that is just amazing.  If I lived closer, I would eat this pizza every week instead of a couple of times per year.
<review# 1429,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/4/2010,12/13/2010,48,320,6,8,4>Wang's Garden is a welcome addition to the Aurora/Naperville dining scene.The dine-in menu lists both Japanese and Chinese dinner and lunch specials- we tried the Chinese lunch items. The full take-home menu can be viewed on their website and saved as a PDF for later reference.Spicy choices are indicated on the menu with a red pepper and on request can be prepared "extra spicy".I am a big fan of hot and sour soup and Wang's Garden includes a larger than average bowl with lunch, as well as your choice of crab rangoon or egg roll appetizers.The waitstaff gives service rivaling much pricier places in the area- we were treated like valued customers and every request was taken care of immediately. The waitstaff is also friendly and fun without being intrusive.The decor is what I like to call "Asian New" and the dining area was spotless and inviting.A couple that came in before us got "freaky fast" service for their take out order. It was absolutely amazing....Our overall impression was that this is a great place for traditional Chinese-American fare either for take out or dining in.Note: Not sure who all voted this place as "spendy" because both times we went here (for lunch and then for dinner), our check was quite CHEAP especially considering the amount of food that we were served.
<review# 1430,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/2/2010,12/12/2010,98,71,3,6,6>So a long time ago when I was a pig-tail wearing little girl my father used to take me slot car racing.  We went pretty frequently at that time.... and by the time I hit teenage-land the slot car place had moved away.  Just recently this place opened up and my dad called me with the excitement of a 10 year old boy.  This weekend my dad and I had our shared birthday dinner, and we went beforehand to play slot cars.  Myself, my brother, my father and my boyfriend all warped ourselves into a world I had totally forgotten about.They have multiple tracks, and there are some really serious slot-car hobby enthusiasts here.  They all line the walls against the sit down counter.  They all have huge tool bins that I prefer to call man-caboodle's.   They were all totally shocked by my fathers vintage cars.  They were clearly shaken that we were actually going to race them and not leave them in the boxes for show.  They put us on the figure 8 race track (the safest one for our vintage cars) and let us begin.  During the beginning 20 mins or so about half the people in the joint came to do a stroll by and check out my father's cars.   There was some younger kids, but mostly middle aged men.    Importantly too, there was an adorable dog that roamed around the store. (I'm a fan of this).  After a half hour of us having wipe outs, spin outs and crashes one of the workers brought us other cars that we could 'go ahead and crash' so we would stop ruining my father's cars.  I'll go ahead and say that my dad didn't care about ruining his cars, he was just happy to be slot-car racing with his kids. *****(Newbie-Slot-Car-Drivers..... feel free to go, they will rent you the guns and the cars to race)We had fun,  I mean it's not a the same kind of fun as going out to see live music, or a carnival or something...but it's totally great for an alternative to a matinee, mini-golf or bowling.
