<review# 1435,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/24/2010,12/7/2010,160,654,6,17,3>What do I love about Mariano's? Everything! It is the ultimate grocery store and so much more, great enough to be my 500th review. From the outside, you really have no idea how huge and spectacular it is inside. Imagine a Trader Joe's multiplied by five or six times in all respects, then add an in-house bakery, cafe, restaurant and coffee shop. And while you're at it, throw in a florist, deli, seafood sections and a butcher shop. Now put friendly and helpful employees everywhere. Oh, and the little shopping carts for the kids? There's a whole bunch of them in front, not just 5 or 6 like at most places. So now you get the idea, but there's more.You enter Mariano's at what is an awesome produce section. There's a mix of regular and organic produce, plus odd varieties of fruits and vegies that you won't find at your usual Jewel, Dominick's or neighborhood store. A table off to the side had 2 girls making these massive caramel apples, covered in colorful "Spwinkos!" as my 4 year old calls them, M&M's, nuts, each one a work of art. I was impressed with the apples so much that I watched the girls dipping apples to decorate. The one told me, "It's my first day here," but from the look of things, she was an old pro at making the most sumptuous caramel apples. And before you leave the produce section, stop at the juice bar where they squeeze fresh oranges to make bottles of all-natural, fresh unpasteurized orange juice on the spot. Yes, the kind with the little bits of juicy orange floating in it. At $2.99 for a half-gallon bottle, it can't be beat at Whole Paycheck or wherever you may be seeking a comparable OJ of such quality. Heck, I think the teary-eyed Minute Maid just got fired and her job outsourced to Mariano's.Be careful around the bakery, especially with small children. They have these brilliantly colored cupcakes decorated beautifully. There's also muffins and cookies. They will want to eat them right then and there. How convenient, someone put tables and chairs nearby so you can enjoy them. In our case, we also needed a carb count since my son is type 1 diabetic. Well, wouldn't you know it! The 16 year old boy working the bakery counter was type 1 and an older woman unloading loaves of fresh bread has a son with type 1 as well. They offered us the nutritional information and a warning to watch out for the blood sugar spike 6 hours later. Just to be sure they're good, we got 2 more cupcakes to bring home.I went for a cappuccino across the aisle while my kids had their cupcakes. As I waited in line, a woman offered me a sample of banana and walnut gelato. Unreal! Made me want to take a scoop of it and drop it into the coffee cup.I can go on and on about the various imported cheese, the walk-in wine refrigerator section, the massive meat and dairy section, and the various ethnic products in the aisles, but my review would be too long. It was our second trip of the day, since my wife found it earlier and insisted I come out with her for a more extensive exploration. We came out with $50 of all sorts of unique goodies the local stores by me don't carry. While it's a bit far to be my once-a-week grocery store, I can see this being our special once a month trip for reasonably priced, unique and exotic products no other place carries.

I had a chocolate and peppermint cupcake and was impressed. The cake is moist and the frosting is super cute (piled high) and not overly sweet. They also have creative flavors, and cute decor. The place has only a few tables, so it's mostly a pick up place, but do what I do and take your cupcake to go and get a cappuccino at Grahams down the street. Cupcakes in general are going to be slightly $$ (2-3 is normal for most cupcake places) but this place is worth it for a special treat. My fav in the 'burbs.Five stars since it's hard to find a really, really solid cupCAKE around chicagoland.

<review# 1438,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/5/2010,12/3/2010,143,312,3,5,3>I've been dying to try this place for awhile since it re-opened, formerly D's Little Italy. I could practically walk here and had been to more banquets when it was D's then I care to remember.Although I was eager to see the new incarnation of this spot, I still had the memory of bland potato wedges and tasteless Italian sausage from D's. Nope. Nothing like that here.The oven-baked pizza is exactly as how it tastes in the town that my dad grew up in Italy. Mind you, their prices went up, and the wood-oven fired pizza is also traditionally Italian in its size - about 9 inches. If you order larger pizza here, it will be American-style and not from that wood oven. So good...definitely worth whatever drive you have to make to the near-western burbs.
<review# 1439,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/28/2010,12/2/2010,117,89,4,4,4>I am so lucky to have White Cottage within walking distance of my house... okay, my hips aren't so happy about it, but at least I can walk off the delicious pizza!  I am just reviewing the take out / delivery operations of White Cottage today. White Cottage has the best pizza around (and I think the freshest ingredients); they even have Italian beef and giardiniera for a topping! I personally love that they have capers (another favorite).  Their thin crust is superb; slightly salty, buttery and crispy. Another reason why I love White Cottage: they will give you plenty of freshly grated parmesan and red pepper and even paper plates (delivery) if you ask! Why I didn't give them five stars:  50% of the time the toppings are incorrect on delivery orders. I have come to learn that I will probably get all the correct ingredients but mixed up. For instance: last night we ordered half sausage and onion, half pepperoni and mushroom but we received half sausage and mushroom and half pepperoni and onion. Why the incorrect orders don't bother me too much: It's delicious.
<review# 1440,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/20/2010,12/1/2010,51,284,4,6,5>When my fiancé and I considered getting a cat, we had a lot of trouble getting shelters to even consider letting us adopt or foster. As total cat newbies who keep vulnerable prey animals as pets, we encountered a lot of rudeness and general ignorance from other shelters' staff. (Fun fact: cats and bunnies can and often do get along, and our cat is actually quite terrified of our rabbits!) A.D.O.P.T. listened to our story and our concerns and worked with us to help us find the perfect kitty for us. Yay!I think we visited the shelter half a dozen times before deciding to bring Henry (formerly Sylvester) home, and the staff was always friendly and accommodating. We initially thought we wanted a kitten, and they encouraged us to spend lots of time playing with the kitties and even let us try out different kitten-cat combinations (kittens have to go home in pairs, either with another kitten or a young adult cat). The cats all live in big rooms with lots of toys, cat trees and space to play in, and they are a friendly and social bunch. The shelter is clean and well-maintained; I would honestly say it is the best of all the suburban shelters I've visited, in terms of both kitty happiness and human helpfulness!

<review# 1444,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/25/2010,11/26/2010,14,63,2,7,2>Yummy!  I don't even know where to start my review rave.   I went to Q for the first time on a Friday night.  I have been to several barbecue restaurants over the past six months, and Q exceeded my expectations where others have fallen short.  I suppose that I'll start in the order that I ate my plate.  I dug right in to the mac-q-cheese.  It totally satisfied my craving for creamy, cheesy goodness.  In my recent experience, it was rare to find a non-dried out mac n' cheese at a barbecue restaurant, but Q was very smooth and velvety. Next I sampled several sauces with the pulled pork.  The pork had a great flavor, and the sauces were delicious.  The Carolina sauce was sweet and sour, with an interesting spiciness.  The mustard sauce was similar but with more tang from the mustard.  The heat in the hot sauce slowly build the more I ate it, which was perfect.  My husband had a sampler platter, and I tried his brisket.  It was melt in your mouth tender.  I didn't get the brisket because I have not had good experiences at other restaurants, but Q met the mark on this one.  I also ate my husband's french fries.  I could tell they were fresh made and they had a great texture.  This place is great, and I can't wait to go back.
<review# 1445,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/1/2010,11/25/2010,22,60,4,7,7>Can I give more than 5 stars? Seriously! My girlfriend and I went here for my birthday and as part of our usual ritual with restaurants we called ahead to speak to a manager or chef about a gluten allergy. At first we were speaking to who ever answered the phone and he assured us we would be okay, that's great but not good enough sir! We eventually talked to the manager, Neldir who said "there are actually only very few items on our menu that you cannot have" and he explained everything to us. It didn't hurt that the night before a celiac group must have passed through! Anyways, the place was spacious, inviting and warm and everyone we spoke with was extremely polite. Neldir even came to our table to bring us some rolls made of yucca flour that is gluten free before we got into the goods. He then took us to the salad bar and gave us the rundown of what to avoid since it would contain gluten. And as far as the meat item we couldn't have- I didn't see it once that night- I secretly think he told them to avoid our table. On top of it, they made a special batch of chicken for us that we could have, who does that? I cannot say enough nice things about this place and the staff! I am impressed. They were accommodating and gracious to have us and even gave us a complimentary meal next time we came in!!!! I have a feeling this might be a go to place for us from now on! Added to my Celiac friendly list.
<review# 1446,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/8/2010,11/24/2010,17,39,2,2,2>Creative and cool atmosphere!The moment we walked in the place, I felt like all the old Greek diners had been left in the dust of the 70's and a new 2010, fresh dining experience was about to begin!  Don't get me wrong, I like the old diners but this is something different for sure.  Hip, young and friendly staff greeted us and took our orders.  Food began to pile up on our table and was not only a feast and wasn't the same tired old eggs that we have come to expect.  In fact, nothing that I saw on the menu looked like the old.  We have all been to nice diners with creative menus, but when the food comes, it's not as exciting as the description.  Now where do you go to get an omelet with caramelized pears or truffle egg toast made with asparagus, fontinella cheese and eggs drizzled with truffle oil?  This place is different in a good way. Way cool - no kidding!  Goodbye old Greek Diner.
<review# 1447,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/8/2009,11/23/2010,8,17,4,6,6>Let me just say that I think Georgio's is the best deep dish pizza you can get outside of Chicago.To start off, I've been coming here since 2004. I've never had a bad experience at the restaurant. All of the food is great, great drink selection, and a very nice feel to it. I've gone with my family, my friends, and my co-workers, and each time it's been a very good experience. The staff is attentive, pleasant, and very helpful. The bar is well stocked, at reasonable prices.Now to the meat of the review. The deep dish pizza. There is something about Georgio's that I just can't find anywhere else out here in the suburbs, and I think's it's the authentic Chicago-style deep dish. The crust is very crisp and flavorful. It's not too dry or hard, the consistency will never leave you think your chewing on a piece of dough. The sauce, though sweet, is not overpowering in any way, giving the pizza a fantastic, one-of-kind taste. Finally, the cheese is proportioned very well to the pizzas, not too much where it's falling out everywhere, which is what I like, though I do realize people prefer more cheese that I necessarily do. Together, the ingredients make a fantastic pizza. And it's great if you have too much and eat if for left-overs.Besides the classic deep dish, they have a vast array of other pizzas, sandwiches, and calzones, which will keep everyone in your party happy. Like I said the drink menu is very broad and fairly well-priced.Oh yeah, it's in the heart of down-town Crystal Lake, next to the train tracks, which adds to the ambiance too. Maybe it's just me, but location definitely plays a part in my overall experience.If you're ever out in the suburbs looking for some authentic Chicago deep dish in a great environment with an attentive staff, I strongly suggest Georgio's. Try it, you won't be disappointed.
<review# 1448,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/1/2010,11/22/2010,64,8,2,8,4>As a recent transplant from Rockford, IL to Naperville, I was excited to see that Kuma's was opening a second location here. I have since become a regular. I'm a vegetarian, and Kuma's has a special menu for vegetarians and vegans. There aren't a lot of restaurants out there that do that!My favorite appetizers are the veggie potstickers and the green beans. The potstickers are nice and crisp, yet not too fried. The stuffing is delicious, and I love the tang and zip of the dipping sauce. The green beans are lightly sautéd in a delicious sauce that's kind of a teriyaki with garlic and ginger. Their Pad Thai with tofu is the best I've ever tasted. The tofu is cooked beautifully and the sauce sets off the noodles perfectly. My favorite dish is the Dolsat Bibim bap with tofu. The hot sauce is excellent, I love how the rice at the bottom of the stone crock is crunchy, the tofu is cooked perfectly, and the veggies are fresh and delicious. The interior of the restaurant is a classy blend modern and old fashioned. The original tile floors, tin ceilings, exposed brick, and woodwork are beautiful. The interior is given a modern test with the deep colors on the walls, cool artwork, and the phenomenal bar. It's fun to sit at one of the window seats and people watch as I leisurely eat my fantastic meal.The patio out back is a relaxing retreat, AND it's dog friendly, like much of downtown Naperville I have always received excellent service. The people who work at Kuma's really care about your experience. And Kuma and Fred are almost always there and talk with the customers to make sure everything is going well. They have a lunch club where your sixth lunch is free, a Last Bites promotion with cocktails and appetizers on the weekend, and wine tastings the second Wednesday of every month. Kuma's is an excellent dining experience whether you're there for a casual night on the town, celebrating a birthday or anniversary, or having a romantic meal.

The champagne will flow as long as you keep putting your glass out there. If a Sunday of heavy drinking is your thing, then join the club. And come to brunch with me. I ate and ate and ate. Then i was hungover by 9pm. What a mother's day!!!!!

It's a GO-TO restaurant for us!  Love the food, love the outdoor seating, even the indoor seating is good.  We avoid the bar area since it tends to be full of loud sports-minded folks guzzling beer and throwing popcorn and that's just not our thing... But they always seem to be having a blast so no harm, no foul, LOL.  The bar has Sprecher root beer on tap, how can this place NOT be awesome :)  They also have a great beer and liquor section, the frozen drinks are pretty tasty, and they even have my Hendricks gin, so that gives them an extra few brownie points too.I've had slow service now and then on crazy busy nights, but nothing that I've ever been all that upset about.  It's partly a sports bar, it has ample outdoor seating and really good food, I expect once in a while to have to wait. Like you do at ANY good place. Now some folks have complained about their food, I admit I am a creature of habit and so maybe I just tend towards the best things on their menu but here are my favorites, each of which I've probably had no fewer than 4 or 5 each:  Shrimp po'boy, catfish po'boy, clam chowder, sweet potato fries, cobb salad, fish n chips and the veggie burger.  I know it's a long list but we go there a LOT. I'm a chubby girl, my husband is chubby, we're foodies, nuff said. None of the items I have listed have EVER been less than delicious and fresh.  And I swear I physically CRAVE those awesome po' boys ocasionally.  I can't speak for anything else but that's still a darn good cross-section of their menu.The only things I have ever had there that were just OK are the mac n cheese side, and the chili.  In both cases well, I have a southern family and those 2 things are family recipes that NOONE can beat :)  I have lots of friends who love both of those things but when it comes to country style homemade foods my bar is pretty high.

The gentleman at the desk explained they were a little short-handed that night so he would walk us directly to our theatre now, which was fine with us. My Mom ooh'd and ahh'd at how beautiful the lobby was as we walked through. It seemed a little light, crowd-wise, for a Saturday. We were presented with a menu by our waiter's (yes, we had two, one for my brother and I, the other for my parents) and in short order had received pillows, blankets and ordered our drinks & meals. My parents were both happy with the automated reclining seats and both of them (yes, even my Dad) were content with the quality of all the food. My Dad ordered the Artisan pizza, which (for a change) he said was pretty good, and Mom ordered the lobster rolls and this chocolate dish that had biscotti, brownies, truffles and strawberries. We all ate a little of that and it was REALLY good :)All in all tho, a wonderful time was had by all. I would definitely go again... For another special occasion :) just a WEE bit pricey for a regular night at the movies, but so worth it! :)Honestly, I don't know what stick is up the butt of some of the Yelpers who reviewed this place. It's NICE! The place was clean (even the bathrooms... Which had yummy smelling soap and lotion, if that matters to you, and it does to my Mom so she kept raving about it :) the service was decent and the food was delicious. It was my first time there and I was very pleased. But being polite to the staff, being patient and being positive had a lot to do with my contentment, so take note.
<review# 1457,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/21/2010,11/12/2010,161,158,3,3,4>Recently, the microwave at my work place finally gave its last final breath.  Out of everyone, I am the one who mourns its depart the most because I am that girl who packs a home cooked meal to work everyday.  But this unfortunate event must have been worked by the food gods, telling me that it's time for me to explore the food paths and broaden my horizons.So on a bright and sunny day, I ventured out after having looked up on Yelp for the best Asian/Thai foods (I could always have Thai food) in the area on an iPad (have you check out the Yelp app?? Awesommmeee.)My search query lead me to Bangkok Village.  Then I found my manager is a big fan of this place.  More validation.  So I went there for the $8 lunch specials which will get you a small entre dish, a small appetizer, and a salad.  My manager said they used to give out a soup too but that deal is no longer in.  Never the less, it's still a fair deal for $8 and it's a good chance to have a taste of different appetizers. I ordered my lunch to go.  I tried out the Red Curry (with Chicken).  It came with a little bowl portion of white rice and the curry came in a small cup.  The curry was savory and tasted authentic.  Everything about it was good.  The rice was a bit dry but it's secondary.  I had Crab in the Cup as my appetizer, which came out to look like 2 mini tater-tots.  It wasn't very much for what you expect of an appetizer in an $8 meal but I will say that it was tasty.  I just wish they gave more of it.  Their salad wasn't anything special, just regular lettuce with some carrots. It's the pink sweet sauce that they gave which I'm not sure what I was suppose to eat it with so I poured it into my salad and it tasted great.  Overall, Bangkok Village serves authentic, great tasting food.  Fun fact: they were the 1st Thai restaurant to open in Naperville and have been around for a long time.  Come here for their lunch special to try out more foods.  Expect to pay around $10 and up per order.  I would come here as a treat every now and then and especially on days when the microwave gives out.

I usually go with my mom or mother-in-law, but I even dared to bring my husband, and he got lost in the wine, candy, and coffee sections.  Its not all fu-fu and frilly grandma stuff.  As a matter of fact, make friends with the ladies in the wine section and you can get hammered trying all the wines they advertise.  My favorite part of the Little Traveler is the Atrium Cafe.  I love going to lunch there.  The menu is so simple but so good.  They have the best veggie soup and sandwiches.  The cafe, though small, has a laid back European feel to it, the main difference here is that your food comes in a timely manner.  After years of going to this store, it still cracks me up that they have women and kids that walk around the cafe to model the clothes, purses, and jewelry.  They tell you what they wear, how much it costs, and where you can find it. It is hilarious.Seriously, if you are coming to Geneva what else would you expect from a store? It is the epitome of why people come to a town like Geneva.
<review# 1461,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/4/2010,11/8/2010,363,708,1,11,8>In a teeny store front in an Addison strip mall, there resides.... delicious chicken.OK, it's not JUST chicken. They also have ribs and seafood (perch, cod, scallops, shrimp). And various fried/roasted accouterments. But we got us some chicken, because after all, the name of the place is *Chicken* Manor! So. Yes. The only customer-seen part is a counter, two benches and some magazines, so you can peruse Redbook while awaiting your fried delights. I came away with a dinner that consisted of two breasts and two wings, plus fries, roll and slaw; and added extra fries and a roll to that. Grand total, about $12. I wasn't super-starving, so this was enough for me and the husband, but you can add on additional pieces of chicken (or change up your piece options) pretty easily. The prices are very good, the combinations of various chicken parts are endless, and the people are very friendly.But most importantly? The food is very good. The skin is delightfully crispy and flavorful -- and not very greasy -- and the chicken was juicy and tender. The fries were, well, crinkle fries, but done well. (Next time, broasted potatoes.) No complaints on the roll, the honey is a nice touch.I'll have to try their seafood sometime... in the meantime, I think we have a winner over Brown's and the like. Sorry it took us so long, Chicken Manor. We'll be back.

There are Wizard of Oz, Academy Awards, Egyptian, Cartoon, Chinese Palace, Underwater, and Mayan themed rooms. Now the food isn't as great as some of the higher end dinner & movie experiences. But the fun time and all the cool things to be seen here make up for the food.

<review# 1464,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/2/2010,11/5/2010,30,52,3,6,4>I'm seriously serious - this is the best diner experience I think I've ever had... awesome food (eggs cooked perfectly), flawless service, and I now know what my new favourite hangover cure is - their perfect pancakes.  YUM!My fiancé and I went on a weekday morning at around 11 AM after a few too many sake bombs the night before.  We were sat immediately in one of the 8 or so booths in the diner.  We were served REALLY good coffee immediately (not any of that brown-colored swill that they serve at some diners - this was strong!), and we both ordered breakfasts - Fiance ordered eggs over easy, I ordered mine scrambled.  My fiancé is definitely a connoisseur of hashbrowns, and I am a pancake connoisseur.  We were both totally dazzled by Louie's entire breakfast.  Both of our egg orders were perfect, and the pancakes were light and fluffy and the hashbrowns were crispy but not overdone.  As mentioned above, the service was excellent.  The waitress at Louie's made me feel like she was happy to serve me.  She was friendly and as we were paying our bill, she told us that she was looking forward to seeing us back soon.  I've eaten (and worked) at some fine dining establishments, complete with white tablecloths and polished silverware, that didn't make me feel half as welcome as she did.  Alternatively, I have eaten at some diners that make me feel like I am intruding on some kind of sub-culture, and as an outsider, I am not to be trusted.  This was not the case at Louie's.  Also, their prices are very good - we left a $20 on the table for our two breakfasts, tax, and tip.   However, beware that they only take cash - no credit cards.  I probably gained 5 lbs, but Louie's is definitely proof that diner food is always the cure to a case of the bottle flu. As we were leaving, the waitress told us that Louie's Grill is expanding into the space next door - I believe she said sometime this fall.  My hope is that as they expand, they maintain all the great points of their restaurant... and that they get a credit card machine.  I can't wait to go back and try their patty melt.
<review# 1465,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/10/2010,11/4/2010,4739,1870,15,18,14>Alright friends, if you go to Knead I will personally guarantee you a 5 star time. And if for whatever reason you go and feel that you didn't have a 5 star time, you can just consider yourself excommunicato with this senora. Because unfans of Knead, are unfriends of mine.. prepare for your facebook friend count to drop by one.As of today, May 10th, Twenty-Ten (sounds so futuristic this way), I have found my favorite suburban spot. In fact, it might just be my fave spot regardless of geographic location- scratch that, I meant universal sector (again, more future-tabulous). It was hard to choose from their vast menu, but for me it came down to the freshly sliced apples, gruyere cheese, frisee salad, red onion, the best dijon you could ever imagine, and some fresh as can be bread AKA the Cheese Monger Sandwich. It was probably one of the most delicious things to have ever slipped past (okay, shoved into) my lips. As a person who's lactose intolerant, I can tell you that it was worth every bit of the inevitable stomach ache I will surely get in the next few hours. The BF got the Zen Tuna which consists of seared rare tuna, wasabi-ginger mayo, mesclun, cucumber, and tomatoes on multigrain slices. He wasn't that hungry going in, but managed to scarf the whole thing down in no time flat. In fact, it was the first time in our 6 years of dating where he actually finished all his food, and finished it before me, no less. It was one for the record books, my friends. We also indulged with a couple of phenomenal chai tea lattes and some chocolate fudge-y squares to round out the meal. Let me tell you, it was all to die for. The owners were so very gracious, not to mention super sexy. They were winding the shop down for the day, as they close at 4 most evenings, and gave us a big loaf of bread to take home since they get their bread fresh everyday and couldn't use it any longer. What we also got was a dinner menu to go as they are now open for dinner on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays from 6-10... oh, and they're BYOB, but don't tell anyone else. I don't need any problems arising involving me having to wait for a table.  I'll likely be here every night, so say hi if you see me and get ready to enjoy a 5 star type of meal.
<review# 1466,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/11/2010,11/3/2010,72,33,7,4,5>I wondered, after all of the reviews, if we would encounter smiley or surly Katy....I'd read she likes babies, but my baby (though quite apparent) is not out of the oven yet.  Think she felt "ma-ma-hu-hu" about the in-between stage and was thus kinda sorta nice.  Katy seated us, moving us from one table to the spot she said was coolest.  We dutifully ordered the dan-dan noodles, beef noodle soup, and boiled dumplings.  I love me some spicy food, but don't wanna overdo it now that I'm hugely preggo and have a little guy drinking my meals.  The spiciness was perfect!  Just the slightest perspiration from the chilis and a warm tongue.  The noodles are, as everyone says, amazing.  You can definitely taste the difference and the mouth-feel is absolutely different from the machine-made noodles of everywhere else.  The broths are richly flavored, and the portions are good.  I still prefer the taste of the beef in the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup from that little place in the International Mall a short drive away (theirs are more...pot-roast-like), but these noodles and broth are a win.  Boiled dumplings were good; the dough had a nice toothiness to them and held the flavorful juices that the meat was leaking.  Bought a bag of pork & chive frozen dumplings for home (I firmly believe that every freezer should be stocked with frozen dumplings in case of dumpling emergency)...so cheap!  50 for what was it, $13?  Fantastico.  Can't wait to try them and go back for another noodle adventure with Katy.
<review# 1467,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/7/2010,11/2/2010,176,176,1,6,3>We were pretty much sold on the quality of the restaurant when we first stepped into Wok 'n Fire in St. Charles. The decor was like a something you'd see in a nice downtown Chicago restaurant... but we were in the suburbs!The place was dimly lit, but had an ever-changing color display of lights throughout the restaurant. A large gold Buddha staged in red light is what you see in the entryway. The lounge area is to the left and restaurant to the right. We were seated at a booth (party of 8) by a golden dragon wall piece, again immersed in color-changing lights.Food was excellent (by suburban standards). Two people in our party agreed that the coconut shrimp appetizer was the BEST they have ever tasted and said they could easily come back and order a few rounds of those as their meal. I ordered basil chicken with brown rice (from their wok tossed entrees), which was nicely presented and had great flavor. Their freshly made ginger ale with flavored vodka was great too. I had one with pomegranate and got to try one with vanilla. Both were tasty and refreshing, but not too heavy on the alcohol.I laughed when each person who eventually made a trip to the restrooms came back exclaiming, "You gotta go see the bathrooms. They're beautiful!" I did check out the men's room and, indeed, it was quite nice with round glass sinks, excellent tile work, more colored lights (see a pattern here?). I opted not to take a picture inside the restroom, for obvious reasons.Great place for a nice dinner with a group of friends. A little more on the pricey side, but definitely worth it. The restaurant is on the corner of a modern parking structure near the river, but don't let that fool you. St. Charles is the right town for this classy suburban restaurant and the parking structure just adds to the convenience of your visit.

It was a perfect day to go, the weather was amazing and it was just the right amount of people, not overly crowded. The roast corn was my favorite! $3 for one, but it's definitely worth it because the corn is super sweet and a touch of butter it makes it so much better! *drools* I can eat it everyday, but my arteries might clog (haha). They have various character boards and a huge pumpkin with corn stocks and hay surrounding it to take photos at. They also have an animal zoo, hay ride, and corn stalk maze that you can pay to see, but we decided to pass and enjoy the food and surroundings. Definitely a cute place to take the kids too!

<review# 1473,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/14/2010,10/27/2010,287,787,6,12,8>Eat.Here.Now. Bring an appetite. Chat with the oh so friendly Chef. And taste whatever samples he offers. Trust me. I have a new favorite food and it's name is Cevapi. Thanks to Ericka A for accompanying me to this corner of Naperville. She and Chef got into a discussion about Bosnian food and I learned so much! In between tastes of the Tomato Basil soup (warm, creamy, fresh tomato flavor) and the chicken salad (great flavor and the dressing is rich but not heavy at all) our cevapi cooked away on the grill as the lepijna warmed as well. There's a lot to choose from on the menu--burgers, fish, chicken, grilled veggies and salads and everything is made to order. Do NOT forget the gelato, that is totally worth a bit of a calorie splurge as well (If you're counting calories I mean).  The white hazelnut was tasty, creamy, flavorful. All the gelato is made on site. There are nice picnic tables set up in the shaded area next door which if you're lucky to visit on a nice day, it's a perfect setting to enjoy the great food. The cevapi meat sausages were amazing--very meaty with good flavor--not greasy at all. The meat, topped with onions, garden fresh tomatoes, piled on the warm fluffy lepijna bread was a flavor explosion!  I did bring an appetite (I ordered a side of fries too) but the servings were huge! I could only finish half of the cevapi and we barely put a dent in the fries. The lucky hubs of mine got to enjoy my leftovers at home. The home-made bleu cheese that Chef insisted I have for the fries was so good. He also insisted I taste some of their home-made coleslaw--that was so amazing as well! Like I said, just do what Chef says and you'll be set. I'm coming back for the chicken salad for sure and there's probably more cevapi in my future.

<review# 1475,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/6/2010,10/25/2010,13,12,3,3,3>After hemming and hawing about deciding on where to eat, some friends and I ended up at Red Dragon, which was in perfect walking distance from their apartment. I would probably go back, but I would ask to be seated somewhere else.

Majored in hotel hospitality so learned Japanese in college. Wait a minute...that sounds a lot like the previous owner of Yu's. What did you say? You owned Yu's? NOODLES, please! I forgot how freakin good Yu's noodles are. Chewy, perfectly chewy. kiu kiu as we say in Taiwanese. Best noodles I've ever had and SO different from anywhere else I've ever had. We got the Ping noodle platter (la jao mien) and the Ping Noodle Soup (chow ma mien). I was a little hesitant because I recently came back from New England and had great seafood. It's so easy to over cook shrimp, but they didn't! I was amazed!   Next time we'll have to try some non-noodle dishes. I'm so excited to go back!
<review# 1477,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/10/2010,10/23/2010,70,159,3,4,3>First what it isn't: fancy. Wing Shack is an apt name for this place, it revels in it's dive-iness. Beer selection isn't very comprehensive, I tend to pick a neutral flavor like Blue Moon to go with the wings. As far as wings go, I have yet to have better. They are bigger, crispier and have just enough breading to soak up that wonderful sauce. For me, the garlic wings define heavenly. The base sauce is a no-holds-barred burst of flavors and the pile of garlic bits just take it over the top. These are not wings for those just looking to get a burn, frankly I've had way hotter. The other flavors (they used to only have two, regular and garlic) are well balanced and good but the garlic wings are what keep me coming back. Prepare to reek of garlic for a good 12 hours. The pizza's very good if not outstanding for a neighborhood bar in Palatine while other menu items are just par for the course. Service is down-to-earth and friendly. Seat yourself in front of one of the TVs for game night. Oh, and ask for a Bloody Mary if you want a change of pace. It works surprisingly well with the wings too.
<review# 1478,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/1/2010,10/22/2010,43,217,3,6,3>This place has midwest written allllll over it. If you don't like gigantic perfectly cooked meat, seafood, or classic sides (double baked potato, mashed potatoes, sauteed spinach, asparagus, mushrooms) along with some strong drinks, this place is not for you...and you are not from here.Gibson's takes the Steakhouse and takes it to the next level. Although you will certainly pay for this next level, you will not be disappointed. I first want to point out that I had the pleasure of coming here on Gibson's dime. So I'd just like to say a big Gibson's portion sized THANK YOU for a wonderful experience! The biggest thing that blew me away, however, was that although your staff knew we were dining here for free, they treated us beautifully. I constantly have my meal ruined by servers who feel they do not need to treat you with as much enthusiasm as they would with a guest who was paying full price when I have a discount through work or yelp or otherwise or are eating for free. This always disappoints me. Its almost as if the waitstaff decides they won't be tipped because these cheap bastards aren't paying for their meal. Missed opportunity, my friends, I will tip much much more if I am treated with the full experience I expect to be. Our two waiters were great! They really took care of us and you could tell they enjoyed cracking jokes and talking meat... or at least are very good actors. They added to our experience immensely. We started by getting the Large Lobster Tail to split for our table of 10. Yes, a lobster tail satiated a TABLE OF TEN. They don't mess around with the word large. Lobster isn't my specialty because it isn't my favorite...but the flavor was there, and the big bucket of butter, so no complaints. Next came our entrees (I had to get the Chicago Cut Steak, med rare). Apparently they have this technology that ensures your meat is cooked perfectly to your order? I am not sure what this does or how it works, but all of our steaks were cooked beautifully to our liking. I split this with a coworker, and was not sad that I did so. We ordered several sides to try and I'd recommend above all else the double baked potato (which is saying a lot, I'm a mashed potato girl and I preferred these to our mashed potatoes!), the mushrooms, and the asparagus. The rest of the sides were quite good, but not comparable to these three. As we were all sitting in a food coma, ready to just go home and crawl into bed, they brought us dessert. GIANT carrot cake slice, the biggest strawberry shortcake I've ever seen, and a macadamia nut encrusted turtle sundae pie that made me want to cry tears of happiness. My stomach somehow allowed me to take small pieces of each of these...and thanked me for it. These are definitely not gourmet takes on any of the desserts, but they are crowd pleasing and delish. If you are out with a group and want to top of the evening and impress everyone, order some shots of espresso (who can fit a whole coffee in their tummy after this experience?) and one of any three of these  to split. Absolutely amazing. Their martinis are quite good and all of their drinks are made strong. They have a decent wine selection and I'm a little sad that I did not partake in it. Clearly I could not afford to go here all the time, but if you are a steak lover you have to go at least once. If you have clients you need to love Chicago, Gibson's is the place. I know I will be recommending it to anyone who asks me where THE place for steaks is in the Suburbs.

<review# 1481,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/13/2010,10/19/2010,223,313,3,8,5>One of my favorite non-charcoal all-you-can-eat korean bbq places in the area.  They don't even have marinated short rib (just plain short rib), but still awesome.Open until 4am, karaoke in the back, and other then the bbq, the perfect spot for a morning hangover breakfast.  After a night of drinking, gamja tang (spicy pork bone and potato soup) hits the spot.Now back to the main event: the BBQ.  All the cuts of meat are fresh and meaty.  Even the pork belly slices come out super thick and unfrozen (unlike other places).  All the meat is cooked on a huge cast iron pig shaped dome and my favorite thing to cook on it is their jooh-muh-luk.  Fat cuts of ribeye marinated in sesame oil... like little bites of steak.  There's no need to constantly change the grill and the pan gets seasoned with all the meat you're cooking.  Also towards the end of the meal they bring out huge strips of leafy kimchi and put them around the edges of the pan to cook.  Of course your usual spread of ban chan (side dishes).  Overall good food any time of the day.  Get your meat on.

<review# 1486,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/9/2010,10/14/2010,191,452,3,9,7>The suburbs have done it to me again.Just when I think I've been banished to the land of boring chain restaurants, Prasino comes along and surprises me with its array of deliciously "green" and creative dishes in its minimalist chic space.  Sitting on the banks of the Fox River, Prasino  is truly a welcomed addition to the ever growing downtown St. Charles.Maryum S. and I came in for a weekday lunch.  We were asked if we'd be looking at the breakfast of lunch menu as well (breakfast is served until 2pm daily!).  Prasino is a very vegan, vegetarian, and gluten-free friendly restaurant.  I assumed that since they specifically use organic and local ingredients that their menu would not offer too many choices.  Boy was I wrong!  It wasn't easy choosing between wraps, whole wheat flat bread pizzas, burgers, tacos, pastas, and more.  We had to get our drink on first....especially since it was a 76 degree day in October...refreshments were definitely a must.  Organic chai iced tea ($3.45) for me, served in a sexy curved glass.  Light.  Subtly sweet. Refreshing! On to the food....We both decided on the short rib tacos (3 per order) which were served with our choice of either fresh fruit, garlic potato wedges, organic chips, or the salad of the day.  For a fancy schmancy restaurant, portions here are quite generous.  I enjoyed every layer of my meaty taco.  The short rib was tender, smoky, and still had a crunch here and there to offer.  The guacamole was rich and creamy and the shredded Wisconsin cheddar gave it a great bite!  I barely even used the poblano cream, not that it wasn't delicious, but this taco didn't need any condiment help.   My only complaint would be that the oil from the short ribs did start to pool and by the time I got to my last taco, I was getting a mouthful of short rib oilyness.Justine, our server, was awesome.  Friendly.  Attentive.  Informative.  I asked her if they offered a kids menu and she even gave me the kids menu to take home.  (Kids meals are available for $6). On our way out, we stopped by their cafe area where they sell their very own brand of teas, coffee, oil & vinegar, and even chocolate covered animal crackers.   Chocolate covered animal crackers...need I write more?

I really enjoyed the white sangria - and there are several other types of sangria I'd love to try the next time around. I plan on going back here several times to try out the rest of the menu - I'm obsessed with Cooper's Hawk!

<review# 1490,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/15/2010,10/9/2010,971,2260,4,31,18>If you live in the Western burbs- you know about the Peabody estate as it was always rumored to haunted which entertained kids for generations of ghost stories. Empty for years- it has now been taken over by the park district who is working to restore this lovely old home and grounds. A bit of history. Francis Peabody (the original owner) made his money in coal. And like many well to do Chicagoans, he wanted a country house worthy of a man of his stature. Mayslake is done in the Tudor Revival style and is fashioned after a 15th century house in Warwickshire, England. It originally sat on 848 acres, has 39 rooms and cost a whopping $750,000 to build in 1921. Back in the day- this estate was the site for drag hunts (where a scent is dragged for the hounds to follow but no animals are killed) and elaborate parties for the elite of Chicago. Want a little more Chicago trivia? The firm that designed and built Mayslake (Marshall and Fox) also did the Drake hotel and the Blackstone hotel. So they were well acquainted with the opulence of the time. The really sad news? Peabody finished the house in 1921 but unfortunately died in 1922 (heart attack at a drag hunt) so the house was back on the market for a little under $2 million. They couldn't sell it, so the Franciscans (a Catholic order) bought it two years later for the bargain price of $450,000. Fast forward to today. Much of the land was sold off over the years for subdivisions in the area and in the 90's, the Franciscans wanted to sell the remainder to another developer who was going to tear it down and build 130 new homes. At that point- historians from around the area stepped in and the Du Page Forest Preserve bought the land and buildings for $17.5 million to save the house and restore it to it's original grandeur. The property today is used for weddings and other functions (I attended an art show there recently) The house has a long way to go to be totally renovated but the grand hall is done as is the living room and the chapel that make for a lovely setting. And the prices to rent the space are about half of what you would find at other venues. Plus- you know that your rental is helping to restore the grounds and house. You can also take guided tours of the house and grounds for about $5 (times are posted on their website) The grounds have hiking trails, a dog park, and a large lake that is stocked for people to fish on. There is also a small chapel, and an outdoor stage. I love that this bit of Chicago history was able to be saved. I marvel at the craftsmanship that is evident everywhere you look. And that future generations will also be able to enjoy this snapshot into the way things were back in the early 20th century.
<review# 1491,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/19/2010,10/8/2010,2184,1339,5,9,6>Everyone loves Yu's! And I must admit, I, too, am a fan of the food.Went here last night with some friends. I've been there before on Sundays and definitely didn't expect it to be completely packed still so late-Good for them!Because it was so packed, the parking lot was completely full. There is tons of parking though so it just meant you had to park a bit further in the lot. <review# 1492,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/31/2010,10/7/2010,33,144,5,8,5>Zenwich is one of those rare places that's truly unique.  See, people throw around words like "kinda unique, or really unique, or most unique" but there aren't degrees of uniqueness.  You're either unique or you're not.  Zenwich is unique.And now I've written the word "unique" so many times it doesn't look like a word anymore.Name me another sandwich shop where you can get an entree from nearly every major cuisine style in Asia slapped between two pieces of ciabatta and served with fresh-made, bizarrely but delicious seasoned potato chips.  You probably can't.  But it's not only unique, it's really quite good.  My wife got a chicken satay sandwich, that I sampled and it was great.  I went a little more traditional and got ham and cheese (I missed that there was a Korean barbeque sandwich on the specials board) but they weren't content with just a ham and cheese sandwich.  They added some lovely dijon and garlic mayo that gave it a special flavor.The chips were easily one of the best parts.  They were clearly made right there and were seasoned with some that was once again uni... not like anything else.The people who run the place were also really nice.  They make everything for your sandwich right there and take care to make sure everything is just right.  I always appreciate that sort of thing.So if you want a sandwich but are also interested in trying something out of the ordinary, I can't think of a better place.  So get to it quickly.  This place is new and we don't want to see it fade away so go there.  Now.
<review# 1493,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/2/2010,10/6/2010,50,130,3,4,3>Comparing The Patio to Portillo's is blasphemous and I for one, won't stand for it!The Patio is sleek and modern, with ample, well spaced seating. The menu is large enough that everyone can find something they like. The cashiers are friendly, and the kitchen looks calm and professional. Whereas Portillo's is loud, with tables smashed together, and the kitchen looks like a bunch of misfits clamoring around preparing your gruel.I highly recommend the: ribs. roasted chicken, beef brisket, pulled pork, chicken kabobs and spaghetti. The sides are excellent as well, although my cornbread has been a bit dry in the past. The meat, and really all the ingredients are high quality, and you can taste the difference. I like to grab a beer at the separate bar, then head to my table and wait to be served my mouthwatering BBQ - Not stand in line and wait for my number to be shouted while my soggy chicken sandwich is pushed at me on a lunch tray ahem, Portillos.After devouring my meal, I like to sit back and relax, take in some tv on the nicely mounted teles and sweetly ask my hubby to fetch me a cappuccino from the dessert bar. Sure you can bus your own table, but an attentive busboy always seems to sweep my dishes away before i have the chance. Just in time to dive into my sugar coma while I feel sorry for the poor suckas at Portillos shoving their nasty remnants into an over flowing trash can, then rushing out the door to escape the terrifying lack of ambience.So for about the same price, you can have a truly enjoyable 'fast food' experience with high quality food, solid BBQ prep, and lots of tasty extras, or you can stoop to the lows of Portillo's - it's your call!

<review# 1501,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/4/2010,9/27/2010,50,220,4,4,3>For the "I want something fatty and delicious" cravings, I go to Mickey's. Growing up I would always get a Big Mickey; sometimes my brother and I would pull out the big guns and get a Triple Mickey, sometimes a gyro. Then, our trips to Oak Park became fewer and our love of Mickey's became a faded memory of delicious, calorie-laden food. No fast food type cheeseburger compared to Mickeys, we'd tell our friends, but we couldn't even be sure if that was true since we hadn't had it in so long.On top of being Big Mickey-less in the STL, finding a good gyro joint in St. Louis is harder than convincing an Imo's pizza fan that they must have burned their taste buds off years ago on hot provel cheese b/c Imo's is just that gross. Again, I began to question my memories - was Mickey's burgers and gyros that good or had my longing for the delicious grub skewed my taste buds' recollection? Taste bud redemption occurred when I decided to go to law school in Chicago. When I moved up to the Oak Park area this past year, the first place my brother and I went on move-in day clearly had to be Mickeys.He got a Triple Mickey (well deserved after the move in) and I got a gyro...and a Big Mickey. After stealing a bite of his burger (I was saving mine for later!) and chowing down on my gyro, I realized that memories hadn't failed me. Even if Mickey's isn't the best food in the world, to me the memories of its splendor as a child coupled with the revelation that it tastes JUST AS GOOD now is truly as good as it gets. Thank you for staying delicious all these years, Mickey's.
<review# 1502,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/27/2010,9/26/2010,69,457,,8,3>This restaurant is located in the Shops on Butterfield at the Yorktown shopping center in Lombard.The story is cool- two retired men who were long-time friends and coworkers (with McDonalds) who dreamed of starting a perfect restaurant with delicious burgers- check out the website at tomandeddies.com for more of their story.We were fortunate enough to get to eat at Tom & Eddie's for lunch on their opening day. There was great energy and excitement. The staff were very friendly and helpful and seemed to care about the experience of everyone there. The line was out the door but there seemed to be enough tables inside and outside for everyone. You walk in, stand in line, and order and pay at a counter. I appreciated that you can see your order clearly on a screen so you can verify that it is correct. You get your own drinks, silverware and napkins and then find a table- they have booths and tables and chairs. They have a neat contraption where you put your number in, it registers where you are sitting, and then a button on it where you can request service if you need it. We had to wait a while for our meal but it was fine with us. They had Beatles music playing during our whole lunch which we enjoyed. Their specialty is burgers and they have some traditional and also unique ones, served on gourmet sesame seed, multi-grain or ciabatta rolls. You can also build your own burger from a long list of cheese, condiment and toppings- you are sure to have fun creating your own perfect burger with so many unique (but also traditional) choices. They also have turkey, ahi tuna, and even edamame burgers. They have three chicken sandwiches (I tried the chicken finger sandwich which was really tasty) and also hot dogs. Each sandwich comes with your choice of french fries (skinny), sweet potato fries, homemade potato chips (warm and yummy), haystack onions (we loved these- very seasoned and crisp), soup or a side salad. The price of the sandwich and side ranged from $8.49 to $9.99. They also had creative and delicious looking salads ($9.49 each, served with a breadstick) and soup. They have children's meals too for $4.99.Drinks are $1.99 each- serve your self. They have Coca Cola products but also more unique selections of root beer (awesome), black cherry, orange, and creme soda. They also sell wine and beer- local craft and also domestic- bottles, cans and draft which range in price. They have delicious milkshakes ($3.99) and what we particularly thought was cool is that they come with extra wide straws which make the shakes much easier to enjoy. They have build your own floats, icecream sandwiches and hot fudge sundaes and what look like delicious, fresh baked natural cookies. They use real dishes and silverware, nice thick napkins, and they come and take your dishes for you when you're done. We saw a lot of people taking home leftovers. There was a container in the breezeway that had Tom and Eddie's umbrellas which struck us as thoughtful. They seem to value attention to detail.Tom & Eddie's is a great addition to Lombard and a wonderful casual restaurant for quality food with a warm, friendly atmosphere. I look forward to sharing this restaurant with my friends and family.
<review# 1503,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/22/2009,9/25/2010,61,216,2,2,2>Yanni's has been a favorite of mine for years.  The restaurant itself is always meticulously clean and airy.  If I didn't know better, I'd swear I was sitting in Paradise.  The food itself is very competent.  Every menu item I have tried has been excellent.  Recently, I chose the Grecian chicken which was delightful.  Four pieces of lightly seasoned chicken cooked perfect.  A few potato wedges and a vegetable medley rounded out the dish.  Excellent flavor all around.If I had to list one gripe, it would be the Saganaki.  The Saganaki itself is just fine, but they really should serve it with a warmed pita.  Other than that, it is pretty hard to complain about any aspect of the dining experience at Yanni's.  When I'm looking for a nice night out in a comfortable environment with great food, Yanni's is the place.

Some friends and I made our first trip there last night for dinner and were loving the atmosphere.  Instead of waiting for big round table for our group of 5 we lady-ed up one of the booths with the lover boys across the table in chairs.  A perfect fit!  And the wait on a busy Friday night wasn't bad at all, about 25 minutes for a large group.  There's a gorgeous Natura water jug on every table and it was an awesome idea, not to mention we all wanted to steal it along with everything else in that place.  They have a lot of stuff on sale in the store (even the salt and pepper shakers) but prepare to break your bank on table accessories.  Buy it or don't buy it, this place rocks.  We ordered some drinks - the guys were raving about the organic beers.  The cocktails looked awesome but they weren't as cool on taste.  The mimosa was lukewarm and the Rose Hipster was a little overwhelming going down.  The only thing we were passing around the table was the slice of pear floating in the pear daiquiri - so tender and juicy!  Great drink too.  The food was so much fun.  None of us could decide what to have to we shared 3 different plates and it was like our own mini buffet of awesomeness.  Great food - slightly pricey, but worth it.  I would say no matter what you order you'll be happy and feel good about what you're putting in your body.  We were.  I must say our favorite part was dessert though.  Candice wanted to order the whole dessert menu and we should have!!  We got the molten lava cake and it was gone in seconds *drool*  Best I've EVER had anywhere!!  Same with the Warm Banana Bread.  Both came with amazingly yummy ice cream.  When the waitress came back to take our plates she said "Are you guys sure you don't want to lick the plates?" and I think all of us were like "Wait! Maybe...."  The management and wait staff all went out of their way to make sure we were happy and having a good time.  We were making friends everywhere, Candice with the tattooed waitress, Rob with some of the staff he caught singing and dancing in the back kitchen, and even Sam with the valet!  They were great and made sure to see if we were coming back as we were leaving.  OF COURSE, Prasino, we loved you!!  My advice is to bring friends and try a bunch of yummy stuff.  Parking on a Friday and Saturday night is slightly hellish so look for street parking in front of the restaurant or in the residential area behind.  There's parking in the back too.  Just know that on either days, call and make a reservation and plan to look for parking.Note: I didn't get to check it out but they sell their own coffee as well so check it out and let me know!

<review# 1506,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/24/2010,9/22/2010,44,97,2,8,3>I rarely ever go check out a new place unless I have someone with me for a second opinion. This time my girlfriend and my brother joined me for a weekday all you can eat food coma inducing night of sushi. I am usually weary of the all you can eat tag put on sushi for many different reasons but this was just about as good as it gets.The waitress was very friendly and we received a complimentary bowl of miso soup which is usually the deal and it was good. Then came the rolls. I like to start out with some of the raw ones and move onto the tempura and more spicy rolls later as to not mask some of the delicate flavors in the beginning of the meal. The usual fare of spicy tuna and Philadelphia were very good and not fishy at all. We then moved onto some more interesting ones like the crazy roll and the fire roll. Both were very good with the crazy roll being a definite order. After that the more notable rolls were the rock and roll and the tiger roll - both very good with the rock and roll being a nice light take on a regular roll.By far the most surprising roll was the K.G. roll. At first glance it seemed a bit odd with the tomatoes and a spicy tuna roll. My girlfriend ordered it and it was the shocker of the meal. A perfect balance between very spicy tuna with fresh tomatoes and cooling avocado. The best part of it was the fact that the garnish covered up the rolls completely. It was essentially a small feast in just one roll.A great place to go and try all you can eat sushi with a group of friends. A huge menu so there is no shortage of items for picky eaters. Take my word for it go and check this place out and order the K.G. roll - im not sure what it stands for and I don't care its just that good.

The salad I got was amazing (and I've had salads at places like this and they mess it up), and my boyfriend highly enjoyed his french dip. I believe you have to reserve those quite quickly. I really hope this place stays in business, I know they are affiliated with Wildberry that is next door and Dunhills out in McHenry and they are both doing well, so keep your fingers crossed.

<review# 1510,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/10/2010,9/17/2010,6,91,2,2,2>We decided to walk down to Xni-pec for dinner last night.  We drive past it daily and decided to finally give it a shot.  We thought it was a Mexican restaurant that serves your standard Mexican food (tacos, fajitas, burritos) but it actually is a more of a regional Mexican restaurant that serves dishes from the Yucatan.  You won't find 3 taco dinner or steak fajitas on the menu.  But don't stray away, it's actually a good thing because we got to try some AMAZING dishes.  The menu is smaller, but we picked out the enchiladas placeras and panuchos y salbutes.  I was a bit nervous because I didn't know what to try, but I decided to just pick something random and give it a go.  I'm glad I tried the Panuchos y salbutes - they were delicious and a huge serving!  You got 4 tortillas and a cup of soup.  The tortilla was fried with shredded chicken on it and 2 had red cabbage and beans and the other 2 had red cabbage, tomatoes, and avocado.  It was so flavorful and I thought I would only be able to eat 2 but I ended up eating all 4 of them.  My husband got the enchiladas and he ate all of it up.  The dish came with a chicken leg and he said the flavor was amazing.  The enchiladas themselves were soft and cooked perfectly.  The flavor had a unique flavor - a balance of cheesey, salty, sweet - it's hard to explain, you'll just have to go and try it yourself.  It was so flavorful - by the end all that was left was a empty drumstick on his plate, LOL.  We're definitely going to go back because some of the other dishes on the menu caught my eye and I'm dying to try them.  Oh they also give you a basket of chips with salsa when you get there.  The salsa is extremely fresh and they give you a little dish of habanera sauce on the side which is extremely spicey - but in a good way.  The salsa was pretty spicy too, but we like spicy so it didn't bother us.  We went on a Thursday night and they were featuring dinner and a movie.  There was only 2 other tables there during our dinner so I think they need to spread the word more.  It seems like there are a lot of fans of this restaurant so hopefully they are going and spending money there and telling their friends.  I think the food is pretty good and would hate to see another place in Brookfield shut down.  The service is "okay".  Support your local establishments and give Xni-pec a try!

<review# 1512,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/25/2010,9/15/2010,283,456,7,4,4>ummmmmm...I'm not sure what else I have to say, except- Hello! Portillo's! Only the best hot dog/burger/beef sandwich place on Earth!Portillo's is my basis for comparison for every hot dog, burger, salad and beef sandwich I ever encounter. I can have any of the 4 anywhere else and somehow, I always compare it verbally, or sometimes to myself, to Portillo's.I actually got a salad from Wendy's a few weeks back and I can remember saying- for like a buck more, I could have had a really great frickin' salad from Portillo's, but nooooooo, someone was going to Wendy's from my office and I settled. I'll admit it-- No one can compare (except Gene and Jude's regarding the hot dogs) You can't find a better beef sandwhich- or better yet- a COMBO (Italian beef and sausage) anywhere- I DARE YOU!!Seriously- Chocolate Cake. Try it. You will never enjoy another piece of cake again in your life like you will enjoy cake from Portillo's. Now, I heard a rumor (which I have a tendency to spread) that they put mayo in the mix which is what keeps their cake some moist and delicious. I don't know if it's true or not, but hell, it could be liver juices in the cake, I don't care. It's the best!!If you haven't had a burger or cheeseburger from these guys, give it a shot. They are charbroiled- and not like burger king's "charbroiled"- they are REALLY charbroiled...they are crispy on the edges and not greasy. Get your burger with extra pickles if you are pickle fan. It just makes it better.Try the chopped salad if you haven't already. They just know what the heck they are doing- plain and simple.Service is always with a smile. While, they can't really call themselves "fast food" it's always worth the wait. They have a great ambiance and excellent food. You don't have to be dressed up to go out and have a gourmet meal- Portillo's doesn't judge!
<review# 1513,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/24/2010,9/14/2010,288,304,13,11,10>There was a time in my life when my summers were filled with picnics and rounds of mini golf at Pottawatomie Park. What are they filled with now? Grueling workouts. It so happens that my trainer lives within earshot of Pottawatomie Park. This place that I found so lovely and serene....that I once frollicked and skipped about...is now my own personal jungle gym...filled with blood, sweat and tears. Looking for a good work out? Go run those stairs up the hill, buddy. Oh, what? It's raining? Don't worry...there's a pavillion by the river...that's covered....with LOTS of stairs you can run! Wooopie! What's that you say? You need to concentrate on strength training? Don't worry my friend! There are plenty of trees and posts for you to wrap your resistance band around so that no part of your body will feel neglected during your work out! Seriously, the park is a really great place to work out...weather it be with your trainer, on your bike, by foot or....by paddle boat. The mini golf is great. Most mini golf courses are mega cheesy (but we love it anyhow) but not this one. It's nicely landscaped and there are some very challenging holes (that's what she said...sorry I'm immature and could not resist). Perfect place to spend an afternoon....bring a picnic or grab a bite downtown (a nice little stroll away). Not in a walking moood? Take a ride on the riverboat!A lovely park that's sure to provide you with a lovely afternoon.....unless you are meeting with my trainer. Blood, sweat and tears I say!

I always get the sweet potato fries... and my most favorite side of all the Green Mac... oh soo good.  I want to learn how to make this!!  Everything pretty much comes with the cornbread... which is just yummy.Should u go here... Absolutely!!  If your into bbq's.. then this is the place for you.

<review# 1517,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/7/2010,9/10/2010,32,103,8,10,6>Teeth, hair, and butt...they do it all!I am the proud pa of a very finicky Wheaten Terrier. I tried The Yuppie Puppy thanks to the positive reviews on Yelp (thank you very much) and waited till I had taken him for a few snips before posting my thoughts: I will not take my dog, Beemer, to any other groomer (as long as The Yuppie Puppy is around).My experiences mirror 99% off my fellow Yelpers, with the exception of Karen B's bummer of an experience. Please seriously consider giving 'em another shot.Here's what to expect:-trained groomers (not flunkies from cosmetology school)-"dog people" who understand breeds and the grooming style associated to them-reasonable prices for excellent services (wash, clip, teeth, and butt squeeze for around $65 + tip)-accommodating hours, easy parking, and drop off / pick up.Here's what not to expect: - you won't get a walk in appointment. Give 'em a week (more like two, in the summer) to book your pup.- no lame, gimicky "services" like massages, organic skin rejuvenation treatments (don't laugh, people...you know it's out there).- no bullshit. If you're clear about how you want your dog groomed (or not groomed), you'll get exactly that.

<review# 1519,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/13/2010,9/7/2010,78,342,1,4,2>Yum! I have passed this place 100 times and never would have thought to try it because of how it looks on the outside. When someone clued me in to the fact that they have super authentic Chinese food, and I read some Yelp reviews I had to try it.  We ordered a few things so we could try a variety: won ton soup, eggrolls, homemade spicy sour noodles, crispy duck and a chef special - stir fry beef with cilantro. The service wasn't the best, but I didn't really care - the food was great and if I asked for something, I got it. They did give you a pot of hot tea, which i thoroughly enjoyed. Now for the food - I am an eggroll snob and I usually judge a Chinese restaurant by their eggrolls. These ones weren't great and I wouldn't order them again. But the noodles more than made up for the mediocre eggrolls. They were perfect in every way and I could eat pounds of those noodles and die happy. The soup, which was my husband's favorite was okay to me, but I am not a huge soup person. The duck was great and so was the beef with cilantro but the beef was super spicy. I love spicy food, so when I saw the chili indicator on the menu, I wasn't worried. But this was mouth-on-fire spicy, and I wished that my waiter would have told me that so I could have asked them to put less hot red chilies in it. My only other gripe was that they had a few authentic Chinese desserts on the menu that I was excited to try, but when I asked I was told that they didn't have dessert at this location. There were tons of things I saw on the menu that I want to go back and try including the dim sum, so I will be back.

They also have many brews from here in the States as well. I personally think, that anyone who come in here and orders a Miller Light should be shot on sight. We came here for a family get-together. Since it was raining that day, we were not able to sit outside on their double-decker patio/beer garden (I will have to come back for that alone- nothing makes for better drinking than a comfy outdoor atmosphere.) But they were able to accommodate our party of ten indoors, without a problem. Our server was great, always there with refills, and asking if we needed anything else. As for the aforementioned beer selection, I was a bit overwhelmed. I ended up choosing a Strawberry organic pale ale. It was great, but at $10 a bottle, definitely a sipping brew. The food was pretty decent as well. We started out with some basic nachos for the appetizers. Huge portion, but nothing spectacular. For my main course, I had the Reuben sandwich. Very delicious. And the potato salad I had as my side choice was really good, creamy and made with red potatoes. We also shared some deserts around the table. Also not very memorable. Parking out front of the place may be a little tricky, but if you go around the block, there is a public municipal parking lot about half a block from the place.

<review# 1522,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/2/2010,9/4/2010,213,305,8,8,6>Okay, full disclosure: I originally went inside this place to make fun of it.  I haven't had much luck with boutiques, generally finding them to be filled with ridiculous clothing for super-high prices.  I had planned on browsing around Bella Caley for ten minutes, occasionally picking up an embroidered camisole the size of a tea cosy and rolling my eyes at my boyfriend.  "Can you BELIEVE they want $300 for THIS?" I would hiss.  "I hate Naperville."  Then I would leave in a cloud of blithe self-righteousness.  Oh yes.  No snotty boutique can pull the wool over THIS thrifty girl's eyes, no siree!Except...when I walked in, I was astonished to find that I actually LIKED the place.  I would actually wear a lot of these clothes.  I agree with Juliana E.'s review when she said the clothes were "flouncy" - there are a lot of bows and ruffles.  I mean, not obnoxious-style, but the merchandise is definitely very "feminine" looking.  Lots of sweet dresses, skirts, cardigans, and jackets...probably not everyday wear for me, but these are definitely things I would choose if I wanted to get more dolled up!What shocked me the most was how affordable things were - most (if not all) the items I picked up were under $100!  I even saw a dress as low as $30.  In boutique land, that is crazy talk.I left empty-handed (since I hadn't planned on buying anything) and perhaps a little bit humbler.  Bella Caley taught me an important life lesson that day: never judge a boutique by its cover.  Now that I'm no longer a boutique bigot, I can confidently say that I'll be back to do more shopping!

We waited a bit to be seated, but not to bad considering it was a 'holiday' and they were jam packed with people. Our server was very polite (I would have been so crabby on a day like today if I worked there!) and our drinks arrived pretty quickly. I'm sure it took a little longer than it usually would to get our food - but not unreasonably long considering. I have three young nieces who were there with us. My sister had ordered one steak for the three of them to split. I had really expected the waiter to bring the steak and two extra plates, but when he brought it, he offered to cut it up. I thought this was nice and figured he'd divide it in three and then serve them. A minute later I looked up to see that not only had he cut it into three, but was cutting it up into pieces for them. I felt like this was such an example of great service - that they were so busy and he took the time to do this. The food was all hot and fresh and very good. My husband ordered something that he assumed would come with the Greek peas - it turned out that it did not and when he asked for some they were there within minutes. I had the Maila Angelou pasta - very tasty and highly recommended. Unfortunately we skipped dessert, but next time I'll give it a try for sure.They also provided complimentary valet parking - though I don't know for sure if this is a standard thing or just on days they expect to be so busy.
<review# 1524,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/6/2008,9/2/2010,30,52,4,8,6>GREAT Greek food!  My parents and I went this weekend on our way home from golfing in Glen Ellyn.  We sat outside on the lovely terrace (for lack of a better word).  Their outside seating was clean and surrounded by flowers.  They had tablecloths on the tables and had service people devoted to strictly outside, judging from how attentive they were.  The service was ok - my only complaint was that she took about 13 hours to get the check at the end of our meal, but she did keep our water glasses full and checked back a few times while we were eating.  There was a large group of Greek gentlemen (who were very loud) that were sitting close to us, and I think she got a little distracted with their ouzo requests.The food was OUTSTANDING.  The menu was large but not overwhelming.  They did offer a family style meal, where they brought a choice between some of their basics, but they had such great choices we all ordered our own thing.My family ordered saganaki (flaming cheese) to share as an appetizer, which had a great flavor and was sizzling, as it should be, on the platter it was served on.  I had a classic greek salad, which I had option of topping with a protein (tuna, gyro meat, and chicken, I think) - I elected for the gyro meat option and it came with a LOT of meat.  The salad had a house-made vinegarette on it and a substantial amount of feta cheese, cucumbers, banana peppers, and red onions.  My mom ordered the gyro plate, which looked excellent but came with a very limited amount of pita.  She had a lot of gyro meat on her plate as well and ended up taking some of it home.  The tzatziki was AWESOME.  My dad had a pasta dish, which he let me try, and it had a great flavor.  The pasta was a tad overcooked, but the meat almost had a sweet cinnamon-y flavor to it. In all, I believe the bill was around $40 for the three of us, which I believe is pretty reasonable for the amount of food we had.  It's definitely a repeat!
<review# 1525,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/28/2010,9/1/2010,72,33,2,3,3>I am a frequent breakfaster at Blue Max.  Nothing on the breakfast menu will knock your socks off with inventiveness, but the quality ingredients can't be missed.  Every time I cut into one of their eggs and the deliciously golden orange hue seeps out onto my plate (I'm a sunny side up kinda girl) I say happiness is an orange (not yellow) egg yolk, and not a warm gun.  Well...er...anyway back to the food.  Blue Max's eggs are organic, free range heaven.  I too love that the roasted potatoes have a couple sweet potatoes thrown in, and there are a plethora of brightly colored, just-cooked-enough veggies in most dishes.  It's like my mother is making me breakfast and looking out for my health, plus it's really yummy!  The fruit bowl has always been fantastic; perfectly ripe apples, bananas, strawberries, cantaloupe, honeydew, and pineapple.  Brownie cookies!  You'll be addicted!  Their scones also make me really happy, the raspberry ones especially.  So many places make flavorful yet leaden scones, whereas Blue Max seems to consistently make flaky, light, perfect scones.  The orange juice is freshly squeezed (you can taste it and I've seen them squeezing the oranges on multiple visits), and the drinks in general are good.  I am pregnant now and have somehow lost all taste for coffee (I'd never have imagined such a thing could happen!), but it certainly smells good and they give you giant mugs of it.  I did try it perhaps a year ago and personally found it slightly bitter for my taste, but they have several roasts and options to accomodate seemingly everyone.  The space is cramped for sure, but I'll happily wait for a seat in this homey spot.  Also, the owner is always very nice, which makes me want to continue supporting the place even more.

It was okay, but I probably won't order that dessert again.All in all, Anyway's is a great option to the other chain restaurants on the block. Nice decor, decent lounge / bar area with flat screens TV's all around, separate dining area that's not as loud as the lounge, friendly service, and pretty good food.And seriously, you had me at "cinnamon ice cream".

A lot of my reviews are full of arguments that are so easily agreeable they're pretty much useless. Like, this pizza tasted so much better than that plastic cup I ate for breakfast. Or, the staff at the theatre made the Nazis seem like pure evil. Now reeling this back to legitimate Yelp review talk, it would be VERY easy for me to say Chicks n Salsa rolls its eyes at Chipotle, but it's something I must state considering their proximity to one another. Chipotle is just across Roosevelt, and I don't care that they are both in the 7th Heavenish town of Glen Ellyn, there is NOTHING worth tasting on that side of the street. Here are some useful facts. I ordered 3 vegetable tacos, a side of guac, and an iced tea for ten dollars. I wish it had been cheaper, but I also wish my hair didn't give off the idea that I'd just escaped from an African tribe. The restaurant is as clean as whistle. I felt so bad at the end of my meal that I'd made a mess. I cleaned it up myself. I hate feeling guilty. I can understand how it might be difficult to retrieve your order when your name is called. Lucky for us, it wasn't crowded, but on a busy night, they'll need to raise their voices. Vegetarians will be well fed! Bring your pale, brittle body here and eat with me!Overall, this is my favorite Mexican place around!
