<review# 1531,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/24/2009,8/26/2010,43,121,3,6,3>Kinta Sushi is a great, relatively hidden gem in Carol Stream. They have fresh and innovative sushi rolls, good service and a very relaxed feel to their establishment.I ordered their Sushi and Sashimi Platter which was good but not as filling as I'd thought it'd be (a Naperville competitor spoiled me). The King Kong Roll is a must-have if you visit Kinta. It's a fried concoction of tempura, spicy tuna, spicy mayo and more.The restaurant doesn't have the sprawling meadows openness of most suburban sushi places but a city dweller wouldn't blink twice at the size of Kinta. It's not small; it's comfortable. There are a handful of booths along one wall, a handful of tables along the opposite wall and a sushi bar parallel to the exterior wall. Unless you're inviting all of Carol Stream to perform a census, I think they'll be able to meet your needs.If you're looking to unwind in a relaxed restaurant with good sushi at very reasonable prices, Kinta is your place.
<review# 1532,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/30/2010,8/24/2010,4739,1870,19,22,22>If it's good enough for Tony Kukoc (and Bill Wennington), it's certainly good enough for this little lover of all things Balkan.  Plus, it's a great excuse for me to do my impressive Tony Kukoc impression. Now, you may have already heard of this quaint little grill and deli located just a brisk walk from downtown Naperville since it's pretty much famous on yelp. This teeny tiny little joint has the highest yelper rating of any restaurant in Naperville; it's practically the Hot Doug's of the burbs and I fear that what I'm about to tell you is going to make it not only a contender for the quality of food, but also for the infamous line.Now, before I get too far into this, I should probably give you a little Croatian:101 so you'll have some phrases handy on your visit... because you are SO going to want to visit. Good Day- Dobar dan! (Doe-Bar Don) Please - Molim (Moe-Leem)Thank You - Hvala (Fvah-Lah)Croatia - Hrvatska (Hur-Vot-Skah)Heaven - Cevapi (Cha-Vop- Eee) ... okay, that's not really how you say heaven but it might as well be. Cevapi (also known as cevapcici, depending on region) is a Balkan dish of grilled minced meat. Now say it with me, People. 'Cause it's Cevapi Time in Naperville!Chef Vedad Vrselj is a master of his craft and from the second I walked in and saw Cevapi on the menu, I knew we'd be fast friends. Now, I'm not Croatian and I don't even eat meat but I know when it's time to bow down to the meaty Gods and show some mutha lovin' respect. I made sure to order up 2 orders of the cevapi meal for both my Daddio and my Boyfriend, of whom I vacationed in Croatia with last Summer. While Chef made up my cevapi orders he also grilled me up a veggie salad of epic proportions and fed me innumerable amounts of his favorite non-meaty items while we discussed the good life in Croatia and which islands are best to vacation on, I think we both agreed upon Split, birthplace of NBA great, Tony Kukoc. See how I brought that full circle, folks? Now, I'm pretty sure the faves of the locale are the fresh burgers, the steak sandwich (3 people ordered multiples of them in a span of 5 minutes), and the grilled salmon. I'm sure you'll love and enjoy all of those things but my specific reco is for the cevapi. My Dad, who is not familiar with Croatian eats, came to me the next day to ask what it was he ate and where he could get more because it had been on his mind all day. Also delicious was Chef's vegetarian tomato basil soup of the day. So good that I actually came back the next day to get another quart of it... and of course some more cevapi for my fave men. Oh, and don't forget to get yourself some of Chef's homemade blue cheese dressing (good on EVERYTHING really- it's his pride and joy) and defo don't forget the gelato. I bought a pint of Chef's favorite, the chocolate hazelnut (basically tastes like creamy Nutella goodness) yesterday and a quart of it today, though the blood orange and coconut flavors (with fresh coconut mixed in) were swoon worthy as well. Now, the place is very small. You're basically walking into the kitchen and ordering and the seating is very limited... like 4 people max in the entire place BUT, in the nicer weathered months, they have a gorgeous picnic area with lots of large tables, flowers, and nature to sit out and enjoy your goodies. One other interesting tidbit about Chef's Corner is that Chef gets his veggies from local, organic farmers and in the Summer he uses tomatoes fresh from his own home garden. Upon leaving on my first visit, I made sure to text the good word to all my Croatian hunny bunnies. Soon after I got multiple responses begging me to come back with them to this magical eatery. To that I replied, "Come back? I'm never going to leave." Now I just need to figure out how to get my mail forwarded here.
<review# 1533,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/4/2010,8/23/2010,174,261,1,10,7>So I will share with you my personal tour of the OP area, beginning with the Frank Lloyd Wright Home and Studio, which is probably the main reason you came here.  Definitely check out the house, a tree grows through it and you find out his son invented Lincoln logs, how cool is that?  If you do the walking tour with the cassette you will probably learn all sorts of things I don't know, but if you walk around or ride a bike around at night you can see inside all the cool big houses in the neighborhood that leave their lights on and forget to close their blinds.  ;-)Read a book about Frank before your visit and find out about his poor business practices, not paying his workers etc., makes things a little juicier.  Also note that there's a Robie house nearby, Hemingway's childhood home, a bunch of Gunderson's etc.Ok, now you'll need a car or at least a bike for the next part.  If you head west on Oak Park Ave. you can rent a bike at Oak Park Cyclery.Go west until you go under some railroad tracks, and immediately turn left into the alley that runs parallel to the tracks.  It's like a rugged mountain road, cool eh?  (I know there's a sign that says no thru traffic, but just ignore, it does go through.)Take a right if you make it out of the alley.  Take Oak St. west until you hit Thatcher woods, stop at Trailside if you're into that kind of thing (not part of this tour) and head south to Lake St. on Edgewood Pl., take a right, and another right onto Auvergne Pl..  Snazzy big houses, maybe a few more Wrights back here even.  Don't go any further west though, Maywood is right on the other side of the woods.Turn around and head east on Lake St., take a right under the tracks on Lathrop, and a left onto Hawthorne, heading east now, parallel to the el tracks.  Turn right into the alley after you pass Ashland.  Check out the three story garage with a glass wall that mirrors the back of the house.  Now go around to the front to see a normal looking Cape Cod, the address is 382 Ashland, River Forest.  Crazy!  I just realized you can see it on the Google map thingy.  Never mind the sign that says "no stopping", I think that's meant for me.I would direct you to go around the block at this point to see the mini Statue of Liberty on Lathrop, but it seems someone stole it.  Jerk.Anyhoo, turn around, head back north on Ashland, under the tracks up to the intersection of Iowa and Ashland and dig the lawn on the northwest corner.  906 Ashland River Forest.  It's golf turf.  One time I was standing out front pondering the lawn when the neighbor's kid peddled out to me on his big wheel.  He asked if I was looking at the lawn.  He told me people come over and shampoo the lawn.  Wow.  I went trick or treating there once thinking they'd probably have really good candy, but they didn't.Continue north on Ashland, take a right on Greenfield.  Head east back into Oak Park, cross Harlem, cross Oak Park Ave. until you hit Fair Oaks.  Southeast corner.  It's a house shaped like a spaceship.  It's the kind of mansion Luke Skywalker would eventually build on Tatooine.  Serious.  My friend said a classmate of his lived here and they took a school field trip to see the inside and the beds are built into the walls.  Cool.If you head back south on Fair Oaks I think you see some more mansions, maybe Cheney?  Pass the high school, and you can stop for yummy eats at Tasty Dog.  Or head back to Forest Park to Goldyburgers to get your drink on and a delicious burger.There used to be faces in the cement walls of the el train tracks, but I think they've been stolen so the tour ends here.  I know, it's hard to believe all the attention is on FLW when there's so much more to see!
<review# 1534,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/2/2010,8/22/2010,287,787,5,8,6>I've dined at La Magdalena many, many times over the past years. My husband introduced me to this place several years ago as it's one of his favorites. I think it's partly for nostalgia as its been around so long--he can remember visiting the place with his folks as far back as when he was in junior high. The food is solid and I've never had a bad entree here. It's your basic Mexican restaurant. I've had tacos, enchiladas and the fajitas here on different occasions and it's been very good. Fresh ingredients and great sauces/guacomole. Each table receives a basket of crunchy tortilla chips and very tasty salsa. The salsa has a nice kick to it--to me it has good spicy heat--but if you find it too hot for your liking, you can ask for the milder sauce. Each entree comes with a cup of chicken soup--it's a bit salty for my taste so I usually take a pass on it. Their service is wonderful. Always professional and friendly. Recently, I reserved a section of the restaurant for my husband's surprise birthday dinner party and could not have asked for better service. I visited the restaurant twice before the party to ensure that all was in order. The manager wasn't there when I made my second visit, but the woman I met with knew exactly where my party was going to be and assured me that the servers would be ready for guests to start ordering drinks while they waited for the guest of honor to arrive. They also allowed us to bring in a cake from a bakery for the celebration without any hassle of a "service fee" that some larger establishments might require. This is where the Fernandez Foods restaurants started--La Hacienda and other La Magdalenas are now established in a few other suburbs. This location is smaller than it's sisters, it's kind of quaint, not very flashy but definitely an Addison staple.

<review# 1538,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/16/2010,8/18/2010,18,32,4,7,6>In my neighborhood, it would seem that Italian delis are a dime a dozen...but then you go to Alpine and see that not all Italian delis are created equal.The menu here is short and to the point -- they make sandwiches and a few different types of either pasta or olive salads.  But stop: these aren't your typical subs.  The Bonaccorsi family should receive a Nobel prize for Alpine's meats and cheeses.  Fresh, flavorful, and quite simply, far superior to any other deli I've ever been too.  Coupled with Gonnella bread, their signature "Alpine" sandwich (made with ham, salami, capicollo & provolone) is so good I'm sure it's been requested among some for their final meal.  It may very well be mine.It's a small shop  with shelves stocked full of lots of imported Italian delicacies.  Small area of seating, though the vast majority of their business is locals coming in to pick up a few sandwiches and perhaps a pastry or two.  Although it's almost always packed, these guys have it down to a science -- you won't wait long.  Besides, even if you did, a) it'll give you a minute or two to peruse the shelves of imports, and b) it's one of those few places where any wait is worth it.

<review# 1540,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/10/2010,8/16/2010,273,603,7,12,10>Woo Hoo! I LOVE JAROSCH BAKERY! (I'm thinking about having this tattooed on me somewhere...) My Grandparents lived in Itasca for years and I remember growing up, sitting at their kitchen table, nibbling on the Swedish flop. Everytime someone came by to visit, they seemed to bring something yummy from Jarosch. Ahhh, those were the days. Fast forward to my wedding day, some twenty years later...Jarosch made and delivered my beautiful cake. It was simple and exactly what I asked for. Delicious and perfect. I also surprised my husband with a groom's cake. A stunning Notre Dame themed cake! He was thrilled...we still can't decide whether it tasted better than it looked or looked better than it tasted. It was awesome! Now, over two years later we still visit on a regular basis. The occasional 8" round buttercream cake, melt in your mouth brownies and perfectly crumbly butter cookies round out my favorite treats. My sister and her boyfriend really like the apple strudel best. Important Jarosch Tip: If you want brownies without nuts, be sure to call the day before. They are a special order item. I love the brownies just the way that they make them, but we have a friend that we surprise sometimes with the world's best brownies and need to call ahead and order them without nuts!
<review# 1541,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/8/2010,8/15/2010,26,135,3,11,5>I have been going to the zoo my whole life and love it. If you plan on going more then once a year the membership is worth the cost for the discount and the friend passes. It can get costly to go on an individual basis but here are some ideas to slow the free flow of cash from your pocket. Bring a wagon if going with children, it will hold all of you stuff and an occasional small child. Bring your own drinks and snacks in a cooler. Brookfield Zoo unlike most places that say you can bring your own food actually make it easy. There are tables all over the zoo for your family to use. When I take kids with me I bring drinks, chips and snacks this way they get to buy their "lunch" by getting a sandwich or burger and it's a happy medium. Take the metra instead of parking if you can the BNSF is the train line you want and it's the Hollywood stop NOT the Brookfield stop. The zoo does have souvenirs for a $1 if you buy the plastic mold things instead of t-shirts and other things like that. All and all I love the zoo, and I think a membership is always a great baby shower or other gift.I didn't talk a lot about the animals because I feel like it's a zoo and that is a given.

<review# 1545,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/11/2009,8/10/2010,15,70,,8,2>I've been meaning to try Nickson's Eatery for a while, and am glad that we made it there for dinner tonight. One of my coworkers is friends with the restaurant manager Rich, and recommended that we give Nickson's a try. My wife and I had planned on going here for an adult date night, but at the last minute we decided to take out kids here for dinner and were pleasantly surprised and how family-friendly Nickson's is. The food is pretty good. I had the half roasted chicken with garlic butter and lemon herb sauce. The chicken was juicy and very flavorful. It was served with green beans, and instead of the two cheese mashed potatoes, I substituted the smoky mac and cheese. I ate every last bit of food on my plate, and really enjoyed it. My wife had the Casa Club sandwich: grilled basil chicken with avocado, bacon and corn relish on a pretzel bun. It was a pretty large sandwich - enough to fill up someone for dinner. My 4-year old daughter had chicken fingers and had tater tots, your typical kid food. The menu has lots of items that sound really tasty, and is probably best described as comfort food with a twist. Some of the items I'm excited to try include the Texan brisket tacos, braised beef short ribs, and sourdough breaded pork chop. The quality of the food is really good, and as a result the prices are somewhat higher; not super expensive, but average entrees between $14 and $18. The also have a pretty decent drink menu. My wife had a chocolate martini ($9) which was actually a little more expensive than her sandwich ($8), but she enjoyed both. The only thing that is missing from this place is maybe some additional art on the walls. It's a really nice space - large, open, and it has a very vibrant, lively feel. The restaurant always seems to be full, which is great. I look forward to coming back and trying it again. Keep up the good work Nickson's!

<review# 1547,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/17/2010,8/8/2010,363,708,2,10,5>Mmmmmmmmburgers.As other reviews have mentioned, this is pretty similar to Five Guys. It's sort of the Qdoba versus Chipotle debate -- Meatheads being the Qdoba. Same basic idea, a few more options.The burgers come in three sizes: 1/4 lb ("lil meathead"), 1/3 lb, and 1/2 lb. They're thinner and griddled, with nice edges while still being juicy and just a wee bit pink in the middle. The fries are nice and crispy, a bit thinner than Five Guys', done just right.There are a huge amount of toppings, including many cheeses, veggies galore, bacon, egg, and about seven different sauces. Most are free; cheese & egg are $1, bacon is .75c, as is avocado. Fries come in regular and large -- a large is plenty for 2 people to share -- and cajun and regular. Good to know: they have cajun seasoning on the condiment bar if you want it on the side. They also have malt vinegar, hot sauce, A-1, etc.While it's not dirt cheap, this is good food, considerably better than your average quickie burger joint, made with real ingredients -- a good value for the menu. We got a 1/4 lb and 1/3 lb burger, cheese and bacon on one, and a large fry - about $14 and we left full and happy. (P.S. To really save money? Drink water. Everyone knows soda's prices are jacked up.)And just to ice the cake -- they have temporary cow tattoos! Which, I might add, has lasted over 12 hours now.

So, the best reason to come here is the beer. They have so many, even my very favorite cider beer (Original Sin...try it. It's oh so worth it) that I've only ever found at one other place in the entire Chicagoland area. Servers are pretty relaxed. They don't hover, but they always seem to know when a refill is needed. it's comfortable, but with the hotel attached, sometimes you'll have wedding guests in tuxedos sitting next to a frat boy sporting a "COLLEGE" t-shirt. But it's all good, since they'll both be watching one of many varied sports games on the TVs. (Once, I think a cricket match was on!) Only a block south of the green line Harlem stop, it is seat-yourself, so in case you come here in the winter, please PLEASE don't stand with the door half open as you case the joint!Food is fairly good. I've been here for lunch, dinner, late night snacks, and I have to say that the food is decent, but not fantastic. The buffalo wings are good, although I think the cook is trying to teach the wings how to do the backstroke, as they are literally SWIMMING in a pool of sauce. Scrape half of it off and you'll be set. Also, anything seafood-y smells awesome and is probably a pretty good bet.

Now that should make the work day a whole lot better!

<review# 1561,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/28/2010,7/25/2010,66,101,3,5,3>Sushi, I love you, you are so yummy, Sushi!As you might have noticed, I love Sushi.  I in particular love the Sushi here, in the To Go containers.  It is super fresh, the rolls are large, and it is very affordable.  I've had far worse sushi, and paid much more for it, at sit down places.However, if you show up too late for Sushi (on the weekends, get there early - they run out fast!), the food court is a great option.  I loved my Ramen, but my absolute favorite is the Gabuto Burger.  It is a pork/beef burger, cooked in some sort of asiany sauce.  It then has yummy toppings and more yummy sauce.  The fries were very good and very fresh - you can shake on all sorts of flavors.  Plus, they take credit cards, unlike the rest of the food court.Once you've eaten, you can explore the rest.  The Japanese bookstore is a gold mine of knitting, quilting, crocheting, and needlepoint books.  Japanese patterns are generally all charted out with illustrations, so not knowing Japanese isn't a huge hurdle.  I love the market, although my friend usually has to drag me through, otherwise I'd stay there forever, buying odd things that I don't know what to do with.  And the bakery - oh, so good.Last, and not least, there is a little china/dishware store tucked in behind the food court.  They have beautiful japanese dishes at very affordable prices.  So, go!  Really.  Right now.  You won't regret it.
<review# 1562,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/21/2010,7/24/2010,101,102,5,11,7>A nice out-of-the-way dive bar.A nice quiet place to get away from the regular hubub of the bars on Madison street. It's a charming little place, less than a block from Goldie Burgers and only two blocks from the Harlem stop of the green line.Local author Stephanie Kuehnert tends bar a few nights a week and it has the best outdoor seating area since Horan's shut down. The only downsides are the patio closes at midnight (completely reasonable, since it abuts some private residences) and the music is sometimes too loud to hold any kind of conversation.Parking is on the street but because this place isn't drawing the crowds it's usually not a problem.The tables are attached to the walls and only seat four each. It's not great for groups that would want to put together a bunch of tables and sit together. It's ok for groups on the go like pub crawls or groups that don't need to sit all at the same group of tables like dart tournaments. There are a few dart boards in the back and they're usually open. The short tables are just small enough to be cozy but not so small as to be a problem. Ladies with large purses, put them on the rail on the wall to save table space. I am not usually this obsessed with tables. Promise.
<review# 1563,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/19/2010,7/23/2010,142,340,5,4,2>YUM! So I'm going to admit two things up front: (1) I am NOT a picky or even remotely discerning eater, particularly when it comes to something I love as much as Thai food. If it's a Thai restaurant, I will eat there and enjoy it unless they slather my food with peanut sauce, to which I'm deathly allergic.(2) Lately I've been boring about what I order, so keep in mind that I can only speak for their potstickers and crab rangoon.I'm definitely a fan of this place - it's a sit-down restaurant with low-priced Thai that comes in big portions (I always take half my meal home). Each time I've eaten here, the service has been efficient and they wrap up leftovers really neatly (including the sauces). Also, before I leave they give me a refill on my Diet Coke in a plastic cup with a lid, so that I can keep sipping as I'm out shopping. Thoughtful!
<review# 1564,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/2/2010,7/22/2010,172,208,5,12,6>Don't let the name fool you.  This place is about 80% Filipino restaurant, and 20% Chinese.  I lived in Glendale Heights a long time ago, and this is when I first discovered this place.  I have often wondered why Filipino cuisine has never found a niche the way Chinese, Japanese, and even Korean cuisine has.  I have gotten in arguments and debates about how our food is not easily presentable, and many of our dishes require an acquired taste.It really is a shame, because I think we have some very good dishes. This restaurant is not going to win you over with its décor, or its ambiance, but with its food.  I don't know how they do it, but they crank out the dishes rather quickly from the tiny kitchen in the back.  You can hear pots clanking, and food frying, and orders being yelled out.  Maybe they just throw everything in a magical turbo broiler, and it comes out magically delicious.My favorites are the Sininang na Baboy (Pork tamarind soup), lechon kawali (deep fried pork belly), and ampalaya con carne (beef sauteed in black bean sauce w/ bittermelon).  The most famous Filipino dishes are probably Pancit (rice noodles), and lumpia shanghai (mini pork egg rolls), which I also love.  The service can be better at times, but I can't say I ever received bad service here.I would love for them to redecorate the place, as the pictures of roosters, and lechon are tacky and outdated.  I mean these pics came straight from someones digital camera, trust me you can tell.  Just a small suggestion, but I can overlook that since the food is delicious. This is the place to go in the suburbs when I have the hunger pangs for some serious Filipino cooking.

<review# 1566,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/3/2010,7/20/2010,30,73,4,4,3>I have been sitting here at my keyboard for hours, up all night, trying to figure out whether or not to give this jewish deli 3 or 4 stars. I consider myself a 'glass of everclear half full' kind of guy, so I will go with 4. First impressions were generally good, although this place does walk a fine line between authentic and trying too hard. The counter people were very friendly, and the menu is presented in a way that allows you to take your time looking w/out being in the way. It being my first time, I had the classic corn-beef, over-stuffed. The over-stuffed was filling, but do not be intimidated. It was big(ish), but not carnegie deli big. It was large, but no larger then most places. The meat was good, although a bit fatty in sections. The sandwich was satisfying, probably 3 stars, but the overall experience is bumped up to 4 stars due to the awesome black and white cookie I had, and the free chocolate chip cookie the staff gave to my 14 month old daughter. I will be back, and this time I will be more adventurous in my ordering. I may get pastrami. I am such a rebel.
<review# 1567,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/8/2010,7/19/2010,161,158,1,2,1>A review of my first encounter with the great Gong...First, we had a late dinner (9pm) so I expected the foods to not be that warm and fresh when it came out.  It was quite the opposite, despite the late hours, they brought out piping hot dishes.  Second, the price is a bargain here.  Their hot & sour soup was only $1.95 so I thought that it would be the size of a tiny little saucer.  My friend and I ordered 2 bowls thinking we won't have enough to share.  It turns out, the soup was in a huge bowl! By the time I finished the soup (which was hot and good though not as spicy and sour as I have had at other places), I was half full already.  It was worth the pocket change. We also got 2 egg rolls (under $3) and they were big and decent.  Then, our 2 entrees came out: sesame chicken w/ fresh, green and crunchy broccoli.  I love it when they don't overcook the veggies in Asian dishes.  The fried rice was good too, it had actual, big & multiple whole shrimp (not pieces- shocker!), pineapple, scallop, and imitation crab.  It wasn't too oily and the rice was soft unlike some other places'. Service-wise, they were decent. It wasn't like first class waiters in tux kind of thing.  Just your average family restaurant kind of service.  They might clank some dishes or toss soy sauce bottles on your table when they come by.  Our guy was really good on refilling our water glass which is the key thing anyways. Overall, our bill of two came out to be around $24 and that included, 2 soups, eggroll dish, 2 entres, and 2 complimentary almond cookies and 2 fortune cookies.  Not a bad deal. I would visit again!

I cant think of a negative thing to say about this shop and it's staff.

My fiance tried the vegan french toast stuffed with orange cream cheese. There are no words to express how delicious this was, you just have to try it. Vegan or not, it tastes like the most decadent french toast and you can feel, somewhat, good about eating it. When the two of us went there today for brunch, I decided to try the Caprese Eggs Benedict, which I thought would be an odd combination with the mozzarella, basil, tomato and poached egg on english muffin and hollandaise. It was a genius combination! I would definitely get this dish again and recommend it to the those who love the traditional eggs benedict. I, hands down, thoroughly enjoy myself at Prasino every time I go. The next time I have brunch there, I WILL try their signature bloody mary infused with horseradish vodka...yum!
<review# 1570,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/10/2010,7/16/2010,311,157,2,6,4>I love that this place looks like absolutely nothing from the outside, and is downright hidden. Then you walk inside and it feels like a real Cantonese place in China, with the tables further apart.Rock star sized portions and authentic Cantonese flavors reign supreme here. Tofu: yum.Scallion pancake: deliciousSesame beef: I've had better, but not badSweet and sour shrimp: fantastic.The service here is friendly and fast, and this place is not for the person on a salt diet. My only real problem with this place is that they have a tendency to make assumptions about westerners that are not valid: like that I want a fork and not chopsticks. This has happened both times I went. I'd like to be asked that question, not just presented with a non-Asian utensil. Also, they have a tendency to take sauces away from the table prematurely. This is a pet peeve of mine.That said, they are delicious, reasonably priced, and I will be back here often with my friends. Try to find it it's worth the treasure hunt.

Sounds like a deal to me!Overall, you can't go wrong with VinoThai unless you are in a hurry.

Cascade does have a little park up front for your kiddos and they provide grills now in that same area. Car stereo speakers are there for your convenience or you can tune in your own car radio. <review# 1574,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/21/2010,7/11/2010,26,65,4,8,5>Had I reviewed this animal hospital last year, I would have given it four stars.  This year, however, they've improved on the  few little gripes I had with it, and now I give it five.I swear, I collect faulty animals like a kid collects toys.  I have a dog who has stomach problems in reaction to any kibble on the market, a cat who pees on everything when he's stressed, and another cat who had disturbing stomach conditions when he ate kibble.Well, I took them all off manufactured pet food, and all the problems stopped.Last year, when I went in, the vets seemed very distraught at my choice of foods.  One of them said, "Your cat has a superior coat.  And his teeth are excellent.  But, I really would feel more comfortable if you switched them back to kibbles."  Being the polite little kibble rebel that I am, I said I understood the concern, but I wasn't changing.When my dog's stomach problems abated  on a cooked and raw diet, I was instructed to try to ease him back to kibble.  I didn't do that either.At any rate, I was in for the shock of my life when I took my dog in this year and two different vets said he was in excellent shape, had great teeth, was toned, etc, and when asked what I fed him, they not only said I was doing a good job, but they suggested ways to round out his diet with some different real foods (not doggie foods).  And then, I got their circular magazine in the mail, and in an article about dog foods and selecting the correct ones, it listed home-made foods as a viable and healthy option.  I almost fell off my chair.From what I gather in my conversations with one of the vets, they either had a holistic vet come in and work with them, or they now have a holistic vet on staff, or they were trained in some holistic medicines at a conference.  No idea, but they have definitely opened their minds to holistic medicine.  When my dog hurt his paw, they gave him a homeopathic pain medication as opposed to a stronger regular one that might have upset his (delicate) tummy.Holistic stuff aside, the staff has always been very nice and very helpful.  When my dog was a pup and had stomach issues, I saw his same vet, Dr. Ruebendall (sp??) over and over, and she never acted like I was being a pain in the rear.  She was nice enough to answer my relentless questions and she gave me options without pushing the most expensive ones.  When my dog had something that appeared to be seizures, she gave me the number to a neurology clinic but suggested other options as well for his treatment.  (In case you are holding on to the edge of your seat, breathless to know what happened, they were not seizures. They were panic attacks from having been attacked by other dogs).  I went to the neurology clinic and it was an excellent recommendation.  Props for referring me to a good place!Dr. Lancaster, too, has worked with my cats and my dog, and my dog loves him.  Dr. L makes a point of answering all questions and gave me some good suggestions and advice for dealing with my hyper, neurotic herding dog.Wheaton Animal Hospital is a non-appointment clinic (except for surgeries, of course...gotta schedule those).  You walk in, and you check in, and you wait.  On Saturdays and weekday evenings, you might wait and wait and wait.  So, I tend to go in on weekday mornings if possible.  If your pet is really in bad shape, though, you do go to the front of the "line."Vets are nice, and the rest of the staff is very nice and caring as well.  The hospital is clean, and the waiting room is big and bright and has magazines.  As an added side note,  I worked at this animal hospital as a teenager, under different management.  It was not all that great then.  It's soooo much better now.  Way more professional.  Great job to the new management!

<review# 1576,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/28/2009,7/8/2010,39,47,3,12,7>If I could give 4 1/2 stars, I would. When it comes to sushi I've been to all the greats ...at least in North America and Hawaii as well as a number of places around the world including Tokyo and I have to say food-wise this place is right up at the top in nearly all regards ...flavor, display, variety, creativity, non sushi dishes... Without question, this is the best sushi place within a 20 mile radius. The closest even worthy opponent being Wild Fish in Arlington Heights.  Personally Kaminari is my Chicago-land favorite. So why the hedge and only four stars? Kaminari has one of the worst possible locations - behind a gas station next to a convenience store in an area not considered a town destination - and in the suburb how can this not affect patronage? The answer is it likely does and I've seen the affects over the years ... the once awesome dessert menu changed to items that keep longer and still are not often on hand, service can be a bit off -inexperienced, the surprisingly hip and swank decor could now definitely use some maintenance, and food quality for a stint had been a bit inconsistent though not of late, BOTTOM LINE: this aside, if you like sushi this place should absolutely be on your list of places to check out. It became the favorite of nearly everyone I've brought there. RECOMMENDATIONS: ***definitely*** try the Spicy Tuna Sushi Bombs. Better yet ask for them to be lightly pan fried in soy oil and butter; a tribute to a well-known dish at the even better known Katsuya in LA. Other highly recommended unique favorites: Hugo Roll, Shrek Roll, California Roll (not so unique but made with real crab -"the perfect" California Roll) , and the Ika Sansai salad,.

<review# 1579,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/14/2010,7/5/2010,123,413,1,5,3>I was in desperate need of a pub for the World Cup match with the US. vs. England. I had called every Irish pub/bar in the area. Believe it or not, no one really had any specials running for the day (or no one was willing to take the time to explain them). Then I called Quigley's and not only had WC specials but the manager (I believe his name was Chris) took the time to explain everything that was occurring during the tournament. That alone, made my decision for me. I knew where my ass would be come Saturday. Believe it or not, this was the first time I've ever been to a pub for breakfast. I was hoping to score the Irish breakfast, but at 8:30 in the morning there was only a limited menu available. Why was I there at 8:30 for a 1:30pm game? Because the place was almost filled by 9:30. Who knew people in America love soccer. I went with the corned beef hash and eggs. The hash was good but the eggs were a little runny. I could've ordered a pint at this point but c'mon I had to drive at some point. By noon time, we were ready for lunch. A Guinness BBQ burger and a pint of ol' Guinness was in order for me. The burger was really good and it was cooked just the way I wanted it. The Guinness was poured correctly and the crowd/atmosphere was awesome. Top that off with great service from the waitress and it was a blast for Saturday morning and afternoon. I have found a great pub for my World Cup viewing. After the tournament, I know I will be coming back here again as well.

<review# 1581,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/28/2009,7/3/2010,213,305,9,8,7>How did I get to age twenty-four without ever trying an Indian buffet?  Crazy, especially because I really like Indian food!  Whatevs, today was my first time, and Cuisine of India made me SO GLAD THAT I WAITED.My boyfriend and I went for lunch today, and I was craving some Chicken Tikka Masala.  Alas, the buffet was sans Chicken Tikka Masala today (prob because the management knows that fatties like me would eat it all).  I considered just ordering it off the menu, but everything in the buffet looked so good, and shouldn't I switch things up a little?  Good thing I did, or I wouldn't have had the big, crispy samosas, the rich, tasty Chicken Makhani, and the aromatic Rogan Josh (which I'd never had before!).  My boyfriend tried the Chilli Chicken, which was good, but incredibly spicy - my stuff was spicy too, but not too bad.  Oh, and did I mention that soup, naan, and Chicken Tikka were brought to our table?  Niiiiice.And the dessert was pretty great as well - the Gulab Jamun (cheesy donut-like balls in a sweet syrup) and Mango Kulfi (thick mango ice cream) were my favorites.  Shit, if I'd have known dessert was gonna be that good, I would have saved more room!  They also had Kheer, but I didn't take much since rice pudding isn't really my thing.  All of this for $9.95.  Yes, please.  The service was swift and sweet, and my water glass was never empty (a matter of vital importance when eating Indian food).  Marry me, Cuisine of India.  Marry me.

<review# 1584,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/2/2010,6/30/2010,43,217,4,7,4>I've back spaced a million times while trying to avoid sounding like a snob. I guess this is the best way to put it. There are two types of Italian places (and I like them both, usually) - you have your American Italian places, that aren't actually Italian at all, but rather an adaptation on the classics, and then there are actual Italian Restaurants (yeah, okay, I definitely prefer these). If you haven't figured it out, Lucca's gets 5 stars because they are one of the few actual Italian Restaurants. I'll start with the pizza just to get that out of the way, as it is called Lucca's Pizzeria. Delish! Authentic thin, crispy crust with fresh toppings. Simple and yummy. I opted for the pasta. The portion was huge, but I couldn't stop eating it! Again, fresh and simple like a good Italian dish should be. Splitting a bottle of wine left me a little wobbly on the way out, but again, definitely not sad. They had a wonderful wine list and getting a bottle was the only solution. The best part of all of this is that it is not snobby. No, not in the least. It is probably the smallest sit-down restaurant I have ever been to, but it was comfortable, cozy, and well done. I would definitely go here on a date or with some friends. It is not pretentious or overpriced, but still manages to be nice and upscale. I would suggest calling ahead. The staff is very understanding of their limited seating and will give you a fair interpretation of how long a wait might be for you. The girl I talked to on the phone was super nice and very honest. She said they had several tables at the moment, but would guaranteed be full within the hour. I showed up as fast as I could as the other 3 people in my party didn't seem to believe my claims about the limited seating, but when we showed up 45 minutes later, we were just able to snag the last table. I could see seating being a trouble sometimes, but I would not mind waiting around to be seated here at all.I don't think I can afford to go back to Italy any time soon, so for now I will stick close to places that can actually get it right. Lucca's definitely gets it right.

<review# 1586,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/12/2010,6/28/2010,77,41,4,6,3>Chai Yo stands in the former space of Rosita's Mexican restaurant - one of my all-time favorite Mexican places. Sadly, near the peak of the recession, Rosita's said "Cerrados". It was a rough and tumble space, but the grub quality was strong. Chai Yo jumped on the space, and I am very happy to say that I have another quality Thai joint within 5 minutes from my abode. Chai Yo is a family business, and the proprietors represent how to give great customer service. They greet you with a smile, as well as a wave from the kitchen. BYOB is not readily available here, but CYT has a great wine and beer selection. I don't mind paying up for drinks because I enjoy the service here, as well as the food. Start with CYT's Tom Yum soup. The Thai version of hot n' sour soup is great - good kicks of vinegar and peppers will be keeping you reaching for a tasty Sing-ha lager to cool down. I'm a fiery hot green curry guy - and I highly recommend it with squid. Solid, not too thick, and the squid is freshly prepared. It's a nice flavor contrast, and, of course, you can vary your spice amount. If you want it sizzlin', get it "Thai Spicy". Finished the meal with sticky rice with mango, a great dish to cool you down after a nice chow. Again, I emphasize the customer service. It's the tipping point to make me a solid fan of Chai Yo. I'll be back soon.

Credit cards are not accepted, but there is an ATM near the entry with a $60 cash limit.Nice little restaurant on North Avenue in West Chicago (the far west suburb) with good service and a friendly staff. The interior has a country feel to it and seats about 80 to 90 customers. The parking lot is small and may accommodate about 30 cars. I took a chance on going on a late Sunday morning, right before noon, and managed to be seated right away (table for two) in the already-full restaurant.I chose this restaurant for the pancakes, of course. I asked my server, who happened to be Rick the owner, if he'd recommend the blueberry pancakes or the cinnamon raisin pancakes. He suggested one cinnamon raisin and two blueberry pancakes so that I could try both. So that's what I ordered, and a side of bacon too. Both types of pancakes had the fruit mixed into the batter and tasted pretty good. Hot blueberries in the pancakes and hot blueberry compote made those pancakes even better.Three types of syrup were on the table: Maple, Strawberry and Boysenberry. After having the standard maple syrup on my cinnamon raisin pancakes, I tried the boysenberry syrup on the second half of my blueberry pancakes and immediately fell in love with the flavor. Good stuff. Boysenberry... I'm coming back for more!The grapefruit juice I ordered with my breakfast was excellent. I had to ask my server what brand of juice it was, simply because it was some of the best tasting grapefruit juice I've ever had. Not too tart, right amount of sweetness and hardly any pulp at all. He said their supplier is in Florida and guarantees fresh squeezed juice shipped within 3 to 4 days of juicing. It was really good and I'll probably try the fresh squeezed orange juice next time.I've really only been to the Olde North Pancake House for breakfast, but their menu has a lunch and dinner section too. A sign outside the restaurant notes their Friday Night Fish Fry special. I also saw a sign inside the restaurant noting an upcoming date when they will be serving pumpkin pancakes. So I guess it's hit or miss when pumpkin pancakes are available, but I definitely want to try those. Yes, I'll be back!

<review# 1589,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/3/2010,6/25/2010,83,281,3,4,3>Sushi at your selection and price point all on the convenience of it being delivered on a nonstop conveyor belt, who could ask for anything more? This place was great in terms of concept and atmosphere. As soon as we walked in the workers cheered as if they were happy for more customers. It wasn't only because we were so dashingly good looking, they did it for everyone. Contrary to some other reviews, the restaurant was not jam packed. We were sat right away right on the bar next to some other sushi-loving patrons. Seeing California Rolls and Cream Puffs come strolling by via conveyor was something I thought I'd be against, but it was really cool to choose what I ate by price per plate. Simply open the window as the plate comes by, pull it out, eat it up and stack your plates as you go. When you're finished a nearby server adds up the total and you pay up front. How easy is that? No one bothered us, they were around if we needed anything and we ate a whole lot for a small price tag, as it pertains to sushi. The thing to note is - the sushi isn't the best. It's alright, but you have no idea how long it's been going round and round on the belt. Has it been there 10 minutes or 10 hours? I don't know. People are constantly making new sushi behind the counter. The overall feeling is, you get what you pay for. We wanted a casual, easy-to-eat, enjoyable experience for a good price and that's exactly what we received. Decent sushi in a unique way at a great price. I plan to go back often and bring new people each time I go so they too can enjoy sushi strolling on by on a conveyor belt.

<review# 1593,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/11/2010,6/20/2010,287,787,9,7,6>My Dad is a huge fan of this place, My Mom says it's not worth it. Lets let the daughter decide who is right! My husband is the one that actually introduced me to Vietnamese food years ago so he's always looking for a good bowl of Pho or Bun. We shared the following order: fresh spring-rolls, Bun--rice noodles with fresh cilantro, shredded cucumber, bean sprouts and choice of meat--we chose pork and fried spring-rolls and a bowl of steamy Pho--beef broth and rice noodles--we chose meatballs for this one. The appetizer spring-rolls were pretty good. Fresh shrimp, pork, rice vermicelli and vegetables. The rice paper wrapper was a little bit chewy but the rolls didn't fall apart when you bit into it--to me,a mark of a perfectly rolled springrolll! The Bun was tasty too--the pork was tender and very flavorful and the pieces of fried spring-roll added a nice crunch. The noodles were cooked perfectly and the sweet fish sauce you can add to it added a bit of sweet/salt. The Pho was wonderful--this was my favorite. Served with the usual items on the side--bean sprouts, jalapeno pepper, basil. The broth was clear and fragrant. The rice vermicelli was cooked perfectly and not overdone. The meatballs were tasty--they're not your italian style meatballs, these are chewy, kind of spongy--really meaty. The portions are huge--we couldn't finish our meal. Service was good--friendly and attentive. It's a small place--nothing special about the decor. Chopsticks and soup spoons are already on the table along with the different sauces you might need. The only thing I'd take a pass at next time is the Vietnamese coffee. It was not very tasty. But the coconut bubble drink we took to-go definitely made up for it. So to wrap up, I think my Dad wins this round. Sorry Mom! We'll be back here for sure!

The nachos (chicken or pork) are the greatest nachos on planet earth and I often just get as a meal to myself. Gabe has a nice selection of hot sauces always available to go with them if you're into that kind of thing. They have various soups of the day but my personal favorite is the cream of mushroom. WOW, different than most mushroom soups but it is great. As far as the main course goes there is quite a bit to choose from and I pretty much like it all. Highlights for me would be the pizza (its great with feta), the meat loaf, the pulled pork (I like to get this with extra BBQ, and the various tap house burgers. Everything always just tastes incredibly fresh and I think they use mostly organic ingredients.The beer:Personally I don't have a visit to 2 Bros. without having a Cain & Ebel. Very original in style and taste and it simply great. Hoppy but not too hoppy, sweet but not too sweet, and plenty of kick to it while going down smoothly. (if you come for a tour you can try 3 for free) Out of their seasonals I'm partial to their Heavy (and Heavier) Handed, Hop Juice, Northwind Imperial Stout, Outlaw IPA, and Red Eye Porter. Their guests beer selection is very good too. (both domestic craft as well as imported) The staff is very good at suggesting different beers per your tastes. Most often when having the guest beers I end up either drinking Ska Modus Hoperandi or something from Green Flash Brewing.The staff:I love the staff there. They've really helped me find great beers and also find great things on the menu. We've become such regulars that they've even contacted us to reserve us spots for special events and things like that. Gabe the manager is always very helpful and accommodating of whatever requests we've been able to come up with. Even with the great food and beer its the staff that really keeps us coming back so often.The atmosphere:Personally this is my kind of place. No neon Miller signs everywhere or Nascar banners. If you're looking for a sports bar keep looking (though they do have sports on the TVs in the bar area). This is a different kind of experience. Very casual and fun and almost every time we sit at the bar we strike up a conversation with some strangers. Its very open and friendly and I very much like the crowd that frequents the place. Ages of folks there can vary from 0 to 100 depending on the day or the hour.Bottom line is they've gotten it all right here: food, beer, service, and atmosphere.

<review# 1600,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/3/2010,6/13/2010,43,121,6,9,4>Sushi Mono gives the north side of Wheaton a nice Japanese restaurant with decent prices.Their focus is definitely on sushi. Most of their menu consists of maki, nigiri and sashimi. They don't have bento boxes and their kitchen entrees aren't distinctly Japanese (ie. filet mignon or lobster soaked in butter).But if you're interested in going to town on some sushi, you've come to the right spot. They offer various sushi combinations: the one I opted for allowed me to pick two classic makis and one special roll. I choose California, Soft Shell Crab and their King Kong roll (fried spicy tuna, crab and shrimp tempura with unagi sauce). I then entered a copacetic sushi coma for a relatively competitive price of $25.The sushi was well-prepared and tasted fresh. I was also very impressed with the presentation on all of my party's dishes.The few downsides I saw was that they were very stingy on their miso soup. It was served in what seemed like a little girl's doll bowl. You may be able to get a larger serving if you used a dental cup. The other was their hours: a group of us went for a weekday dinner. We were having a good time but they close up right at 9:00 PM. I know Wheaton residents slink back into their homes and/or churches at 4:00 in the afternoon but a 9:00 curfew is pretty brutal for normal people, especially if you're having fun.Other than that, this place is great. The decor is classy and modern. Add that to good sushi and you can't complain too much. I'm just glad that I won't have to travel to Naperville or Carol Stream every time for my sushi fix.
<review# 1601,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/14/2010,6/12/2010,49,309,4,6,4>This place is a great place for dinner with friends--fancy style. It's a romantic place for couples, but when ordering tapas, I feel that life is so much richer when shared with friends (and your love).We went with two friends on a Wednesday evening and sat in the room on the right. It's a converted home/mansion and is really elegant. There were plenty of people there for a Wednesday! It was recommended by our friends who had previously been there.The exterior was full of gardens and a ballroom looking structure. It's obvious that the place is used a lot for weddings and other events. If I were getting married (again, that'll never happen... best husband ever!), I'd absolutely look into having my reception at this gorgeous location.The sangria were a bit weak. The fruit was small and I wouldn't consider it to be the best I've experienced... though I didn't even order one. They bought a pitcher for the table, but I only ate the tiny slivers of fruit from my husband's glass. The tapas were awesome. I think the amount was reasonable. We ordered about 2 tapas per person... about 1 cold and one hot. I also had the gazpacho which was excellent. I'm a vegetarian, so I had the spicy potatoes (hot), grilled vegetables + asparagus (cold) and the meat eaters had a variety of other items including a Spanish cheese/fruit plate. Overall, we were really pleased and content at the end of our meal. It's nice eating slowly as you go... that super full sensation just doesn't exist!I'd highly recommend this place. I'm excited to go back in a few months.

<review# 1603,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/10/2010,6/10/2010,58,191,4,5,4>I was here this past weekend for a private party for work, so we had the upstairs private room and my experience was great.When I got there it was super packed....literally every table was full (8:00 on a Saturday night). They directed me upstairs, past some teens in prom attire (pre-prom dinner I assume), and into the private room, complete with an electric (?) fireplace, flat screen TV, and bar.Let me start off by saying I can't speak to the prices of anything...this was a work party and everything was paid for by the company. I did see the appetizer menu they faxed to us that listed some prices, but I'm not sure if that's what we actually got. Even that menu seemed decently priced - a little on the expensive side, but for a nice restaurant like Ivy, not at all unreasonable.Now, to the food and drinks.We had pre-purchased a certain number of drinks for the 20-some people we had, so yay for drinking on the company dime :) Their wine list is pretty extensive, but being the huge wine novice I am, I had no idea what I was doing. Therefore, I went to the martini menu - something that will never let me down.While they don't have nearly the selection of martinis as some places (say, Blu, which is now called Futami or something, a sushi and martini bar in downtown Evanston), the martinis they do have are phenomenal. Again, I can't speak to the price - I don't have a clue. I had the keylime martini, which I had never tried anywhere before. Oh. My. God. It was delicious. I honestly could not taste any of the liquor, but I got a decent buzz so it was definitely there. It actually tasted like keylime pie. Definitely going to try to recreate this one. Some of my coworkers also had martinis, both the Sunkissed (or something like that) and the French Dream varieties...everyone seemed pleased. We were also served a variety of appetizers that we could pick and choose from. The crabcakes were great - not too fishy, soft but perfectly flaky. The shrimp skewers were PHENOMENAL, but very spicy. Their bruschetta was also insanely good, although instead of tomatoes they used roasted bell peppers. It was an interesting twist, but I really liked it. The balsamic vinaigrette (or whatever it was) they drizzled on the bruschetta was a perfect way to top it off. I also tried the spinach artichoke dip on their ginormous pita chips (delish), and friend calamari - this was the first time I've ever had fried calamari, and while it was weird, I think I liked it. It was perfectly fried and not too rubbery, which was great - the tentacles just freaked me out a little.  Then they brought out dessert....an assortment of little custard-like dishes. I tried two of the three - a vanilla bean custard/creme brulee with blackberries, raspberries, and strawberry slices on top, which was perfectly sweet, and the keylime pie in a dish (perfect to bookend my meal between keylime martinis and keylime pie). The pie was insanely rich, but so good. The only one I didn't try was the chocolate mousse, although I probably should have given it a shot.Overall it was a great experience, and I would love to come back here and try dinner in their dining room. The service was great too...there was only a limited selection of drinks at the bar in the upstairs private room, but the waitress was more than willing to go downstairs to make us our special order drinks, bring up different liquor, etc. They were also very on top of bringing out the food, explaining what everything was, etc. The only thing that was a little weird is that they seemed to be rushing us out a bit at the end, when they started turning off the candle lights in the hanging lanterns and rearranging the tables while we were still all chatting, especially considering that their bar is open until at least after midnight, if not later, and this was barely 11:00. Again, I had a great experience and would love to come back. I've never been anywhere in downtown Wheaton before (funny, since I work only a few blocks from this place), and I was really impressed with everything around it. Parking is super easy, and free, in a garage just behind the building (3 or 4 hour parking, depending on the spot).

<review# 1607,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/13/2010,6/5/2010,363,708,4,4,4>In our continuing efforts to try every pizza place within a 5-mile radius of home, we went with some take-out from Aurelio's.My husband arrived home with a large cheese thin-crust that was a little cool in one corner and had that "cheese has just started to get cold" look about it. (This cannot be blamed on Aurelio's, but rather, Lake St traffic.)And yet it was one of the more delicious thin crusts I have had in recent memory. The crust was crispy around the edges and had a great flavor; the sauce, while just a hair on the sweet side, had plenty of savory to it; and the cheese was delicious, plentiful, and actually broke when you bit into it. (It is a minor pet peeve of mine when you take a bite of pizza and all of the cheese comes with it.)The rest of their menu is large and varied, and I'd like to dine in or at least try an appetizer or two, but honestly, it will be hard to resist the pizza, which is currently up there with Home Run Inn as my favorite thin crust in the area.=====================11/1/10:We've now eaten in and tried a few different things. The atmosphere is sort of odd, a mash-up of Chicago history, random old ads, and red-and-white checked stuff.We started with their focaccia appetizer, which was different and delightful -- crispy bread stuffed with cheese and basil and served with a sweet, thick sauce for dipping. We moved on to a stuffed cheese pizza, which probably wouldn't be my first choice again, if only because there wasn't much sauce on it and the top crust got lost and turned into kind of a mess. It was good overall, and I definitely appreciated the "handle" part of the crust, which had a nice light crispiness to it and wasn't overly bready or thick. But I wonder if their version of deep dish has more/chunkier sauce.I'd certainly be willing to eat it again, and try more of their menu, but as far as I'm concerned their thin crust is where it's at.

<review# 1613,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/9/2010,5/30/2010,15,107,1,6,5>Things that make going to the horse races fun.1. There are races all afternoon. You can walk in any time, watch as many races as you'd like, and leave any time.2. There's a race about every 1/2 hour. The horses make it around the track in less than 2 minutes. The rest of the time you can chat w/friends, walk around, look at the horses scheduled to run in the next race, eat, etc. and you won't be missing a thing.3. They know how to use technology. You can watch the race on the big screen. They replay the race in case you missed it. The odds and pay outs are posted, just to name of few things.4. Anything can happen. I've seen the favorite come in last and the long shot come in first. There's always a chance the horse you pick will win.5. Never bet on a horse race? The program explains everything and there are also helpful employees who will answer your questions.Arlington Park is a beautiful clean track. The Union Pacific North West line of the Metra stops right at the track. The park website lists specials (I got $2 off admission by printing my own ticked today.) Great fun for the whole family. They often have things for the kids to do.

I'm not quite sure what you would do...do you tip? No one really serviced you but a one-time buser that took away your baskets of food trays.We'd go here again and the best part is....it's across the street from us! I'd recommend to try this place and get the ribs. :)
<review# 1617,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/4/2010,5/26/2010,971,2260,6,13,9>The Golden Steer is "old school" all the way.  In business for 40 years in the same location, there is little about this place that has changed since the 70's.Located on a street corner in Forest Park, the Golden Steer is the size of a small neighborhood bar.  As you walk in the door- close your eyes for a minute to let them adjust to the dim light in the place- as there is not a window in sight.  And look out- as servers and bussers will be "zooming" by you as you try to make yourself invisible as you wait for your table.  I opted to stand by the bar while my dining companion "hid" in the coat closet.We were seated within 15 minutes, by "Carol", a hostess who looks and acts like she's been doing this for a long time.  This lazy supper club got a shot in the arm as it was recently featured on "Check Please" which has sent droves of people to sample their fare.  The regulars are greeted by name, while the newcomers are thanked and genuinely asked to return.If you can get a seat (we went early around 6pm) and the place was already hopping, you are in for a cheap meal of some pretty good food.On Saturday- they have a prime rib special.  Now while not a huge fan of prime rib- how could I turn it down for it was a steal!  For $23.95 you get a crock of french onion soup (so much cheesey goodness you'll want more!) a salad of mostly iceburg lettuce (eh not so good) and then the glorious prime rib with your choice of potato (Perfectly cooked and the baked potato was so loaded with sour cream and butter it almost tasted mashed!)Our server had to be in her late 60's and she told us she had worked there for 22 years!  I can just imagine that her and the "other girls" that keep this place running have got many a story to tell.The decor is old and tired but it's just part of it's quirky charm..  I can't remember the last time I saw mirrors and timber on walls and vertical louvered panel room dividers.  But at the Golden Steer- it's just as much of the "ambiance" as are the "longhorns" hanging over the kitchen.    I even got to watch as the owner helped one of his bus boys tie a tie so he could work the "dinner shift".   Definitely a family run place.Dinner for two was $75 including drinks.  Parking is plentiful on the side street.Take a step back into the 70's with dinner at the Golden Steer.  For with those kinds of prices for plenty of pretty good food, what have you got to lose?
<review# 1618,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/8/2010,5/25/2010,127,193,9,11,13>The year is 1994.  North Park Mall is thriving.  Just for Fun arcade is right next door, and I am the NBA Jam all-time champion.  I love Garibaldi's spaghetti and meatballs, and their cheese pizza is the bomb.  My grandma works there and brings dinner every Friday night.Fast forward.  North Park "Mall" is now an indoor swap-mart.  I suck at video games.  I crave Garibaldi's cheesesteak sandwiches, and their pizza is STILL the bomb, as well as their burgers, italian ice, and did I mention their pizza?  Everything inside is almost exactly the same as it was back then, from the bright green fiberglass booths to the "stained glass" designs in the walls, to the same ancient registers used to ring up orders.  Sadly, grandma is no longer with us, but I'll always have an affinity for this place and the food!

yum! i quickly changed my mind. =) but was afraid i might not get one 'cause the people ahead of me were ordering bunches of them to go!i was able to score one along with a pretzel loaf, their Ambrosia cinnamon bun thingie and a double mocha. all of it was great and fresh... especially the croissant. i'm usually not a croissant fan but this one, with the salmon/cream cheese filling was divine.the food is really, really awesome and in regards to the flavors i have no complaints. my only issues were with the baked goods display case itself. it's really small and right next to the register so it gets really crowded. it's also placed up high so you have to attempt to talk through it or keep poking your head around it.  there were no signs that said what everything was so i had to ask and eavesdrop when other people were asking. the case was filled with delicious looking pastries and i seriously wanted to know what everything was but there was a line and i didn't want to hold everyone up. signs would definitely help.i would easily come here again to try everything. =)
<review# 1620,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/6/2009,5/23/2010,143,312,4,15,13>It's easy to pass up The Standard. The neo-minimalist architecture really helps it to blend in and not stick out among the many entertainment options of downtown Elmhurst, and it's also not on the main drag York st. But besides that, the Stella Artois umbrellas for the sidewalk dining tell you something about The Standard.Although my friends and I ate outdoors, I did get to go inside this newer addition to the Elmhurst scene. It's supposed to be a cut above your average bar and restaurant. Darker and more intimate seating, but also with TVs and a full bar. Not so much a gastropub, but not an exquisite restaurant, either. The food is newer American fare with an upscale twist, a menu with some gourmet options and ol' fashioned American favorites. I had the "Maytag Burger" with onions, Blue Cheese, and skinny fries, which appear to be gaining in popularity as evidenced at many other restaurants I've been too. Our server was very outgoing and helpful. The bill for four people who had the fairly large and satisfying hamburgers wasn't so bad; under $80 including drinks.

<review# 1622,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/29/2010,5/21/2010,172,208,6,4,5>So last Friday my wife and I were tossing around ideas for what to eat for dinner. I wanted Italian, she wanted Mediterranean, and we listened to each others restaurant suggestions. The debate continued for a good 5-10 minutes, and we were at an impasse. All of a sudden when it was looking like we were going to end up at the KFC drive thru, she blurted "I want some sushi." I have mentioned on several reviews before that I am the only Pacific Islander in existence that doesn't like fish/seafood, but I love me some Katsu and Udon. We both agreed to find a good Japanese Restaurant in the area, and she left it up to my Yelp-pertise to find one. I brushed off the old dusty laptop and went on Yelp.com and started searching. On a totally unrelated topic, I just wanted to exclaim my love for "high speed internet." Please give me a moment while I hug my modem ((((hugs)))). OK back to the review. My fellow Yelpers seemed to really like this restaurant called "Sushi Ya" in Schaumburg, so the decision was made simple. I give a call to one of my best buds who was in the area to ask if he wanted to join us for some dinner, and he quickly agreed. We walked into Sushi Ya and was happily greeted by the staff with "Irasshaimase!!!" I felt like Norm entering Cheers, but there was no Sam, Carla, Woody, or Cliff in sight. I asked what the greeting was and our waitress simply said it means, "Welcome." The restaurant is small, I would guess it seats about 30+ with some extra seats by the sushi bar. We ask for a table for 3 and was quickly seated by the window. My friend BBM'd me that he was 10 minutes away, which is cryptic code for "I'll be there in 25." The wife and I decided to order, and she went straight for the sushi order sheet. I order the Beef Udong (Udon) for starters, and decided to go with Chicken Katsu. I don't know anything about sushi, but I think the wife went for California Rolls, Spider Rolls, and something else. As we were waiting for our food to arrive, our friendly waitress gave us some complimentary edamame to snack on. We also got our salads, and apparently I get miso soup with my dinner meal...so that was a pleasant surprise. Our entrées came shortly after we finished our starters. My Beef Udon was very good. The noodles were so soft, and the broth had a nice light flavor. The Chicken Katsu portion was pretty big, with a small bowl of rice and the dipping sauce. The Panko crumbs were so light and crispy, and the chicken was so tender. The stir fried veggies on the side was a very nice touch. The wife seemed to be delighted with the sushi, I can tell it by her eyes. My friend finally arrived in the middle of our meal, and was greeted with "Irasshaimase!!!" He quickly looked over the sushi menu and got Spicy Tuna something, and Eel something...again I know diddly squat about sushi. His order came out before we got done with our meals, and he quickly chimed in with the praises as well. He exclaimed that the tuna was so fresh and delicious. I will assume that he meant "fresh and delicious" in the non-urban dictionary sense. So let me recap our dining experience at Sushi Ya. Service: The service we received was excellent. We were greeted when we entered, and when we left. The service in between was friendly and attentive. Food: The food was the "bombdotcom." The sushi was "fresh and delicious." My Chicken Katsu and Beef Udong was exxxcellent...and yes I added 2 extra "x's" to emphasize my point. Ambiance: The restaurant is small, but very quaint and lively. Add all those in with good company and bubbly conversation, and it was a very good dining experience indeed. Now everybody sing along with me: "Throw your chopsticks in the ayyer and waive em' like you just don't cayyer. If you want fresh sushi, then go to Sushi Ya...somebody say, Oh yeaaaah!!!"
<review# 1623,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/22/2010,5/20/2010,101,102,21,17,10>I had a hilarious wreck of a car to unload a few years ago. How hilarious? CarMax offered me $50 for it. That is not a typo, that is two twenties and a ten and a dirty look from the sales rep.  I called up Victory Auto almost on a whim; their commercials are hilarious and I thought maybe people were doing more laughing than buying and they'd gone out of business. Nope, they were still open and they were going to offer to pay me three times what CarMax offered, and they weren't even going to judge me (to my face).They sent the tow truck out for my wreck on the day I requested, and the guy was pretty much on time. He called about half an hour before he was due to arrive. He kept insisting that my address wasn't where I said it was, which was stupid and irritating. When he finally showed up I asked "So...where were you when you called?" in a light tone as if we shared between us the joke of his little navigational sanfu. he glared at me and didn't answer and put my poor beast on his flat bed. Oh well.A few months later I couldn't find the sales receipt for that car and I called up to get a copy. The woman on the phone was friendly and helpful and the slip came in the mail two days later. Overall, great customer service...just don't make fun of the driver's geographical shortcomings.
<review# 1624,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/4/2010,5/19/2010,26,105,2,3,4>Hubby and I found ourselves in Naperville today when a craving for corned beef hit us.  After checking Yelp!, we made our way over to Schmaltz Deli and were both very glad we did. We each had a 'Wall St.' with spicy mustard, and they really hit the spot!I concur with what most previous positive reviewers have contributed, so won't regurgitate all that. What I really appreciated about Schmaltz is that their sandwiches have two price points - 'Overstuffed' and 'Almost Overstuffed'. Being that my metabolism isn't what it used to be, I rarely allow myself to polish off a huge deli sandwich, but am left feeling guilty for wasting food I paid for. The smaller 'Almost' option was the perfect size for me, and at the same time I saved $2.  Love it.We will definitley be back to try the Mayor Pradel sandwich.  Maybe tomorrow...

The food itself was excellent, and once again provided a glimpse into the chef's vision. My entree of Veal shoulder, sous-vide, was tender and flavorful. Served with white beans and broccoli, the portion was perfect sized. I do not want nor need to be wowed by the massive portions at a restaurant, I would rather finish my meal completely and feel satisfied, not as if I need to be rolled out of the place on a gurney. Dessert was awesome. I had 'ants on a log'- a piece of celery root cake with peanut butter mouse and rum raisin ice cream. tremendous and thoughtful. All in all, a great meal. Trends toward spendy, but we all live in Naperville, so that makes us rich anyway, right?

Once ya get past the converted Taco Bell façade, you're immediately welcomed by a very simple, but unmistakably Asian décor - with guess what?  Yep - 90% occupied by people with Asian ancestry (find that in a Chinese restaurant in McHenry county).  I might as well have walked into a restaurant in Sha Tin.  The Pho was wonderful - tasty broth, and I love the fact that they have fish sauce, crushed chili peppers in oil, and Sriracha as added condiments that I could liberally roll into the Pho.  The meatballs and beef were very tasty, but they used the fake crab (yeah - please don't).   I also had a spicy shrimp salad that was pleasantly offset by nice amounts of basil.  I wish they'd introduce some Filipino cuisine - pansit maybe?  Stay with the noodle theme?  Can't wait to come back - wonder what their Pad Thai is like?
<review# 1634,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/8/2010,5/9/2010,288,304,2,5,4>Love, love LOVE Egg Harbor Cafe. I've been a fan for years. I was so sad that the one in Danada moved but remembered that the one in Yorktown was just around the corner. Phew! I've always loved EH but have come to appreciate it even more because of the healthier breakfast & lunch options. On my last visit I had the mini wrap and soup combo which also came with mixed greens. It was the perfect portion and I was pleasantly, but not uncomfortably full. The juice is always so fresh and the strawberry oj is delish. Yum! My favs are the cassie crepes, sir dugan frittata and the door county chicken salad. They close at 2:30PM and it tends to get crazy at breakfast time. So, you might want to try to do a call ahead or get there 20 minutes early and cruise the mall while you wait. I've never had a problem with service and the servers are friendly & accomodating. If you're looking for a fresh breakfast spot with plenty of tasty options for everyone, give Egg Harbor Cafe a try. You won't be disappointed.
<review# 1635,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/31/2010,5/7/2010,65,785,6,5,4>Huuumm,  looks like I'm the first to Yelp review the "new" Rosebud in Naperville.  We never made it here during the brief Comfort Food stage, and my last visit was maybe 5 years ago.  I felt this place had been going a bit downhill from 10 years ago, getting to the over-rated stage, about 5 years back.   But back to the present....  and we really liked it.  Big portions served here, though some items do look overpriced.  Most were very reasonable for the portion size.  The veal francese (three large egg-battered veal medallions) were excellent  for $21.  The cheesy risotto special was pricy at $28, but could make about 4 meals.  The $21 pork chop calabrese (2) were spicy, huge, and good, and served over 4 smashed potatoes.  We also had the cavatelli which was ok, and again huge.   $12 for 3 stuffed mushroom appetizers was pricy.   The $12 calamari appetizer was good for amount we got.  Overall - you have to pick the value meals, but no complaints at all on food quality here.  We had lots of leftovers except my veal francese, which I enhaled with pleasure.  They also serve pizzas for dinner as indicated by their name.  The restaurant  has a smallish dining room now, as the back portion of the restaurant looks to now be taken up by an adjoining takeout Rosebud pizza storefront.  Restaurant was warm and stuffy at beginning of night, as it was warmest evening of year-to-date (65F or so), but cooled off nicely at sunset.  It's also not as dark as the old setting, which was another thing I didn't enjoy much with the old setup.  They also have outdoor riverside dining, and I can't recall if the old configuration had that or not.  Overall, nice place for Italian, and you can't beat the DT Naperville location.
