<review# 1639,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/3/2009,5/2/2010,83,308,6,7,6>I love a good dive bar but Eaton's has probably been the weirdest dive bar I have ever been to. After getting carded, the bartender made it very clear that they only accept cash, how old school! But I didn't care, cash is all I had. I have been to some seedy bars but Eaton's was straight up scary! I was afraid to touch anything in fear I may leave with a disease.Décor: The set up was super simple, mainly made up of a colossal bar that took up most of the place. There were some booths and couple of tables along the walls, but that was about it. The walls are made up of wood paneling and exposed brick, while the ceiling was made up of some antique moldings. There are only 2 restrooms, 1 men's and 1 women's, that don't have paper towels. They have that revolving towel in the machine that just rotates the same sheet over and over, nastiness. There is a pool table stuffed in one of the corners of the bar along with a couple of slot machine-like arcade games, very fitting for the casino town.The Crowd: Like any dive bar it doesn't exactly attract many posh patrons which is why I like them! If I wanted to hang out with preppy brosef's I would go to a club.Service: A-ok, not too welcoming when you first enter but after they card you & order a couple of drinks they seem to warm up a little.Liquid Courage On Tap: Bud, Bud Lite, PBROriginally I was going to order something in a can or a bottle, just to protect myself from any herpe that may be floating around waiting to infect me, but when Berto noticed they had mason jars we were drawn in. 24oz Baller mason jar of Bud for $4.50? I'll take my chances against the herpe! I think it's safe, I'm pretty sure alcohol sanitizes anyway. Right?Eats: I'm not gonna lie, I could have munched on some bar food but the looks of this fine establishment terrified me. I'm sure if you even ordered food they would have a hard time starting up the grill because it didn't seem like the sorta place you have dinner and a few drinks. They have a corn dog machine that looked like it hadn't been turned on in years. Eaton's offers a variety of bagged chips and nuts. There are also 2 liquor store like fridges filled with pop.  I have to mention the pickled mystery items in the life-size cloudy jar on the bar. It was very Moe's Tavern.Sounds: Other than the drunken banter of the regulars it was karaoke night. I am always up for karaoke! I did notice the line was fairly large but I put in my request anyway. I have to give props to the KJ, he didn't waste time with filler, he got everyone up n' out and before I knew it it was my turn!Parking: It's downtown Elgin, so all street parking.Overall: Eaton's, you really freaked me out at first glance but after getting to know you I think we may have something here. I will keep a mental note to always bring cash and to eat before my outing in tackling another mason jar!
<review# 1640,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/11/2010,5/1/2010,65,392,3,6,3>Here for the hamburger. Period.Pleasantly surprised to find the place mostly empty at 530pm. Got a great seat at the window in the bar. Had the burger with cheddar, got an order of the truffle potatoes, too.The burger was excellent! Cooked perfectly, had that good backyard grill crust (my brother and I call 'em "dirty grill burgers") and the cheese was just right. The onion roll was good, although the onion strips ON the roll were pretty much burnt to ash -- probably should have gone with thicker yellow onion slivers instead of the red onion -- I'm guessing. The fries were skinny, fresh cut and a little greasy. It would have worked better with slightly larger cuts (see Gene & Jude's review)...All in all, a top notch burger with outstanding service in a beautiful space -- with good company to boot! And the best part -- the burgers start at just $10! Recommended!TIP: They only serve the burger in the bar, so that means you'll need to eat a burger and beer appetizer up front if the rest of your gang wants to enjoy the REAL dining room!
<review# 1641,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/25/2010,4/30/2010,160,654,8,18,10>Paradise Pup is to the burbs what a place like Kuma's or Hot Doug's is to Chicago. OK, I knew about it for a while now, but I never came here before till this weekend. We arrived about a few minutes before noon, and just enough minutes before the line was out the door.Paradise Pup is a crowded little place where there's hardly room to sit down for dine-ins when the line keeps getting bigger. Lucky for us, it was a warm day and there were plenty of tables outside.I had the bacon cheddar burger and my wife had a cheddar burger, while both kids went for the plain hot dog. We split a basket of fries and a side of onion rings. Regardless of the menu item, it was a can't miss choice. The burgers are astoundingly juicy, plump and satisfying. So good you can skip dinner later. Their 1/3-pound burger can outmuscle a 1/2-pounder at other joints. Onion rings have a certain snap and freshness to them like no place else.I watched as the production line worked on orders after I had placed mine. It's amazing how they get the burgers and hot dogs made, one after another, executed to perfection in one fluid motion by the cook and the guy loading up the buns. A jet of flame shoots off the grill and another masterpiece is ready to be served.While their burgers are certainly among the best I've had, I really want to try their Polish sausage next time. I got a look at those sausages and let's just say they're porn star-sized big! Or you can use one of those Polish for self-defense to fight off a carjacker.Certainly worth a visit if you're in Des Plaines, but get there early or be prepared to wait.

<review# 1647,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/17/2010,4/24/2010,1,10,3,5,2>I'm pretty sure that I've not been here before under this name, but I'm surprised to see how far back some of the other reviews go, so maybe this wasn't my first visit. Regardless, I'm glad the place is here and we had a chance to go.We went there on Mardis Gras after seeing a promotion for their Fat Tuesday Feast Winter Tasting Menu. This being a minor holiday for most but big for foodies, we expected a crowd, and there was none. In fact, there were only two other tables occupied during the 2 hours we were there, which makes me fear for the future of the place. Maybe it's just the Tuesday night factor.Everything we ate was thoughtfully prepared, from fine ingredients, and tasted fantastic. We started with the best pork belly I'd ever eaten, went on to lobster fritters, fried oyster on brioche with crawfish étouffée, strawberry sorbet intermezzo, chicken sausage jambalaya, and a perfect pecan tart. Our server, Jeffrey, was attentive, pleasant helpful, and warm, and didn't bat an eye at several "information requests" that we made. Realizing that we were there on a slow night, I nevertheless couldn't imagine a more pleasant atmosphere.The wine list is intimidating and we copped out to a special offering associated with the current tasting menu. I'm not a huge wine person, but I recognized very few of the offerings, most of which where in the $50-$100 range, or beyond. We didn't ask for suggestions, but I don't doubt that we would have gotten good advice if we had.I suspect the place is very forgiving with respect to dress and protocol. I would be comfortable there in anything from jeans and a nice shirt, to a suit and tie, and there was no hint of pretense or snobbery from any of the staff. Thy have coat check service for those so inclined, or just hang your coat on the back of your chair.We intend to put this long overlooked venue into our rotation, and are looking forward to our next excuse to go there (St. Pat's special sounds intriguing!).

With an ancy three year old, we bolted M's when the almost out the door line wasn't moving.  Thankfully I remembered Stash's being literally down the street.It was as good as I remembered.  The Hot Dogs and Polish we ordered were perfectly charred.  The only mistake was that my wife loves fries well done.  Stash's fries are so good that they should never be altered and ordered how they want to cook them.  It's right up there with Michael's and it's not as busy.  If you need a quick quality meal made to order, Stash's is perfect in downtown HP!!!

<review# 1650,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/29/2009,4/21/2010,39,47,5,7,5>With how much everyone says they like/love this place I'm surprised with all the 4 star reviews. Here's my quick take: * Some of the best fish tacos I've had anywhere! * Easily the * best* restaurant within the area * Beats most restaurants downtown Chicago * Way better than may same or higher rated restaurants on this site * Not as high end as TRU but many will enjoy more and certainly less expensive; definitely higher end than typical franchise places * Original and for what you get extremely inexpensive * Great staff and service The food is overall American themed with a nice variety  of changing seafood (fish, clams, scallops, lobster, crab), meat (steak, pork, duck, lamb, rabbit, chicken), and pasta dishes. The salads and soups are also top notch. The steaks were better than at many high end steak restaurants like Ruth Chris's. I personally recommend ordering a mix of small plate items and sharing a soup and salad (the pear and bake brie is my favorite). Order an entry but save room for dessert. I've eaten here probably over 50 times and with the exception of 3-4 years back when they had a different chef (not the original and not the current) the food has always been at least good and in recent years has been outstanding. I eat out at least 3-4 times week and travel nationally for work. As a result, I've had a chance to dine at many of the highest rated restaurants around the county and I can say overall this is my favorite. Montarra will be a bit more intimate but compares to places like "The Gage", "Roy's", and "Wildfire" in quality and level. Definitely check Montarra out and judge for yourself!

I don't live close to Forest Park, but I will probably make a special trip back to dine at Caffe De Luca.

<review# 1662,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/3/2010,4/9/2010,4739,1870,21,18,18>BEST CRAFT BEER SELECTION IN ELMHURST... oh, and of course an outrageously rockin' wine list. Okay, I've been making a lot of declarations of "Best Beer Selection in_________ (insert town name here)" lately, but I do it all for you, my beloved and fellow yelpers. I don't want you people to miss out on anything that could drastically improve and enhance the quality of your life. On the night I came to Flight 112, I noticed my mom's fave beer, Duvel Green, and my fave stout, Two Brothers Northwind Imperial, on tap- which, by the way, is normally served in a 6 oz. snifter glass but they only had Two Bros Pint glasses... does that mean you get an extra 10 ounces on the serving in the pint glass? If so, score! Because Northwind Stout is 10% ABV. In addition to the tappers, they've also got 97357097327 other kinds of bottled craft beer to offer. Okay, it's not really that arbitrary number that I made up by mashing my number pad with my palm, but it's a lot... like 35 other choices and they're constantly evolving. And in case you were wondering, that selection includes the 60, 90, and 120 minute IPAs from Dogfish Head... yep, that's right folks! They carry the 20.5% ABV 120 minute IPA which is ever elusive in the burbies. Too bad I live so far from here... Anyone know any cab specials from Elmhurst to Naperville? Wait! I know, I can further indulge on the bites here to soak it all up. For din, I'd recommend going with a few friends so you can each order a dish to share tapas style. I went with the Spinach and Goat Cheese Flatbread that has fresh spinach, artichoke hearts, tomatoes, red peppers, and drunken (would you want it any other way?) goat cheese. It was heavenly! Next time I'll go with the Wasabi Zucchini Cakes (well, actually they're crab cakes but the zucchini is their vegetarian version)... and maybe get the flatbread again, too. I will say that the food takes quite a while, so don't plan on being in a hurry. It's meant to be a place where you sit back, relax, and imbibe on some truly unique wine, beer, and bites. And if you do get bored, the adorable bartender, Kyle, will certainly keep you entertained (for some good stories and pics, ask him about his trip to Thailand). Now on to the wine... I decided to err on the side of caution and have just one glass of white wine (keeping Carol Js dental advice close to heart). I went with the Seyval Blanc from Owl Creek Vineyard, which is a local winery... okay, it's in Southern Illinois but can we just pretend that Southern, Ill is still local? Thanks!    ...Anyway, it was delicious and the perfect thing to keep me warm on that cold and snowy night. Next time, I'm planning on doing a wine flight or getting the Kung Fu Girl Reisling because I like the name, and as some of you may know, I'm a Karate Kid and won third place in the Midwest Tang Su Do and Hap Ki Do regionals in 1997... though I was totally robbed of second place. Yea, you pretty much don't want to step to this, but do yourself a favor and step on over to Flight 112. You will not be disappointed.
<review# 1663,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/18/2010,4/8/2010,140,273,3,3,3>This place is a favorite gathering spot for several of our local friends and family. Sometimes we come when we have a buy one/get one meal - they actually honor the coupon on the meal I usually order even though it is technically an appetizer. Prices are pretty low, too.It's kind of dingy looking and parking is a bit whack, but you're in Coutryside...it's certainly not a grodie place or we wouldn't' return time and again. <review# 1666,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/1/2010,4/5/2010,9,35,16,5,7>The Viagra Triangle in Oakbrook - Ditka's, Tuscany, and The Clubhouse.  In my single days, it was common knowledge that the first weekend of the month was the time to head out to Rush Street - that's when the divorcees would be patrolling in gangs and spending their alimony checks.  You could always find someone to dance with.  The Clubhouse institutionalized that system with a raucous monthly event called "First Friday"- it appears that there is certainly no shortage of newly single people (or newly implanted chests) in the Western burbs.  Get there early. We go to people watch - Think Animal Planet - Predators and Prey.  Cougars - stalked by - I am not sure what to call the middle aged single guys - Hyenas (?).   I have observed that apparently the 80's fashions are in fact still "In" for single gentlemen, as is BRUT cologne -  I wish I could find my leather bomber just in case wifey boots me.... Where the hell in did I put my silk shirts?   When not catering to Cupid, The Clubhouse actually is a very good upscale restaurant and a regular part of our rotation.  Two floors - bar and dining on the main floor, dining room and several party rooms upstairs (there is an elevator). The bar is usually busy, the bartenders friendly, knowledgeable, and we are usually taken good care of.  They have an outstanding Sunday Brunch (worth 5 stars in my book) with prime rib, seafood, vodka pasta and a chocolate fountain among my favorites.  On the regular menu - try the carne asada cobb salad, lobster bisque, and if you like short ribs, get them here.  Prime steaks and seafood.  Lobster mac and cheese!  Meatloaf Sundae!  Good stuff.    Busy place during lunch - try the grilled filet Tuscan sliders on focaccia.  Take a nap at your desk.    We consistently get good service here and have had some very interesting servers (with personalities) who are regulars.  You can also usually spot a friendly manager making the rounds eager to please.Alas, with so many similar joints in the area providing a similar menu with good service, I hesitate to give it a full 5 stars.  Too bad I can't give  1/2 star to make it a solid four and a half - shave  1/2 off for ubiquitousness.....   Check out that First Friday event.  No cover, free appetizers, drink specials - DJ / dancing after they clear the food warmers.  Affordable entertainment!  Hook up with an unemployed fund manager!
<review# 1667,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/7/2010,4/4/2010,122,412,6,9,6>4.5 stars - first time there!What an awesome find!  This restaurant, tucked in a non-descript strip mall off of Lake Street, is easy to miss and has been the site of several Italian restaurants.  I pass by here frequently as it's right on the way to the local Caputo's produce store.  After hearing the buzz about this place from a couple of friends, one of who hails from Italy, we stopped in last night for a late dinner.  The place was empty (around 9:30), but the bartender/server was absolutely solicitious and helpful.  Here's a great tip about this restaurant: go for the specials if possible.  Now I did not order anything on the regular menu, which was fairly interesting and comprehensive for an Italian restaurant; and I'm sure that their regular entrees were good.  But the specials - very unique and have to be tried!We were going to order a buffala mozzarella caprese, but the server advised us to try another special cheese from the Apuglia region of Italy - apparently difficult to get in this country but the chef imports it in.  The cheese, burrata, is a pouch of bufala mozzarella, filled with panna (cream).  Served over a bed of fresh, delicious arugula, with a very thin slice of parma prosciutto, this is an absolutely orgasmic dish - simple combination of wonderfully fresh ingredients!As the server recited the specials, it was apparent that they do unique food - rabbit, goat, quail, unique fish - all can be found on their specials menu.  In fact, the server told us that if you are planning on coming in on the weekend, just call them and let them know what you want - they'll make sure it's ready for you!  Kind of like eating at your Italian grandma's house!We opted for the quail, done spectacularly in a demi-glace sauce; and an orata fish, which is a seabream fish common to the Bari region (where my gramps hails from!).  Baked whole with rosemary and olive oil, it was to die for.They also make an "almost" authentic version of Italian pizza - delish!Great selection of Italian wines and they carrry the Danny DeVito limoncello as well.They've also got these storage bins, located in a large cabinet on the wall of one of the dining areas, that you can rent to store your favorite wine selections, all available at a discounted price.  So you can go there with clients, start a bottle of wine, and then they'll store your unused portion in your bin to be used on another occasion.I'd give it 5 stars but I want to try it again before I do that.  Prices - specials are not cheap but not bad for the unique quality of food.  Menu prices are fairly reasonable. Pastas start around $14 and entrees can go upwards to $30.  The high end of the price range is for the more unique specials, though.Atmosphere:  it was pretty quiet when we were there, although the bar filled up with a couple of people.  Honestly, I loved the place - the owners and bartender were cool, full of information, and very friendly. They definitely take pride in their food and in their establishment.  Give it a try - it's a hidden gem that I hope does well.
<review# 1668,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/3/2009,4/3/2010,29,77,2,3,2>For a vast selection of new books at competitive prices, there really is no better place to go than The Book Table. The store is large, but very well kept and easy to navigate. Far too often are otherwise great places plagued by idiot staff who treat the customers like lepers. This is not the case here. I have never had a negative experience with anyone there.Also a plus is the fact that The Book Table is very centrally located in Oak Park, no more than a block or two from all the cool locations in the town. Easy to get to all the nearby hotels and sight seeing events from there, including the Unity Temple and the Ernest Hemingway exhibits. Whenever I'm in town for the tourist attractions, I have to stop at The Book Table.

<review# 1670,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/21/2009,4/1/2010,18,32,,4,2>Even if sampling olive oils in the same way you taste wines isn't your thing, I guarantee that a stop at Olive and Well will be well worth your time.  This place opened a few years ago in a primo, though for whatever reason jinxed, location in downtown Oak Park.  Even after my first visit, however, I knew this place was a keeper and would eventually become a staple on the Avenue (which it has). After not having been in in a long time, I went in over the weekend to do some holiday shopping.  Took no time at all to be reminded of why it is that I love this store so much.  Quaint yet sophisticated, down to earth yet complex, and unique, unique, unique.  Sondra, the proprieter, couldn't be sweeter -- to every customer, every single time you come in there.  She remembered that I was married a year and a half ago and made sure to ask how things were going.  Almost 8 months pregnant, she was sure to congratulate me on the baby-on-the-way and insisted that I come back in with the baby once the weather warms up so she can meet the little one.  In some stores, this type of chit-chat with the owner would be perceived as annoying or perhaps pushy -- but not here.  Sondra is as genuine as they come and knows more about oils and vinegars than I thought was humanly possible.  She always makes a great recommendation -- be it for a gift, a food pairing, or tasting.  I can't recommend this place enough for anyone looking to expand their palate or that of a good friend or family member.  Plus, you have the added bonus of being in the heart of downtown Oak Park, which is just full of cute little shops.Hands down, one of the better boutiquey food shops in the area.  This Oak Park location is jinxed no more!
<review# 1671,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/28/2009,3/31/2010,32,291,2,3,2>Rammy's is a perfect example of a Yelp success story.  Periodically, I will use my address and just search for restaurants within a birds eye view.  Mostly it's the same places that have been popping up.  Then the blip happens:  close to home, 4.5 stars, 4 reviews (all good).  Now, I have to try it.  A little off the beaten path, so I would not have found it unless someone I know or trust (like Yelp)  told me about it.  I had a fantastic sandwich called the radical beef.  It had a very interesting au jus and pesto taste and lots of meat.  I left totally stuffed and happy.  Rammy's falls into the category that I call the "gourmet sub".  I would not even bring them up in the same sentence with Quiznos or Subway.  Is it better than Potbellies or Jimmy John's?  It's not nice to compare three places you love, but Rammy's is making it into the rotation.  Rammy's has a quality standard and I think the sandwiches are more creative than PBs and JJs.  If you like PBs and JJs, try Rammy's toasted subs.   You have to love a excellent meal for under $10.    It's located on the north side of Higgins road, one door west of the Lou Malnattis.

<review# 1673,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/12/2010,3/29/2010,117,89,4,11,8>U Gazdy is ever-so-conveniently located in walking distance of my house and also serves wine from the winery I work at - Lynfred - in neighboring Roselle.  My husband and I happened upon this place on their GRAND OPENING on a snowy day a few years ago and fell in love with the owners, Betty and Shawn, and everything about the place.The building:  first of all, U Gazdy is located next door to Helen's Deli (HELLO!) and all the gorgeous and authentic woodwork was done by owner Shawn and I think his father-in-law if I remember the story right. Ask them about the beautiful murals while you are there- they show landscaping of the Highlands of Poland, which is where their families are from. My husband and I love to sit at the bar because of the beautiful woodwork and listen to all the regulars speak Polish. We are not Polish but the servers all speak Polish and it seems to be a home away from home for many.The food:  P.i.e.r.o.g.i.s.  AMAZING!  The meat pierogis are my favorite (with a side of bacon and its grease to pour on top if you desire - I DO) followed by the Potato and Cheese. We usually order the Pierogis with an entree.  We personally love the cutlet or potato pancake with goulash dishes.  You always know when someone is ordering a cutlet because  you hear the pounding from the kitchen into the dining room.  Authentic Hylander Polish food that tips the border on extreme comfort food!!!  I can't even begin to tell you how much I love U Gazdy in Wood Dale for its food, people and intimate atmosphere.  If you live in city take the Milwaukee District West train and get off in Wood Dale - walk two and a half blocks west on Irving Park for a truly authentic experience!
<review# 1674,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/30/2009,3/28/2010,9,68,3,3,2>French bistro is my favorite type of cuisine, and Mon Ami Gabi is among the best bistros in the western burbs: casual and elegant.  True--the illusion of dining at a Parisian sidewalk cafe is shattered by the mall parking lot.  C'est la vie.I stopped in for lunch today and found myself the only fellow in a sea of  lady shoppers--a gentleman in jeans among the Ladies who Lunch.  It is, after all, in a suburban mall.  The food here, though, is always good.  This afternoon I ordered the prix fixe lunch--soup/salad, an entree (I had the steak sandwich), and a trio of mini-desserts for $15.00.  Even with a Campari and soda, my bill was only $22.The best part of the meal was the soup du jour--chilled watermelon soup.  The dish was simple but delicious: pureed watermelon seasoned with mint and cayenne and a touch of champagne.  That's an odd combination but it really works. (More about the soup later.)The staff is always extraordinary.  Two examples:A few months ago, I joined my friend T. for a three Campari and dessert outing at MAGabi.  After raving about the little butter cookie that came with his ice cream, T. asked the waiter if we could have another cookie so that I could taste one.  The accommodating waiter returned with a whole BASKET of these things.   (Yeah, they ARE good.)Today, after being bowled over by the watermelon soup (sorry--lousy pun) I told the waitress, Lisa, how much I enjoyed the unusual combination of flavors and asked her to pass along my compliments to the chef.  When she brought my check, Lisa also brought me a bag with a little container of the soup to take home ("For later," she said).One of my favorite words (and concepts) is "lagniappe," a Southern word meaning a small gift that accompanies a purchase.  The staff at Mon Ami Gabi (especially Lisa) really understand the power of a lagniappe.

<review# 1684,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/17/2010,3/18/2010,78,342,2,3,3>Why would I give 5 stars to a simple breakfast/lunch place?  I don't give them out very easily...a restaurant has to be a pretty big deal to get a 5 star review from me.  But Tangerine deserves the 5 star rating.  Here's why:1) They take reservations on Sundays.  I cannot tell you how many breakfast places I have been in the area that will not take reservations making it difficult to dine with a big party - and hey, I always travel with an entourage.  2) They have drink specials for breakfast!  There is nothing like an alcoholic beverage to put a little pep in your step.  I had the Chocolate Heaven which turned out to be the best cup of hot cocoa that I had ever had. They also have several varieties of fresh squeezed juice for the less adventurous. 3) They have a great selection of breakfast and lunch items including specials.  You can go to most places to find your standard eggs, bacon and pancake breakfast platter.  Tangerine has something like this, but they also have really unique things like french toast with Nutella and strawberries.  It was a struggle making a choice, but I settled on the Banana Walnut French Toast and a side of O'Brien Potatoes.  Both were excellent.  The other things that the rest of my group ordered all looked and tasted good too.  The portions are big here and you won't leave hungry, you may even have leftovers.4) The service was great.  Our waitress was very friendly, attentive and had no problem splitting the check for us.  The decor of the place is nice - bright and refreshing.  I didn't have a single complaint about this place and better yet I am left wanting to go back to try another one of their amazing breakfast items.  The lunch items look pretty good too.  If you are looking for something a little different this is a great place to try in downtown Naperville and it is right next to a parking garage so you don't have a long walk to parking.
<review# 1685,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/20/2010,3/17/2010,116,200,8,8,7>Is everyone eating crazy pills? China Cook is the goddamn BOMB.Decent Chinese food outside of the city limits is a rarity. If you guessed DAMN fortuitous then you guessed correctly!  China Cook could steam some styrofoam and serve it on a bed of broken glass and I'd eat it with relish. They could bring me empty boxes that just SMELL like their food and I'd dine with glee. China Cook is some of the best Chinese food I've had, burbs or otherwise. Firstly, their Mongolian Beef/Chicken comes with those crunchy little white noodles and anyone that's ever read a Chinese food Yelp of mine knows that's worth 5 stars all by itself, but that's not all China Cook does well. Their customer service is specta-frickin-cular. They actually give a crap about their customers and it shows both in the food as well as how fast and hot the food gets to us. They've given us free egg rolls in the past, they also gave us a freakin' wall calendar for the Chinese New Year. These things cost them virtually nothing but it's gotten them hundreds of dollars in business that might've gone elsewhere. Aside from the Mongolian factor, I can personally recommend the Pineapple Chicken with its sweet, creamy sauce and succulent pineapple, the Four Seasons special, the Lucky 7 special as well as the Honey Glazed Walnut Shrimp - all really delicious. They're located off Irving Park Road, tons of parking and really no space to eat there so order carryout or delivery and you'll thank me. China Cook - way better than your typical Chinese and a frickin GEM here in the Northwest burbs.

<review# 1700,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/31/2010,3/1/2010,15,70,5,8,6>Knead Marketplace is my go-to coffee house cafe in LaGrange. There are so many things about Knead that are great, but one thing keeps bringing me back: their highly addictive croissants. I've been digging their croissants for late breakfast for about 10 consecutive Saturdays in a row, and not one has disappointed. The maple sausage and provolone stuffed croissant is ohhhh sooooo good. Once I had the ham and Swiss croissant by accident (I ordered the sausage and provolone, but they gave me the ham and Swiss by mistake) - and it was the best accident I've ever had. The one that keeps my wife and daughter coming back is the chocolate croissant. My wife likes the chocolate croissant warmed, and my daughter likes it cold. I'll take it either way; it's simply delicious! Recently I've been ordering the basic breakfast croissant sandwich -- bacon, scrambled egg and cheese served on a buttery croissant. It never disappoints. There are plenty of other things about Knead that are noteworthy - most of them noted by other Yelpers. The pastries and baked goods are wonderful, and they all taste as if they're made from an old family recipe with lots of butter. All of their food is made to order, and there is a sign that thanks you for your patience in waiting for your food. Let me tell you - the food is definitely worth the wait. Their lunch sandwiches are very creative and interesting. Knead also does dinner Thursday through Saturday from 6-10pm, and it's BYOB which is a huge plus. I haven't tried Knead for dinner yet, but am thinking about doing it soon. The owners/chefs are from Emilio's Sunflower Bistro across the street (where Nickson's Eatery is now), and I've heard their food was awesome, but for some reason it never survived. A few more things about Knead worth noting: - Family friendly for all meals, including dinner - Small cafe-style tables, so not great for groups more than 3-4 people - High-quality food and beverage menu, which means you might spend more than normal but not obscenely overpriced - They have a small butcher case with selected cheeses and meats to buy by the pound - The coffee is good, and they offer free refills which is nice when you're handing out for an extended period of time (as I often am!) - The staff and owners are really nice, and always open for compliments, complaints and suggestions Knead is awesome. I hope they continue to remain busy, and they are here to stay for a long time.

However, if you are a beer drinker, they do have these huge honkin glasses that you can get filled with beer that will literally last you the entire night. It was worth the money. That was $24. A Cherry Pepsi for my son was $10.00. You see, they do not offer any other cups except souvineer cups.Second - if you have little kids with you, they are going to want the blinky swords or something like that. It's expensive. We got a princess hat thing made out of gift ribbons for my daughter and the thing was $8.00. A blinky sword for my son, which broke the minute he held it from the wrong end, was $15 and now resides in a landfill. If you are going to get that much money for those things, feel free to get some not made in China.While you are waiting for the show to start, the kids (or 79 year old man in this case) get knighted for their birthdays in the main hall. The announcer guy is really funny. The king advised to get out of his way or he would punch you in the face, which made me laugh - though then my son asked why the king was going to punch people out. When you get into the arena/theater/whatever it's called, I will say this upfront. IT IS WORTH THE 20 EXTRA DOLLARS TO SIT IN THE KING'S ROYALTY AREA. You get to sit in the front row. You get pictures for everyone in your party, and not stupid cheesy crap pictures, these are pictures of you and who you come with, in a nicely bound folder thing. At most touristy places you'd pay $20 just for the picture itself.The food was decent. You get to eat with your hands. I didn't like the soup. You drink the soup from a bowl and I have a hard time drinking soup that has hard crusty celery in it. So I skipped that. The dessert was nasty as well. I think it was supposed to be an apple pie roll up type thing or something. My son kept asking where the apples were. The show itself is good. You get to root for your knight and just kind of enjoy the horses and performers.The service, however, was not great. First of all, they don't inform you anywhere (at least that I saw, I could be wrong) that gratuity isn't included in the huge price you pay to go. Our server came by us at the end, dropped the tray in front of me and says, "This is my Tip Tray" and then went to the next table. Tacky. However, since I did not know that this was going to happen, I also only had a small amount of cash to give him. So, my advice should you choose to go here my Lords and Ladies, is to bring LOTS OF CASH - an imagination - and a sense of humor. And don't expect to get out of the parking lot quickly when the show is over either. That in itself took a half hour.GREEN KNIGHT RULES!

We have fewer and fewer left around these parts, it seems. I'm glad the owner chose to set up shop here in the old Masonic Temple building.

I've been to at least 50 Chinese buffets and this one has the most consistently FRESH food -- and possibly because of their immensely high turn-over (it is usually packed this place, and the lady who was mentioning the Asian moms was possibly onto something).The seafood is good, the spicy chicken is good, they have nice stuffed shrimp and much more. I usually stock up on eating for days here.The think I like the most about it though is that as you get closer to the back, the buffets get more and more authentic. So if you are a guy like me who hadn't ever had nose or feet or strange octopus dishes before, this is an excellent place to sample them without laying out for an entree. The staff has always been helpful to me at pointing out their favorites among the more exotic dishes. I recommend you ask a staff member to point out a few favorites, they really know what they are talking about.I've never liked the New China Buffet across the street. This place seems to be getting ratings slammed by some New China bias enthusiasts so bear that in mind as you read through these reviews that this place might be experiencing ratings sabotage.
<review# 1705,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/1/2009,2/23/2010,27,158,4,8,8>This place is simply amazing.  One of the best restaurants I've ever been to.  Period.Service goes above and beyond average.  Our server was knowledgeable, friendly, and unpretentious.  He knew the menu front and back, and offered excellent recommendations.Food was superb.Drinks ordered:  Stella Artois Beer and Cucumber Martini.   Obviously, beer is beer, but the Martini was light, refreshing, and delicious.  And better yet... My server didn't think I was given "enough" martini, so he came back and filled my glass to the brim.   That is frickin' awesome piled on top of some awesome sauce.  Want to make me happy?  Give me some liquor for free.  And the price?  $8 isn't too bad at all.Food:I ordered the special fixed prix meal at $25.  I received a glass of red wine, soup or salad (I upgraded to the Lobster Bisque) and I had the Cedar Plank Salmon.  For dessert, I had the Vermont Maple Syrup Cotton Candy.  For $25, that was flippin' amazing.  The Lobster Bisque had chunks of fresh Lobster, and some ravioli in it and was light, yet creamy.The Salmon I ordered medium rare, and it melted in my mouth.  Simply wonderful.The cotton candy?  Ha.  I LOVE cotton candy.  I've never had maple syrup flavored cotton candy, but it was reallllly good.  I brought some home to my puppy (cotton candy freak) and she loved it.  Don't yell at me for giving her sugar.  I aim to please here.My man ordered the Cedar Plank Halibut that was on special.  It was firm, yet tender, and had a nice smokey flavor to it.He also had the Clam Chowder, which I agree, was the best ever had.It was an amazingly relaxing evening, with great food.  The food was so good, I didn't even focus on the drinks for once.  And I heard many other people around me raving about their food as well.Price?  $80 range.  Which is GREAT for independent restaurants that focus on service and quality of food.  I'm hoping to make this a regular stop....  Any time we have a special occasion, this is where we are going locally.
<review# 1706,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/17/2010,2/21/2010,25,58,5,13,5>I can't tell you how many times I've driven by this place while they were opening, patiently waiting for them to let me in!  Hubby and I were finally able to check it out the other day and it was really worth the wait.I'm going to say off the bat that I am NOT a sushi person.  I like the *idea* of it and have always wished I could love it but even when I ordered "wimpy" sushi, i.e. no raw fish, it always made me gag.  I thought it was a mental issue but then I had the most amazing sushi.  Well, at least to this novice.Hubby convinced me to do the spicy tuna roll - his fave.  I winced as it was brought to the table, thinking that I am going to completely embarrass myself.  It's not that the raw fish makes me gag it's all the rice and the nori.  Well, apparently, I've been eating complete crap for sushi because this was nothing like that.  The rice wasn't all packed tight and a mass of starch.  It was light and fluffy and fell apart in my mouth.  The nori... wait, was there nori in there?  I didn't feel a tough, fibrous mass in my mouth.  Yep, there was nori.  It melted away as well.  And the tuna?  It was creamy and delicate and amazing.  Then the little punch of spice kicked in and I was sold.  Hubby said it was the best he's had.We also ordered the chicken teriyaki lunch box and an order of ramen.  The teriyaki was pretty standard.  The veggies it was served with were kind of blah but that's fine.  The ramen wasn't what I expected, however.  I was hoping for a chicken broth but it was a miso ramen and.. well, one can only have too much miso, IMO.Their entree menu is pretty limited compared but it seems like the sushi is the main draw.  This place used to be  Subway and there is nary a trace of it anywhere.  The decor is calm and soothing, the pottery is beautiful and the staff is very helpful.They also do take-out and will deliver to a 2-mile area.  We will definitely be trying this place again and I suspect I will meet many a friend for lunch.

<review# 1709,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/9/2009,2/18/2010,363,708,4,9,7>Like Pier 1 indeed...I've known, shopped at, and supported Ten Thousand Villages stores since before I could drive myself to a Pier 1. Since it was called Self-Help Crafts of the World. There's not much comparison, really--one is a nonprofit store run by a peaceful, non-preachy denomination that ensures the people who make the goods get fairly paid for them; the other is a for-profit corporation that could care less about its artisans. (It seems like most people don't realize this is a Mennonite-run shop. Set in lovely downtown Oak Park, you will do your conscience and soul a world of good. PS, tip for those unfamiliar with the area, you can park on the other side of Harlem in the shopping center lot for three hours for free. :)

<review# 1713,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/13/2009,2/14/2010,850,1294,9,9,8>When I first moved here I had noticed the restaurant and made a mental note to check it out. I LOVE Balkan food. But their storefront was quite forgettable and the sign was so small that it was easy to pass by and not think twice about it. Now they are under new ownership.Fast forward 5 months and I'm taken aback when I turn the corner and spot huge Bulgarian flags and a sign in giant, ethnic lettering: MEHANATA. It practically screams at you to come in. The signs are bright and colorful, but the windows are curtained off and dark. It had us imagining the possibilities for a week.Mehanata is set up to host very large groups. My guess is that their clientele consists of those looking to catch some DJs or live music and that most of the money comes in from the bar and hosting birthday, religious and wedding groups. We came on a Thursday and were the only people there.Bulgarian hit music videos break the silence. The servers greet you, take orders, deliver the food and disappear. You dig into your bread, salad, fried appetizers, meat, dessert and alcohol. These things make up a complete Bulgarian meal. If you feel ambitious then you may even finish the evening with a Turkish coffee. It's a lot of food, so you should expect to take a lot of time. And you're not very likely to get the bill until you walk up to the bar and ask for it.All in all it was a good time. I would give 5 stars just for the experience and for being so damn excited at having this so close to me; however, I felt I've had slightly better food at other places. That's not to say this isn't A-MAZ-ING, but just not the best of the best food wise or with service. But that's true Balkan form and that's why I go.Oh, and my cat has never been one for human food, but he just stole the bread I brought home right off of my plate and wouldn't give it back. I can't blame him either. Their bread is quite delicious.

<review# 1715,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,1/4/2010,2/12/2010,176,176,3,6,7>I have friends from Florida who grew up in Chicagoland and who always, ALWAYS stop at Barnaby's for pizza whenever they are in town. When their plane lands, these friends literally head for Barnaby's before they do anything else. They say it's simply the best pizza in the area. That's how I found out about Barnaby's.I had driven by this place several times and never knew it was there. It's a small, easy to miss brown building next to a large auto dealer on Golf Road, just west of Roselle Road. If you're not looking for it, you could miss it. Parking is on the side and behind the restaurant.Inside the restaurant the decor is reminiscent of a 1970's pizza place with heavy wooden beams painted brown, gray linoleum floor, brown wooden booths and tables, and dim lighting. Doesn't look like much has changed since the 70's except for some mounted TV's.This is definitely a family friendly place. Sometimes they have a magician going table to table doing magic tricks for the kids. Balloon animals were in the mix too.As far as the food, I've only tried their pizza. It's a thin crust pizza and is pretty decent. Not a show stopper in my book, but I can see how my friends really like it. Order at the counter and move over to the bar to order drinks separately, then find a table and wait for your order number to be called. Tables will be bused for you when you're done. Carry out pizza is put on a cardboard circle and a paper sleeve, just like in the old days.If you're looking for a family friendly place with good pizza at a very reasonable price, Barnaby's is the place to go. And there's something about the feel of the place that makes me want to order root beer when dining in. So that's what I do. Makes me feel like a kid again.

<review# 1718,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/15/2009,2/9/2010,136,719,2,14,3>Excellent modern little Indian bistro, not too long a drive for us, and we will be back.When we sat down they gave us some pappads and a delicious cardamom tamarind chutney, and dark savory chutney which we liked. The pappads are well cooked, unlike at other Indian restaurants.We ordered the mushroom pakora as a starter, and it was small and great-tasting appetizer.I ordered the mulligatwany soup and the sweet potato chat. The mulligatwany was rich with yellow dal, completely smooth and well-seasoned with few grains of rice at the bottom of the bowl for added texture. The sweet potato chat consisted of an appetizer (small) sized plate of cubed potatoes in a delicious, dark hued lemon-based chat sauce. Significant-other unit had the lamb vindaloo and labeled it the best vindaloo he's had in 13 years since coming to the US. The great part about this restaurant is that they give you a rice bowl with your meat entree as part of the price, and not at an extra fee.We finished our meal by splitting a kheer, which featured plump and juicy rice pudding topped by a sprinkling of badam and pista (slivered almonds and crushed pistachio). It was refreshing and a perfect ending.I also tried their apple/cinnamon juice, which is a fresh-made apple juice seasoned with fragrant cinnamon--a perfect autumn beverage which is a twist on the usual seasoned apple cider we're used to.All around, great value, an enjoyable atmosphere, and really great, up-tempo fusion music. If you are in the area and prepared to try a new, modern take on traditional Indian, take a look and you won't be disappointed.NOTE: they are still waiting for their liquor license as of mid-November 2009.The staff was relaxed and friendly, and the kitchen pumped out the food at good intervals - we didn't have to wait even though there was a large group of diners at one end of the dining room. The owner came out personally to talk to each table and check on the food. The Polish waiter was friendly, well-informed on what was available/freshest, and was prompt, curteous, and fast. I can see some delays in food preparation/serving in the case of a full-house/busy evening, but the quality and freshness (no cans) merits a trip or two at the very least.

<review# 1724,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/25/2009,2/3/2010,364,363,10,13,8>I need to get my review in quickly, before I explode from so much overeating. To get 5 stars from me, everything about a place has to be top-notch. The service. The cleanliness. And of course, the food. At Taste of Thai, everything was. A fresh rose at every table. A soothing fountain in the background. Muted lighting. Nice.The husband and I started with the Thai Platter. Sweet baby Jesus, that was almost a meal by itself. Chicken satay, pork satay, egg rolls, baby egg rolls, fresh spring rolls, mee krob, crab rangoon, golden triangles, pot stickers, and silk purses. Elegantly presented and quickly decimated. I had to try the Tom Yum soup. Very generous chicken breast, tangy flavor. Yum is right! This would have been the perfect time to stop as my stomach was already giving me plenty of  "me full" signals. But since gluttony is my favorite sin, and Pad Thai my favorite dish, I plundered on. I know a previous review said that their Pad Thai was soggy and the sauce was just "meh". I have to say that this was the best Pad Thai that I have eaten since moving to the burbs. THE BEST. Again, very generous with the chicken breast and the perfect blend of sauce, noodles, bean sprouts and peanuts. I ate half and declared I would take the other half home. I then spent 20 minutes of "baby-stepping" until the last half was gone. I desperately wanted to undo the button of my jeans because I couldn't breathe but there were other patrons in there and I didn't want to embarrass myself. Don't ask me how I managed to also eat banana eggrolls for dessert. But I did. The husband had Thai fried chicken and banana sticky rice. He was not a fan of Thai food until dining here. Even he raved about everything, including the cute, efficient, and very friendly waitress. Ladies, have you ever been SO full that you not only had to undo the button of your pants but your bra as well? I should be ashamed, but I'm not. There will be no turkey tomorrow stuffed as well as I am tonight. Word.
<review# 1725,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/1/2009,2/2/2010,30,52,6,10,8>I never knew that I could fall in love with a store full of yarn!  Chix with Stix is an awesome boutique store in downtown Forest Park that is warm and inviting.  The owners/workers there are inviting, and most of the patrons are also.I took a class there a few weeks ago.  Through a schedule mix-up that was entirely my fault, I found out just how patient and flexible a knitting teacher (Sue) could really be.  The class was three one and a half hour sessions, and I was out of town for the middle session, so Sue arranged with me to make-up the lesson during one of the open-knitting nights.  And she wasn't only just patient with my scheduling snafu, she was very patient with my silly rookie knitting mistakes!The open-knitting night that I went to was really enjoyable!  I am not usually much for forced socialization, but I really did enjoy the hour that I spent knitting here.  The store is well-lit, clean, and comfortable.It is a bit pricey for yarn, but while browsing on the internet, I found very similar prices, plus Chix with Stix is in a convenient location and the selection they have there is amazing.  The workers there are always willing to recommend a medium for knitting or crocheting or help with questions about a project.My only "con" about this place is the limited hours that it's open (usually 12 noon to about 7 pm) on most days.  I also wish that there were more classes offered.  The staff is so marvelous that I just can't get enough Chix!
<review# 1726,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/5/2009,2/1/2010,143,203,12,17,14>Is it INSANE that I look forward to waking up early on Saturday mornings because of the OP Farmer's Market?  Thought so.  And, I do.  I actually get giddy over it.* $1 bag of fresh cat nip for my kitty.  He gets one every week.  Spoiled cat.* Only the freshest and most in season fruits and veggies.  All grown by farmers within a 200 mile radius.*  Fresh flowers to brighten my kitchen and my day.* Donuts.  The donuts that everyone talks about.  I have yet to savor them.  I WILL wait in the line this year.* Always a come one come all, free for all live blue grass jam session.  Grab your instrument and come on down!  Anyone is welcome to join in.  I always stop shopping and listen for a bit.Last year the chef from Trattoria 225 started doing the occasional cooking demo here.  He'd creates a recipe based on what is in season and will be available in plenty at the market.  This is what actually enticed me into his restaurant.  Great addition to the market!OP Farmer's Market is definitely not a large as Green City, but it has a heart almost twice the size!
